One of the main objectives of the Court and part of its mission to promote transparency and accountability is to bring the European Court of Auditors closer to EU citizens. 
It is therefore a great pleasure to welcome you as a reader of the first Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors. 
The report aims to provide an overall overview of the Court and to account for its activities in 2007, the year in which it celebrates its 30th anniversary as an external auditor of the European Union, who, according to his mandate, contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens. 
The Court makes its main contribution to its audits and reports enabling the audited body to improve its financial management and assist the discharge authority (European Parliament and Council) in its control over the implementation of the EU budget. 
This report provides an overview of the audit reports published in 2007 and highlights the main conclusions on the implementation of the 2006 EU budget and the sound financial management of EU funds. 
The Court not only reports on the financial management of past years, but also actively contributes to the establishment of an EU financial control framework. 
2007 was of great importance for EU financial management. 
The Court's position 'The Court's position' outlines the Court's view on significant developments in the accountability of the Member States and the Court's contribution to the public consultation launched by the European Commission on budgetary reform. 
None of the Court's findings in 2007 would be conceivable without the commitment, know-how and competence of its 850 staff. 
Staff is the most important asset of a forward-looking authority that strives for continuous improvement. 
This first Annual Activity Report provides details of the Court's reform process, which was launched in 2006 with a self-assessment. 
Progress was made in 2007 in the implementation of the resulting action plan and at the end of the year a so-called peer review procedure was launched under the leadership of a group of auditors belonging to the national auditors of Canada, Austria, Norway and Portugal. 
A first result of this reform process was the following statement on the Court's mission, mission statement, values and strategic objectives, based on the future activities on which the Court will report in due course. 
I wish you a lot of pleasure in reading the first Annual Activity Report and hope that it will be useful to you. 
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5 
The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing EU finances in accordance with the Treaty. 
As an EU external auditor, he contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

8 THE ROLE AND WORK OF THE COURT, WHAT ROLE DOES THE COURT HAVE? 
The budget of the European Union amounts to around EUR 120 billion, representing about 1 % of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States. 
This represents a small proportion compared to national budgets. 
However, for some Member States, EU funding plays an important role in financing public activities. For example, the total budget volume is close to the GNI of some countries, such as Romania. 
Over time, the composition of the budget has undergone changes, with agriculture and cohesion policy being the main expenditure areas (see Box 1). 
The budget is determined annually, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, by the Council, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and the directly elected European Parliament on a proposal from the European Commission. 
The Commission carries out the budget on its own, but shares a significant share of the administrative tasks with the Member States, in particular in the area of agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure. 
Depending on the rules on expenditure, national authorities may be responsible for defining expenditure strategies, selecting beneficiaries and projects and making payments. 
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on applications from the beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union. 
9 BOX 1 - HOW DOES THE EU SPEND ITS MONEY? 
EU budgets largely serve different uses than national budgets, partly due to the different areas of competence. 
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually account for a large proportion of national expenditure. 
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which usually takes the form of payments to farmers throughout the Union, accounts for the main share of household expenditure, albeit with a declining trend at present. 
In 2008, slightly less than half of the budget is earmarked for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development. 
Since the 1980s, a significant part of the expenditure has been devoted to cohesion - i.e. regional and social development - to co-finance a wide range of projects ranging from road construction in Slovakia to training courses for the unemployed in Denmark. 
For 2008, expenditure on sustainable growth, the lion's share of cohesion, was estimated at 38 % of the budget. 
This heading also covers a large part of the EU funding earmarked for research. 
Around 6 % of the budget is spent on the administration of the Community institutions. 
EU spending Citizenship, Freedom, Security and Justice 1 % The European Union as a global player 6 % Administration 6 % Cohesion - Sustainable growth 38 % Agriculture - Conservation and management of natural resources 49 % 
Democratic societies need complete and accurate publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both with a view to improving financial management and ensuring accountability. 
In its capacity as an external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds have been correctly accounted for regardless of where they are used and spent in accordance with the legislation with due regard to the optimal use of funds. 
The results of the Court's audit work are used by the Commission, Parliament and Council as well as by the Member States to improve EU financial management. 
In addition to the Court's work, many national supervisory authorities are auditing EU funds provided that they are managed and spent by public bodies in the Member States. 
Overview of internal and external control of the EU budget EU level 10 Commission (DG, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing bodies European Court of Auditors National Control Authorities National level External control Internal control 
WHAT AUDIT RESULTS DOES THE COURT DELIVER? We apply three different types of audits to 1: Auditing of the accounts, compliance audit (legal compliance audit) and performance audit, depending on which of the following three issues is the starting point of the audit: 11 • • • Does the annual accounts present, in all material respects, a true and fair view of the financial position, results and cash flows for the year in accordance with the applicable accounting framework? 
Under the EC Treaty, the Court is obliged to provide such a declaration - or opinion - on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. 
The annual statement of assurance is generally known by the French acronym DAS ("Déclaration d'Assurance"). 
1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, please refer to the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu). 
The Court conducts its audit of the annual accounts of the EU in accordance with International Audit Principles (ISA), which are valid both in the public and private sectors. 
Together with the national control authorities, the Court actively participates in the further development of international audit standards promoted by the standardisation bodies (Intosai, IFAC) 2. 
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with the legislation and frameworks, the Court relies on the results of both its analysis of supervisory and control systems aimed at preventing or detecting and correcting legality and regulatory errors and a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2). 
Where systems are verified and found to be reliable, the number of transactions that the Court has to audit in order to reach a sound conclusion regarding their legality and regularity shall be reduced accordingly. 
In the selection of topics for its performance audits, the Court strives to identify audit areas where the greatest impact can be expected in terms of the potential for improvement identified in terms of the economy, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending. 
12 2 Intosai (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions - IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) International Audit Organisation. 
13 KASTS 2 - The Court does not have the resources necessary to examine in detail all the operations of the EU budget. 
The Court monitors these operations until the final beneficiary of the aid, such as a farmer in southern Germany. 
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks, such as measuring the size of the agricultural area, in order to determine whether the relevant information in the application for support corresponds to the actual circumstances.

In practice, the Court's sampling methods are more complex, for example a two-stage sampling method is used to improve the efficiency of audit work.

14 Management structure AND ORGANISATION OF THE EUROPEAN COUNCIL The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body of 27 members, each with one member per Member State. 
As shown in the organisation chart (see page 17), there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas (maintenance and management of natural resources - structural policies, transport, research and energy - external policies - own resources, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies). 
The fifth audit group (CEAD or Coordination, Communication, Evaluation, Quality Assurance and Development) is responsible for "horizontal" issues such as coordination in the area of assurance, quality assurance, development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports. 
In addition, an administrative committee composed of members of all audit groups is responsible for the preparatory treatment of all administrative matters requiring a formal Court decision. 
The Members of the Court are appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, in accordance with the proposals of each Member State for a term of office of six years, re-election is permitted. 
In addition to its function within the college, which is responsible for final decision-making on audits and opinions as well as on broader strategic and administrative issues, each member is primarily responsible for his or her specific tasks in the area of auditing. 
The Member then took over the presentation of the report in the audit group or in the Court and after its adoption in the European Parliament, Council and other interested third parties. 
With the accession of Bulgaria and Romania on 1 January 2007, the Court welcomed two new Members, Ms Nadeschda Sandolova and Mr Ovidiu Ispir. 
One year later, on 1 January 2008, the Court added three new members, Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) and Mr Harald Noack (Germany), as the term of office of their predecessors had expired. 
In addition, the Council extended the term of office of four members (Greece, the Netherlands, Austria and the United Kingdom) for a further six years.

16 OF THE PRESIDENT At the head of the European Court of Auditors is the President, who is elected by the members from their middle for three years, with re-election allowed. 
The role of the president is that of a Primus inter pares. 
The President represents the Court in all his external relations, in particular in his relations with the discharge authority, the other institutions of the European Union and the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States and beneficiary countries. 
On 16 January 2008, Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, the Portuguese member, became the 11st member. President of the Court elected. 
The Secretary-General is the highest-ranking member of the institution and is appointed by the Court for a period of six years and re-election is permitted. 
The Secretary-General is responsible for the Court's human resources and material management, including vocational training and the Directorate for Translation, each with one unit per official language (22), except Gaelic. 
The Secretary-General shall also be supervised by the Secretariat-General. 
The term of office of the current Secretary-General of the Court, Mr Michel Hervé, was extended on 1 July 2007. 
The staff of the European Court of Auditors amount to around 850 staff (836 at 31. December 2007) and includes auditors (484), translators (162) and administrative staff. 
The Court's auditors have a wide range of training profiles and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the areas of accounting, financial management, internal and external audits and law and economics. 
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States. 
The results of the audits of the Court's accounts and compliance audits mostly feed into annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds (EDF), as well as the specific annual reports on the Union agencies and bodies. 
The results of the performance audits will be published in the form of special reports during the year. 
We also publish opinions on draft legal acts affecting financial management. 
As the Court repeatedly noted in its annual reports on the implementation of the general budget of the EU, sufficient and appropriate internal control systems set up by the Commission and the Member States are of central importance to ensure proper EU financial management. 
In recent years, we have recognised the Commission's efforts to promote and implement improved internal control and administrative procedures, both in terms of the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions reported therein. 
The 2006 Annual Report continued this tradition by identifying areas with - sometimes significant - improvement needs as well as large spending areas where the situation remains unsatisfactory. 
The Court concluded that the 'final accounts of the European Communities', which shows the implementation of the 2006 EU budget, provide, in all material respects, a true and fair view of the Communities' financial position and results, except for the designation of excessive amounts of settlement liabilities and pre-financing in the balance sheet. 
Further improvements are therefore considered necessary to ensure that the newly introduced accrual accounting function is fully satisfactory and its potential as a reliable management and control tool can be fully exploited. 
3 This section is intended to introduce the Court's reports and opinions, and not to summarise its content. 
More nutritious information can be found in the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after its adoption. 
With regard to the expenditure areas in which most payments are incurred - agriculture [mainly agricultural expenditure not covered by the Integrated Management and Control System (IACS)], structural measures, internal policies and large parts of external policies, the Court gives a negative opinion on legality and regularity and concludes that these areas of expenditure remain materially affected by error. 
In the case of payments in these areas, the supervisory and control systems could only partially limit the risk of legality and regularity errors in transactions. 
The Court stresses that complicated or unclear eligibility criteria or complex legislation had a significant impact on the legality and regularity of the transactions. 
However, the Court found a significant decrease in the estimated overall error rate in agricultural transactions and concluded that IACS, where properly applied, is an effective system to mitigate the risk of irregular expenditure. 
In addition, the Court found that the transactions underlying the commitments and revenue did not show material errors; this also applies to payments related to administrative expenditure, most of the pre-accession strategy and parts of external policies (see Box 3). 19

In 2007, the Court also published an annual report on the European Development Funds (EDFs). 
While the Court was able to give an unrestricted opinion on the reliability of the EDF accounts, the audit opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the payments authorised under the responsibility of delegations in the beneficiary States was limited in view of the material error rate in these transactions. 
In addition, a further 28 special annual reports on the European Agencies and other decentralised bodies were published in 2007 as well as an annual report on the audit of the efficiency of the management of the European Central Bank. 21 
In 2007, the Court published a total of nine special reports published in 2007. 
The reports related to investigations of financial management issues in many different areas and ranged from cooperation in the field of VAT. (No 8/2007) up to capacity building in countries as remote as Angola and Vietnam (No 6/2007). 
The Court's audits revealed problems of various kinds with various consequences. 
The weaknesses identified by the Court in relation to the building expenditure of the EU institutions (No 2/2007) show that not all EU funds have been used meaningfully in this area. 
The deficiencies identified in the report on monitoring, inspection and sanctioning systems concerning the rules for the conservation of Community fisheries resources (No 7/2007) could have serious consequences not only for aquatic resources but also for the future of the fisheries sector. 
Notwithstanding the different ways of using funds in the different areas of the EU budget, the Court's reports highlight several common issues, which can be outlined as follows: 22 • • • Although the use of the means should take place both swiftly and efficiently, a tension ratio may arise when trying to achieve these two objectives at the same time. 
This topic is the subject of the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and the report on the management of the CARDS programme by the Commission in the Western Balkans countries (No 5/2007). 
Although planning does not guarantee effectiveness, it is of considerable importance. 
Strategic and long-term planning issues were raised in the reports on building expenditure of the EU institutions (No 2/2007) and on the evaluation of the EU Framework Programmes for Research and Technological Development (RTD) (No 9/2007) as well as in two reports related to external assistance, one of which referred to the CARDS programme (No 5/2007) and the other on the effectiveness of technical assistance in the context of capacity building (No 6/2007). 
The Commission's evaluations are a key element of its performance management system when it comes to assessing performance and, if necessary, highlighting the need for improvement. 
Where evaluations take place at a too early stage of the programming cycle, this means that progress is inadequate and insufficient data is available for evaluation purposes. 
On the other hand, the possibility of making timely changes during the current period and improvements before the start of the next may be reduced if evaluations are carried out at a later stage. 
The question of proper scheduling of evaluations was addressed both in the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and in the RTD evaluation report (No 9/2007). 
Evaluations and audits are more difficult to carry out if the objectives of the spending programmes are unclear. This was another issue addressed in the latter two reports. 
Management and controls of EU expenditure are subject to complex regulations, which must be clearly and unambiguously formulated in order to ensure that the funds are used for the intended purposes. 
The existence of clear definitions and rules is crucial if funds are to be collected or used as planned. 
This was the subject in the reports on the European Refugee Fund (No 3/2007) and on checks on goods and substitution by Member States on the export of agricultural products (No 4/2007). 
The lack of common definitions is one of the factors that may affect the completeness, comparability and reliability of data originating from the different Member States. 
This can have consequences if the data becomes the basis of decisions, for example, for allocation of funds.

The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management by issuing opinions on proposals or budgetary matters in the YEAR 2007 OPINION. 
These opinions are required as part of the adoption procedure of financial rules 4 or may be made at the request of one of the other Community institutions. In addition, the Court can provide opinions on its own initiative. 
The Court's opinions may address issues relating to specific expenditure areas, such as the two 2007 opinions concerning new regulations for the European Development Funds (Nos 2/2007 and 9/2007). 
However, they can also cover wider issues of EU financial management, such as the Court's opinion on the annual summaries, national declarations and audit work of national audit bodies (No 6/2007). 
Opinions are based on the Court's expertise on EU financial management issues acquired in the course of our audits over the years, and in some cases reference is made to certain audits. 
For example, in the opinion on ensuring the correct application of customs and agricultural legislation (No 3/2007), the Court refers to a recommendation in a previous special report that the Commission should take action to improve the reliability of sources of information on fraud. 
The need for simplification is a recurring issue in the Court's opinions (see, for example, Opinion No 7/2007 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities). 
In a 2007 opinion (No 6/2007), the Court presented its position on the annual summaries as well as the so-called national declarations provided voluntarily by some Member States on their own initiative. 
This opinion will be discussed in more detail in the section "The Court's position".

Article 248(4). 
Most of the Court's opinions have been published in the Official Journal of the European Union and are available on the Court's website. 
Public financial control plays a key role in modern democratic societies from the point of view of efficient financial management. 
The audit activities shall be held accountable to the addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, as to whether their taxpayers' money is spent in a proper and appropriate manner. 
From this point of view, public financial control forms a central part of accountability and a useful basis for public discussion. 
In this respect, the Court's work has considerable potential for impact. 
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned - primarily in the European context of the Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States. 
On the basis of this information, they may take action with or without reference to the audit conclusions. 
Although the Court's audit work has its main impact on its published reports, there is already some effect throughout the audit itself. 
In particular, all audits result in the submission of detailed audit findings, which are sent to the audited body in order to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations. 
The final report text is also subject to a "contradictory procedure". 
The replies of the audited body, namely the Commission, will be published together with the reports. 
In the replies, the audited body often acknowledges the problems identified by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them. 
Upon completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the results of the audit will be evaluated and used by the Parliament and the Council to carry out their political role of monitoring the use of the budget. 
In the context of the annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form a basis for the Council's recommendation and Parliament's decision in this regard. 
In the 2006 discharge procedure, particular attention was paid to the conclusions put forward by the Court in the field of structural policies. 
In its 2006 discharge resolution, Parliament refers directly to an action plan proposed by the Commission as a direct consequence of the conclusions of the Court's annual report and calls for quarterly reports on the progress of its implementation. 
Parliament also calls for a better insight into the corrective measures taken to address errors and weaknesses. 
Special reports are also taken into account in the discharge procedure. 
However, given the fact that they are published in the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on this matter have usually taken place at an earlier stage at the meetings of the Parliament and of the Council. 
A good example of a possible follow-up is provided by the most recent special report on building expenditure (No 2/2007). 
In fact, the Parliament had already entrusted its administration with the preparation of a report examining whether it would be practicable to create a European Building Office to be responsible for the construction and maintenance of the buildings of the institutions and bodies of the European Union. 
The Court's audit report on controls carried out by Member States on the export of agricultural products (No 4/2007) can be given as a further example. 
The Council and the Commission responded without delay to the recommendations made by the Court by amending the existing legislation. 
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by their topic in the relevant media, which attracts greater attention and encourages public discussion. 
The media is the most immediate source of information for citizens. 
As a rule, media coverage for the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive, but some special reports have also been followed up with interest by the press. 
For example, the fisheries report (No 7/2007) has attracted great attention in the media. 
An Extraordinary Fisheries Council was convened to discuss the Court's report and the Commission initiated a procedure that could lead to amendments to the legislation to remedy the identified deficiencies. 
This is an example of a report that, due to its relevance and up-to-dateness, was able to make a particularly valuable contribution to the decision-making process. 
This section provided some guidance on the impact of the Court's reports published in 2007. 
Further information on the follow-up of previous observations by the Court can be found in the respective chapters of its annual report. 
The Court's most frequently remarked in its last annual report is that despite the measures taken, the deficiencies identified in the previous year were only partially addressed. 
When considering the impact of the Court's work, the opinions should also be considered. 
The Court intends to analyse increasingly the long-term impact of its work - audits and opinions. 
This can be illustrated by the example set out in Box 4. 
27 KASTEN 4 - The OPINION OF THE HOUSE TO 'Single PRESS' Over the years, the Court has published several opinions highlighting ways of strengthening the overall internal control system for the EU budget. 
The opinion on the 'Single Audit' (No 2/2004) in 2004 made a landmark contribution in this regard. 
In this opinion, the Court proposes to incorporate the definition and implementation of all internal control into a single integrated control framework, which includes common principles and targets and ensures that costs and benefits are proportionate. 
The opinion on the 'Single Audit' developed into a reference document for the Commission but also for the Court, for example in 2007 in its observations on the definition of effective and efficient internal control in the updated Implementing Rules of the Financial Regulation (Opinion No 1/2007). 
The integrated audit approach is reflected in the Commission's Action Plan for an Integrated Internal Control Framework 2006. 
The Commission has taken steps to emphasise the role and responsibilities of Member States in the area of internal control. This includes the new obligation to submit annual summaries of audit opinions, declarations and audits carried out in accordance with the regulations applicable to each expenditure area. 
The Commission and Member States have taken initiatives to strengthen the involvement of Member States in the accountability cycle of EU funds. 
In part, the aim is to address the problem of the material error rates with regard to the legality and regularity identified in the main expenditure areas of the budget, especially in those areas where the Commission and the Member States share management. 
Significant recent developments include the obligation for Member States to provide annual summaries of available audit results and declarations, the voluntary initiatives of some Member States to submit national declarations and the decision of some national control authorities to prepare audit reports on the management of EU funds. 
In our Opinion No 6/2007, the Court considers that all of these elements, where properly implemented, could lead to improved management and control of EU funds. 
The opinion sets out the conditions under which these elements can provide added value and can be used by the Court in compliance with the requirements in international audit principles. 
As annual summaries form an integral part of the internal control system, the Court will assess in its usual audit procedures the extent to which they improve the functioning of internal control. 
Annual summaries can lead to better overall control of EU funds in areas under shared management, in so far as they highlight strengths and weaknesses. 
National declarations are based on voluntary initiatives of certain Member States; they are handed over at the highest level and submitted to national parliaments. 
Although they do not, on their own, constitute conclusive audit evidence, they can be understood as a novel element of internal control and provide valuable information on the implementation of the EU budget. 
The Court recognises the potential benefits of national declarations and national audit work in raising awareness in Member States of the importance of internal control of EU funds. 
The audit work of the national control authorities (national audit reports) related to the legality and regularity of EU expenditure or with the national declarations could provide audit evidence to the Court if it can be satisfied that the audit work is usable and quality in accordance with international audit principles. 
In this case, the Court will take into account the activity notes issued by national control authorities when planning and carrying out its own audits. 
National declarations and national audit reports contain statements on control systems. 
National declarations may also contain certain audit opinions on the legality and regularity of the transactions. 
Experience shows that the main risk to the legality and regularity of transactions is the reliability of the information provided by beneficiaries when applying for EU funds, and less in the way in which this information is processed by the Member States and the Commission. 
The declaration that systems function as required by the EU regulations alone cannot guarantee the legality and regularity of the transactions in question. 
Recognising the need for a stronger role of national supervisory authorities in the overall context of accountability of EU spending, the Contact Committee of the EU Supreme Audit Institutions has set up a working group on the harmonisation of audit standards and standards specifically tailored to the EU context. 
Common audit approaches and methods increase the possibility for the Court to rely on the work of the national supervisory authorities, provided that the quality of this work is directly proven. 
In September 2007, the Commission published a consultation paper to launch an open debate on EU finances as part of a far-reaching review of the budget. 
At the beginning of April 2008, the Court presented its contribution to the debate, highlighting the main principles to be taken into account in the design of new programmes in order to provide European added value in terms of clarity of objectives, the pursuit of simplification, the sense of reality, transparency and accountability. 
Among other things, the Court recommended that the following aspects be taken into account: • • • • • Alignment of spending programmes not by input, but by output; better use of the concept of acceptable risk in the design and adoption of spending programmes; The degree of discretion to be given to national or regional authorities in managing and accounting expenditure programmes; Considering whether VAT own resources are still a useful part of the own resources system, calling for a review of all the compensatory mechanisms based on the guiding principles for the own resources system - equity, transparency, cost-effectiveness, simplicity and contribution of each Member State. 29

We also decided to provide more detailed information on the results of our Statement of Assurance, in particular on the results of the audit of individual transactions.

The Court is constantly striving to improve all aspects of its work. 
In 2005, the Court decided to undergo a peer review procedure. 
In doing so, senior staff of a small number of Supreme Audit Institutions assess the organisation or results of a sister body on the basis of professional standards and in the light of their respective professional experience. 
As all Supreme Audit Institutions have similar tasks, peer review procedures can make a very valuable contribution to the improvement of audit bodies. 
As part of the preparation for the peer review process, the Court carried out a self-assessment in 2006 which gave the institution the opportunity to explore its strengths and weaknesses. 
In 2007, the Court adopted an action plan to address the weaknesses identified. 
The plan included a total of 23 actions, six of which were the subject of task forces involving members of the Court and staff from different areas and hierarchy levels of the institution: 31 1. Mission statement, mission, strategic goals and planning 2. Management structure (leadership), structure and organisation 3. Internal performance indicators 4. Employees and internal communication 5. External stakeholders and communication approaches, external communication strategy 6. The results of these Task Forces presented in 2007 included new statements on mission, mission statement and values as well as strategic objectives for the Court, a new strategy and guidelines for internal communication and a report on ways to improve reporting quality. The peer review process started at the end of 2007. 
Quantitative AND QUALITATIVE SECURITY OF THE audit work Several of the adopted strategic objectives concern the output of the institution. 
The Court strives to make the impact of its audits more visible through the selection of relevant topics, timeliness and a clearer and more reader-friendly design of its reports. 
It has also begun to increase the number of performance audits and improve their quality. 
In 2007, considerable efforts were made to further develop the methodological foundations of the Court's work as an essential prerequisite for high-quality audit work. 
A new manual for accounting and compliance audits has been developed, which will be finalised in 2008. 
The new Handbook of the Court's performance audit was adopted at the end of 2006 and was therefore available to auditors for the first time as guidance in 2007. 
In order to further improve the quality of the Court's work in the field of performance audit, additional guidelines have been developed and several seminars and training events have been held. 
In addition, we set new ambitious targets in terms of the use of information technologies. 
In the new IT strategy adopted in 2007, the Court expresses the intention to expand its capacity to carry out IT audits and to make the use of computer-assisted audit techniques (CAATs) a common practice for audits of accounting and performance audits. 
It is important that the amount and quality of the Court's output can be properly assessed. 
The Court is about to develop performance indicators that should enable it to provide a variety of performance data in future Annual Activity Reports. 
In the future, the Court plans to develop a methodology for assessing the institution's cost-effectiveness. 32

In addition, the Court started modernising its information systems in the areas of audit, translation, knowledge and communication, management information and staff.

In the selection of new audit tasks, the Court has based a number of priority issues on the basis of a number of priorities, to which particular attention will be paid in 2008. 
In accordance with the EC Treaty, the European Court of Auditors has to carry out its audit in "link" with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States, whereas the Amsterdam Treaty added: "The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies shall cooperate with confidence while respecting their independence." This scheme was extended in the Treaty of Nice by explicitly calling on the Court of Auditors in the 18th Declaration of the Final Act to set up a committee for contacts with the national audit bodies, in which all SAI Presidents and the Court meet annually to discuss matters of common interest. 
The ongoing contacts are maintained by the liaison officers appointed by each SAI. 
Working groups have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices. 
In 2007, a delegation of the Court took part in the 3 rd and 4th In December, the Finnish Court of Auditors held an annual meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the SAI of the European Union in Helsinki. 
The meeting focused on risk management, acceptable risk and integrated internal control system in the management of EU funds and discussed the role of SAIs in this area. 
The Court will host the next meeting of the Contact Committee on 1st and 2. December 2008. 
Two liaison officers were held in 2007 to prepare the Contact Committee meeting. 
The first meeting took place in The Hague on 23 and 24 April and the second meeting took place in Luxembourg on 11 and 12 October, chaired by the European Court of Auditors. 
Recent developments in the field of EU financial management were discussed at both meetings and highlighted the work of the Cooperation Task Force, which deals with the Contact Committee itself, its functioning and opportunities for improvement; in this context, proposals were made for a more efficient design of workflows. 
The meeting also covered the activities of the various working and expert groups set up by the Contact Committee to address specific issues of common interest. 
The Court attended meetings of the Network of Candidate Countries and Candidate Countries "in spe" (Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Turkey). 
The Presidents of the SAIs of Candidate Countries and Candidate Countries "in spe" and the European Court of Auditors met in Skopje (former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia) on 11 and 12 June 2007. 
An important aspect of all efforts to improve practical cooperation in the auditing of EU funds concerns the audit principles used. 
Against this background, in 2006, the Contact Committee decided to set up a working group chaired by one of the members of the Court, Mr Josef Bonnici, to develop "common audit standards and comparable audit standards based on internationally recognised audit principles and adapted to the EU context". 
In 2007, the first meetings were held at the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg. 
In December 2007, a progress report of the working group was submitted to the Helsinki Contact Committee and a related resolution was adopted. 
The Court continued its active participation and involvement in the improvement of international audit principles through its membership in European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, namely Eurosai and Intosai. 
As part of Eurosai, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and the IT Working Group and participates in the Eurosai Training Committee. 
The Court hosted a seminar on "Analysis of the most common IT problems of SAIs" in Luxembourg on 17 and 18 April 2007 as well as a seminar entitled "Economic audit - Where do we stand?" from 4 to 6 April 2007. December 2007.

43 KASTEN 6 - THE Fisheries Report - RESULTS A RELATED TEAMING The report on fisheries resource monitoring, inspection and sanction systems adopted by the Court in 2007 (Special Report No 7/2007) caused considerable attention both among policy makers and in the media. 
Articles in numerous newspapers, as well as the rapid responses to both the Commission and the Council, proved the relevance and up-to-dateness of the report. 
The starting point for this success was a team of a dozen auditors from the Court who worked closely with the rapporteur member, Mr Kikis Kazamias, and his cabinet. 
Mr Emmanuel Rauch, a French auditor who has been working at the Court for several years, and his Spanish colleague Mr Alejandro Ballester were the team leaders of the audit during the preparatory phase in autumn 2005. 
The audit included missions to six Member States, from Denmark to Italy, both to central managing authorities to gain insight into the control systems and to the main ports to assess how the systems work in practice. 
As far as the language skills of the team members were insufficient, translators from the Court's language service provided assistance. 
The auditors' team is very proud to have contributed to the gradual recognition by policy makers of the serious consequences of the way in which the Community's fisheries policy is implemented. 
Other auditing authorities have also shown interest in the audit, as it provides suggestions and know-how, for example, for an upcoming audit on a similar issue in the Baltic Sea countries.

The Court's Internal Audit Service is designed to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives through a systematic, methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures. 
In addition, Internal Audit proposes to increase the efficiency of the Court. 
More generally, it is a matter of assessing the performance of individual services in the implementation of policies, programmes and measures with the aim of continuous improvement. 
In 2007, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused on auditing the accounts (including supporting the work of the Court's external auditor), the audit of the ex ante audit, the implementation of internal control standards, the recent enlargement of the Court (the so-called K2 building) and the Court's recruitment procedures. 
The Court's Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and one external expert, monitors the work of the Internal Auditor and ensures its independence. 
It also examines and approves the work programme and the reports of the Internal Auditor and, where necessary, instructs them to carry out specific audit tasks. 
The Committee met eight times in 2007.

The Court of Auditors, as an independent EU audit body, makes a unique contribution to improving EU financial management and promoting transparency and accountability by providing audit services and performing a role model. 
For the Court, 2008 was characterised by a significant number of significant progress and important developments in the area of EU financial management, which is further addressed in this Annual Activity Report. 
One defining event was the peer review of the European Court of Auditors carried out by an international expert panel, which led to a positive conclusion on the usefulness of the Court's audit management framework and the independence and objectivity of its work. 
In its 2007 annual report published in November 2008, the Court issued a full audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's accounts for the first time. 
However, as in previous years, he found too high levels of legality and regularity errors in the areas of the EU budget, which accounted for most of the expenditure. 
In 2008, we also recognised the developments launched at EU and national level, which are expected to lead to significant improvements in EU financial management in the future. 
Two examples set out in this Annual Activity Report concern the ongoing process of reviewing the EU budget to which the Court has actively contributed and the Communication on tolerable risk of error issued by the Commission. 
In the area of international relations, the Court took the lead in organising the discussions of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the European Union on EU budgetary reform and the revised Lisbon Strategy, as well as the host role in a recent workshop on the role of the EU-ORKB in the context of actions to address the current financial crisis. 
As our audit environment is undergoing rapid change, we are prompted to adapt through internal reforms in order to better meet our obligations under the Treaty and to be able to effectively fulfil its mission. 
A significant step in the implementation of our mission and mission statement in 2008 was the development of an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012. 
The audit strategy is based on two priority objectives: Maximise the overall impact of the audits and improve efficiency by making the best use of resources. 
These objectives will significantly shape the Court's work programmes during that period, as well as its efforts to continuously improve and exploit the main challenges and opportunities identified in the peer review process in relation to the exploitation of potential for improvement. 
Thanks to its competence and commitment, the Court's staff play a central role in carrying out the audit work carried out by the Court as an independent guardian of the financial interests of citizens in order to improve financial management. 
On behalf of the Court and on my own behalf, I would like to thank all employees for their commitment and professional work last year. 
Special thanks for his personal commitment and commitment is due to our former Secretary-General, Michel Hervé, who was retired at the end of 2008. 
I wish you a pleasant reading of this Annual Activity Report, which provides an insight into the Court and an overview of the activities carried out in 2008. 
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5 
The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing EU finances in accordance with the Treaty. 
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work, providing valuable support to its audience in order to improve EU financial management. 
Values Independence, integrity and impartiality Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and employees. 
Professionalism Maintains a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work. 
Creation of relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the interests of its audience and contain important and forward-looking statements. 
Excellence and efficiency acknowledging the value of the individual, supporting the further development of special skills and rewarding performance. 
Role AND WORK OF THE HOUSE WORK IS THE EU Budget The European Union budget amounts to around EUR 120 billion, representing approximately 1 % of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States. 
However, for some Member States, EU funding plays an important role in financing public activities. For example, the total budget volume is close to the GNI of some Member States. 
The revenue of the European Union consists mainly of contributions from Member States derived from their gross national income (GNI - 65.4 %) or on the VAT levied by the Member States (VAT). 16.9 % are based. 
Customs duties and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources - 16.5 %) also account for a substantial part of the revenue. 
Over time, the composition of the budget has undergone changes, with agriculture and cohesion policy being the main expenditure areas (see Box 1). 
BOX 1 HOW DOES THE EU SPEND ITS MONEY? 
The EU budget is financed from financial contributions from Member States (mainly based on national GNI) as well as customs and agricultural duties. 
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than national budgets, partly due to the different areas of competence. 
For example, the Union is not responsible for the social security systems, which usually account for a substantial part of national expenditure. 
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which is usually made in the form of payments to farmers throughout the Union, accounts for the main share of household expenditure, albeit with a decreasing trend at present. 
In 2009, 45.3 % of the budget is earmarked for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development. 
Since the 1980s, a significant proportion of the expenditure on cohesion measures, i.e. regional and social development, has been used. This involves co-financing a wide range of projects - from road construction projects in Poland to training for the unemployed in Spain. 
In 2009, spending on sustainable growth amounts to 39.6 % of the budget, of which cohesion measures account for the lion's share. 
This budgetary area also covers most of the EU's research funding. 
In addition, EU funds contribute significantly to development aid and humanitarian aid, as well as to countries that have close ties with the Union or are candidate countries. 
6.7 % of the budget is spent on the administration of the Community institutions. 
EU citizenship, freedom, security and justice The European Union as a global player Administration Agriculture - Conservation and management of natural resources 45.3 % 1.2 % 7.2 % 6.7 % EU spending Cohesion - sustainable growth Source: General budget of the European Union for the financial year 2009 (OJ L 69, 13.3.2009). 39.6 % 
The budget is determined annually, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, by the Council, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and the directly elected European Parliament on a proposal from the European Commission. 
The Commission draws up the budget and is also responsible for its implementation. 
The majority of the budget, in particular in the area of agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure, will be implemented in cooperation with the Member States. 
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on applications from the beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union. 8 
Democratic societies need complete and accurate publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both with a view to improving financial management and ensuring accountability. 
The EU, as well as its Member States, has an external audit body, which plays the role of an independent guardian of the financial interests of citizens. 
In its capacity as an external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds have been correctly accounted for regardless of where they are used and spent in accordance with the legislation with due regard to the optimal use of funds. 
The results of the Court's audit work are used by the Parliament, the Council and the Commission as well as by the Member States to improve EU financial management. 
The Court's work is an important basis for the annual discharge procedure, during which Parliament decides, on the basis of Council recommendations, whether the Commission has fulfilled its responsibility for budget implementation in the previous year. 
Despite its designation, the Court has no judicial powers. 
In the budget areas under shared management, Member States shall cooperate with the Commission in setting up supervisory and control systems, i.e. internal control, to ensure that the funds are used properly and properly. 
Internal control thus has a European as well as a national dimension. 
In addition to the Court's work, many national supervisory authorities are auditing EU funds provided that they are managed and spent by public bodies in the Member States. 
9 ABOUT THE INTERNATIONAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROL OF THE EUHAUSHALTS EU-level Internal Control External Control Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) European Court of Auditors Member States Implementing bodies National Control Authorities National level 
(Audit) WHAT REPORTS THE HOF ON YOUR RESULTS? 
The Court publishes the results of its audit work in the following types of reports: Annual reports - including the results of the audit of the accounts in the form of a statement of assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and the activities under the European Development Funds3. 
Special annual reports - the results of the audit of the accounts of the agencies and bodies of the Communities. 
Special reports - with the results of selected profitability or compliance audits. 
10 1 Further information on the Court's audit methods can be found in the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu). 
2 According to the EC Treaty, the Court is obliged to provide such a declaration - or opinion - on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. 
In this context, the underlying transactions are usually payments to the final beneficiaries at the expense of the EU budget. 
The annual statement of assurance is generally known by the French acronym DAS ("Déclaration d'Assurance"). 
In contrast to practice in the Member States, the Court makes such a statement on the EU budget as a whole. 
3 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are based both on international agreements between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries. 
The Court conducts its audit of the annual accounts of the EU in accordance with International Audit Principles (ISA), which are valid both in the public and private sectors. 
However, the existing international audit principles do not fully cover the compliance audit carried out by the Court. 
Together with the national control authorities, the Court actively participates in the further development of international audit standards promoted by the standardisation bodies (INTOSAI, IFAC)4. 
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with the legislation and frameworks, the Court relies on the results of both its analysis of supervisory and control systems aimed at preventing or detecting and correcting legality and regularity errors and a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2). 
Where systems are verified and found to be reliable, the number of transactions that the Court has to audit in order to reach a sound conclusion regarding their legality and regularity will be reduced accordingly. 
Other sources, such as the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions. 
In performance audits, the Court uses a variety of audit methods to assess the management and monitoring systems and to assess performance data against the criteria derived from the legislation with regard to the principles of sound financial management. 
In the selection of topics for its performance audits, the Court strives to identify audit areas where the greatest impact can be expected in terms of the potential for improvement identified in terms of the economy, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending. 11 were concluded, as well as decisions of the Council on the Association of Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs). 
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see External Relations, Development and Enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries. 
The EDF investment facilities are managed by the European Investment Bank (EIB) and are not subject to the Court's audit mandate. 
4 INTOSAI (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions - IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) 
12 CASTES 2 THE PROCESSIONS OF THE HOUSE INSTRUCTIONS OF THE EUHAUSHAL We do not have the resources necessary to examine in detail all the transactions financed by the EU budget. 
In the context of the preparation of the DAS, it therefore uses statistical sampling methods to obtain a result representative of the population as a whole. 
The sample shall be selected by randomly selecting a representative sample of underlying transactions from all areas of the Union budget, such as agriculture, for in-depth examination. 
The Court monitors these operations until the final beneficiary of the aid, such as a farmer in France. 
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks - e.g. measuring the size of the agricultural area - in order to determine whether the relevant information in the application for support corresponds to the actual circumstances. 
By being a statistical sample, the results can be extrapolated to the population concerned, i.e. a specific revenue or expenditure area, and, together with information resulting from the system assessment, serve as the basis for an overall audit opinion. 
In order to determine how the opinion was to be assessed, in practice, the Court compares the results of its audits on statistical samples with a certain limit which it considers reasonable - the so-called materiality threshold. 
Random selection of a representative sample Payment to an agricultural holding in France Population of payments in the agricultural sector 
The Court of Auditors acts as a collegiate body consisting of 27 members, each with one member per Member State. 
All audit reports and opinions are adopted by the College. 
The Court is divided into five audit groups to which individual members are assigned. 
As shown in the Organisation Chart (see page 17), there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas (maintenance and management of natural resources - structural policies, transport, research and energy - External policies - Revenues, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies). 
The fifth audit group (CEAD or Coordination, Communication, Evaluation, Quality Assurance and Development) is responsible for "horizontal" issues such as coordination in the area of assurance, quality assurance, development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports. 
In addition, an Administrative Committee is responsible for the preparatory treatment of all administrative matters requiring a formal decision by the Court. 
The Members of the Court shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, in accordance with the proposals of each Member State for a term of office of six years; Re-election is permitted. 
Members shall carry out their activities in full independence for the general good of the European Union. 
In addition to his function within the college, which is responsible for final decision-making on audits and opinions as well as on further strategic and administrative issues, each member is primarily responsible for his or her specific tasks in the area of auditing. 
The actual audit work is usually the task of the auditors in the individual audit units and is coordinated by the relevant member with the support of his cabinet. 
The Member then took over the presentation of the report in the audit group or in the Court and after its adoption in the European Parliament, Council and other interested third parties. 
On 1 January 2008, three new members - Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Harald Noack (Germany) and Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) - replaced their predecessors after their term of office. 
The Council also extended the mandate of four Members - Mr Hubert Weber (Austria), Mr Maarten B. Engwirda (Netherlands), Mr David Bostock (United Kingdom) and Mr Ioannis Sarmas (Greece) - for a period of six years. 
The President at the head of the European Court of Auditors is the President, who is elected by the members from their middle for three years, with re-election allowed. 
The President represents the Court in all his external relations, in particular in his relations with the discharge authority, the other institutions of the European Union and the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States and beneficiary countries. 
On 16 January 2008, the Portuguese Member, Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, was elected the tenth President of the Court. 14 
The Secretary-General is the highest-ranking member of the institution and is appointed by the Court for a period of six years; Re-election is permitted. 
The Secretary-General is responsible for the Court's human resources and material management, including professional training and the Directorate for Translation, each with one unit per official language (22), except Irish. 
The Secretary-General is also under the authority of the Court's secretariat. 
The former Secretary-General, Mr Michel Hervé, left the Court on 31 October 2008. 
On 9 October 2008, Mr. John Speed was appointed Secretary General, m.d.d.G.b. 
On 10 March 2009, the Court appointed Mr Eduardo Ruiz García as the new Secretary-General with effect from 16 March 2009. In the budget for the financial year 2008, there are 858 posts for the European Court of Auditors (at 31. In December 2008). 
The Court's auditors have a wide range of training profiles and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the areas of accounting, financial management, internal and external audits and law and economics. 
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States. Staff are subject to the EU Staff Regulations.

Overview OF THE PRECIFICATION REPORTS AND OPINION5 YEAR REPORTS TO THE HOUSE YEAR REPORT 2007 YEAR REPORT ON THE EUHAUSHALTSPLAN REPORT The annual accounts provide, in all material respects, a true and fair view of the financial situation and the results of the EU. 
The limitations set out in last year's annual report on the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2006 are no longer valid due to the improvements made in 2007. 
On some areas, such as the Union's administrative expenditure, the Court gives full audit opinions on legality and regularity. 
However, the Court cannot give an unrestricted opinion on most expenditure areas. 
Although most of the payments we audited have been made in accordance with the legislation, we still consider the error rate in payments to final beneficiaries, such as farmers and holders of EU-funded projects, to be too high. 
With the exception of cohesion measures with an error rate of at least 11 %, the estimated error rate in these topics ranges from 2 % to 5 %. 
In some areas of expenditure, in particular those previously covered by internal and external policies, the estimated level of error has decreased, but not so much that it would change the overall picture. 
The result does not mean that these breaches of legislation are due to fraud or that most of the operations in these areas are unlawful and/or illegal. 
In three areas - administrative and other expenditure, economic and financial and revenue - the audits carried out by the Court of Auditors on representative samples of transactions showed low estimated error rates. 
In the Union's largest expenditure area - agriculture and natural resources - the estimated overall error rate remains essential. 
Rural development and its often complex schemes account for a disproportionate proportion of this error rate. 
For expenditure under the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the value of the error rate estimated by the Court is just below the materiality threshold of 2 %. 
As in previous years, cohesion measures, accounting for more than a third of the budget volume, constitute the most error-related area. 
On the basis of the sample estimate of the proportion of transactions affected by error, at least 11 % of the total amount of refunds should not have been paid. 
5 The purpose of this section is to introduce the Court's reports and opinions and not to summarise their content. 
Further information can be found in the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after its adoption. 
The high level of error in areas such as cohesion is partly due to inherent risk due to the high number of beneficiaries applying for EU funding under complex rules and legislation. 
The shortcomings in the design and functioning of the systems also contribute to the shortcomings identified. 
Most EU-funded programmes contain provisions on corrective measures that provide for the recovery of funds unduly disbursed due to errors on a multi-annual basis. 
However, there is no information on the impact of these measures. 
This means that it cannot be specifically determined whether they effectively reduce the proportion of illegal and/or irregular expenditure. 
The Commission has been working on a reform programme to improve the management of the EU budget since 2000, which includes an action plan from 2006. 
By the end of 2007, the Commission had implemented two thirds of the sub-measures from the Action Plan. 
However, it is still too early to assess the impact of these measures. 
Improved high-level controls, such as the Commission's monitoring of Member States' control activities, cannot compensate for inadequacy of lower level controls such as on-the-spot checks. 
However, the benefits resulting from the increased implementation of on-the-spot checks must be weighed against the costs. 
We recommend that the Union's political authorities define what level of risk of error would be appropriate. 
In order to reduce the level of error in EU payments, the Court recommends simplifying rules and legislation, streamlining internal control measures and improving monitoring and reporting.

In the YEAR 2008 OPINION The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management by delivering opinions on proposals or budgetary matters. 
These opinions are required as part of the adoption procedure of financial rules7 or may be made at the request of one of the other Community institutions8. 
In addition, the Court can provide opinions on its own initiative. 
The Court's opinions may address issues relating to certain EU spending areas, such as the amendment of the Financial Regulation of the European Aviation Safety Agency (No 1/2008) or issues related to EU revenue, such as the amendment of the Regulation on the Community's own resources system (No 2/2008). 
Opinions are based on the Court's expertise on EU financial management issues acquired in the course of our audits over the years, and in some cases reference is made to certain audits or opinions. 
For example, in its Opinion on the new Financial Regulation of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor), the Court refers to its annual report on the financial year 2006, in which he had already pointed out high risks regarding the legality and regularity of payments for research aid.

Opinion No 1/2008 Opinion No 2/2008 Opinion No 3/2008 Opinion No 4/2008 Opinion No 5/2008 on the proposal for a decision of the Management Board of the European Aviation Safety Agency amending the Agency's financial rules on a proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1150/2000 implementing Decision 2000/597/EC, Euratom on the system of the Communities' own resources 
Public financial control plays a central role in promoting accountability and makes a useful contribution to public debate. 
The audit activities shall be held accountable to the addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, as to whether their taxpayers' money is spent in a proper and appropriate manner. 
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned, primarily in the European context, namely the Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the Member States. 
On the basis of this information, they may take action with or without reference to the audit conclusions. 
Although the Court's audit work has its main impact on the published reports, there is already some effect throughout the audit itself. 
In the replies, the audited body often acknowledges the problems identified by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them. 
Upon completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the results of the audit will be evaluated and used by the Parliament and the Council to carry out their political role of monitoring the use of the budget. 
In the context of the annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form a basis for the Council's recommendation and Parliament's decision in this regard. 
29 examples can be found in the 2007 discharge procedure, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to make efforts to simplify and further clarify the rules in order to reduce the risks of error, streamline controls and reduce costs. 
This applies both to shared management areas, such as expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures, as well as direct management areas, such as expenditure on research or culture and education. 
Special reports are also taken into account in the discharge procedure. 
However, due to the fact that they are published in the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate in this regard took place at the meetings of the Parliament and of the Council at an earlier stage. 
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by their topic in the relevant media, which attracts greater attention and encourages public discussion. 
As a rule, media coverage for the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive, but some special reports have also been followed up with interest by the press. 
An example of this is the Special Report on the Cross Compliance Scheme (No 8/2008), which was currently published on the adoption of the Health Check of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). 
Due to the importance of the cross-compliance regime and its central role within the CAP and due to the time of publication, the report found a broad echo in the various media: Television, newspapers, trade press, internet publications (press, agricultural associations, MEP websites, web blogs, etc.). 
The report was also dealt with in detail in the European Parliament and almost all the Court's recommendations were taken up in the draft discharge report. 
Further information on the follow-up of previous observations by the Court can be found in the respective chapters of its annual report. 
The Court's most frequently remarked in its last annual report is that despite the measures taken, the deficiencies identified in the previous year were only partially addressed. 
The Court intends to analyse increasingly the long-term impact of its work - audits and opinions. 
As an example, the Court uses a Commission database containing the follow-up to its audit recommendations as a basis for assessing the impact of our audits. 
The assessment may result in separate in-depth audits leading to further findings and recommendations. 
These may be included in a subsequent special report on the area concerned or recorded in a follow-up report and the impact of recommendations on financial management. 
In the context of the development of an internal Community control framework, the Court considered in its Opinion No 2/2004 that it is up to political authorities to decide on the level of risk they are willing to accept when approving EU spending regimes. 
We suggested that Parliament and Council agree on an appropriate ratio between the costs and benefits of controls, in other words the tolerable residual risk of errors in expenditure. 
The costs of the controls should be proportionate to the benefits they provide from a monetary and political point of view. 
Since the publication of this opinion, both the European Parliament and the Council have expressed the desire in their discharge resolutions to pursue the issue further and to reach a common understanding of the tolerable level of risk. 
At the end of 2008, the Commission issued a Communication entitled 'Towards a common understanding of the concept of tolerable risk of error'. 
The Court welcomed this communication and sent a reply to the Commission highlighting certain limits and setting out the main aspects to be considered in the future follow-up of this issue. 
In its Communication, the Commission states that any decision on a tolerable risk of error should be based, inter alia, on the potential for further simplification. 
The Court also highlights the importance and benefits of further simplifications and the potential impact on reducing errors or irregularities. 
The concept of "tolerable risk of error" must be clearly separated from the concept of materiality threshold as defined and applied by the Court. The latter is the responsibility of the external auditor10. 
In the Court's view, the cost-benefit analysis of spending programmes could provide information not only for discussions on the tolerable risk, but also for the review of the regulatory framework and the governance structure of the programmes concerned. 
In this context, the relevant question may not be whether there is a tolerable risk of error, but whether the risk of error is so high that the scheme or programme concerned should be abolished/terminated or fundamentally modified. 
Specific attention should also be paid to the concept of tolerable risk when designing expenditure (and revenue) schemes or programmes. 
It would be useful if, at the time of their adoption, expenditure programmes had sufficient information on the risks involved and the costs of the controls envisaged to reduce those risks to a reasonable extent. 
In this way, decisions would be taken in an informed manner, taking into account the risks and costs involved. 
The process of budgetary reform may provide an opportunity to reflect on this issue, as suggested by the Court in its reply to the Commission communication entitled 'To reform the budget, change Europe'11. 
31 10 The concept of 'materiality' is defined in the International Examination Principle ISA 320 as follows: 'Informatio-n are essential if their omission or misrepresentation could affect the economic decisions taken by final addressees on the basis of a conclusion. 
Materiality depends on the size of the item or error resulting from the particular circumstances of omission or misrepresentation. 
Thus, materiality is more of a threshold or limit, and less a primary qualitative requirement that information needs to be useful. 11 See the European Court of Auditors' response to the Commission's Communication "Reforming the budget, changing Europe", April 2008.

Audit strategy The audit strategy is based on the Court's strategic objectives. 
33 STRATEGISCHE ZIELE Professionality Output audience Further development and growth Consolidated audit methods, appropriate audit strategy, further development of audit practice in the public sector, development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards for EU funds, cooperation with the EU SAIs, effective "Community control framework" selection of relevant audit topics, timeliness, clarity and legibility of the reports, quality of performance audits, increase the impact of reports deepening relations with audit bodies in order to improve understanding of the audit process and to achieve greater acceptance of audit results in order to strengthen and develop contacts with the European Parliament and Council as budgetary and discharge authority effective communication with EU citizens using peer review experience in order to strengthen and develop the organisation, methods, procedures and results and to achieve maximum efficiency tracking of effective and dynamic staffing policies.
