The purpose of the audits and reports carried out by the Court is to contribute to improving EU financial management and protecting the EU's financial interests for the benefit of EU citizens. 
The following key aspects are taken into account in the formulation of the relevant strategy for the Court's activities: Impact EFFIZIENZ Reports Audit work Programme To implement its mission and mission statement, the Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 in 2008. 
A summary of this document is available on the Court's website. 
The Court's strategy is based on two priority objectives: Maximise the overall impact of the audits and improve efficiency by making the best use of resources. 
These objectives will have a major impact on the Court's work programmes during that period as well as its continuous improvement efforts. 
The Court aims to maximise the overall impact of its audits over the relevant period by selecting and designing audits that focus on topics from risk areas and which are of greatest interest to the Court's audience; • continue to present sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement and follow up on whether these proposals are being implemented; • carry out a wider range of audits and present new types of audit products that complement the current annual and special reports; • create a larger number of special reports and improve their timeliness and ease of use; • further strengthen its relations with its main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public. During the relevant period, the Court aims to improve efficiency by making the best use of its resources. 
These include: • a better line; • an effective and dynamic human resources policy; • rationalisation of audit tasks; • the improvement of IT tools; • the development of expertise; • the development of relations with the audited bodies. 34 
12 As in previous years, the 2009 work programme includes the preparation of annual reports setting out the results of the audits of the accounts that the Court has to carry out in accordance with the EC Treaty and other EU legislation. 
For 2009, the Court identified a number of audit topics relating to policy developments and issues of EU financial management. 
As regards developments in EU policy areas, the following topics have been selected: • Growth and employment; • Climate change and sustainable development; • Europe as a global partner; • better regulation. 
In addition, in the area of EU financial management, the Court focuses on the following issues, which we consider to deserve particular attention: • Completion of the 2000-2006 spending programmes, in particular in the area of the Structural Funds; • EU accountability and reform; • Progress of the Commission's Action Plan for an Integrated Internal Control Framework, taking into account the concept of tolerable risk; • Administrative and control measures at Member State level. 
The Court's objective is to address these issues as of 2009 as part of its annual reports, special reports and a number of new types of reports (see comments below). 
The Court intends to publish a series of special reports and related novel reports drawn up on the basis of the audit tasks it selected. 
The planning and implementation of these selected audit tasks, as well as their reporting, usually extend over a period of more than one year. 
Therefore, most of the reports published in a given year are based on audit work initiated in previous years. 
Box 5 contains the selected audit tasks that have been completed or are ahead of completion and the results of which are therefore expected to be published in special reports in 2009 or early 2010. 
35 12 A more complete and detailed overview of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2009 work programme, which is available on our website (www.eca.europa.eu). 
The follow-up of the recommendations is an important tool for the Court to actively contribute to improving financial management. 
The report will include an analysis of the extent to which our recommendations have been followed and, where appropriate, an assessment of the effectiveness of the measures taken. 
It is expected to be published at approximately the same time as the annual report. - The other new type of report we intend to present is a report on high-risk areas in the context of EU financial management. 
The report is addressed to the new Commission, which will start its work towards the end of the year, and will provide guidance. 
In 2006, the Court carried out a self-assessment which identified its strengths and weaknesses. 
Subsequently, an action plan was drawn up to address the vulnerabilities. 
The Action Plan included a number of actions, following which the Court set out its mission statement, mission, strategic objectives and strategic planning; • developed internal performance indicators that are gradually introduced (see section below); • adopted an internal communication strategy which has already been implemented and has opened new channels for better dissemination of information within the institution; • taken various measures to improve the quality of its reports, for example through a new graphic design to improve readability and external evaluations; • adopted a progressive strategy to improve the Court's relations with its addressees, the press and the general public. 
As part of its efforts to improve, in 2009 the Court will seek to take up the observations and recommendations of the International Peer Review Report on the European Court of Auditors published in December 2008, which is an important step in the Court's ongoing reform process. 
Peer review was carried out by representatives of the national supervisory authorities of Canada, Norway, Austria and Portugal. 
The peers carried out their work in 2008 and in this context also contacted the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament. The final report was presented at the end of 2008. 
The objective of the peer review process was to assess the design and functioning of the framework set by the Court for audits. 
The assessment covered the following areas: • Planning and auditing procedures for accounting and performance audits; • Reporting on the results of the audit; • Services that assist the Court in achieving its objectives. 
The peer review team concluded that the design of the framework set by the Court for audits complies with international audit principles and good practice for Supreme Audit Institutions. 
In addition, the peers noted that • the Court carries out its activities independently and objectively; • the Court's audit reports are based on sufficient and appropriate audit evidence as foreseen in the international audit principles; • place a high level of confidence in the Court's reports and generally consider them fair, objective and objective. 
The Court welcomes the constructive comments and recommendations made by the peers to identify ways to further strengthen its role as the Supreme Audit Authority and draw attention to the challenges involved. 
This includes, among other things, the need to develop a culture that focuses on a uniform approach of the Court as an audit body; • to strengthen quality assurance and quality control activities with the aim of consistent interpretation and application of its audit strategies and methods; • to develop risk-oriented audit strategies in order to make the most of the resources in view of the different needs of the addressees. 
The peer review report acknowledges that most of the recommendations have already been anticipated within the framework of the action plan drawn up before the procedure. 
The Court intends to include the remaining recommendations in its audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 following an exchange with its staff and addressees and will endeavour to implement them during this period. 
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS INTERNATIONAL PEER REVIEW OF THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS 38 
In 2008, the Court decided to introduce a system of key performance indicators (ZLIs) for its audit-related and non-audit activities to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and objectives set out in the Annual Work Programme. 
ZLI serves to strengthen internal and external accountability and increase work efficiency and quality. The ZLI will be introduced gradually in 2009 and 2010. 
WHY KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS? • To inform management of how successful the Court as an institution implements what it intended; • to support the decision-making process by focusing the institution's attention on efficiency issues and by promoting improvements; • to provide the addressee with information on relevant aspects related to the Court's performance. 
They are intended to provide information about the Court's performance as a "company" and become an integral part of the Court's management system. 
The volume and quality of audit work can also be improved by looking at the impact of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management. 
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work. 
They will be developed with a view to their inclusion in the Court's annual work programme for 2010. 
As a sample, the Court measured performance in 2008 on the basis of ZLI 5 and 6. 
ZLI 5 - Number of reports adopted compared to the number of planned reports In 2008, the Court adopted 79 % of the planned number of reports. 
The annual report and most of the special annual reports were adopted as planned. 
Of the planned 20 special reports, only twelve were adopted. 
The remaining eight special reports were at 31. ==References====External links== 
ZLI 6 - Number of reports adopted on schedule In 2008, the Court adopted 73 % of its reports on time. 
The annual report and all specific annual reports were adopted on time; however, further efforts are needed to improve compliance with the deadlines for the adoption of the special reports. 
ZLI 7, which measures the number of key audit notifications prepared on time, will provide useful performance information and will be prepared in 2009. 
A ZLI (8) covers aspects related to the Court's financial management. 
Two ZLIs (9 and 10) will contribute to the improvement of staff satisfaction and optimise the use of professional training as a tool for continuously updating the knowledge of the latest examination methods and techniques.

In accordance with the EC Treaty, the ECA has to carry out its audit in "link" with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States (ORKBs) while the Amsterdam Treaty added: "The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies shall cooperate with confidence while respecting their independence." This scheme was extended in the Treaty of Nice by explicitly calling on the Court of Auditors in the 18th Declaration of the Final Act to set up a committee for contacts with the national audit bodies, in which all SAI Presidents and the Court meet annually to discuss matters of common interest. 
In December 2008, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the EU-ORKB Presidents' Contact Committee. 
Thematic priorities of the meeting were the reform of the EU budget and the revised Lisbon Strategy for the period 2008-2011. 
The Contact Committee aims to strengthen cooperation among its members in order to improve external audit and accountability in the EU. 
The role of the Contact Committee has evolved over the years in parallel with European integration. 
In addition to facilitating the exchange of information between the SAIs and the ECA, this body has made significant progress in effective cooperation between the different supervisory authorities. 
At its meeting in Helsinki in 2007, the Contact Committee recognised the need to address emerging or new issues in good time and agreed to provide for a permanent agenda item for dealing with such current issues. 
Accordingly, at its meeting in 2008, the Contact Committee discussed the economic and financial crisis and agreed to set up a workshop on the role of the EU-ORKB in the context of the crisis. 
Subsequently, a network was set up to promote cooperation on audits related to the Lisbon Strategy and EU crisis management measures. 
The Court attended meetings of the SAI Network of Candidate Countries and Candidate Countries "in spe" (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Montenegro). 
These meetings took place at the same time as Liaison Officers' meetings in May and October. 
A delegation from the Court also participated in a workshop on the audit/evaluation of internal control systems of public finances organised by the Network on 8 and 9 July in Ankara, Turkey. 
Throughout 2008, the Court actively participated in the various working groups set up by the Contact Committee. 
The Working Group on Common Audit Standards, whose objective is to develop common audit standards tailored to the EU environment and comparable audit standards based on internationally recognised audit principles, met four times under the chairmanship of the Court in 2008. 
With effect from December 2008, the Court took over the (rotating) chair of the VAT Working Group and the Agricultural Expert Network resumed its work under the chairmanship of a Member of the Court. 
The Court continued its active participation and involvement in the improvement of international audit principles and procedures through its membership in European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, namely EUROSAI and INTOSAI. 
A delegation from the Court took place on VII. EUROSAI Congress, which took place from 2 to 5 June in Krakow (Poland). 
The main topics of discussion were the introduction of audit-related quality management systems in an SAI, the examination of social programmes in the field of training and the professional integration of disabled people. 
The President of the Court presented a contribution to the role of management in the implementation of a quality management system for auditing. 
As part of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and the IT Working Group and participates in the EUROSAI Training Committee. 
He also works on the VII. EUROSAI Congress working group to develop a guide on best practices to achieve quality in an SAI. 
In addition, the Court is a member of the EUROSAI Task Force to audit disaster relief funds. 42 
At the EUROSAI Congress, the European Court of Auditors, together with the Supreme Audit Authority of the Slovak Republic, was appointed as auditor for the period 2009-2011. 
Since the Court became a full member of INTOSAI in 2004, he has actively participated in the Financial Audit Guidelines (FAS), the Subcommittee for the Audit of Legal Standards (CAS) and the Subcommittee for Performance Audits (PAS). 
The Court contributed to the Subcommittee on the Promotion of Best Practices and Quality Assurance through voluntary peer reviews. 
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on the accountability and audit of disaster relief (succession body of the INTOSAI Task Force Tsunami). 
A first meeting of this working group was hosted by the Court in the period from 30 June to 2 July 2008. 
At this meeting, the draft work programme for the period 2008-2010 was discussed and adopted. 
The main objective is to develop guidance on accountability and audit in this area, with the aim of reaching all stakeholders through the relevant responsible body. 
In addition to its coordinating role, the Court has assumed responsibility for a number of tasks, two of them in cooperation with the Norwegian Court of Auditors. 
The Chair of this Working Group also requires the Court to be represented in the meetings of the INTOSAI Bureau. 43

Translation Translation is an important administrative task that enables the Court to achieve its communication objectives and to comply with its legal obligation to publish in 22 languages. 
Translation volumes increased by 17 % in 2008, mainly due to the assumption of a higher number of special reports. 
The vast majority of translations are done internally, and during peak times when the normal capacity of the translation units is exceeded, translation orders are awarded to the Translation Centre (CTOU) or to external translation agencies. 
In addition, the translators take part in audit trips and assist the auditors before, during and after audit trips, including in the subsequent stages of the drafting of audit reports. 
The translators provide constant support in the ongoing updating of the content of the intranet and the website in English and French. 
They also support INTOSAI working groups and cover other specific needs related to the Court's activities. 
The Court's Directorate for Translation is actively involved in the work of the Interinstitutional Translation and Interpretation Committee (CITI), is a member of international committees and participates in international conferences related to the development of electronic tools for translation and documentation. 
Audit visits During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States and other beneficiary countries from EU funds in order to obtain adequate audit evidence. 
Visits usually apply to central and local authorities involved in the authorisation, management and disbursement of EU funds, as well as the respective final recipients. 
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the length of a test trip may be up to two weeks depending on the type of test and distance. 
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the visited Member State, which provide useful logistical and practical support. 47 
Costs of EUR 3.29 million were incurred in connection with audit missions in 2008. 
This substantial investment is needed to ensure sufficient audit coverage at all levels and locations of the management of EU funds.

The report on the Intelligent Energy - Europe Programme 2003-2006 (Special Report No 7/2008), adopted by the Court in 2008, provided an insight into the functioning of an aid scheme to improve the use of energy-efficient technologies. 
It covered the procedures established for the allocation of funds for individual projects, the monitoring and evaluation modalities, the administrative costs and the impact of the establishment of an executive agency. 
The team responsible for carrying out the audit worked closely with the rapporteur member, Mr David Bostock. 
The head of the department responsible for overseeing the audit was Hendrik Fehr, and Peggy Vercauteren was head of the team. 
The auditors involved were Oliver Müller, Peter Zsapka, Zoltán Giday and Carl-Christian Buhr, with Gerhard Ross, Thomas af Hällström and Peter Welch from Mr. David Bostock's cabinet also playing an important role. 
The audit included a survey to obtain information from a broad group of participants. 
Various cost accounting techniques have been used to complete and complement the information available to the Commission. 
The audit found that the programme was managed in accordance with the Commission's usual approaches and guidance. 
However, the spending pattern was poorly targeted and the monitoring and evaluation did not make it possible to assess the overall quality of the programme. 
During the programme period, relatively high administrative costs (for the Commission, the Agency and the participants) were incurred - approximately the same amount as the amount paid to participants during the same period. 
The establishment of the Executive Agency improved the satisfaction of the participants with the programme.

4 BORWORD OF THE PRESIDENT 4 Welcome to reading the Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors for 2009. 
The aim of this report is to provide readers with an overview of the main findings and progress made by the Court during this year and to inform them of the main developments in its audit environment and internal organisation. 
2009 was an important year of renewal for the EU, marked by the election of a new European Parliament, the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and the launch of the process to select a new European Commission. 
The new Treaty confirms the Court's role and mission, as well as its status as an EU institution, and introduces changes in the management and control of EU funds, strengthening the role of the European Parliament and underlining the responsibility of Member States for the implementation of the budget. 
The Court expects that these developments will provide good opportunities to improve EU financial management. 
The Court's position section summarises our opinion on the risks and challenges faced by the new Commission. 
A high priority is given to improving the quality of EU spending. 
We have made significant progress during this year in implementing our audit strategy 2009-2012 and towards achieving our goals - increasing the impact of our work and making better use of our resources. 
A decisive step was our decision to submit a new Rules of Procedure to the Council of the European Union to streamline our procedures for the adoption of reports and opinions. 
In addition, the number of reports prepared by the Court increased from 42 in 2008 to 57 in 2009. 
I am also pleased to report that our core product, the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, once again received positive reception among our main institutional addressees who agreed to many of our recommendations. 
During 2009, the Court continued its active cooperation with the Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) to develop common approaches to auditing EU funds and to reflect on how the SAIs can support governments in coping with the financial and economic crisis. 
The performance of the Court depends on the competence and motivation of its 880 employees. 
Your satisfaction is a key factor in the Court's success and is quantified for the first time in this report. 
I would like to thank the Court's staff for their tireless and dedicated work, with which they enable the Court to fulfil its mission. 
The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing EU finances in accordance with the Treaty. 
As an EU external auditor, he contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens. 
Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and staff supplying its addressees with appropriate audit results, with all forms of influence being rejected by instructions or pressures from outside PROFESSIONALITY Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of its work MOREWERT EXCELLENZ AND EFFIZIENZ Establishing relevant, timely, high quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the interests of its addressee and improvement of the EU's role in improving the functioning of the EU's activities and enhancing the effectiveness of the EU's performance in terms of efficiency and efficiency.

Maximising the overall impact of the audits ? Improving efficiency by making the best use of resources 
The European Union's budget (2010) amounts to around EUR 123 billion, accounting for approximately 1 % of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States. 
However, for some Member States, EU funding plays an important role in the financing of public activities, and compared to the GNI of several Member States, the overall budget is significant. 
The revenue of the European Union consists mainly of contributions from Member States derived from their gross national income (GNI - 76 %), customs duties and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources - 12 %) and a contribution based on the VAT collected by the Member States (VAT). 11 %. 
BOX 1 - WHAT IS THE EU SPENDING ITS MONEY ON? 
The EU budget is financed by Member States' financial contributions (mainly based on national GNI), customs duties and agricultural duties, as well as VAT contributions. 
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than national budgets, partly due to the different areas of competence. 
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1. 1 % Conservation and management of natural resources (mainly agriculture) 47.3 % The largest single expenditure area of the EU is agriculture and rural development, mainly in the form of payments to farmers, accounting for almost half of the budget expenditure. 
Cohesion measures - regional and social development - co-finance a wide range of projects, from road construction projects in Latvia to training for the unemployed in the Netherlands. 
This sector accounts for about one third of budgetary expenditure. 
The European Union as a global player EU spending Source: General budget of the European Union for the financial year 2010. Management 6.4 % 6.3 % Sustainable growth (mainly cohesion) 38.8 % 
The budget is determined annually, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, by the Council, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and by the directly elected European Parliament. 
The European Commission sets up the budget and is also responsible for its implementation. 
The majority of the budget, in particular in the area of agricultural and cohesion policy expenditure, is implemented in cooperation with the Member States. 
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on applications from the beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union. 9 
10 WHAT ROLE DOES THE COURT HAVE? 
Democratic societies need proper, publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both with a view to improving financial management and ensuring accountability. 
In its capacity as an EU external auditor, the European Court of Auditors shall ensure that the EU funds have been correctly accounted for regardless of where they are used and spent in accordance with the relevant legislation and taking due account of the need for optimal use of funds. 
The results of the Court's audit work are used by the Commission, Parliament and Council as well as by the Member States to improve EU financial management. 
In addition to the Court's work, many national supervisory authorities are auditing EU funds provided that they are managed and spent by public bodies in the Member States. 
Overview ABOUT THE INTERNATIONAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROL OF THE EU-HAUSHALTS EU level Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing bodies European Court of Auditors National Control Authorities National level Internal control External control 
(AUDIT OF ACCOUNTS) 2. Are financial transactions in all material respects in line with the relevant legal and other regulatory framework? 
(COMPLIANCE TEST) 3. If financial management is economic, i.e. the use of funds has been minimised (separity), results have been achieved with the lowest possible use of resources (economicity) and have the objectives pursued (effectiveness) been achieved? 
The Court publishes the results of its audit work in the following types of reports: Annual reports - including the results of the audit of the accounts in the form of a statement of assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and the activities under the European Development Funds3. 
Specific annual reports - the results of the audit of the accounts of the Union agencies and decentralised bodies. 
11 1 Further information on the Court's audit methods can be found in the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu). 
2 According to the TFEU, the Court is obliged to provide such a statement - or opinion - on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. 
The annual statement of assurance is generally known by the French acronym DAS ("Déclaration d'Assurance"). 
12 HOW DOES THE COURT PROCEED IN ITS AUDITS? 
The Court conducts its audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with international audit principles that are valid both in the public and private sectors. 
However, the existing international audit principles do not cover the compliance audit carried out by the Court. 
Together with the national supervisory authorities, the Court actively participates in the further development of international audit principles promoted by the Standardising Organisations (INTOSAI, IFAC)4. 
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with the legal and other regulatory framework, the Court relies on the results of both our analysis of supervisory and control systems aimed at preventing or detecting and correcting legality and regularity errors as well as a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2). 
Other sources, such as the statements of the management of the audited bodies in the form of the annual activity reports of the Directors-General of the Commission and the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions. 
In performance audits, the Court uses a variety of audit methods to assess the management and monitoring systems and to assess performance data against the criteria derived from the legislation and the principles of sound financial management. 
In the selection of topics for its performance audits, the Court strives to identify audit areas where the greatest impact can be expected in terms of the potential for improvement identified in terms of the economy, efficiency and effectiveness of EU spending. 
3 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are based both on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries, as well as on Council Decisions on the Association of Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs). 
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see External Relations, Development and Enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries. 
4 INTOSAI (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) - International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions; IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) - International Association of Accountants. 
Box 2 - PRACTICE OF PAYMENTS FROM THE EU HOUSE THROUGH THE HOUSE 13 We do not have the resources necessary to examine in detail all the transactions related to the EU budget. 
It therefore uses statistical sampling techniques to provide a result representative of the populations concerned. 
The Court monitors these transactions until the final beneficiary of the grant, for example a project promoter in Italy. 
The Court then checks - often on the spot - whether the application is in line with the actual circumstances. 
By being a representative sample, the results can be extrapolated to the population concerned, i.e. a specific revenue or expenditure area, and, together with information resulting from the assessment of management and control systems and other sources, serve as the basis for an overall audit opinion. 
Selection OF A PROVISION OF PROVISIONS Random selection of a representative sample Population of payments in the Cohesion area Payment to a project promoter in Italy 
5 14 Management structure AND ORGANISATION The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body of 27 members, each with one member per Member State. Members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a term of office of six years. 
Members elect a president from among them for three years, with the possibility of re-election. 
Five audit groups to which individual members of the Court are assigned prepare the reports and opinions for adoption by the Court. 
As shown in the organisation chart, there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas, as well as another audit group dealing with "horizontal" issues. 
In addition, an administrative committee composed of members of the Court is responsible for preparing the Court's administrative decisions. 
At the end of 2009, the Court submitted to the Council a proposal to amend its Rules of Procedure in order to allow certain categories of opinions and reports to be adopted by the Court instead of the entire College of Chambers. 
These amendments will make the Court's decision-making more streamlined and efficient, including by reducing the time needed to adopt decisions. 
Each Chamber has two areas of competence: The first is the adoption of special reports, special annual reports and opinions, second, draft observations for the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds and draft opinions for adoption by the College. 
As for the Court, decisions are taken by a majority of the members of the Chamber. 
Members may attend the meetings of all chambers, but are only entitled to vote in the Chamber to which they were assigned by the Court. 
Of course, the entire College continues to meet to discuss and adopt the documents for which the Court alone is responsible, such as the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds. 
The role of the Management Committee will be strengthened. 
The Committee shall be composed of the President of the Court, who is chaired, and the Doyens of the Chambers. 
Administrative matters, the treatment of which requires a Court decision, as well as decisions on procedural, principle or strategic issues, are prepared by the Committee before they are submitted to the Court for adoption. 
The Member then presents the report in the audit group and in the Court and, after the report has been adopted, will also present the report to the European Parliament, the Council and other interested third parties. 
5 Further details can be found on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu). 
In the budget for the financial year 2009, there are 880 posts for the European Court of Auditors (at 31. In December 2009). 
The Court's staff in the field of audits are responsible for the planning and execution of audits and the preparation of the resulting draft reports. 
The auditors work in teams of different sizes: For some specific audits, a team comprises four or five auditors, while some broader audits of the Court (e.g. audits of accounts/compliance audits in the area of agricultural and cohesion expenditure with a view to drawing up the annual statement of assurance) involve 20 or more auditors. 
As a general rule, auditors must obtain audit evidence in the context of an audit by means of different procedures: through desk checks in Luxembourg, visits to the European Commission and on-the-spot audits in the Member States where the revenue accruing to the EU budget is generated and the actions financed by the EU budget are implemented. 
The Court's reports and opinions must be accessible to readers throughout the Union. In addition, the Court has to maintain contacts with public authorities and other bodies throughout the Union in the course of its audit work. 
This would not be possible without the Court's translators who translate his reports and opinions (in almost all cases in English or French) into 22 of the official languages of the Union. 
They also translate correspondence between the Court and other bodies as needed and in some cases assist auditors in carrying out audit missions in the Member States. 
The Court's administrative staff is responsible for a variety of support tasks in a multinational body operating in the EU context. 
This concerns finance, accounting, budget, buildings, information technologies, transport, security, etc. The Secretary-General is the Court's highest-ranking staff member responsible for human resources management and administration. 15

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET: Six key statements • The annual accounts of the European Union give a true and fair view of the financial situation and results. • As regards the legality and regularity of transactions, the overall results for 2008 reflect the improvements in budgetary management achieved in recent years. • The overall progress achieved in 2008 is primarily due to the better results in the main theme, "Agriculture and natural resources". 
In rural development, while the estimated level of error is lower than in previous years, it is still substantial. 
For the first time, the Court does not issue a negative audit opinion on the topic "Agriculture and Natural Resources" as a whole. • The second largest issue, 'Cohesion', accounting for almost one third of the budget, remains problematic as the most flawed budgetary area. 
According to the Court's estimate, at least 11 % of the total amount of reimbursement payments should not have been made. • The recommendations made by the Court in the past to improve supervisory and control systems remain valid. 
They shall be regarded as part of an ongoing process in which the relevant measures can only be considered effective after some time. • In addition, particular attention should be paid to expenditure areas where the Court continues to complain about a high level of error. 
In many cases, errors are a result of excessively complex regulations and regulations. 
That is why simplification remains a priority. 19 
20 Unrestricted opinion on the reliability of the accounts The Court concluded that the accounts of the European Communities for 2008 provide, in all material respects, a true and fair view of the financial position of the European Communities and the results of their operations and cash flows. 
For 2008, the Court issued unrestricted audit opinions on "revenues", commitments in all the subjects, as well as payments in the "Education and Citizenship" and "Administrative and Other Expenditure" issues. 
Limited audit opinions The payments in the "Agriculture and Natural Resources" theme, with the exception of rural development, were legal and regular in all material respects. 
Payments under economic and financial affairs, with the exception of expenditure related to the Sixth Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development (FP6) covered by this theme, were legal and regular in all material respects. 
Negative audit opinions On the topics "Cohesion", "Research, energy and transport" and "External aid, development and enlargement", the Court issued negative audit opinions. 
Payments in these issues were material, albeit of varying degrees, affected by errors. 
The supervisory and control systems in the areas of research, energy and transport, external assistance, development and enlargement, as well as "education and citizenship" were partially effective in preventing or detecting and correcting the reimbursement of excessive or non-reimbursable costs. 
In the case of agriculture and natural resources, the Court also concluded that the supervisory and control systems were partially effective. 
However, he pointed out that the Integrated Management and Control System (IACS) remains an effective control system in general. 
However, improvements are needed in some areas, particularly in rural development, where there were shortcomings. 
In the case of economic and financial affairs, the supervisory and control systems were found to be effective in two of the three audited areas. 
In the third area, 'Company', the systems were only considered to be partially effective, mainly due to shortcomings related to FP6. 
In the case of cohesion, the Court found that the Member States' systems dedicated to correcting errors detected in national controls were at least partially effective in most cases. 
Further efforts must be made by the Commission, Member States and other beneficiary States to implement the necessary improvements in the above-mentioned issues in order to adequately manage the risk of irregular expenditure. 
Box 3 - INTERPRETATION OF PRACTICES 21 An examiner may issue the following types of audit opinions: • full audit opinion where it is demonstrated that the accounts are reliable or that the underlying transactions, i.e. payments, are legal and regular in all material respects; • negative audit opinion where the error rate in the underlying transactions is material and comprehensive or the accounts are not reliable; • • refusal of the opinion if the auditor is unable to obtain sufficient and adequate audit evidence in support of his or her opinion and the potential impact is both substantial and comprehensive; limited opinion where no unrestricted opinion can be delivered, but the effects of disagreements or limitations on the scope of the audit are not so substantial or comprehensive that they require a negative opinion or refusal of the opinion.

24 SPECIFICATIONS7 The selection of topics for economic performance and compliance audits and their design is based on criteria such as risk regarding the economic viability of certain revenue and expenditure or their compliance with legislation, expenditure volume, timing of the last audit, imminent developments in regulatory or operational framework conditions, as well as political and public interest. 
Since cost-effectiveness and compliance audits are complex and require a lot of detail work, their full implementation from the preliminary study to final reporting usually takes more than a year.

Sustainable Development • No 3/2009 "Impact of expenditure under structural measures for wastewater treatment during the 1994-1999 and 2000-2006 programming periods" • No 7/2009 "Management of the development and validation phase of the Galileo programme" • No 8/2009 "Networks of excellence and integrated projects in Community research policy: Have the objectives been achieved? • No 13/2009 "Did the transfer of implementation tasks to executive agencies be an appropriate instrument?" • No 17/2009 "VET measures for women co-financed by the European Social Fund" 25 Management of the development and validation phase of the Galileo programme The Court examined the development and validation phase of the Galileo programme, which was launched with the aim of creating a European Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) and explained the causes of the identified misdevelopments. 
It concluded that the development and validation phase was inadequately managed. 
If the reorientation of EGNOS (Geostationary Navigation Supplementary Service for Europe) and Galileo programmes is to be successful in mid-2007, the Commission needs to significantly improve its programme management. 
The report contains a number of recommendations to facilitate this task for the Commission. 
Finally, if the EU decides to participate in other major infrastructure programmes, the Commission must ensure that it has appropriate management tools at its disposal. 
Preservation and Eminence of NATURAL RESSOURCES • No 6/2009 "European Union Food Aid to the Most Deprived: Evaluation of objectives, means and methods used • No 10/2009 "Information and promotion measures for agricultural products" • No 11/2009 "Sustainability of LIFE-Nature projects and their management by the Commission" • No 14/2009 "Has market control instruments for the market for milk and milk products achieved their main objectives?" 
26 Have the market control instruments for the milk and milk products market achieved their main objectives? 
The Court took stock of the functioning of the milk and milk products market since the introduction of milk quotas in 1984 and examined the Commission's approach to managing the gradual deregulation of the milk sector initiated in 2003. 
The situation at the end of 2008 forms the basis for the Court's recommendations to the Commission: Preventing new overproduction, monitoring the price formation process in the food chain, deepening the reflection on the future of producers in disadvantaged areas and the impact of the geographical concentration of milk production on the environment, continuing the focus of milk production on the needs of the European internal market and on high added-value dairy products that are exportable to the world market without budget support. 
EU citizenship, freedom, safety and law • No 2/2009 "The European Union Programme in the field of public health (2003-2007): an effective way to improve health? The European Union's Public Health Programme (2003-2007): an effective way to improve health? 
We analysed the European Union's Public Health Programme (PHP) for the period 2003-2007. 
The Court's audit should determine whether the framework conditions for projects financed by the EU budget have been defined in such a way that they effectively complement Member States' actions to protect and improve public health. 
The report contains detailed conclusions and recommendations on the design, implementation and management of the programme. 
Based on our findings, the Court questions the benefits of certain programme elements of European public health programmes such as PHP. 
The Commission and the Member States are invited to reconsider the EU's approach to public health funding. 
The EU AS GLOBALER PARTNER • No 1/2009 "Banking activities in the Mediterranean under the MEDA programme and the previous protocols" • No 4/2009 "Management of the involvement of non-state actors in Community development cooperation" • No 12/2009 "Impact of Commission projects in the field of Justice and Home Affairs for the Western Balkans" • No 15/2009 "EU assistance provided through United Nations organisations: Decision-making and control • No 16/2009 "The European Commission's management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey" • No 18/2009 "Effect of EDF assistance for regional economic integration in East Africa and West Africa" 27 Management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission. 
In particular, the first implementation period of pre-accession assistance (2002-2006) was characterised by many weaknesses that had already occurred in previous pre-accession programmes. 
The objectives set by the Commission with regard to grants were not specific enough to allow an assessment of the impact of the project; in addition, the Commission did not have the necessary information to demonstrate the effectiveness of pre-accession assistance. 
Nevertheless, the planned outputs have been delivered for the audited projects and the project results are likely to be sustainable. 
The Commission has already made some significant improvements; nevertheless, the Court makes recommendations for further corrective action. 
Areas where improvements are most needed include the definition of strategic objectives for the grant, the definition of more realistic deadlines for achieving the objectives and monitoring of actual project performance and project results on the basis of clear objectives and appropriate indicators. 
28 ADOPTED • No 5/2009 "Cash management at the Commission" • No 9/2009 "Economicity and effectiveness of staff selection activities of the European Personnel Selection Office" Economicity and effectiveness of the staff selection activities of the European Personnel Selection Office The Court focused on how the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) managed the significant increase in the number of competitions due to the enlargement of the European Union and whether it provided timely aptitude lists that contained the required number of successful candidates and were geographically balanced. 
It concluded that EPSO had successfully managed the increase in the number of competitions due to the enlargement of the European Union. 
However, the following weaknesses were to be criticised: The staffing needs of the institutions were not notified in good time to EPSO, the staff selection process took too long, the competitions showed on average only two thirds of the planned number of successful candidates (who were included in the list of candidates) and the management information was not consistently reliable or complete.

The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned, in the European context, primarily by the Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States. 
On the basis of this information, they may take action with or without reference to the Court's audit conclusions. 
Although the Court's audit work has its main impact on the published reports and opinions, there is already a certain impact throughout the course of the audits itself. 
The replies of the audited body - notably the Commission - will be combined 29 As examples of the impact of the Court's work, the Commission took action in response to the 2007 discharge resolution (and the impact of which mainly came into effect in 2009): In the field of agricultural expenditure, the management and control system for expenditure under the newly created European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) has been aligned with the EAGF guarantee system, so that the broadly recognised benefits of this system will also apply to EAFRD expenditure (see paragraph 5.54 of the 2004 Annual Report and paragraph 5.57 of the 2007 Annual Report).

In the field of external policy areas In order to strengthen controls at the level of implementing organisations, the Commission plans to develop a specific instrument to better support these organisations in managing EU funds and comply with EU rules (see paragraph 8.33(a) of the 2007 Annual Report). 
In the field of internal policies, including research, the Commission has drawn up a multiannual control strategy for the Sixth Framework Programme. This is based on the detection and correction of errors that could not be detected by desk checks prior to the payment. 
In order to simplify the procedures of the Seventh Framework Programme, the Commission introduced a Participant Guarantee Fund to significantly reduce the number of ex ante financial controls and safeguards to be provided (see paragraphs 7.43(b), 10.34 and 2.42(a) of the 2007 Annual Report).

Special reports are also taken into account in the discharge procedure. 
Due to the fact that they are published in the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on this matter have usually taken place at an earlier stage at the meetings of the Parliament and of the Council. 
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by their topic in the relevant media, which attracts greater attention and encourages public discussion. 
As a rule, the media coverage of the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive. 
This was also the case in 2009 with media focus primarily on improvements in agricultural spending. 
Several special reports were also followed by the press with interest. 
For example, the Special Report on the Milk Market (No 14/2009), which assessed the extent to which the control instruments for the milk and milk products market achieved their main objectives, was the subject of intensive discussions in the Council and Parliament. In addition, at a time when the sector is struggling with a variety of problems, it triggered a broad echo in the media and the relevant professional groups. 
The Court is working to further analyse the impact of its activities. 
In 2009, it started developing a systematic follow-up procedure for its special reports to identify and document the progress made by the audited bodies in addressing the weaknesses identified and the implementation of the recommendations made. 
This procedure will provide additional feedback to the Court, as well as Parliament and other interested parties, on the impact of its activities. 
31 OPINION OF THE HOFES OPINION NO 1/2010 - CONSOLIDATION OF THE FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT OF THE EUROPEAN UNION: In February 2010, for the first time, the Court delivered an opinion on measures to reduce the level of irregular payments at the level of the EU budget and to improve the quality of expenditure (saving, cost-effectiveness and effectiveness). 
We concluded that, in order to increase recent progress in reducing the level of irregular payments, legislation in the high-risk areas needs to be simplified and more cost-effective control systems should be put in place. 
Such reforms should take place in the context of the ongoing broader review of EU spending regimes. 
In the Court's view, improving the quality of expenditure is of high importance, which can be achieved by applying the concept of European added value in setting spending priorities and by addressing the specific problems identified by the Court in the selection, design and implementation of expenditure programmes and grant schemes. 
Although the level of irregular payments from the EU budget as a whole has decreased, it remains high in the areas of cohesion and external assistance, development and enlargement, as well as the Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development and rural development expenditure. 
Most irregularities are based on the notification of ineligible expenditure by beneficiaries, the notification of excessive eligible expenditure and non-compliance with payment conditions, for example in the area of public procurement rules. 
They are primarily due to the complexity of the rules and payment terms and to deficiencies in the risk management systems at the level of final beneficiaries. 
The Commission should address the specific system deficiencies identified by the Court in the high-risk areas and improve its oversight. 
However, with more and more controls and correspondingly decreasing error rates, the point at which control costs are no longer proportionate to the benefits achieved has been reached at some point. 
Simplification should therefore remain a priority objective. 
Clearly interpreted and easy to apply rules and legislation can reduce not only the risk of error, but also the costs of control. 31 
32 CONCEPTION OF expenditure programmes In addition to simplification, the Commission should ensure that clear objectives are set when revising existing measures and designing new measures. 
More sense of reality as well as increased transparency and accountability are often required. 
To this end, the Commission could further strengthen the existing procedures for the development of future strategies, in particular ex ante evaluation and impact assessment. 
We propose to clarify the concept of European added value in an appropriate political declaration or in EU legislation in order to provide guidance to EU political authorities in defining expenditure priorities. 
The Court considers that the Commission should finalise the review of the budget as soon as possible and take into account the corresponding results in the preparation of the financial framework starting in 2014. 
Improving the quality of expenditure should be of high importance to the institutions of the European Union and should therefore be the main objective of the new Commission. 
33 HOFES FOR 201010 The Court presents its future audit work every year in a work programme submitted to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and available to the public on the Court's website. 
The work programme provides interested parties with information on new and ongoing audits as well as on planned reports. 
We developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 based on two priority objectives: Maximise the overall impact of the audits and improve efficiency by making the best use of resources. 
These objectives will significantly shape the Court's 2010 work programme and its continuous improvement efforts. 
The Court aims to maximise the overall impact of its audits over the relevant period by selecting and designing audits that focus on topics from risk areas and which are of greatest interest to the Court's audience; • continue to present sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement and follow up on whether these proposals are being implemented; • carry out a wider range of audits and present new types of audit products that complement the current annual and special reports; • create a larger number of special reports and improve their timeliness and ease of use; • further strengthen its relations with its main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public. During the relevant period, the Court aims to improve efficiency by making the best use of its resources. 
This includes • a better line; • an effective and dynamic human resources policy; • rationalisation of audit tasks; • the improvement of IT tools; • the development of expertise; • the development of relations with the audited bodies.

On 1 July 2009, the foundation stone for a new building, the second enlargement of the European Court of Auditors, was laid in Luxembourg. 
Vítor Caldeira, President of the European Court of Auditors, Claude Wiseler, Luxembourg's Minister for Buildings, Patrick Gillen, President of the Fund d'urbanisation et d'aménagement du Kirchberg, and Eduardo Ruiz García, General Secretary of the Court, signalled the start of the construction work with the symbolic first groundbreaking ceremony. 
This extension of the European Court of Auditors' building complex, already consisting of two buildings, will allow staff recruited in the course of successive Union enlargements to be accommodated. 
In 2009-2012, the Court will endeavour to broaden its range of audit-related reporting types. 
To this end, it will coordinate with its main external addressees to ensure that they gain a clear understanding of their different needs and how best to meet their expectations in fulfilling their mandate under the Treaty. 
A significant proportion of the resources available to the Court is used to audit the accounts with a view to drawing up a statement of assurance (the so-called "DAS"). 
This requires, for each financial year, the examination and audit of the accounts and transactions under the general budget of the EU. 
Separate declarations of assurance are drawn up on the European Development Funds and each of the 40 European agencies and bodies. 
The audit work shall cover from June of year n to June of year n+ 1 in order to publish the annual reports in November of year n+ 1 in accordance with the Financial Regulation. 
The Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2009 will therefore be drawn up and published in 2010, and at the same time the Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2010 will start11. 
The aim of the Court's work is to provide clear conclusions on the state of play of accounting and financial management in the various areas of the general budget and to make appropriate and cost-effective recommendations where improvements are possible. 
The Court's annual report on the general budget for 2009 will continue to be in line with the structure introduced in 2007 and taking into account the reorganisation of the budget12. 
The findings are presented under chapters relating to related groups of policy areas (thematic groups). This structure is largely - but not entirely - in line with the headings of the new financial framework. 
It will also be a particular concern for the Court to present its findings and conclusions even more clearly and coherently in order to make them more comprehensible and legible and to simplify the comparison within and between them and between financial years.

In 2008, the Court decided to introduce a system of key performance indicators (ZLIs) for its audit-related and non-audit activities to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and objectives set out in the annual work programmes. 
ZLI serves to strengthen internal and external accountability and increase work efficiency and quality. WHY KEY PERFORMANCE INDICATORS? • To inform management of how successful the Court as an institution implements what it intended; • to support the decision-making process by focusing the institution's attention on efficiency issues and by promoting improvements; • to provide the addressee with information on relevant aspects related to the Court's performance. 
The ZLIs primarily concern the achievement of the Court's strategic objectives, as they cover audit quality, output, impact and economic management of the Court's resources. 
They provide information on the Court's performance as a "company" and are an integral part of the Court's management system.

40 40 PERSONAL AND support services The main asset of the Court is its staff. 
At 31. In December 2009, the Court's staff was 880 (officials and temporary staff but excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees). 
Of the staff, 525 (including 115 staff in Members' Cabinets) were involved in audit-related tasks; 163 were translators, 171 staff with administrative support and 21 in the office of the President. 
The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.

Recruitment The ECA's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and staff consists of both officials and temporary staff. 
Open competitions for ECA posts are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). 
In addition, the Court provides internships for a limited number of graduates for periods of three to five months. 
In 2009, the Court hired 112 employees: 69 officials, 14 temporary staff and 29 contract staff. 
Recruitment depends on whether reserve lists of EPSO competitions are available and sufficient. 
The Court managed to recruit an adequate number of new staff in 2009. 
The 73 at the 31st By 26 January 2010, unsubstantiated posts could be reduced by 33 % to 49 in December 2009. The number of vacancies will continue to decline sharply in the coming months, as further staff members will take up their duties as part of the recent wave of recruitment. 
At 31. In December 2008, 68 posts were not filled. 
The reserve list for recruitment based on EPSO competition AD/126/08 was published in August and the first successful candidates joined the Court in early November, i.e. only three months later. 
The profession of examiner requires continuous training. 
In addition, due to the specific circumstances of the Court's audit environment, auditors need good foreign language skills. 
In 2009, the Court's staff completed an average of nine days of professional training. 
Language courses accounted for 64 % of the total number of training days in 2009 (compared to 48 % in 2008). 
Without taking into account the language courses, the examiners completed four days of professional training in 2009 (see ZLI 10 on page 38). 
This figure is expected to increase in 2010 as new staff will have to undergo a mandatory training programme. 
On the basis of the long-term strategic objective "Development and growth" and the guidance plan for training for the years 2008-2011 and the training paths adopted in 2009, the Professional Training Unit has made improvements in the content of training activities and developed new training courses in line with the priorities decided by the Court. 
In addition, cooperation with the other institutions and with inter-institutional bodies such as the European Administrative School has been successfully continued. 
Box 5 provides a portrait of the staff of an audit unit within the Court to give the reader a picture of the work carried out and the persons involved. 43 
44 KASTEN 5 - THE PRESS FOR THEMA "JUSTIZ AND INNERS IN THESE BALKAN" PROVIDED TEAM The Western Balkans have been marked by violence in the past. 
The European Union's interest in this region is to promote security and long-term stability. 
The rule of law, border security and the fight against corruption are prerequisites for joining the EU and pose a major challenge in the Western Balkans. 
The European Commission is the main donor of funding in the region. 
The Court's 2009 report on the effectiveness of the Commission's Justice and Home Affairs projects for the Western Balkans (Special Report No 12/2009) provided an insight into the situation in this particularly important area. 
The audit concerned both investment projects and institution building projects in the four areas of asylum, integrated border management, the judiciary and the police. 
33 completed projects were examined on the spot, including an asylum centre, a prison in Albania and a court responsible for human rights and war crimes in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 
In addition, several EU-funded border crossing points in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia were visited to assess whether EU action led to improvements. 
The team responsible for carrying out the audit worked closely with the rapporteur member, Maarten B. Engwirda. 
The Heads of Unit responsible for monitoring the audit were Raija Peltonen and Ossi Louko; the team leader was Jussi Bright. 
The auditors involved were Enrico Grassi and Miroslav Matej, with Horst Fischer and Jan Pieter Lingen from the cabinet of Maarten B. Engwirda also playing an important role.

Translation Translation is an important activity of audit support that enables the Court to fulfil its mission and achieve its communication objectives. 
In 2009, the total translation volume increased by 5.2 % compared to 2008. 
The proportion of translation services provided on time was over 95 %. 
The linguistic support of auditors in connection with audit visits and the drafting of reports has been increased. 
In addition, the Directorate for Translation supported INTOSAI working groups and covered other specific needs related to the Court's audit work. 
In January 2010, a new computer application (Artemis) was introduced to manage translation work more efficiently. 
Information technology provides the auditors with essential tools and services. 
The most important developments were recorded in 2009: • Simplifying processes and continuing the transition to a paperless office by applying automated authorisations (visibility notes) and electronic forms, introducing electronic signatures and launching work on the establishment of an archive database; • Improving the security of the Court's IT infrastructure by establishing a data recovery centre and releasing a further developed version of the Lotus Emergency Platform, the basic framework for the Court's news and audit documentation/archiving systems; • Adoption of a long-term IT plan for the period 2010-2012 to align the information technology sector with the Court's main audit strategic objectives and to continue efforts to provide high-quality services. 45 
The Directorate for Finance and Support Services is responsible for administrative services and infrastructure. 
These include internal controls and accounting, as well as administrative and logistical services. 
In 2009, the Directorate focused on reorganising its services in order to improve efficiency and effectiveness and to release staff for redeployment in favour of audit services. 
This reorganisation resulted in a reduction in the number of units belonging to the Directorate (from five to three) and the implementation of several posts in audit services. 
An important activity of the Directorate concerned the construction of a new farm building (the "K3 building"). 
In 2009, a project manager was appointed after a call for tenders. 
Construction work is expected to begin in March 2010 and is expected to be completed in 2013. 
The time and cost of the project will continue to be respected. 
Audit visits During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States and other beneficiary countries from EU funds in order to obtain adequate audit evidence. 
Visits usually apply to central and local authorities involved in the authorisation, management and disbursement of EU funds, as well as the respective final recipients. 
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors and the duration of an audit trip may be up to two weeks depending on the type of examination and distance. 
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the visited Member State, which provide useful logistical and practical support. 
The graph below gives an overview of the number of audit visits carried out by the Court in 2009 in the EU Member States (300). 
In addition, 36 audit missions outside the Union took place in 2009.

50 SERVICES "INTERNE REVISION" The Court's Internal Audit Service is designed to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives through a systematic, methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures. 
In addition, the Internal Audit Service makes proposals to increase the efficiency of the Court. 
This requires a permanent assessment of the internal control systems within the Court in order to assess their effectiveness. 
In 2009, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused its work on auditing the accounts (audit of accounts), a review of ex ante control, payroll and custody accounts audits, follow-up of contracts and public procurement procedures and an analysis of the promotion procedure. 
Most of the audit recommendations issued by the Internal Auditor in 2009 were accepted by the audited bodies and included in corrective action plans. 
The Court's Internal Audit Committee monitors the work of the Internal Auditor and ensures his independence. 
It also examines and approves the work programme and the reports of the Internal Auditor and, where necessary, instructs them to carry out specific audit tasks. 
In 2009, the Internal Audit Service was audited and certified by an independent auditor, Deloitte S.A.. 
The report of the independent auditor on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2008 was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 23 October 2009.

European Court of Auditors YEARABLE TODAY REPORT 2010 
The Court of Auditors is committed to the following values: The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing EU finances under the Treaty. 
As an EU external auditor, it contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens by promoting accountability and transparency. 
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work, providing valuable support to its audience in order to improve EU financial management. 
Independence, INTEGRITITY AND UNPARTICILITY PROFESSIONALITY PROFESSIONALITY EXCELLENT AND EFFIZIENZ Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and staff drawing up relevant, timely, high quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, take into account the concerns of its audience and include important and directional statements recognising the value of the individual, supporting the development of specific skills and rewarding performance by promoting team spirit through effective communication of its audience with appropriate audit results, with respect to all forms of efficiency and external impact on all aspects of the EU's work-making and management. 
3 CONTENT page 4-5 7 9-25 22 23-25 26-45 26-27 28-33 34-39 40-42 43-45 BORWORD OF THE PRESIDENT 2010 ON A CLICK OUR TACTIVITIES Audit reports and opinions Cooperation with other ORKB OUR MANAGEMENT Implementation of the 2009-2012 Strategy Measurement data on the Court's performance in 2010 Audit support Financial information Audit and accountability 
4 OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the fourth edition of the Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors. This year, we took the opportunity to reclassify the content, namely the two main sections "Our activities" and "Our management", and present an overview of all performance indicators for the first time. 
In 2010, the Court of Auditors offered two important opportunities to participate in the debate on the reform of EU financial management. 
At the beginning of the year, the Court presented an opinion to the new Commission on the main risks and challenges of improving EU financial management and, towards the end of the year, an opinion on the Commission's proposals to amend the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the EU. 
With a view to 2011, the Court will continue to implement its values unchanged and further expand the performance and earnings achieved. 
We will once again present high-quality, independent and objective reports and opinions that help improve EU financial management and promote accountability and transparency. In particular, the Court will continue to closely monitor developments in the area of EU economic governance and address the new legislative proposals affecting EU financial management after 2013. 
We plan to publish 45 annual reports, i.e. the annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and on the European Development Funds, as well as the specific annual reports on the agencies, institutions and other bodies. 
Special reports provide an important opportunity to achieve added value, as they focus on areas at increased risk and on topics of particular relevance for the target groups. In particular, the Court intends to report on the quality of EU expenditure in a wide range of areas ranging from financial instruments and the SME Guarantee Facility to EU-funded projects in the field of eGovernment and the Single Payment Scheme in agriculture. 
In further implementing its 2009-2012 strategy, the Court hopes to fully exploit the merits of its recent reforms, including the streamlined decision-making procedures. The Court will continue its efforts to recruit suitable staff, limit the vacancies to a minimum and promote the professional development of its staff. 
Without the commitment and professionalism of all our employees, we would not have achieved what we achieved in 2010.

9 OUR REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are as follows: annual reports - with the results of its accounts and compliance audits on specific financial years (including the specific annual reports published separately on the Agencies, Institutions and other bodies of the European Union); O Special Reports - which can be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits, mainly performance audits to assess the economy, efficiency and effectiveness in selected EU revenue and expenditure areas; O Opinions on draft legal acts with financial implications.

The key statements of the annual report were as follows: • The annual accounts of the European Union present fairly the financial situation and the results of operations and cash flows in all material respects as a whole. • Except for two expenditure areas ("economic and financial" and "administrative and other expenditure"), payments from the budget remain materially affected by errors. • According to the Court's estimates, the most likely error rate for cohesion expenditure was significantly lower than in previous years, and for the budget as a whole, the error rate estimated by the Court has decreased in recent years. • The Commission has improved its information on recovery of amounts unduly paid and other corrections. 
However, this information is not yet fully reliable. The Commission's information on corrective actions does not allow a meaningful comparison with the error rate estimated by the Court. In the report, we set out recommendations on how financial management could be improved by strengthening management systems and simplifying rules and regulations.

12 Special Reports adopted in 2010 When selecting and designing its tasks for cost-effectiveness and compliance audits, the Court is always committed to achieving the greatest possible impact, taking into account the best possible use of the resources allocated to these tasks. 
In the selection of topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: • the risks to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the relevant revenue or expenditure area; • the amount of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the time elapsed since any previous examination; • upcoming developments within the relevant legal or operational framework; • political and public interest. 
In order to obtain the required audit evidence, the selected profitability and compliance audits must be carefully planned and carried out. In addition, before the report is published, the Court gives the audited bodies the opportunity to comment on its findings and to formulate responses. 
As a result, these tests usually take more than one year.
