In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of the support measures "design studies" and "development of new infrastructures" in the Sixth Research Framework Programme (Special Report No 2/2010) - "Design studies" are intended to examine feasibility aspects in potential future research institutions and the "Development of new infrastructures" measure aims to support the development of new or the improvement of existing infrastructures. 
In the course of the audit, we examined whether the two measures effectively contributed to achieving the objectives of the Infrastructures strand of the Sixth Framework Programme for Research 2002-2006. • Impact assessments in the EU institutions: Do you help with decision-making? 
(Special report No 3/2010) - Impact assessments are one of the cornerstones of better regulation policy to improve and simplify EU legislative proposals. The audit analysed whether the Commission's impact assessments effectively supported decision-making in the EU institutions. The comments of this report are also relevant for other budgetary areas. 
• Allow the design and management of the Leonardo da Vinci mobility measures to deliver effective results? 
(Special report No 4/2010) - The mobility projects of the Leonardo da Vinci programme enable organisations active in the field of vocational education and training to arrange study visits to another European country. The actions are part of the integrated lifelong learning programme. The audit examined whether the measures are expected to meet their objectives, based on an assessment of design and management by the Commission and the national agencies. • Improving transport performance on the trans-European rail axes: Were EU investments in rail infrastructure effective? 
(Special report No 8/2010) (see box "Close to a performance audit"). • Will EU spending on structural measures in the area of household water supply be used optimally? 
(Special report No 9/2010) - The Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund allocated more than EUR 4 billion in the 2000-2006 programming period to support projects in the area of water supply infrastructure for households. We examined whether these funds were used effectively to address a number of needs such as increasing water availability, extending geographical coverage, improving the efficiency of water supply systems and improving the quality of services. 15 
16 CLOSE-UP OF AN PERFORMANCE AUDIT IMPROVEMENT OF TRANSPORT PERFORMANCE ON THE TRANS-EUROPEAN RAILWAY AXES: WERE THE EU INVESTMENTS IN RAILWAY INFRASTRUCTURE EFFECTIVE? Special Report No 8/2010 The focus of the audit was on EU co-financing of railway infrastructure, examining whether an effective contribution was made to improving the performance of the trans-European axes. 
In view of the upcoming revision of the TEN-T guidelines for 2011, the Court's report was presented at a particularly favourable time. The Court recommended that the Commission • cooperate with the Member States and the iron railway authorities to identify the significant needs of trans-European corridors and, where necessary, develop knowledge and improve analytical bases; • to place greater emphasis on reducing practical constraints in international rail transport; • to promote and facilitate cooperation between Member States' bodies responsible for the railway sector so that developments can be planned together and common solutions to practical problems can be achieved. 
17 "The exam presented the team with some challenges," reports Gareth Roberts, the head of the auditor team. "We had to get acquainted very quickly with the realities of European rail transport and saw some successful examples of fantastic modern railways, but also some sections of the network that seemed to come from another age. 
We wanted to explore the extent to which the European rail system gradually evolved from a patchwork to a network. 
Up to 10 auditors were involved in the on-site work, as we had to cover many different languages. "I really enjoyed working on this exam." 
Since then, I have become something of a railroad fan!" says Andrej Minarovic, the examiner responsible for the work in Germany and Austria. 
At the end of the test, Fernando Pascual Gil was nicknamed "Maul Throw" within the team because he had spent some time in railway tunnels in the Alps and the Pyrenees. The audit team visited eight Member States and examined the impact on trans-European rail transport of 21 railway projects co-financed by the European Union under the trans-European transport networks and cohesion policy. 
For this purpose, the team members drove over and through the Alps with freight trains and visited large tunnel construction sites. 
These visits were a valuable addition to the findings that the auditors had gained from the review of reports, surveys of railway workers and the usual financial analyses. 
18 Conservation and management of natural resources With a budget of EUR 413 billion for the period 2007-2013, the EU has extensive powers and high political responsibility in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. Three-quarters of the funds are spent on agricultural markets and direct payments to farmers. These payments are financed by the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the "first pillar" of the common agricultural policy (CAP). 
More than one fifth of the expenditure comes from support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second 'pillar' of the CAP. 
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States. 
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Implementation of the Leader approach to rural development (Special Report No 5/2010) - Leader is a bottom-up approach based on local partnerships to support rural development. The audit examined whether the Leader concept was implemented in such a way as to generate additional benefits compared to the traditional top-down approach while minimising the risks to sound financial management. • Has the sugar market reform achieved its most important goals? 
(Special report No 6/2010) - In 2006, the EU carried out a profound reform of its sugar sector with the aim of ensuring the competitiveness of the EU sugar industry, stabilising markets and ensuring supplies and ensuring an adequate standard of living for the agricultural population. 
This resulted in the transition to greater regional participation and more flexible decision-making. The audit examined the effectiveness of the special measures following the reform. The EU as a global partner In addition to enlargement, the EU has three main objectives in the field of external relations: Fostering stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood ("The EU and its Neighbourhood Policy"); active support for sustainable development at international level ("The EU as a partner for sustainable development"); Promoting global policy "governance" and ensuring strategic and civil security ("the EU as a global player"). 
Expenditure is mainly managed directly by the Commission through its Headquarters or Delegations. 
Some support measures are also managed jointly with international organisations. • Commission management of the system of veterinary checks on meat imports following the 2004 reform of the hygiene rules (Special Report No 14/2010) - Veterinary controls on imports are an essential part of the EU's food safety policy and contribute to mitigating the risk of diseases and health crises potentially causing high costs to the detriment of the EU budget. The audit examined how the Commission monitors the EU system of veterinary checks at border inspection posts introduced in 2006 as part of the reform of the legislation on food hygiene. 
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Commission management of general budget support in ACP countries and Latin American and Asian countries (Special Report No 11/2010) - General budget support is generally considered by many donors, including the European Commission, as the most effective way to provide development assistance. 
The audit examined whether the Commission effectively managed its budget support programmes in Africa, the Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) and Latin America and Asia. 19 
20 • EU Development Assistance for Basic Education in Sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia (Special Report No 12/2010) - The Education for All initiative and the Millennium Development Goals have committed the EU and the international donor community to ensure primary education for all children, to eliminate gender inequalities and to improve education quality. The audit examined whether EU development assistance contributed to these objectives in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia and whether the Commission managed its interventions satisfactorily. 
Revenue The budget of the European Union is mainly financed from own resources and other revenue. Traditional own resources - mainly customs duties - account for around 12 % and VAT own resources represent a further 12 % of the total revenue. Most of the EU own resources (70 %) come from the own resources derived from gross national income, which, as a residual income, ensure that the budget is always balanced. • Has the new European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument been successfully launched and achieved in the Southern Caucasus (Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia)? 
(Special Report No 13/2010) - The European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument (ENPI) provides a framework for the planning and management of assistance to partner countries and territories. 
Since 2007, more than 311 million euros have been allocated to three countries in the Southern Caucasus. The audit examined whether the ENPI was successfully launched there and whether it achieved results. 
In 2010, the Court adopted a Special Report on Simplified Customs Procedures (No 1/2010) - In simplified customs procedures, authorised economic operators benefit from accelerated customs clearance and a simplified system for paying customs duties, which are part of the EU revenue. 
The audit assessed the effectiveness of the legal framework and the control approach of the Commission and the Member States. Opinions issued in 2010 also contribute to improving EU financial management through its opinions on proposals for new or amended legal acts with financial implications. 
Opinion No 6/2010 concerns an important proposal from the Commission for a revision of the Financial Regulation, which regulates how the EU budget is collected, issued and booked. 
Based on our comments in Opinion No 1/2010 (see above), the Court also points out that improving the quality of EU spending in certain areas of expenditure of the EU budget requires simpler and better legislation and other measures to support, promote and demand economic action by managers at the Commission, the other institutions and in the Member States. 
The ongoing contacts are maintained by liaison officers appointed by each SAI. 
The pilot project will be completed in 2011. 24 SAI Network of Candidate Countries and Potential Candidate Countries The Court actively participated in meetings of the Network of SAIs of Candidate Countries and Potential Candidate Countries (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Iceland, Montenegro, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia)4 which took place in parallel with the meetings of the Contact Committee.

Other forms of cooperation The Court continued its active participation and involvement in the improvement of international audit principles and procedures through its membership in European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, including INTOSAI5 and its European regional group EUROSAI. 
A secondment of the Court took place on XX. INCOSAI Congress held in South Africa from 22 to 27 November 2010. 
Since 2004, when the Court became a full member of INTOSAI, he actively participates in the subcommittees on the different types of audits. In addition, the Court contributed to the subcommittee "Promotion of Best Practices and Quality Assurance through Voluntary Peer Reviews" and supported the increased activities in the field of the development of expertise of INTOSAI members. 
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on Accountability and Disaster Assistance Audit. 
An important objective of these working groups is to develop guidelines in the area of accountability for disaster relief, to identify and disseminate best practices, focusing on activities aimed at stakeholders (multilateral bodies, aid organisations, governments, private auditors). The interim report of the Working Group was submitted to the INTOSAI Congress in November 2010. 
In 2010, the Court also participated in the INTOSAI Task Force "Global Financial Crisis". As part of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and the IT Working Group and participates in the EUROSAI Training Committee. 
The Court also participated in the VII. EUROSAI Congress working group set up in 2008 to develop a guide on best practices for achieving quality within an SAI. In addition, the Court is one of the auditors of EUROSAI. 25 
26 OUR MANAGEMENT OF THE STRATEGY FOR 20092012 In recent years, following a self-assessment and a peer review process (2008), the Court has initiated an internal reform process on the framework conditions of its audit management. 
A strategy for the period 2009-20126 was then developed to address the weaknesses identified. The overarching objectives for the period are: maximising the overall impact of the tests; O Improve efficiency by making the best use of resources. 
Many of the priority actions foreseen in the strategy have already been completed. The other measures will be implemented in 2011 and 2012. The most important achievements achieved in 2010 are: O the achievement of the objective of providing 12 to 15 performance audit reports per year; O the development of new products - a document on risks and challenges for the new Commission (opinion No 1/2010) and the establishment of a new system for reporting on the follow-up of the Court's recommendations from 2012 onwards; O the revision of the Court's Rules of Procedure to streamline decision-making procedures through the establishment of chambers and to strengthen the governance structure; O the preparation of an overview of all performance indicators; O the further development of the approach to the annual audit of the implementation of the EU budget (declaration of reliability) based on recommendations from an internal panel of experts assisted by external experts; O the redeployment of a number of posts from support services in favour of audit services. 
6 The audit strategy 2009-2012 is available on the Court's website. 
27 INTRODUCTION OF CHAIRS ON THE NEW CHRISTMAS REGULATION One of the main recommendations stemming from the Court's reform process was to make use of the possibility provided for in Article 287(4) of the Treaty to adopt certain categories of reports and opinions of chambers while maintaining the principle of collegiality. 
After approval by the Council of the necessary amendments to the Court's Rules of Procedure, chambers were set up on 1 June 2010. These are composed of members of the Court and adopt special reports, special annual reports and opinions on draft legal acts. Previously, all these reports and opinions were adopted by the whole College, and this remains the case in the annual reports on the EU budget and on the EDFs. 
Although most of the Court's reports are now accepted by the Chambers, the Chambers have the possibility to transfer their documents to the Court for adoption. 
All members may attend meetings of chambers to which they are not members without voting rights. 
The Members of the Court 
Since 2008, the Court has gradually developed a set of key performance indicators (ZLIs) to inform management of the progress made in the implementation of the 2009-2012 targets; O to support the decision-making process; O to provide performance-related information to the Court's addressees. 
As an overview of all indicators is available for the first time in 2010, this year will serve as the reference year for future progress. The Court is very pleased with the results achieved in 2010 in its key performance indicators, in particular on the quality and impact of its work. 
More importantly, however, is the fact that the indicators clearly identify the areas in which progress is needed and which problems need to be clarified in order to achieve a future increase in performance. 
29 Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of assessments by the addressees, expert reviews and follow-up of its recommendations. 
By means of a survey, the Court asked the main addressees of our reports (European Parliament and Committee on Budgets' Committee on Budgets) and the main audited bodies (mainly staff of the European Commission) to assess the quality and impact of the annual reports published in 2009 (on the general budget and on the EDF) and special reports. 
The assessment should be based on a five-stage scale (1 - very poor, 2 - poor, 3 - appropriate, 4 - good, 5 - very good). 
2010 Target Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's reports by a main addressee 4.2 = 4 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit work by the audited body The result shows that the main addressees of the Court's reports are on average for 'good'. 
The Court strives to maintain or improve this level of performance. 
Two external bodies have reviewed the content and presentation of a sample of the Court's reports published in 2009 and 2010. The auditors assessed eight special reports and the annual report on the general budget and the EDF for both years and assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale from "significantly impaired" (1) to "quality" (4). 
2010 Target 3.0 = 3 3.7 = 4 reviews of the content and presentation of the Court's reports by external experts The result shows that the auditors consider the quality of the Court's reports to be "satisfactory". 
The reviews have provided valuable insights and the resulting recommendations will be used to improve the quality of future reports. 
30 Follow-up of recommendations The Court uses its audit experience primarily in the form of recommendations to help improve financial management. In order to make changes, the Court's recommendations must first be accepted by the audited bodies and subsequently implemented. The indicator is based on the recommendations in the 2009 published, i.e. the last available, annual and special reports. 
2010 Target 90 % = 90 % percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the audit body, the Court strives to maintain or even improve this high level of acceptance in its recommendations. 
In 2010, the Court set up a system to monitor the implementation of the recommendations by the audited bodies. 
In the coming years, this system will serve as a basis for a further indicator of the extent to which recommendations are implemented in practice and lead to improvements. 
It will also provide the Court with valuable insights to improve the quality of its recommendations and thus increase their acceptance by the audited bodies. 
The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources on the basis of the extent to which it is able to provide reports and audit findings on time, to fulfil its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its staff. Punctuality of the reports The Court strives to adopt all planned reports within the specified deadlines. 
For the publication of the annual reports and the specific annual reports, deadlines laid down in legislation must be observed. 
For special reports for which there is no publication date set out in legislation, the planned date of adoption shall be deemed to be the date of adoption. 
2010 Target number of reports accepted compared to the number of planned reports 90 % 100 % share of reports adopted on time 80 % 100 % All in particular, the Court failed to meet the target in 2010. 
The Court adopted fewer reports in 2010 than planned; the performance level is comparable to the previous year (91 % in 2009). Moreover, while the share of reports adopted on time increased in 2010 (80 % from 67 % in 2009), there is still a need for further improvement. 
While all annual reports and all special annual reports were adopted and published on schedule, this was only the case for three special reports. 
In the case of six special reports, the adoption was delayed until 2011. 
The Court strives to achieve the targets by launching further measures to improve the governance of the procedures of special reports by the end of 2012.

The Court will continue its efforts to achieve the target. 34 Audit support The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by its specialised services. These services shall provide the logistical, technical and/or technical know-how which enables the Court to recruit, retain and motivate its staff and to develop its professional skills; O to disseminate the results of the examination in all official languages of the EU; O to make the best use of information technologies; O to manage its budget and maintain its infrastructure; O Examination missions to all countries where EU funds are spent. 
The most important asset of the farm is its staff. At 31. In December 2010, the Court's staff was 889 (officials and temporary staff but excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees). 
Of these, 557 are in examination chambers (including 123 staff in Members' cabinets), 151 in the Translation Directorate, 157 in administrative support services and 24 in the services of the President. With a view to achieving the best possible use of resources, all activities once again explored and implemented ways of improving efficiency by simplifying procedures and streamlining services. 
Where possible, efficiencies outside the audit area were transferred to the audit service, increasing the number of posts used for audit tasks by 6 %. This process will continue in 2011.

37 Professional training The profession of examiner requires continuous training in order to be able to keep up with new developments and acquire new skills.

Audit AND Accountability Internal Audit The Court's Internal Audit Service is designed to assist the Court in achieving its objectives through a systematic, methodological assessment of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures. In addition, on the basis of assessments of the effectiveness of the Court's internal control systems, the Internal Audit Service makes proposals to improve the Court's efficiency. 
In 2010, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused its work on following up its recommendations from previous years, reviewing the reform of the Court's ex ante audits system, auditing the implementation of the Court's SOS II/SAP system and the conformity of the video surveillance system with data protection rules and requirements.

European Court of Auditors' Annual Action Report 2011 
The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing EU finances under the Treaty. 
As an EU external auditor, he contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens. 
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work, providing valuable support to its audience in order to improve EU financial management. 
Independence, INTEGRITITY AND UNPARTMENT PROFESSIONALITY PROFESSIONALITY EXCELLENT AND EFFICIENCE Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and staff. 
Impartial audit, which takes into account the positions of the entities concerned, but rejects any form of influence by instructions or pressure from the outside. 
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work. 
Contribute to the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level. 
Producing relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the concerns of its audience and containing important and forward-looking statements. 
To contribute to an effective improvement of EU management and to contribute to strengthening accountability for the management of EU funds. 
Fostering team spirit through effective communication. 
Increase efficiency in all aspects of his work. 
3 INSTITUTIONS page 4 OF THE PRESIDENT 7 2011 ON A BLICK 9 OUR ACTIVITIES 9 Audit reports and opinions 23 Cooperation with other SAIs 28 Other activities 31 OUR MANAGEMENT 31 Implementation of the Strategy for 2009-2012 33 Measurement data on the Court's performance in 2011 37 Support to audit activities 43 Financial information 46 Audit and accountability 
4 OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the 2011 Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors. 
In 2011, the economic and financial crisis led to significant developments in the EU's economic governance, with a significant impact on the future use of public finances. 
Against this background, in May, the Court published a position paper highlighting the impact of the measures taken to address the financial and economic crisis on accountability, transparency and public financial control. 
Later in the year, the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States and the European Court of Auditors called on EU decision-makers to ensure that the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control are properly respected whenever public funds are used. 
In particular, the SAIs of the euro area called for adequate arrangements for public external financial control of the European Sta-bility Mechanism. 
This resulted in a decision setting up an audit committee for the Stability Mechanism, which will include a member proposed by the Court. 
Also in 2011, the results of our key performance indicators are encouraging, in particular with regard to the follow-up of the recommendations accepted by our audited bodies and the assessment of our audit work by addressees and external experts. 
We were able to increase our output in terms of the number of audit reports and opinions adopted in 2011; nevertheless, we failed to achieve the ambitious goals we set ourselves on the punctuality of reporting. 
Our annual reports now contained more detailed information and a new chapter on performance aspects. We also produced 42 special annual reports and 16 special reports in addition to seven opinions and a position paper. 
The scope of our institution's audit powers with regard to the Union's revenue and expenditure, in particular as regards VAT own resources in the Member States, was confirmed by the European Court of Justice in November 2011. 
As of 2012, we will be able to report on the extent to which our recommendations will be followed in practice. 
In addition, we will subject our methods of performance audit to a peer-review process with the aim of further improving the process of producing our special reports. 
In 2011, we published ethical guidelines to further strengthen the Court's audit management framework and revised the Court's audit strategies and audit guidelines to streamline the audit process and reporting process. 
In addition, we will launch a new survey on employee satisfaction in 2012. 
Looking ahead, we will complete the preparation of our strategy for the period 2013-2017 in 2012. 
Some of the most important challenges have already been identified: The EU's regulatory framework will continue to evolve and we must continue to push for proper compliance with the principles of accountability, transparency and public financial control. 
The need for high quality and timely assurance of the use of EU funding is constantly increasing and we need to develop our audits and reports accordingly. 
As the EU is subject to a continuous process of change, we will also endeavour to make the best use of our audit experience to help policy makers improve financial management. 
Strengthening the EU's financial accountability is an objective we share with other actors and we will try to pool our efforts by entering into strategic partnerships. 
Finally, like the other EU institutions and bodies, we need to be prepared to do more with less to improve the efficiency of our organisation. 
Addressing these challenges will depend to a decisive extent on the efforts of all our staff. 
The development of the excellence of our employees - a core value of our organ - is and remains an important concern for us. 
With regard to the professionalism, commitment and the results achieved by our employees in the past, I am confident that the Court will be able to achieve these future goals as well. 
Vítor Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President 5

Number of reports and opinions 2007 2008 2009 2010 2011 Annual reports (EU general budget and EDF) 2 2 2 Special Annual Reports on EU Agencies and Decentralised Bodies 29 29 37 40 42 Special Reports 9 12 18 14 16 Opinions and other statements 9 5 1 6 8 The full version of the individual reports and opinions is available on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu in 22 official EU languages. 
This led to the publication of the 2010 Annual Report, including the Seventeenth Statement of Assurance (DAS), on 10 November 2011. 
The 2010 annual report had some changes in order to improve clarity and information content. 
This includes the redesign of the topics (and the corresponding annual chapters) among which the Court grouped expenditure, the publication of estimated error rates by policy area (see below), increased attention to recommendations to improve financial management and a new chapter on performance aspects. 
For the first time, we published estimated error rates for both the EU budget as a whole and for individual thematic groups. 
The error rates are determined by extrapolating the quantifiable errors detected in the audited samples of transactions. 
The Court compares the estimated error rate with a materiality threshold of 2 % to determine whether the error is material, taking into account further evidence. 
Error rates are not a measure of fraud, but reflect the Court's estimate of the breach of the rules governing expenditure. 
This includes breaches of public procurement rules, ineligible or incorrectly calculated costs for projects co-financed by the EU, or excessive land data supplied by farmers. 
The key statements of the 2010 Annual Report were as follows: O The annual accounts for the financial year 2010 represent the financial position of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for the year as a whole. 
On the other hand, the payments underlying these accounts are materially affected by errors; the estimated level of error for the EU budget as a whole is 3.7 %. 
The control systems were partially effective with a view to ensuring the regularity of payments as a whole. O The Court's estimated error rate for cohesion, energy and transport (the most error-prone expenditure area in the EU) was 7.7 % higher than in 2009. O In the rest of the EU expenditure areas, the error rate remained relatively stable. 
For agriculture and natural resources, the estimated error rate was 2.3 %, above the materiality threshold. 
However, direct payments to farmers had no material error. o The share of advances - pre-financing - within the EU budget has increased significantly. 
The accounting rules and supervisory arrangements have not been adapted accordingly. o When planning EU spending programmes, the Commission and the Member States should pay greater attention to setting SMART objectives, i.e. concrete, measurable, achievable, appropriate and dated targets, but also to identify and mitigate risks that may arise during implementation. 
In its Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDF) for the financial year 2010 (published on 10 November 2011), the Court concluded that the annual accounts of the EDFs for 2010 represent the financial position of the EDFs and the results of their operations and cash flows in all material respects in accordance with the Financial Regulation. 
The revenue of the EDFs is not affected by material errors. 
The EDF commitments were legal and regular, regardless of the non-quantifiable errors detected in the field of procurement. 
However, EDF payments for projects were materially affected by errors; the estimated error rate is 3.4 %. 
The errors found related to non-compliance with eligibility conditions. 
The Court assessed that the control systems established in the EDF only partially guarantee the regularity of payments as a whole. 
In December 2011, the Court published special annual reports on the financial year 2010 for all 42 agencies, decentralised bodies (e.g. joint undertakings) and other EU agencies (in particular the efficiency of the management of the European Central Bank). 
The Court delivered an unrestricted opinion on all audited bodies, with the exception of the European GNSS Agency because certain assets were not included in the accounts, and the ENIAC Joint Undertaking because the financial statements were not included in the accounts. 
The EU agencies and decentralised bodies have been set up by the EU legislator to carry out specific tasks. 
Each agency shall have a mandate, a management board, a director, staff and a budget. 
The agencies operate in many areas, such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and travel. 
11 President Caldeira at the presentation of the 2010 Annual Report at the plenary session of the European Parliament 
In addition to its annual reports, the Court publishes special reports during the year containing the results of the performance and compliance audits carried out by the Court on specific budgetary areas or management topics of its choice. 
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court is keen to achieve maximum impact and to make the best use of its resources. 
In the selection of topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: O the risks to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the relevant revenue or expenditure area; O the amount of the respective revenue or expenditure; O the time elapsed since any previous examination; pending developments within the relevant legal framework; O the political and public interest. 
In 2011, the Court adopted 16 special reports on a number of topics, an increase compared to the 14 special reports adopted in 2010. 
These special reports are presented in a concise form below under the corresponding headings of the financial framework - the multiannual budget of the EU. 
The special reports are available in 22 EU languages on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu in full length or available through the EU Bookshop. 
13 Sustainable growth focuses on growth and jobs and covers two topics: Competitiveness includes the promotion of research and technological development, the networking of Europe, education and training, the promotion of competitiveness in a fully integrated internal market, the social policy agenda and the dismantling of nuclear installations. 
EU spending on growth and jobs in the period 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 89.4 billion, i.e. 9.2 % of the total budget, of which almost two thirds are R & D. Cohesion for growth and jobs mainly concerns cohesion policy, which is implemented in the form of funds dedicated to specific areas of activity - European Social Fund, Cohesion Fund and European Regional Development Fund. 
The funds will be spent by the Commission and the Member States through shared management. 
The EU budget for cohesion for the period 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 348.4 billion (35.7 % of the total EU budget). 
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: O Effectiveness of the SME Guarantee Facility (Special Report No 4/2011) from the point of view of its design and planning, the management of the related operations and the achievement of objectives. 
The SME Guarantee Facility (SMEG Facility) is a financial instrument managed by the European Investment Fund on behalf of the European Commission. This Facility provides financial intermediaries with guarantees or counter-guarantees for loans granted by financial institutions to SMEs, thereby increasing the availability of debt financing. o Effectiveness of projects in the field of tourism co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (EFERE) (Special Report No 6/2011) from the perspective of expected results, sustainability, European added value and project design. 
The audit was based on a broad survey of projects in new Member States and 26 regions. 
During the period 2000-2006, EU funding of EUR 4.6 billion from the ERDF was allocated to in-kind investments in tourism projects. Projects are selected and managed by managing authorities in the Member States. 
Effectiveness of eGovernment projects supported by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) (Special Report No 9/2011) with a focus on the 2000-2006 programming period and the four Member States Spain, France, Italy and Poland. 
The audit assessed whether the co-financed projects were selected on the basis of the identified needs, whether they were implemented as planned and whether they were appropriate and sustainable. 
This funding of EUR 6.7 billion from the ERDF for the promotion of the information society was intended to develop new secure technologies, develop infrastructures and connect regions via broadband. o Effective management of State aid control by the Commission (Special Report No 15/2011). 
The audit examined whether the procedures and systems ensure that the Commission handles all relevant cases of aid, that cases are handled effectively and within the deadlines foreseen, and that it is possible for the Commission to monitor the impact of its State aid control. 
It is the Commission's task to ensure that State aid granted by Member States is compatible with the internal market of the European Union. 
Member States must first notify aid measures to the Commission and obtain the approval of the Commission before granting State aid. o Implementation of EU financial support for the decommissioning of nuclear power plants in Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia (Special Report No 16/2011) to assess whether the measures of the nuclear decommissioning programmes have been designed to meet the needs of the nuclear decommissioning programmes, whether they have been implemented as planned, and whether the accountability and management structures were designed in such a way as to ensure effective use of EU funds. 
Bulgaria, Lithuania and Slovakia committed to the early shutdown and subsequent decommissioning of eight non-renewable nuclear reactors as part of their EU accession negotiations. 
In view of the exceptional burden, the EU provided EUR 2.9 billion in grants for the three country programmes in 1999-2013. 
The EU has a high political responsibility in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. 
The planned budget for 2007-2013 amounts to 413,1 billion euro, i.e. 42.3 % of the total budget. 
Three quarters of the expenditure concerns direct payments to farmers and support to agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) - the "first pillar" of the common agricultural policy (CAP). 
More than one-fifth of the expenditure comes from EU support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second pillar of the CAP. 
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States. 
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: O Single payment scheme under the common agricultural policy (Special Report No 5/2011) - See box: How good are the design and management of the subsidised agri-environmental measures? (Special report No 7/2011). 
This report assesses whether agri-environmental policy is designed and accompanied in such a way as to generate tangible environmental benefits, whether farmers are adequately supported by appropriate guidance and correctly determined aid amounts, and whether specific environmental needs are taken into account in the management of agri-environmental policy. 
The objective of agri-environmental policy is to meet the growing societal demand for environmental services by encouraging farmers to introduce or maintain production practices that are compatible with the protection and improvement of the environment. 
This area is subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States. o Recovery of undue payments under the Common Agricultural Policy (Special Report No 8/2011) to assess the effectiveness of the systems for recovering identified claims established and operated by Member States. 
This audit examined whether Member States properly record and process claims, whether Member States' actions to recover identified undue payments have been successful, whether Member States act appropriately in the derecognition of irrecoverable receivables, and whether the monitoring and supervision of the Commission is effective. 
The European Union spends around EUR 55 billion annually on agriculture and rural development. Part of the funds will be wrongly paid due to irregular or incorrect applications. 15 
16 o Effectiveness of the School Milk and School Fruit Programmes (Special Report No 10/2011) to assess whether EU aid has a direct impact on beneficiaries' consumption and whether the programmes are capable of delivering the intended educational impact and impacting future eating habits. 
These EU programmes aim to encourage children to eat healthily through the consumption of dairy products and fruits and vegetables; another objective is to contribute to improving the market conditions for these products. 
The EU is currently providing an annual budget of EUR 180 million for these two programmes. o Enable the design and management of the geographical indication scheme to be effective? (Special report No 11/2011). 
This audit assessed the reliability of the control system, the attractiveness of the scheme for producers and its awareness among consumers. 
The objective of the EU Geographical Indications Scheme is to protect the names of products where there is a link between their characteristics and the geographical area from which they originate. 
The scheme offers economic opportunities for farmers and food producers and can have a positive impact on the rural economy in the EU regions. o Effectiveness of the EU's measures to adapt the fishing capacity of the fishing fleets to existing fishing opportunities (Special Report No 12/2011). 
The audit examined whether there was a clear framework for the reduction of fleet capacity and whether the specific measures were clearly defined and implemented. 
The audit took place at the Commission and in Denmark, Spain, France, Italy, Poland, Portugal and the United Kingdom. 
The objective of the EU Common Fisheries Policy is to promote sustainable fisheries by establishing a balance between fish stocks and the fishing fleet in order to avoid overfishing of stocks. 
For many years, the overcapacity of the fishing fleet has been a problem. It threatens both the sustainability of fish stocks and the long-term viability of the fisheries sector. 
The European Fisheries Fund will provide EUR 4.3 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period. 
17 OPINION OF ECONOMIC REPORT NO 5/2011 This performance audit concerned the sound financial management of payments under the single payment scheme currently being applied in 17 of the 27 EU Member States. 
Expenditure related to this scheme amounted to around EUR 28.8 billion in 2009. 
The introduction of the single payment scheme was a key element of the 2003 reform of the EU's common agricultural policy. 
The aim of this scheme was to encourage farmers to respond better to market demand and to provide them with income support. 
As part of the reform, the link between support and production was dissolved ("decoupling"). 
Instead, farmers must have eligible agricultural land and 'payment entitlements'. 
From 2006, the Court carried out a series of audits of the procedures established by the Commission and in the Member States to ensure the accuracy of payment entitlements and the accuracy of payments to farmers. 
These tests covered all 17 Member States applying the scheme. The results of these audits were included in the 2006 and 2007 annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget. 
Based on these results, the Court decided to carry out a performance audit focusing on: O beneficiaries of the scheme, access to single payments and the definition of eligible areas; O the contribution of the scheme to the objectives of income support for farmers and the preservation of agricultural land in good agricultural and environmental condition; O the specific consequences of the application of the different models for implementing the scheme. 
Audit visits took place in 2009 and 2010 with the Commission, France, Italy and the United Kingdom. 
The conclusion of the resulting Special Report No 5/2011 was that the single payment scheme contributed to the achievement of the two main objectives of the common agricultural policy: Farmers were encouraged to respond better to market demand and the income of the agricultural sector as a whole was supported. 
In general, however, several questionable characteristics have emerged in the implementation of the scheme, which concern the definition of the beneficiaries of that policy, the nature of the eligible parcels and activities, the impact of the scheme on the environment, the distribution of aid between Member States and within the Member States and the specific impact of the historical and regional model. 
18 In the report, the Court recommends that it is better for the single payment to flow in active farmers and to exclude non-agricultural parcels and activities that do not contribute to increasing agricultural productivity or actively maintaining the ecological value of the land. 
In addition, the Court recommends that the level of single payments should take into account the costs of environmental and other external effects and that a more balanced distribution of aid among farmers is sought. 
The calculation of single payments should be based on the current management conditions. 
The exam was carried out by a multidisciplinary team of eight chamber I examiners. The audit work provided not only further information on the concept of decoupled single payment, but also with regard to the impact of the conversion process from the previous coupled support scheme on the current scheme. 
According to team leader Sven Kölling, the examination of the various existing models and variants for implementing the scheme together with the coexistence of national and regional administrative strategies and their impact on the profitability and effectiveness of the premium was a particular challenge. 
Audit visits to final beneficiaries and on-the-spot checks at establishments proved essential to obtain the audit evidence supporting the findings and conclusions. 
Many of the Court's recommendations have been reflected in the Commission's proposals on the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy post-2013 (at the time of preparation of this report in the discussion) including the definition of an 'active farmer' and of minimum activities on certain areas, the distribution of premium payments among beneficiaries, the reduction of the large number of implementation models for the single payment scheme and the better consideration of environmental externalities in the calculation of single payment payments. 
Team of auditors from left to right: (first row) Heike Walz, Court Member Michel Cretin, Aurelia Petliza, (second row) Pietro Puricella, Dirk Pauwels, Sven Kölling, Sylvain Lehnhard 
The EU AS GLOBALER PARTNER 19 The EU's external relations activities focus on: Enlargement, stability, security and prosperity in their neighbourhood, active support for sustainable development at international level, promoting global policy "governance" and ensuring strategic and civil security. 
The EU has earmarked EUR 55.9 billion for the period 2007-2013, i.e. 5.7 % of its total planned expenditure, for these objectives. 
Expenditure is mainly managed directly by the Commission through its Headquarters or Delegations. 
Some support measures are also managed jointly with international organisations. 
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: O Has the deconcentration of the management of external aid from the Commission's central services to their delegations led to a better provision of assistance? 
(Special report No 1/2011). 
The purpose of the audit was to examine the administrative modalities and their impact on faster delivery and better quality of assistance and the establishment of stable financial procedures. 
The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid, with a large share of this assistance (EUR 8.4 billion in 2009) managed by the Commission under its management system. From 2002 onwards, this system has delegated powers to the Commission's external offices in partner countries. o Economicity and effectiveness of EU contributions made available through United Nations organisations in conflict-affected countries (Special Report No 3/2011) focusing on projects in Afghanistan, Iraq and Sudan for the period 2006-2008. 
EuropeAid provided around EUR 4 billion over the period 2005-2009 through UN agencies. 
The EU can provide funds as the sole donor or with other donors, as contributions to trust funds, without providing funds for specific activities or objectives, or as a contribution to the general budget of a UN organisation. o Effective EU assistance in improving Croatia's capacity to manage post-accession funding (Special Report No 14/2011) to assess the Commission's planning of the aid and whether the targeted results of EU-funded projects have been achieved. 
The aim of EU pre-accession assistance is to assist candidate countries in developing their administrative capacity in order to prepare them for the management of the larger EU aid to which they will be entitled as Member States. 
EU pre-accession assistance to Croatia has been EUR 150 million annually since 2007. 
The budget of the European Union is mainly financed from own resources and other revenue. 
Traditional own resources - mainly customs duties - account for around 12 % and VAT own resources represent a further 12 % of the total revenue. 
Most of the EU own resources (70 %) come from the own resources derived from gross national income, which ensures that the budget is always balanced. 
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: O Administration of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) (Special Report No 2/2011) on the evaluation of the measures taken to implement the recommendations of the Court's previous Special Report No 1/2005 on this issue. 
The starting point of the investigation was whether OLAF has now shifted the focus of its activities to its investigative function and is more efficient in its investigations, how it demonstrates the effectiveness of its investigative work and whether the role of the Supervisory Committee has been clarified. 
OLAF's mission is to combat fraud and other illegal activities affecting the EU budget. 
The Office is affiliated with the Commission, but has full independence in carrying out its investigations and employs around 500 staff. Its annual expenditure amounts to around 50 million euros. 
In 2011, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: O Can VAT evasion be prevented and detected by the control of customs procedure 42? (Special report No 13/2011). In the course of this audit, we examined whether there is a sound legal framework to combat VAT evasion under customs procedure 42. 
Audits were carried out in Belgium, Denmark, Spain, France, Austria, Slovenia and Sweden. 
Customs procedure 42 is a mechanism used by an EU importer to obtain VAT exemption. 
The procedure applies when goods imported from outside the EU to one Member State are transported to another Member State. 
In such cases, VAT is due in the Member State of destination. 
The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management through its opinions on proposals for new or amended legal acts with financial implications. 
These opinions are delivered at the request of the other EU institutions and used by the legislators - European Parliament and Council - in their work. 
The Court can also issue position papers on other issues on its own initiative. 
In 2011, the Court adopted seven opinions: O 1/2011: Proposal for a Council Regulation amending Regulation (EC) No 215/2008 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the tenth European Development Fund as regards the European External Action Service o 2/2011: Financial Regulation of the Clean Sky O 3/2011 Joint Undertaking: Proposal to amend the Financial Regulation of the European Schools o 4/2011: Commission Green Paper on Modernising European Public Procurement Policy o 5/2011: Proposal for a Council Regulation (Euratom) laying down the rules for the participation of undertakings, research centres and universities in indirect actions under the Framework Programme of the European Atomic Energy Community and for the dissemination of research results (2012-2013) o 6/2011: Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1073/1999 concerning investigations conducted by the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and repealing Regulation (Euratom) No 1074/1999 Opinion 7/2011 concerned proposals for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions on cohesion expenditure, which could account for up to 45 % of the total EU expenditure for the period 2014-2020. 
Therefore, the contribution from the EU budget to the Europe 2020 targets depends to a large extent on the economical, efficient and effective use of these funds. 
This will also affect the credibility and legitimacy of EU action. 
The EU continues to face the challenge of achieving good quality results with a regime where the funds are allocated in advance among Member States and the use of these funds is an implicit objective. 
The effective monitoring and exercise of accountability by the Commission would help Member States to use the funds successfully. 
The opinions are available on the Court's website www.eca.europa.eu in all the official languages of the EU. 21 
22 COURT'S POSITION PAPER: Consequences OF THE TIME FINANCIAL AND ECONOMIC CRISIS FOR THE OPINION OF THE COMMISSION AND THE OPINAL FINANCIAL CONTROL OF THE EU SOW FOR THE ROLL OF THE HOF The ongoing global financial and economic crisis has had far-reaching consequences for the European Union. 
To address the crisis, the EU took measures to ensure the long-term sustainability of the financial sector, to promote economic recovery and economic growth, to provide financial assistance to Member States and to strengthen fiscal and economic coordination between Member States. 
Moreover, these measures have a decisive influence on how public funds, i.e. taxpayers' money of EU citizens, are used in the Union. 
These changes to the regulatory framework of the Union pose new challenges in terms of accountability, transparency and public financial control. 
In the Court's view, the implementation of these new measures is based on the principle that adequate modalities for transparency, public accountability and public financial control should be laid down whenever the use of public funds is concerned. 
We therefore adopted on 19 May 2011 a position paper on the consequences of the current financial and economic crisis on public accountability and public financial control in the EU as well as on the role of the Court. 
In this position paper, the Court concluded that it would involve the new supervisory authorities, the assistance mechanisms with EU budgetary guarantees and, where possible, the Commission's activities under the European Semester in its audits. 
The ECA considers that the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism should provide for a form of external public financial control. 
Finally, the Court notes that in a number of cases, accountability and transparency issues need to be reconsidered by the relevant EU institutions, in particular the European Parliament and the Council. 
Cooperation with OTHER SAIs The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) mainly in the following bodies: O Contact Committee of the SAIs of EU Member States; O Network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; O international organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its European Regional Group (EUROSAI). 
In accordance with the EU Treaty, the Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies cooperate with confidence while respecting their independence. 
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of EU Member States within the Contact Committee. 
In the Contact Committee, the Presidents of the EU-ORKB and the Court meet once a year. 
The Contact Committee provides a forum for cooperation and exchange of expertise and experience in the area of EU funds and other EU issues. 
Working groups have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices. 
In 2011, the Court was acting Chair of the Contact Committee, continued to provide administrative support to the Committee and actively participated in the various working groups and networks. 
The 2011 annual meeting of the Contact Committee took place on 13 and 14 October 2011 at the Court's premises. 
The meeting focused on a seminar on the impact of the European Semester and other recent developments in the EU's economic governance on the EU-ORKB and the Court. 
In this context, inter alia, the regulation and monitoring of financial systems and financial institutions, state aid to the financial sector and the assessment of the mechanisms to deal with the euro crisis were addressed. 
The Contact Committee adopted a statement addressed to the European Parliament, the European Council and the European Commission, as well as the parliaments and governments of the EU Member States. 
In addition, the Contact Committee adopted a resolution to take into account the call of the SAIs of euro area countries for adequate external financial control of the European Stability Mechanism. 
Statement and resolution are available on the Contact Committee website (www.contactcommittee.eu).

On 15 November 2011, the Court of Justice delivered its judgment in Case C-539/09 Commission v Federal Republic of Germany concerning the audit powers of the European Court of Auditors in the field of VAT (VAT). 
The case is based on the refusal of the German Federal Ministry of Finance in 2006 to allow the European Court of Auditors to carry out audits on cooperation between the administrative authorities of the Member States in the field of value added tax in accordance with Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 in Germany. 
In preparing its Special Report No 8/2007, the Court decided to carry out audits in eight Member States, including Germany. 
The German authorities objected to the Court's right to carry out the audit in question. 
The German Government argued that the cooperation between the administrative authorities of the Member States, as provided for in Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003, did not have a direct link with EU revenues, since VAT was to be distinguished from a national tax and, therefore, from VAT own resources. 
The latter are determined according to a number of calculations and represent a relatively small proportion of the amounts collected by the Member States as VAT. 
The Court rejected the German Government's reasoning, which is based on a strict distinction between the Member States' VAT revenues from the Union's own resources. 
Based on the arguments put forward by the Commission, the European Parliament and the European Court of Auditors, the Court of Justice emphasised the dependence of VAT own resources on the VAT revenue of the Member States. 
The Court reiterated that the scope of Regulation (EC) No 1798/2003 on administrative cooperation in the field of VAT was to establish mechanisms of cooperation between Member States which enable them to combat VAT evasion more effectively and to collect VAT more effectively. 
This also has an impact on the availability of VAT own resources for the EU budget. 
Where cooperation between national authorities is carried out effectively and in accordance with the Regulation, it can contribute to a reduction of fraud and the effective collection of VAT in the Member States, as well as to ensuring that VAT own resources remain at the level they must have under the various relevant EU legal acts, thereby maintaining the overall balance of own resources. 
The Court of Justice concluded that the Court of Auditors was empowered to carry out the audit envisaged in the context of administrative cooperation in the field of VAT, since it related to the EU's revenue from the point of view of its legality and sound financial management and was therefore directly linked to the powers conferred on the Court of Auditors by the Treaty. 
In Case C-539/09, the Court had to rule explicitly on the scope of the Court's audit powers for the first time. 
The Court's judgment is valuable and encouraging because it clarifies and substantiates the institution's scrutiny power vis-ŕ-vis the Member States.

The most important achievements achieved in 2011 are: O an increase in the number of special reports; in the period 2009-2011, an average of 16 special reports were published per year, surpassing the target of 12-15 reports per year; O important contributions to the reform of the EU budget; O Initiating the preparation of regular follow-up reports on previous findings, including an overall follow-up report to be prepared for the first time in 2012; O revised audit strategies and audit guidelines; O increasing focus on core activities by relocating staff from support services to the audit service; O Publication of a position paper on the impact of the current financial and economic crisis on public accountability and public financial control within the EU and on the role of the Court. 
On the basis of the recommendation of the peer review carried out by an international expert panel in 2008, the Court strengthened the framework for its audit management by adopting ethical guidelines based on the INTOSAI obligations and code of conduct and the International Standard for Quality Control within SAI3. 
In this context, the Court has put in place a procedure to provide sufficient assurance on an annual basis that our auditors comply with the relevant ethical requirements. 
Respecting the values set out in the ethical guidelines, such as impartiality, objectivity, loyalty and professional secrecy, ensures that the Court's employees act in the public interest, unaffected by external pressure and unaffected by personal or financial interests. 
The Court's framework for professional conduct promotes the credibility of the information provided to its addressees.

The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources according to the extent to which it is able to present reports and audit findings on time, to fulfil its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its staff. 
Punctuality OF THE REPORTs The Court strives to accept all audit reports within the deadlines set. 
For the annual reports and specific annual reports, dates laid down in legislation must be observed. 
For special reports for which there is no publication date set out in legislation, the planned date of adoption shall be considered as a benchmark for punctuality. 
35 4 2010 90 % Number of reports adopted on time 80 % in 2011 83 % 90 % 75 % 90 % Overall, the Court did not fully meet its targets in 2011. 
The very high target for the number of reports was not met, while the overarching target of 12-15 special reports per year was exceeded and output was higher than in 2010. 
All annual reports, with the exception of all special annual reports, were adopted on schedule and published on time. 
4 The targets for these indicators have been changed from 100 % (2008-2010) to 90 % to reflect unexpected events. 
Punctuality OF audit findings Examination notices contain details of the specific audit findings and are drawn up after audit visits to Member States or the Commission. 
The Court uses them to confirm the factual accuracy of its findings by the audited bodies. Audit notifications are therefore an important stage in the audit process. 
The Court has previously found that there is a need for significant improvement in the preparation of the audit notices in terms of punctuality. The target to be achieved by the end of 2012 is: Preparation of 80 % of the audit notifications within two months of the audit visit concerned. 
2010 2011 Percentage of audit notifications prepared on time 54 % 58 % target for 20114 Number of adopted reports compared to the number of planned reports target for 2011 80 % to 2012 We improved the punctuality of audit notifications in 2011, however, the target has not yet been met. 
Significant progress has been made over the past three years (only 27 % of audit notifications were prepared on schedule in 2008) and the Court will continue to strive to improve its performance. 
The Court strives to obtain from its independent auditor an unqualified opinion on the annual accounts and the use of resources and discharge from the European Parliament following a favourable recommendation from the Council. 
In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), the Court strives to provide the auditors with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training (without language courses). 
In an internal employee satisfaction survey conducted in 2009, 86 % of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with their work, with a total of 2.8 employee satisfaction levels ranging from 1 to 4. Any value above 2.5 indicates overall satisfaction. 
The Court strives to maintain or improve this result if a similar survey is conducted in 2012. 
The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by its specialised services. 
These services shall provide the logistical, technical and/or technical know-how which enables the Court to recruit, retain and motivate its staff and to develop its professional skills; O to disseminate the results of the examination in all official languages of the EU; O to make the best use of information technology; O to manage its budget and maintain its infrastructure; O to carry out audit visits to obtain evidence on the spot in the countries where EU funds are collected and spent. 
37 PERSONAL Staff allocation The most important asset of the Court is its employees. 
At 31. In December 2010, the Court's staff was 887 (officials and temporary staff but excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees). 
Of these, 564 are employed in examination chambers (including 123 staff in Members' cabinets), 148 in the Translation Directorate, 148 in administrative support services and 27 in the services of the President. 
With a view to achieving the best possible use of resources, all services once again explored and implemented ways of improving efficiency by simplifying procedures in 2011. 
Where possible, efficiencies outside the audit area have shifted posts to the audit service, contributing more than half to the 12.6 % increase in audit posts since 2008.

38 SETTINGS The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output. 
The ECA's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and staff consists of both officials and temporary staff. 
Open competitions for ECA posts are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). 
In addition, the Court advocates a limited REGULATION OF MEN AND WOMEN, like the other EU institutions, the Court operates an equal opportunities policy within the framework of its human resources policy and recruitment. 
After a continuous increase in the proportion of women over the years, the Court has now reached a balanced proportion of men and women among its employees. 
In 2011, the Court hired 75 employees: 23 officials, 24 temporary staff and 28 contract staff. 
In particular, the Court succeeded in recruiting new staff to audit bodies. 
On 31. In December 2011, 25 vacancies were vacant - significantly less than in 2010 (44). 
As a result, the vacancy rate fell below 3 % for the first time.

39 3.8 % 16.3 % 20.7 % 19.2 % 17.5 % 11.5 % 7.6 % 3.4 % REQUIREMENT The examiner's profession requires continuous training to keep pace with new developments and acquire new skills. 
In 2011, the Court's staff completed an average of 9.3 days of professional training. 
Language courses accounted for 54 % of the total number of training days (compared to 57 % in 2010). 
In addition to language courses, the auditors completed 6.1 days of professional training in 2011 and thus fulfilled an important objective of the institution. 
In 2011, improvements in the content of training activities were made and new courses were developed in order to meet the priorities in the field of testing. 
In addition, the Court has streamlined the training management system. 
Translation Translation is an important activity of audit support that enables the Court to fulfil its mission and achieve its communication objectives. 
In 2011, the volume of translation was comparable to the workload of 2010. 
More than 99 % of the translation services were delivered on time. 
In 2011, additional posts and staff from the Translation Directorate were transferred to the Audit Service. 
The Court's Directorate for Translation also provided valuable linguistic support for auditors during missions and in the subsequent stages of the drafting of audit reports. 
In addition, the Translation Directorate supported the Contact Committee, INTOSAI working groups and covered other specific needs related to the Court's audit work. 
In addition, the Court's Directorate for Translation was actively involved in inter-institutional and international specialised bodies. 
Information Technology (IT) plays a key role in the implementation of the overall objectives of the Court's strategy for the period 2009-2012. 
In 2011, the Court took the following measures: O Strengthen its investment in knowledge management by launching the development of a new version of the screening support instrument (assyst2 project) based on the recently established cooperation platform; O active continuation of its efforts to streamline internal processes through electronic workflows in areas such as mission management and training, and electronic archiving of personnel files to continuously increase efficiency and effectiveness; continuing support for mobility through the use of smartphones and laptop computers, as well as launching a project for an extranet, which will also play a central role in facilitating electronic exchange with a large number of ECA partners (including audited bodies, budgetary authority, newly recruited staff, suppliers). 
These developments were carried out while enhancing operational security and emergency measures to ensure the necessary availability and quality of all the Court's IT services. 
Management AND INFRASTRUCTURE The task of the Directorate for Finance and Support Services is to provide the Court's auditors with adequate support in an efficient, effective and timely manner and to ensure that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all our activities. 
In 2011, the Directorate continued its efforts to further improve efficiency and effectiveness with a view to unlocking resources to relocate to the Audit Service. 
Following an agreement with the Budgetary Authority (Parliament and Council) at the end of 2008 on the financing of the K3 building, a key activity in 2011 was the construction of the second extension building to the Court's main building. 
Construction work was completed during 2011 and the shell construction was made weatherproof at the end of the year. 
Great progress has been made in interior design. 
The time and budget of the construction project is respected. 
The Court is expected to take possession of the building at the end of 2012 and the move is expected to take place in the first quarter of 2013. 
Analyses carried out in 2009 and 2010 led the Court to conclude that its security objectives could best be achieved and that risks could be managed most efficiently and cost-effectively if the recession and security services are provided internally. 
This was achieved in April 2011 by replacing the external security service contractor by a small team of contract agents. 
The annual costs will be more than EUR 0.5 million lower in 2012 than in 2009. 
Audit visits During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to the Member States and to other beneficiaries of EU funds as well as to the headquarters of international organisations such as the United Nations. 
The purpose of these audit visits is to obtain direct audit evidence. 
Visits usually apply to central and local authorities involved in the authorisation, management and disbursement of EU funds, as well as the respective final recipients. 
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member State visited. 
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors and the duration of an audit trip may be up to two weeks depending on the type of examination and distance. 
In 2011, the Court undertook a total of 379 audit missions5-343 in Member States and 36 outside the EU in relation to audits related to annual reports and specific annual reports and selected audit tasks. 
A comparable number of audit visits were carried out to the EU institutions and bodies in Brussels and Luxembourg. 
5 This corresponds to the number of Member States and beneficiary countries to which audit visits were carried out in connection with the individual audit tasks.

The task of the Internal Audit Service is to provide independent and objective assurance and to provide advice in such a way as to increase and improve the Court's activities. 
It supports the Court in achieving the objectives of the institution by applying a systematic and rigorous approach to assessing and making recommendations to improve the effectiveness of risk management, control and governance processes. 
In carrying out its duties, the Internal Audit Service shall act in accordance with the EU Financial Regulation, the legislation applicable to EU officials and the International Standards for the Professional Practice of Internal Audit. 
In 2009, the Court's Internal Audit Service was audited and certified in accordance with the internationally recognised standards of the Institute of Internal Auditors. 
The annual accounts of the European Court of Auditors are audited by an independent auditor. 
This is a key component of the Court's efforts to ensure that it applies to itself the same principles of transparency and accountability as to the bodies it audits. 
In 2011, the Court's Internal Audit Service presented reports on the following issues: State of play of the implementation of the Court's strategy for the period 2009-2012; Implementation of key performance indicators; Construction of the new K3 building of the Court; Use of the escrow account for payments to eligible beneficiaries; Follow-up of previous recommendations. 
In all respects, the Internal Audit Service assisted the Court's independent auditor in its audit with regard to the certification of the Court's annual accounts and the effectiveness of its internal control procedures. 
The Court's Internal Audit Committee advises on internal audit issues and monitors the related internal control environment as part of the institution's risk management procedures. 
In 2011, the Internal Audit Committee and the Internal Auditor analysed the results of the Internal Audit Service's audits, the implementation of the Action Plans with an impact on the internal control environment and the risks to the institution's governance. 
The audit opinion of the auditor - PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL - on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2010 was published in September 20116.

Luxembourg, 8 March 2012 Eduardo RUIZ GARCÍA Secretary General 
The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg. 
The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body consisting of 27 members, each with one member per Member State. 
Its members shall be appointed by the Council for a six-year term after consulting the European Parliament. 
Members elect a president from among them for three years, with the possibility of re-election. 
The Court is organised by chambers to which members are assigned. 
The Chambers prepare reports and opinions for adoption by the Court. 
Audit Chambers I to IV cover various revenue and expenditure areas, while the fifth, the CEAD Chamber, is responsible for horizontal matters. 
The chambers are supported by audit directorates. 
Since the amendment of the Court's Rules of Procedure in 2010, certain categories of reports and opinions of the Court may be adopted by Chambers instead of the whole College of the Court. 
The Administrative Committee shall meet under the chairmanship of the President and shall be composed of the Doyens of the Chambers and the Secretary-General (responsible for the Court's administrative and support services). 
The Committee has a coordinating role and prepares the Court's decisions on strategic planning, performance management and administrative matters. 
Each member is responsible for specific tasks, primarily in the area of audit. 
Members shall submit audit proposals and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible to the respective Chamber and to the Court. 
Following the adoption of a report, it will be presented by the "rapporteur" to the European Parliament, the Council and other relevant stakeholders. 
Members will be assisted by their cabinet staff and the audit team. 49
