European Court of Auditors JEARLY ACTIVITY REPORT 2012 
The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances under the Treaty. 
As an EU external auditor, he contributes to improving EU financial management, promotes accountability and transparency, and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens. 
Independence, INTEGRITITY AND UNPARTMENT PROFESSIONALITY PROFESSIONALITY EXCELLENT AND EFFICIENCE Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its staff. 
Maintaining a high and exemplary level of professionalism in all aspects of his work. 
Active participation in the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level. 
Producing relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the concerns of its audience and containing important and forward-looking statements. 
To contribute to an effective improvement of the management of the EU budget and to contribute to strengthening accountability for the management of EU funds. 
Fostering team spirit through effective communication. 
5 INSTITUTIONS page 6 OF THE PRESIDENT 8 2012 ON A BLICK 9 OUR ACTIVITIES 9 Examination Reports and OPINIONS 30 SUMMARY WITH OTHER OVEREST Audit Institutions 34 OUR MANAGEMENT 35 WECTS IN THE COLLEGION OF THE HOUSE 36 MESSDATES FOR PERFORMANCE OF THE HOUSE 44 COMPANY OF THE Audit Activities 49 FINANCIAL INFORMATION 54 35 YEARS IN THE SERVICE OF A BEATHER FUNCTION OF THE EU 6 BORLD OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the European Court of Auditors' Annual Activity Report 2012! 
In 2012, an important focus of the Court's work was to prepare the Union for the key challenges in the area of financial management post-2013. 
At the beginning of the year, the Court adopted its opinion on some proposals for regulations relating to the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), probably the most well-known EU policy. 
The draft regulation was part of the package of legislative proposals related to the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. 
With a number of opinions and reports published in 2012, the Court actively contributed to strengthening the new rules to which the EU's revenue and expenditure will be subject during this period. 
Furthermore, in 2012, the Court continued to closely monitor the impact of developments in the EU's economic governance on public accountability and financial control. 
This year, the Treaty establishing the European Stability Mechanism entered into force and the Audit Committee of this new body, including a representative of the Court, met for its first meeting. 
In December 2012, the Council of the European Union adopted its position on the establishment of a single supervisory mechanism to ensure prudential supervision of euro area credit institutions and the Court announced its position on public accountability and financial control to EU policy makers. 
Many changes in the area of economic governance and the EU budget result from the need to achieve better political outcomes with lower public resources while strengthening democratic legitimacy and accountability. 
Due to its unique powers and perspective, on the one hand, and the audit experience gained over the course of its 35-year history and the partnerships established, on the other hand, the Court is well positioned to support the EU in addressing these challenges. 
Based on our successes in recent years, the Court's objective is to maximise the Court's contribution to improving the EU's accountability over the period 2013-2017. 
The farm is currently celebrating its 35th anniversary. 
Europe has changed fundamentally since the Court began its work in 1977. 
The structure of the Court and the way it performs its audits reflect these changes. 
With the accession of new Member States, the transfer of competences to the Union and the establishment of numerous bodies at EU level, the Court's audit area has widened. 
The Court has also grown as an institution, from nine members and 120 employees in 1977 to 27 members and nearly 900 employees in 2012. 
This growth allowed the farm to build up a professional, dedicated and experienced workforce. 
2012 was the last year covered by the Court's strategy for the period 2009-2012. 
The Court recorded encouraging results over the course of this period. 
As this Annual Activity Report shows, output has been increased, external experts classify the quality of our reports as good, and the main institutional addressees find them useful. 
The level of acceptance by the Commission of the Court's recommendations is consistently high and the Court's new follow-up report highlights the positive impact of the recommendations. 
The Court can also show efficiency gains in the area of management and translation, which led to the deployment of 40 additional staff in the audit area at the end of the period. 
In order to achieve the objectives for the period 2013-2017, the Court will prioritise products to improve EU accountability and strengthen and expand our partnerships, professionalism and efficiency. 
In 2013, an international peer review team will examine the Court's performance audit practices and follow up on the results of the previous 2008 peer review process. 
Other key actions launched in 2013 include streamlining the Court's reporting procedures and making even better use of our shared knowledge, expertise and expertise. 
With these and other initiatives, the Court intends to support the EU in addressing its growing public accountability and financial control challenges in the years to come. 
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 7

9 OUR REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are as follows: O Annual Reports - including the results of its financial and compliance audits on the budget of the European Union and on the European Development Funds (EDF); in addition, special annual reports on EU agencies, decentralised bodies and agencies are published separately; O Special reports - which may be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits on specific budgetary or management areas; these are mainly performance audits; O Opinions on draft acts affecting financial management and statements and position papers on other issues at the Court's own initiative. 
Since 2008, the number of special annual reports and special reports of the Court has increased sharply. 
The annual reports have also been further developed: More analytical information is now available, the presentation of the data has been more unified to facilitate the comparison between areas and over time, and a new chapter on performance-related issues has been added. 
The significant increase in the opinions issued is due to the fact that the Court has been consulted on the large legislative proposals related to the new financial framework (2014-2020).

While the vast majority of audit work takes place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, auditors also make visits to the EU institutions, agencies and decentralised bodies, the authorities of the Member States and other beneficiaries of EU funds (including the headquarters of international organisations such as the United Nations in Switzerland). 
Audit visits usually apply to central and local authorities involved in the authorisation, management and disbursement of EU funds, as well as the respective final recipients. 
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited. 
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors and the duration of an audit trip may be a few days up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and distance. 
In 2012, the Court's auditors spent 6 816 days of on-the-spot audits - 6 054 in Member States and 762 outside the EU - and obtained audit evidence for the annual reports, specific annual reports and selected audit tasks. 
They spent a similar amount of time at the EU institutions and bodies in Brussels and Luxembourg.

11 The key statements of the Annual Report 2011 o The annual accounts for the financial year 2011 represent appropriately the financial position of the European Union and the results of its operations and cash flows for that year. 
Revenue and commitments were not materially affected by errors. 
However, payments were materially affected by errors, with the estimated error rate for the EU budget as a whole being 3.9 %. 
This error rate is comparable to that in 2010, which stood at 3.7 %. O All individually assessed EU spending areas are materially affected by errors, with the exception of external relations, external assistance and enlargement, as well as administrative expenditure. 
This shows that improvements continue to be needed in the management of EU funding. o The Court's estimated error rate for rural development, environment, fisheries and health (the most error-prone expenditure) expenditure was 7.7 %. 
The estimated error rate for regional policy, energy and transport remained high at 6.0 %. 
This is based on the fact that the Commission has recognised the existence of a high risk of error in some areas, in particular rural development, cohesion and research. 
Many cases have been identified where the controls failed. o The Commission's self-assessment in terms of performance has been further developed, which has led to positive improvements compared to previous years. 
Nevertheless, the Court's performance audits in 2011 found that good quality needs analysis was often lacking, weaknesses in the programme design impacted reporting on results and impacts, and that the Commission must demonstrate European added value. 
In the course of 2012, the Court devoted the bulk of its audits to the 2011 EU budget to the implementation of the EU budget for 2011. 
The 2011 Annual Report, resulting from this work, was published on 6 November 2012. 
The aim of the annual report is to support the European Parliament, the Council and citizens in assessing the quality of EU financial management by presenting findings and conclusions, and recommend appropriate improvements. 
The 18th Annual Statement of Assurance ("DAS") on the reliability of the EU accounts and the regularity of the underlying transactions is the core element of the 2011 annual reports. 
The 2011 annual report on the implementation of the EU budget included two new chapters, which include more targeted results for agriculture and cohesion. 
The previous chapter on agriculture and natural resources was covered by the chapter "Agriculture: Market support and direct payments' and 'Rural development, environment, fisheries and health'. 
In addition, the separate chapters "Regional policy, energy and transport" and "Employment and social affairs" replace the previous chapter on cohesion, energy and transport. 
The European Development Funds (EDF) are financed by EU Member States but managed outside the EU budget. They are subject to their own financial regulations. 
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of EDF-funded actions. 
From the European Development Funds (EDFs), the European Union provides development cooperation assistance to African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs) on the basis of the Cotonou Agreement signed in 2000. 
In line with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of ACP countries and OCTs into the world economy, the expenditure concerned is aimed at curbing and finally eradicating poverty. 
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars: development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension. 
The Court's 2011 annual report on the EDFs was published in parallel to the annual report on the EU budget on 6 November 2012. 
We found that the financial statements of the EDFs for 2011 represent the financial position of the EDFs as well as the results of their operations and cash flows. 
However, 33 % of EDF transactions were affected by errors, including an estimated rate of 5.1 % of error-related payments. 
Special YEAR REPORTS TO THE AGENTURES, DECENTRAL INSTRUCTIONS AND SOCIAL STATEMENTS OF THE EU FOR 2011 In 2012, the Court published 50 special annual reports, mostly covering the financial year 2011, on the agencies, decentralised bodies (e.g. joint undertakings) and other EU agencies. 
EU Agencies and Decentralised Bodies are set up on the basis of EU legislation to carry out specific tasks. 
President Caldeira at the presentation of the 2011 Annual Report at the plenary session of the European Parliament (November 2012) 
In addition to its annual reports, the Court publishes special reports throughout the year containing the results of the performance and compliance audits carried out by the Court on specific budgetary areas or management issues of its choice. 
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court is keen to achieve maximum impact and thus make the best use of its resources. 
In the selection of topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: O the risks to profitability or compliance with legal standards in the relevant revenue or expenditure area; O the amount of the respective revenue or expenditure; O the time elapsed since a previous test; pending developments within the relevant legal framework; O the political and public interest. 
In 2012, the Court adopted 25 special reports covering a wide range of topics. 
This represents a significant increase compared to the 16 special reports adopted in 2011 (and the 12 special reports adopted in 2008). 
All special reports are available in 22 EU languages on the Court's website http://eca.europa.eu in full length or available through the EU Bookshop. 
The following pages present the topics of the special reports adopted in 2012, each under the corresponding headings of the 2013-2017 financial framework - the EU's multiannual budgetary plan. 
14 RUBRIK OF FINANCIAL COMMUNITIES - FINANCIAL RESULTS The EU spending on sustainable growth covers two areas: Competitiveness includes promoting research and technological development, networking Europe through EU networks, education and training, promoting competitiveness in a fully integrated single market, the social policy agenda and the dismantling of nuclear installations. 
The EU spending for growth and jobs for the period 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 89.4 billion, i.e. 9.2 % of the EU budget, of which almost two thirds are R & D. 
Cohesion for growth and jobs mainly concerns cohesion policy implemented by funds dedicated to specific areas of activity: European Social Fund (ESF), European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and Cohesion Fund (CF). 
The EU budget for cohesion for the period 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 348.4 billion, or 35.7 % of the total EU budget. 
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: O Financial instruments for SMEs co-financed by the European Regional Development Fund (No 2/2012) - This special report assessed the efficiency and effectiveness of the financial technical measures co-financed by the ERDF during the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods. The audit concerned a sample of projects in Germany, Portugal, Slovakia, Hungary and the United Kingdom and included an investigation of the management, monitoring and information systems of the Commission and the Member States. 
The Court concluded that the effectiveness and efficiency of the expenditure incurred under the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) on financial instruments for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) was affected because the regulatory framework did not provide an adequate basis for the use of the different types of financial instruments. 
Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) form the backbone of the EU economy and ensure employment, innovation and prosperity. 
However, SMEs may not be able to meet their financial needs in the form and amount they need. 
To support them, the EU is deploying its corporate and cohesion policy, mainly in the form of aid, and increasingly in the ERDF framework through financial instruments. 
Financial instruments are repayable, revolving instruments. 
According to the Commission's figures, the ERDF allocations for financial instruments amount to 1.6 billion euro and EUR 10.4 billion respectively for the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods. 
O Structural Funds - Have the Commission reacted effectively to deficiencies identified in Member States' management and control systems? 
(No 3/2012) - This special report examined the extent to which the Commission initiated appropriate corrective measures, ensured their timely implementation and had a sufficient level of assurance that their measures would result in appropriate financial corrections on past irregularities, as well as improvements in systems in order to avoid the recurrence of irregularities. 
The audit was mainly carried out on the basis of a review of 40 programmes where significant deficiencies had been identified. 
We found that the Commission was quite successful in ensuring the correct application of financial corrections with regard to the deficiencies in the Member States' management and control systems, but that it was only to a lesser degree of assurance that its measures led to improvements in Member States' systems. 
Structural Fund expenditure is subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States. 
Member States shall draw up multiannual programmes which are examined and approved by the Commission and subsequently implemented by the Member States. 
If there are significant deficiencies in the management and control systems of the Member States, the Commission shall endeavour to ensure that irregularities are corrected and systems are improved. o Use of Structural and Cohesion Funds to co-finance transport infrastructure in seaports: an effective investment? 
(No 4/2012) - This special report assessed the effectiveness of the objectives and outputs of 27 projects co-financed by the ERDF and Cohesion Fund under the reporting code for "Transport Infrastructure" during the period 2000-2006. 
We found that investments in seaport transport infrastructure under cohesion policy were only effective for 11 of the 27 audited projects. 
Maritime transport is the second most important mode of transport in the EU. 
The Commission forecasts growth of 3.8 billion tonnes in 2006 to 5.3 billion tonnes in 2018. 
Since 2000, the EU has allocated around 6.2 billion euro to co-finance seaport infrastructure from the Structural Funds and the Cohesion Fund. 
15 Examination of EU expenditure on transport 
16 RUBRIK OF THE FINANCIAL REGULATION - RELIABILITY OF WATER o Does the support of urban waste management infrastructure projects in structural measures provide effective support to Member States in achieving the objectives of EU waste policy? 
(No 20/2012) - This special report assessed the performance of 26 sampled waste management infrastructure projects. It examined the achievement of the objectives of the EU waste policy and the implementation of accompanying measures in the eight regions where the infrastructures are located. 
We found that the effectiveness of the support for municipal waste management infrastructure in EU structural measures was affected by the inadequate implementation of accompanying measures and weaknesses in EU legislation and guidelines. 
In 2010, every citizen of the 27 EU Member States produced an average of about 500 kg of waste, which, if not properly collected, treated and disposed of, could lead to negative environmental impacts. 
The EU has introduced common standards and targets in the form of guidelines for the management of municipal waste and co-finances waste management infrastructures in certain regions. 
For the period 2000-2013, the EU has earmarked EUR 10.8 billion for waste management infrastructure. o Cost-effectiveness of investments in energy efficiency under cohesion policy (No 21/2012) - This special report assessed whether investments in energy efficiency made under cohesion policy were cost-effective by examining whether planning and financing had the right conditions to enable cost-effective investments in energy efficiency and whether energy efficiency projects carried out in public buildings were cost-effective. 
We found that the average payback period of EU investments in energy efficiency is more than 50 years (in extreme cases up to 150 years). This means that funds for this type of investment could be used more cost-effectively. 
The cost of increased energy consumption, the depletion of fossil fuels and the impact of human action on global climate change are the drivers of recent EU policies to increase energy efficiency. 
Since 2000, the European Union has spent almost EUR 5 billion under cohesion policy on co-financing energy efficiency measures in the Member States. 
(No 23/2012) - This special report examined whether the project objectives were achieved, whether the target orientation of EU funding was based on sound criteria and whether the results achieved were achieved at the lowest possible cost for the EU budget. 
We audited the performance of 27 projects for the revitalisation of fallow areas using EU co-financing totalling EUR 231 million and analysed the instruments for the revitalisation of fallow areas, which are the framework for the specific co-financed actions, in Germany, Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and the United Kingdom. 
(The conclusions of this special report will be published on 18 April 2013.) 
In recent decades, more and more dismantled industrial and military areas (so-called "breaking areas") have become available. 
Many fallow areas are contaminated. 
The revitalisation and re-use of fallow land will be promoted through EU structural measures with the aim of promoting the protection of human health and the environment and to counteract the sprawling of the landscape. 
EU funding for this area amounted to a total of EUR 5.7 billion in 2000-2013. 
O European Union Solidarity Fund response to the 2009 Abruzzo earthquake: Relevance and costs of actions (No 24/2012) - This special report assessed whether the actions financed were in line with the EUSF Regulation and whether the construction project "CASE", which accounted for the bulk of the expenditure, was well planned and designed and carried out with due regard to the aspect of economy. 
We found that while the other projects financed were eligible, the CASE project was not in line with the EUSF Regulation. 
There were also weaknesses in the planning of the CASE project and in ensuring the economy in its implementation. 
The 2009 earthquake, centered in the Italian region of Abruzzo, caused damage of more than 10 billion euros. 
The European Union supported the Italian disaster management with a contribution of EUR 0.5 billion from its solidarity fund, which was used for rescue operations, the provision of emergency shelters and temporary schools, as well as for the CASE project for the construction of earthquake-proof homes. 
The Cathedral of L'Aquila in Italy almost four years after the 2009 earthquake o Are there instruments to monitor the effectiveness of the European Social Fund expenditure on older workers? 
(No 25/2012) - This special report examined whether and to what extent the Member States and the Commission have developed and deployed appropriate tools to assess the achievement of the objectives for older workers. 
Six programs worth 222 million euros were selected. The programmes concerned four Member States: Germany, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom. 
We found that neither the Member States nor the Commission can make any representations on the extent to which the ESF-supported measures were actually beneficial for older workers. 
From 2007 to the end of 2013, the ESF will spend more than EUR 75 billion in support of Member States in the field of employment, representing around 8 % of the EU's overall budget. 
One of the most disadvantaged groups is older workers. 
17 Newly built, earthquake-proof housing in L'Aquila, Italy 
The EU has a high political responsibility in the fields of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. 
The planned budget for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 413,1 billion, i.e. 42.3 % of the total EU budget. 
Three quarters of the expenditure concerns direct payments to farmers and support to agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) - the "first pillar" of the common agricultural policy (CAP). 
Another fifth of the expenditure is the support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second 'pillar' of the CAP. 
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: O Reform of the common organisation of the market in wine: progress made so far (No 7/2012) - This special report assessed progress towards one of the main objectives of the wine reform, namely progress towards a better balance between supply and demand. 
The audit focused on the measures "finishing premium" and "restructuring and conversion of vineyards", which constitute the two main areas of expenditure and are of crucial importance for achieving the objective of achieving a better balance between supply and demand. 
We found that these two measures were at odds with each other and that the structural surplus was not significantly reduced. 
For the three-year period of application of the grubbing-up measure (2008/2009 to 2010/2011), the EU provided a budget of EUR 1.1 billion. 
For restructuring and conversion, EUR 4.2 billion was allocated for the ten-year period up to 2010. 
We found that the measure to modernise farms would have been potentially more effective by making more targeted use of the means to meet EU priorities and specific needs in the Member States, on the one hand, and through the actual use of selection procedures. 
This aid concerns the financing of investments in agricultural holdings, ranging from investments for simple items such as agricultural equipment or wooden boxes for fruit to investments in complex projects such as biogas plants. 
The EU budget for this aid (derived from the EAFRD) amounts to a total of EUR 11.1 billion for the 2007-2013 programming period, representing around 11 % of all EU expenditure earmarked for rural development. o Audit of the control system governing the production, processing, distribution and import of organic products (No 9/2012) - This special report examined whether the control system for organic products provides sufficient assurance that the key requirements for the production, processing, distribution and import of organic products are met. 
It examined how the various bodies involved (EU Commission and competent authorities of the Member States, accreditation bodies and control bodies) have fulfilled their tasks within the EU and in the management of import arrangements. 
We found that the competent authorities in the Member States encountered difficulties in ensuring the traceability of organic products. In addition, there were weaknesses in the system that need to be addressed in order to provide sufficient assurance that the system works effectively and to ensure that consumer confidence is not undermined. 
The objective of the EU regulatory framework for organic production is to provide a basis for the sustainable development of organic production, to ensure a level playing field, to protect consumer interests while ensuring the proper functioning of the internal market. 
A control system was established to control and certify each operator in the supply chain. o Direct aid for suckler cows and ewes and goats under the partial implementation of the single payment scheme (No 11/2012) - This special report examined whether the aid was targeted at the most relevant regions in the Member States, whether it was effective in maintaining a specific production and thus avoiding negative social, economic and environmental impacts, and whether it was the subject of proper monitoring and evaluation by the Commission and the Member States. 
We found that CAP direct aid for dam stock does not deliver better results than decoupled aid. 
Following the 2003 CAP reform, agricultural aid previously granted in the form of direct payments linked to the production of certain agricultural products (so-called 'coupled' aids) should no longer be paid (i.e. decoupled) after the introduction of the single payment scheme (i.e. they were decoupled). 
However, for certain sectors and regions, some exemptions from full decoupling have been foreseen in order to limit the potential negative effects of an immediate transition to such a scheme. 
The budget available for this direct aid for 2011 amounted to a total of 1.0 billion euro.

20 RUBRIK OF THE FINANCIAL COMMUNITIES - Awareness and Emotion of NATURAL RESSOURCES o Implementation of EU hygiene rules in the slaughterhouses of the countries that have joined the EU since 2004 (No 14/2012) - This special report examined whether the Commission and the Member States concerned have taken the necessary measures to ensure that the relevant adaptations to EU hygiene rules have been made in slaughterhouses. 
The monitoring, orientation support, implementation and financing of hygiene compliance measures were checked. 
The Court examined slaughterhouses in Poland, Romania, Slovenia, the Czech Republic and Hungary, which had received EU funding. 
While the Court found that the systems set up to monitor the hygiene rules were adequate overall by the Commission and the competent authorities, the audit identified a number of shortcomings in the implementation of these systems, highlighting the need for greater rigour at all levels to mitigate risks. 
The Member States that have joined the EU since 2004 had to ensure that their slaughterhouses complied with EU hygiene rules. 
As these rules generally contained much stricter requirements than the respective national rules, EU funds were allocated to assist slaughterhouses in complying with hygiene rules and related modernisation. 
Around EUR 117 million was allocated to 241 slaughterhouses under the Special Preparation Programme for Agriculture and Rural Development (Sapard programme). 
The support was then continued under the EAGGF and the EAFRD. o Effectiveness of the single area payment scheme as a transitional system for supporting farmers in the new Member States (No 16/2012) - This special report examines the main weaknesses, such as payments to beneficiaries who did not carry out (or only marginal) agricultural activity, payments for abandoned land or land used for non-agricultural activities, payments to government authorities and aid focusing on a few large beneficiaries. 
We found that some of the aid was paid to beneficiaries engaged in only marginal or non-agricultural activities, including public bodies, and that the distribution of the aid did not take into account the regional characteristics of the agricultural activity or the contribution of farmers to the production of public goods. 
In addition, the vast majority of farmers receive very small amounts of aid. 
The single area payment scheme is a simplified income support scheme for farmers in the Member States who have joined the EU since 2004. 
In 2011, payments amounted to around EUR 5 billion. 
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: O Do the European Integration Fund and the European Refugee Fund effectively contribute to the integration of third-country nationals? 
(No 22/2012) - This special report assessed whether the European Integration Fund and the European Refugee Fund, which are parts of the EU General Programme "Solidarity and Management of Migration Flows" for the period 2007-2013 (SOLID), contributed efficiently to the integration of third-country nationals into the EU, whether the results were supported by efficient monitoring and evaluation of the programme, whether the design of the Funds contributed to the effective implementation of the Funds and whether the systems for implementing integration measures under the SOLID programme were properly managed. 
We found that although positive results could be found for individual audited projects, inappropriate systems had been put in place to measure the success of the Funds. 
The effectiveness of the Funds was reduced by the design of the programme and coordination with other EU funds was insufficient. 
The EU promotes measures for the integration of third-country nationals in EU Member States and increases solidarity through the distribution of financial burdens resulting from the management of common external borders and the implementation of common policies in the field of asylum and immigration. 
Expenditure under the EU budget for SOLID is expected to amount to a total of 4.0 billion euro over the period 2007-2013.

22 RUBRIK OF FINANCIAL COMMITTEE - THE EU AS GLOBAL PARTNER The EU's external relations activities focus on: Enlargement, stability, security and prosperity in their neighbourhood, active support for sustainable development at international level, promoting global policy "governance" and ensuring strategic and civil security. 
For the period 2007-2013, the EU has allocated EUR 55.9 billion, i.e. 5.7 % of its total planned expenditure, to these objectives. 
Expenditure is mainly managed directly by the Commission through its Headquarters or Delegations. 
In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: O European Union Development Assistance Effectiveness for Food Security in Sub-Saharan Africa (No 1/2012) - This special report examined the effectiveness of EU food security development assistance in sub-Saharan Africa by analysing whether EU development assistance for food security is relevant to countries' needs and priorities and whether EU action has been effective. 
The audit focused on EU direct development assistance for the three pillars of food security, namely food availability, access to food and balanced nutrition. 
The Court concluded that EU development aid for food security is predominantly effective in sub-Saharan Africa and makes an important contribution to achieving food security. 
However, the Commission did not take sufficient account of the possibilities for EU support to other countries also affected by chronic food insecurity and did not give the food aspect an adequate priority. 
Food security is a major and persistent problem in sub-Saharan Africa, where 30 % of the population is affected by hunger. 
Over the period 2002-2010, the EU financed food security measures in this region from the European Development Fund (EDF) totalling more than 3.2 billion euros. o The Common RELEX Information System (CRIS) (No 5/2012) - This special report examined whether CRIS had been designed to effectively meet the needs of the Commission and whether the information it provided was reliable. 
The audit included a review of the CRIS documentation available to the Commission and the audit of the data contained in CRIS. 
We concluded that CRIS was largely effective in meeting the Commission's need for information on external actions. 
However, after ten years of development, it still has weaknesses. 
CRIS is the information system set up by the Commission to support the management of external actions. 
The functions of the system have been continuously expanded since its commissioning in 2002. 
It is now the main reference information system for the management and documentation of external actions, including its reporting, and is financed from both the general budget of the EU and the European Development Fund (EDF). 
O European Union Aid to the Turkish Cypriot Community (No 6/2012) - This special report examined whether the Commission developed an assistance programme that was in line with the objectives of the instrument, whether appropriate implementation modalities were established and whether the individual projects achieved their respective deliverables. 
The purpose of the audit was not to assess whether the programme had contributed to achieving the political objective of reunification. 
We found that the programme met its objectives as a financial support instrument for the Turkish Cypriot community and that, despite considerable constraints, it had generally put in place appropriate arrangements. 
Some results have already been achieved, but their sustainability is often questionable and the programme's most comprehensive project could not be built. 
About one third of this amount was examined by the Court using our sample of contracts. o European Union development aid for drinking water and basic sanitation in sub-Saharan Africa (No 13/2012) - This special report examined whether the Commission had managed EU development assistance to improve drinking water and basic sanitation in sub-Saharan Africa in order to achieve effective and sustainable results. 
We found that EU support improved access to drinking water and basic sanitation. 
On the other hand, the needs of the beneficiaries for less than half of the audited projects have been satisfactorily met and the benefits will only be of stock if it is possible to secure non-tax-based revenue. 
Improvements in water and sanitation are crucial for achieving the Millennium Development Goals. 
The supply of clean drinking water and sanitation contributes to economic growth and poverty reduction. 
EU water and sanitation expenditure in the sub-Saharan region for the period 2001-2010 amounted to approximately EUR 1.0 billion; as funding is provided for water and sanitation, but also in other areas of assistance, the Commission has overall allocated a higher amount.

24 RUBRIK OF FINANCIAL COMMUNITY - THE EU AS GLOBAL PARTNER o Contribution of the European Development Fund (EDF) to a sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa (No 17/2012) - This special report examines whether the EDF has made an effective contribution to the sustainability of the road network in sub-Saharan Africa, whether the EDF-supported road infrastructure is sustainable and whether the sustainability of road infrastructure has been effectively promoted by the Commission. 
The audit focused on the technical, financial and institutional sustainability of road infrastructure. 48 programmes have been examined which have been supported since 1995 under the eighth, ninth and tenth EDFs in six partner countries. 
The Court concluded that the Commission's support for a sustainable road network in sub-Saharan Africa is conditionally effective. 
The partner countries visited by the Court do not make sufficient efforts to ensure the sustainability of road infrastructure, which affects roads to varying degrees of premature wear. 
Roads and other transport infrastructures are essential for regional integration, economic growth, social development, effective public administration and security. 
In sub-Saharan Africa, road transport is the main mode of transport for passenger and freight transport, accounting for more than 80 % of the total trade in goods and services, with transport needs increasing rapidly. 
The EU had committed some EUR 7.4 billion of EDF funding in this region over the period 1995-2011. o European Union Rule of Law Assistance to Kosovo (No 18/2012) (see "Complete performance audit"). 
Control of a road in Tanzania 
The Kosovo police and EULEX on the border patrol in Kosovo (c) EULEX, 2011, Photo by Enisa Kasemi In the context of our review of EU rule of law assistance to Kosovo, the Court highlighted for the first time a Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) mission. 
Kosovo is the world's largest per capita recipient of EU financial assistance and the site of the largest civilian crisis management operation ever launched by the Union (EULEX). 
Our Special Report No 18/2012 dealt with the effectiveness of EU assistance to Kosovo in the area of the rule of law. 
The audit focused on the four police, judiciary, customs and anti-corruption sectors. 
We also examined coordination with other donors and the implementation of EULEX. 
The examination of such a complex area was a challenge. 
Four audit visits were carried out in Kosovo. 
Officials from EULEX and the European Commission were interviewed as well as local officials, representatives of the international donor community and civil society organisations. 
The auditors' team examined projects of the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and Stability Instrument projects, as well as monitoring, guidance and advice (MMA) measures implemented by EULEX. 
Meetings were held in Brussels with the Commission, the European External Action Service, the Council Secretariat and NATO. 
In addition, a panel of experts supported the Court. 
We found that EU assistance was not sufficiently effective. 
Although the EU has contributed to capacity building, in particular in the field of customs, the success of assistance in the field of police and justice has been modest. 
The level of organised crime and corruption in Kosovo remains high. 
The judiciary continues to suffer from political influence, inefficiency and lack of transparency and enforcement. 
The limited ability to protect important witnesses within Kosovo and the difficulty of relocating witnesses abroad are significant shortcomings. 
In the words of Gijs de Vries, the ECA member responsible for the report, the Kosovo authorities do not attach sufficient priority to the rule of law and EU assistance should be more effective. 
Francisco de Miguel Rodriguez, head of the audit team, says there is no other place in the world like Kosovo, where so many international donors could be found to provide capacity building in such a small area. 
The Court concluded that EU coordination mechanisms, including coordination with the international community, are in need of improvement. 
Unlike the rest of the Western Balkans, the incentive for possible EU accession in the case of Kosovo is jeopardised by the lack of a common EU position on its independence. 
In terms of communication, this examination took new paths. 
This was the Court's most cited report in 2012: To him, more than 130 articles appeared in print and electronic media. 
In addition, a video was published on the Court's website which summarised the report. 
This was a premiere for the court, reflecting his ambition to reach a wider audience. 
The European Commission and the European External Action Service have accepted the Court's conclusions and recommendations. 
The report was presented to the European Parliament and Council Working Groups. 
Given the importance of its findings, the British House of Lords has decided to deal with the report in detail. 
26 ORGANE, AGENTURES AND SOCIAL INSTRUCTIONS OF THE EU In 2012, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: The administrative expenditure of the EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on staff (salaries and pensions) as well as on buildings, equipment, energy, communication and information technology. 
The total expenditure for 2007-2013 amounts to EUR 55.9 billion, or 5.7 % of the total EU budget. o Effective measures to develop staff at the European Commission (No 10/2012) - This special report examined whether the Commission adapted the evolution of its staff to the needs of the organisation, provided opportunities for its staff development, created an environment that motivated staff to develop their skills and apply them in the workplace. 
The Commission's annual budget for external trainers and teaching material amounted to EUR 26.6 million in 2010. The annual investment in learning and development in 2010 also included 230 000 days of staff to participate in training activities and an equivalent of 310 staff for the management and implementation of training and career development activities. o Have the procedures for producing reliable and credible European statistics improved by the Commission and Eurostat? 
(No 12/2012) - This special report assessed whether the procedures for producing reliable and credible statistics have been improved by the Commission and Eurostat. 
Improvements are directly linked to compliance with the European Statistics Code of Conduct, which sets standards for the development, production and dissemination of statistics, and to the implementation of the European statistical programme. 
There was no assessment of the reliability of specific statistical results. 
We found that the Commission and Eurostat have not yet achieved the full application of the European Statistics Code of Conduct and that Eurostat had not designed the European statistical programme 2008-2012 as an effective planning, monitoring and accountability tool. 
Reliable and credible statistics are crucial for the performance of the tasks entrusted to the European Union. 
Statistics are needed in almost all areas to formulate, apply, monitor and evaluate the tasks and objectives set out in the Treaties. They are also needed for the collection and allocation of EU funds. 
European policy decisions are increasingly based on statistics, and statistical indicators are increasingly used as a trigger for policy decisions or sanctions. o Treatment of conflicts of interest in selected EU agencies (No 15/2012) - This special report assessed whether the selected agencies adequately handled conflicts of interest, whether appropriate policy guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflict of interest situations exist, and whether the selected agencies have adequately implemented their policy guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflict of interest situations. 
The audit assessed the guidelines and procedures for dealing with conflict of interest situations in the case of four selected agencies that make influential decisions affecting the safety and health of consumers. 
The Court concluded that the selected EU agencies did not adequately manage conflicts of interest.

28 IN YEAR 2012 OPINIONS AND Position Papers The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management through its opinions on proposals for new or amended legal acts with financial implications.

29 OPINION No 1/2012 TO THE COMMISSION LEGISLATIVORABILITY FOR THE REFORM OF AGRARPOLICY from 2014 The Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) is to be reformed by 2013. 
In October 2011, the Commission published a proposal setting out the main elements of a legal framework for the CAP for the period 2014-2020. 
The new legal framework proposed to maintain the current two-pillar structure of the CAP and thus the two existing European financial instruments of agricultural policy, namely the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD). 
We recognised the Commission's efforts to simplify the CAP provisions (e.g. waiving the different implementation models for the current single payment scheme, introducing a simplified scheme for small farmers). 
Through its proposals, the Commission has received a number of observations from Parliament, the Council and the Court. 
Nevertheless, the legislative proposals remain essentially focused on expenditure and their control, thus continuing to comply with legislation on performance, contrary to the stated intention. 
We took note of the Commission's objective of preferentially disbursing CAP aid to "active farmers" and its attempt to achieve a more balanced distribution of direct payments among beneficiaries. 
However, the Court doubted that the proposed measures could be implemented effectively without imposing excessive administrative burden on managing authorities and farmers. 
In his view, the solution may consist of a combination of general principles laid down in the Regulation and systematic monitoring and expert monitoring of their implementation by the Commission. 
It noted that the so-called 'coverage' (reduction of aid exceeding a certain ceiling) will have a limited impact on the redistribution of the aid. 
This opinion had a significant impact on the reflections on the future of the CAP. 
More than 2,000 articles have been published on this topic in the media. 
The Court has been invited by numerous NGOs, organisers of agricultural fairs and other industry forums to present the opinion to the respective audience. The European Parliament invites representatives of the Court to participate in working groups on this subject. 
Members of the European Parliament have included most of the recommendations in their own proposals for legislative amendments. 
The legislative package will be voted after the adoption of the Multiannual Financial Framework. 
30 SUMMARY WITH OTHER OVEREST Audit Institutions The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) mainly in the following bodies: O Contact Committee of the SAIs of EU Member States; O Network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; O international organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its European Regional Group (EUROSAI).

31 According to the EU Treaty, the Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies cooperate with confidence while respecting their independence. 
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of EU Member States within the Contact Committee. 
In the Contact Committee, the Presidents of the EU-ORKB and the Court meet once a year. 
Working groups and task forces have been set up to support the development of common positions and practices. 
In 2012, the Court supported the Chair-in-Office of the Contact Committee (ORKB of Portugal) in preparing and holding the 2012 annual meeting held in Estoril, Portugal, on 18 and 19 October 2012. 
The meeting had two main topics, namely the challenges for the SAIs in preparing for the next EU financial framework (2014-2020), as well as recent developments in responses to the financial crisis and the SAIs' experience with appropriate audits. 
At the meeting, the Contact Committee decided to set up a Task Force to analyse the tasks and role of SAIs, taking into account recent developments in the EU in building a new economic, budgetary and financial architecture and the potential impact on SAIs. 
The Court is a member of this Task Force, which is expected to report to the Contact Committee in 2013. 
We also provided administrative support to the Contact Committee in 2012 and actively participated in the various working groups and networks. 
In 2012, the Court also supported the initiative of the SAIs of the euro area with a view to ensuring adequate external public financial control of the European Stability Mechanism. 
A common position on a proposal for the Statute concerning Article 30 of the Treaty establishing the Mechanism was submitted to the Secretary-General of the Council of the European Union in April 2012. 
The final version of the Statutes is broadly in line with this common position with regard to the Audit Committee. 
32 NETC OF THE OVEREST Audit Institutions of the Supervisors and the POTENCIAL Surveillance Authorities The Court cooperates with the SAIs of the Candidate Countries and the potential candidate countries. 
One of the most important tools for cooperation is the network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries1 with its organisational structure comparable to the Contact Committee. 
This network includes regular meetings of the SAI presidents and liaison officers, as well as working groups, seminars, workshops and parallel audits. 
In 2012, the Court supported the implementation of the work programme, which is part of the Istanbul Memorandum of Understanding adopted at the meeting of the Presidents of the Network in March 2011.

34 OUR MANAGEMENT OUTLOOK: A TRATEGY FOR THE TIME 2013-2017 The Court adopted and published its strategy for the period 2013-2017 in 2012. 
The Court's objective for this period is to maximise the value of the Court's contribution to the EU's public accountability. 
The main priorities for achieving this objective are: O Orientation of the Court's products towards improving the EU accountability; O Cooperation with other actors to strengthen the Court's contribution to the EU accounting obligation; O Further development as a professional audit body; O optimal use of the farm's existing knowledge, expertise and expertise; O Evidence of the Court's performance and the performance of its accountability. 
The Court will use its unique powers and perspective, as well as its knowledge, expertise and partnerships built up during the 35 years of its existence, to make a positive contribution to future developments in the field of EU policy and financial management; O to support the other parties involved in the accountability process at EU level in identifying the risks to EU accountability and making easier use of audit results; strengthen its professionalism by contributing to the development and application of new audit standards and best practices; O further streamline the processes for drawing up its reports and opinions; O to improve its performance and the accountability framework in line with its obligations as an EU institution and SAI; O to implement budgetary discipline measures in accordance with the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, including any necessary staffing cuts during the period of application of this strategy. 
For the period 2013-2017, the Court will focus on the following aspects of our reports, opinions and comments: O Strengthen public accountability and audit arrangements; O Improving financial management and reporting on the implementation of the EU budget and its impact; O Improved design of EU policies and spending programmes. 
In accordance with the contract, the term of office of the members of the Court is six years and a reappointment is possible. 
In 2012, five new members of the Court were appointed: Henrik Otbo (Denmark), Pietro Russo (Italy), Ville Itälä (Finland), Kevin Cardiff (Ireland) and Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain). 
In February 2012, the Court adopted a new Code of Conduct for Members, taking into account the changes that have occurred since the previous Code was adopted eight years ago. 
In addition, the Court now publishes the declarations of interest of its members on its website, which significantly contributes to transparency. 35 
36 MESSDATA FOR PERFORMANCE OF THE HOUSE OF THE STRATEGY 2009-2012 In 2008, the Court published its first strategy. 
This strategy was applicable for the period 2009-2012 and aimed to maximise the impact of the Court's audits and to increase efficiency through the best use of resources. 
Overall, the Court successfully implemented its 2009-2012 strategy. 
The Court's recommendations were largely accepted: According to the Commission, around half of the recommendations made in 2011 were implemented. The main institutional addressees of the Court are satisfied with its annual and special reports, the quality of which is considered good and improved by external experts. In addition, efficiency gains allowed us to increase the number of staff in the audit chambers by 60 (501 in 2008 compared to 564 in 2011) and reduced the number of administrative and translation staff by 40. 
For the 2009-2012 strategy period, we set out a number of key performance indicators for the following purposes: O to inform management of progress in the implementation of the objectives; O to support the decision-making process; O to provide performance-related information to the addressee. 
The key performance indicators are used to measure core parameters of the quality and impact of the Court's work, paying particular attention to the point of view of key addressees and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources. 
Since 2012 was the last year of the strategy period 2009-2012, the results of the key performance indicators will be presented, where available, for every four years. 
The Court will update the key performance indicators to be applied during the 2013-2017 strategy period, so that they reflect its new or revised priorities and demonstrate its performance and accountability as a professional audit body. 
Quality AND ECONOMIC OF THE WORK OF THE HOFES The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of assessments by the addressees and expert reviews. 
By means of a survey, the Court asked the main addressees of our reports (the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and the Council Committee on Budgets) to assess the quality and impact of the 2011 annual reports and the special reports published in 2012. 
The assessment was made on a five-step scale (1 - very poor, 2 - poor, 3 - appropriate, 4 - good, 5 - very good).

The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources on the basis of the extent to which it is able to present reports and audit findings on time, to fulfil its financial management obligations and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its staff.

Punctuality OF audit findings The Court uses audit reports to confirm the factual accuracy of the specific audit findings by the audited bodies. 
Audit notifications are therefore an important stage in the audit process. 
According to the Court's internal rules, audit notifications should be drawn up within two months of the relevant audit visit, measuring annually to what extent this deadline has been met.

The result for this indicator was between 27 % and 61 % in the period 2008-2012. 
Although performance improved significantly and the annual targets were largely met, the result in 2012 is still below the long-term target of 80 %. 
The Court will continue to strive to achieve even better performance in this area. 41

54 35 YEARS IN THE SERVICE OF A Better FUNCTION OF THE EU The European Court of Auditors has been the external auditor of the EU for 35 years. It shall continuously add value to the financial management of the Union and ensure public accountability for the use of taxpayers' money. 
The Court was founded at a time when the European Community (the forerunner of the European Union) moved towards more democracy and became more accountable to its citizens. 
Two particularly important steps were the enlargement of the European Parliament's budgetary control powers and the full financing of the European Community budget from its own resources. 
The Community recognised that it needed an independent external auditor who assisted Parliament and the Council in ensuring democratic control of finances. 
Heinrich Aigner, Chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, who since 1973 strongly supported an external audit body at Community level, launched the initiative which led to the establishment of the European Court of Auditors by the Treaty of Brussels on 22 July 1975. 
The Court started its operations in October 1977, with its head office in Luxembourg. 
Hans Kutscher, then President of the Court, recognised the Court as a financial conscience of the Community. 
With the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty on 1 November 1993, the Court obtained the status of a fully-fledged European institution, thus guaranteeing its independence and authority as an equivalent body. 
The Maastricht Treaty also introduced what is now a core product of the Court, namely the Declaration of Assurance (DAS) on the EU accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts. 
The Court's role was strengthened with the entry into force of the Treaty of Amsterdam on 1 May 1999, which strengthened the Court's independence and extended its audit powers to other policy areas. 
The Nice Treaty of 1 February 2003 confirmed the principle that the Court should be a member of each Member State. In addition, the importance of the Court's cooperation with national audit bodies has been emphasised and the Court has been given the opportunity to establish a chamber structure. 
Since its establishment, the Court has consistently promoted cooperation with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States in the audit of EU funds, in particular through its participation in the Contact Committee of the EU-ORKB Presidents. 
In its role as SAI, the Court has also sought to help shape forward developments in public sector audit by working with other SAIs in the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and its EUROSAI regional group to define technical standards and best practices. 
The Court recognised early on the peer review process as a tool for developing and disseminating best practices within the SAI Community. 
During its 35th anniversary, the Court sought to contribute to the improvement of EU financial management by presenting high-quality products reflecting the EU's developments and the changing needs of its addressees. 
Over the past 35 years, the EU has added new Member States, gained new powers and created new bodies at EU level, all of which had to be taken into account by the Court in its work. 
As a result, the Court's output increased significantly compared to the two opinions we issued in the first year of its activity. 
The Court's products today include annual reports, special reports, statements of assurance, special annual reports, opinions and position papers. 
The number of outputs increased to 87 publications in 2012. 
For several years, the Court has given a higher priority to the audit of the results achieved in the implementation of EU policies and the provision of indications to improve profitability. 
Like the EU, the Court has developed further. 
Based on nine members and 120 employees in 1977, the Court now has 27 members and almost 900 employees. 
Like the Union itself, the Court's success depends on close cooperation between members and staff from all European countries. 
The Court is proud that since 1977 it has been able to build a dedicated, professional and experienced staff that is committed to protecting the financial interests of citizens. 
In the coming years, the Court will devote itself to contributing to improving accountability for the funds allocated to citizens to meet the objectives.

In memory of our colleague Henrik Otbo, Member of the Court, who died unexpectedly on 1 February 2015 Henrik Otbo was born in 1949 and had Danish citizenship. 
From 1995 to 2012, he was President of the Danish Court of Auditors and, since 1 March 2012, Member of the European Court of Auditors in the CEADChamber("Coordination, Evaluation, Quality Assurance and Development") with special responsibility foraudit development and evaluation. 
His lifelong commitment to the service of public financial control, in particular his leading role in the creation of international standards for Supreme Audit Institutions as Chair of the Committee on TechnicalStandards of INTOSAI, were particularly valuable to the Court, its former colleagues at the Danish Court of Auditors and the audit sector as a whole. 
01 European Court of Auditors 02 Mandate The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing EU financesunderthe Treaty. 
As an EU external auditor, he contributes to improving EU financialmanagement, promotes accountability and transparency, and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens. 
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism and the quality and impact of its work,providing valuable support to its audience in order to improve EU financial management. 
Values Independence, integrity and impartiality Professionalism Value Excellence and efficiency Independence, integrity and impartiality of the institution, its members and its employees. 
Impartial audit, which, while taking into account the positions of the Court's addressees, rejects any form of influencing byinstructions or external pressure. 
Maintaining an exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work. 
Active participation in the further development ofpublic financial control at EU and worldwide level. 
Preparation of relevant and timely high quality reports based on sound findings and evidence,taking into account the concerns of its adrenaline and containing important and forward-looking statements. 
To contribute to an effective improvement of the EU financial management and to contribute to strengthening theaccounting obligation for the EUfinancial management. 
Promoting teamspirit through effective communication.

Foreword by President 04 Dear reader, 2014 was a year of profound change for the EU and its finances. 
The EU entrusted the European Central Bank with responsibility to supervise the large banks in theeuroarea. 
It was the first year of the new multiannualfinancial framework relevant tothe implementation of the EU budget for the period 2014-2020. 
Also of particular importance were the re-election of Members of the European Parliament and the renewal of top positions in the Council and the European Commission. The European Court of Auditors (ECA) also welcomed six new members. 
In 2014, our institution produced 91 reports, comments and other products - more than ever before. 
They are the result of our audits ofaccounting,complianceaudits andprofitability audits, including auditsfalling within the scope of our new responsibilities in terms of fiscal and economic governance. 
They contain numerous important findings, conclusions and recommendations on improving the EU's financial management and accountability during the 2014-2020 programming period. 
Some of its key statements can befound in the present annual activity report. 
On the basis of our audit experience,we also aim to provide our addressees with as much insight as possible on the key issues facing the EU in the financial and implementation of its policies. 
To this end - and as a contribution to thisperiod of innovation - we introduced a new product in 2014, the so-called "Landscape analyses". 
In addition, at the request of the European Parliament, we have published an overview of the resultsofour accounting and compliance auditsin the agricultural andcohesion sectorsof the period 2009 -2013. 
The Court is also committed to working with its addressees to ensure that the addressees can make the most of the results of their work. 
In 2014, the Court appointed a member responsible for institutional relations and a spokesperson. 
It also organised a number of events to provide anopportunity to exchange views with high-level stakeholders from the EU and the Member States. 
This conference brought together a large number of people in charge of managing and controllingEUfunds, including Members of the European Parliament, the European Commission, SupremeAudit Institutions and representatives of science. 
The Vice- President of the European Parliament andformer EU Commissioner Olli Rehn gave an introductory speech. 
Particular attention should also be paid to the visit of a delegation of Members of the Court to Lithuania, where meetings were held with Members of Parliament, members of the Government and representatives of the National Court of Auditors and the Lithuanian Central Bank. 
President's foreword 05 Throughout the year, our 2013-2017strategy has pioneered our work and the steps taken to reform our institution. 
In 2014, we reduced the average time needed to prepare our special reports, and we reduced the number of our staff, as required by an interinstitutional agreement. 
We also set up the fundamen for future efficiencyand effectiveness gains by introducing an internal reform project. 
This project coordinates the implementation of the recommendations of internal working groups as well as the recommendations from the independent external peer review on the practice of our performance audit and from theEuropean Parliament's report on the future role of the Court. 
The Court is based in Luxembourg, butour teams travel as part of their work to obtain audit evidence wherever EUfunds are spent. 
This activity report provides an overview of the audit visits and the firstreports by us. 
A special highlight will be given to our assessment oftheEU support for European airport infrastructure. 
It is an illustrative example ofour performance audits to assess the impact and added value of EUfundingand shows the Court's efforts to fulfil its mission. 
In addition, this audit demonstrates the commitment and professionalismof the Court's partners, whose expertise and commitment can always be relied upon by the Court and the citizens in whose interests it acts. 
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President

Our activities 07 Audit reports and other products The three main products of the European Courtof Auditors are: • Annual reports - with the results ofits accounts and complianceaudits on the budget of the European Union and on the European Development Fund (EDF). 
In addition, there are separate published specificannual reports on the EU Agencies, Decentralised Entities and Joint Undertakings. • Special reports - which can be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits on specific budgetary areas or management topics. 
These are essentially economic audits. • Opinions - on new or amended acts affecting the financialsituation and other analytical products produced either at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative. 
In 2014, the Court produced more products than ever before and also presented new products. 
Many analytical information can still be found on the annual basis. They also provide a comprehensive presentation of the results of our annual accountingandcomplianceaudits. 
In 2014, there was a strongerfocus on performance audits, providingtheEU budgetary authority with additional insights on the quality of the implementation ofthe EU Household Plan. 
In addition to the annual reports, we published for the first time a summary of our audit results on agriculture and cohesion expenditureunder shared management over the period 2009-2013 to provide a multi-annual perspective. 
The important development was a new product called landscape analysis. 
In Landscape-Ana- lysen, information and analysis on central topics are presented based on our expertise in the area of examination. 
In 2014, we published twolandscapeanalyses: The first focuses on the main challenges facing the EU,plus accountability and public financial control; the secondfocuses on the risks to the EU's financial management.

Our activities 08 audit visits in 2014 While most of the audit work takes place at our premises in Luxembourg, our auditors also carry out audit visits tothe authorities of the Member States, other recipients of EUfunds (including at the headquarters of international organisations such as the World Health Organisation in Switzerland) and the EU agencies and bodies. 
The purpose of these visits is to obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the authorisation, management and disbursement of EUfunds, as well as from the respective final recipients. 
Our audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the duration of an audit visit is a few days up to two weeks, depending on the type of audit and distance. 
Within the EU, our audit visitsare often carried out in consultation with the SupremeAudit Authorities of the Member States visited. 
The frequency and intensity of audit work inthe individual Member States and beneficiary countries depends on the type of audit and the results ofthe sample selection. 
The number and duration of audit visits may therefore vary by country and year to year. 
In 2014, the Court's auditors spent 4 915 days of on-the-spot audits in Member States and outside the EU and obtained audit evidence for the annual reports and the selected audit tasks (son-of-the-reports). 
They also spent some time with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralised agencies and bodies across the EU. 
In 2014, our auditors used fewer days for on-siteaudits than in previous years. 
This is due to more efficient working methods and an increasing use of technologies such as the use of videoconferencing. 
The EUauditors used EUauditors to audit installations for maritime transport.

Our activities 10 Annual Report on the implementation oftheEU budget for the financial year 2013 The majority of ourauditson accounting and compliance audits were devoted to the implementation of theEUbudget for 2013. 
The 2013 Annual Report, which emerged from this work, was published on 5 November 2014 and presented to our addressees, including the European Parliament and its Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the EU (Economic and Financial Affairs Council), national parliaments and governments, and the media.
The aim of the annual report is to support the European Parliament, the Council and citizens in assessing the quality of the EU'sfinancial management by presenting findings and conclusions. 
The key element of the 2013 annual report is the 20th Annual Statement of Assurance ("DAS") on the reliability of the EUaccountsand the regularity of the underlying transactions. 
That report provided even more information on the profitability of EU spending and on the Commission's performance reporting. 
Estimated level of error for theEUbudget: 4.7 % President Caldeira handed over the 2013 annual report to the President of the European Parliament, Martin Schulz. 
Our activities 11 The key statements of the 2013 Annual Report ? The Court delivered an unrestricted opinion on the reliability of the 2013 accounts of the European Union. 
The revenue for 2013 was overall legal and orderly; this also applies to commitments. ? Payments for 2013 were materially affected by errors. 
Therefore, the Court delivered a failed opinion on its legality and regularity. 
This figure is close to the error rate for 2012 (4.8 %) and is consistently above the materiality threshold of 2 %. ? Most error-prone were the two spending areas of regional policy, transport and energy with anestimated error rate of 6.9 % and rural development, environment, fisheries and health with an estimated error rate of 6.7 %. 
In total shared management, the estimated level of error was 5.2 %. ? Overall, the monitoring and control systems examined, with significant divergences between Member States, ensured the regularity of payments in a conditional manner. 
As in 2012, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before requesting reimbursement from the Commission. ? corrective measures and recoveries by Member States' authorities and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate. 
In the absence of these measures, the estimated overall budget would have been 6.3 %. ? The use of EUfunds in the 2007-2013 programming period wasdue to absorption (use it or loose it) and compliance with legislation rather thangood performance. 
This lack of focus on performance is a key weakness in the way a large part of the EUbudget is built up.
