Our activities 13 Agriculture and Cohesion: In parallel to the annual reports, theCourt published a backgrounddocument for the first time - in 23 official EU languages - to provide a multi-annual perspective on the underlying findings of the statement of assurancein the two main expenditureareas of agriculture and cohesion. 
It drew lessons onissues encountered in the past spending period in EU financial management and control, summarised audit results and highlighted challenges related to the new spending period 2014-2020. 
In addition, this overview was in line with the European Parliament's wish to receive country-specific information on shared management. The core statements: ? In addition to direct aid and market support measures for farmers in the field of agriculture, the pressure to use the funds is a key aspect of the risk of expenditure under shared management. ? The main risks to the regularity of agricultural expenditure are that the areas or animals or the costs on which the aid payments are based are not eligible, the beneficiaries of aiddo not comply with the advances set for it and the aid is not correctly calculated. 
Non-compliancewith agri-environmental requirements, specific requirements for investment projects and procurement rules are important factors that increase the risk of rural development expenditure. ? The biggest risk of cohesion spending is breaches of EUand /or national public procurement rules. 
The second largest risk is that expenditure (or projects) are noteligiblefor EU funding. ? Although control systems require significant improvement, the main challenge is to take action to simplify the management of programmes. 
The Court notes errors in all EU Member States. 
Many errors have occurred due to the complexity of the overall management and control architecture. ? Despite improvements in the reporting of risks and errors by Member States' authorities, it remains very difficult for the Commission to ensure the reliability of this information. ? The amendments to the Regulations for the new programming period may not have asignificant impact on the level of risk. 
Our activities 14 Annual Report on the European Development Funds for 2013 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are funded by theEUMember States. They are subject to their own financial rules and are managed outside the general budget of the EU. 
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management ofEDF-funded actions. 
Under the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs)onthe basis of the CotonouAgreement of 2000. 
Expenditure is aimed atcurbing and finally eradicating poverty, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of ACP countries and OCTs into the world economy. 
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars, namelydevelopment cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension. 
The Court's 2013 annual report on the EDFs became paral- lel to the annual report on the EUbudget on 5. Novem- ber 2014 published. 
It contains the 20th. Declarationof assurance on the EDFs. 
We found that the 2013 accounts represent the assetsand financial position of the EDFs, the results of their operations and cash flows and the changes in net assets as a whole. 
The Court estimated the error rate for EDF expenditure operations for the financial year 2013 at 3.4 %, representing an increase of 3.0 % comparedto 2012. 
Special Annual Reports for the financial year 2013 In 2014, the Court produced and published51 separate annual reports responsible for the financial year 2013. 
The reports covered the 41 decentralised bodies, executive agencies and agencies of the EU, the seven EU Joint Undertakings active in the field of research, as well as the European Central Bank, the European Schools and theSisnet Communication Infrastructure. 
The Court also published twosummaries with an overview of the results ofits annual audits for the financial year 2013 - one on the EU agencies and other bodies, the second on the Community'sresearch activities. 
These two analytical and comparative summaries were presented to the President of the European Parliament, the Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets.
Together with the special annual reports, these summaries are available on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu). 
The EU Agencies, Bodies and Joint Undertakings are drawn up on the basis of EU legal acts to carry out specific tasks. Its seats are located throughout the European Union. 
They are active in many areas, such assafety, health, research, finance, migration and travel. 
They all have a mandate, a management board, a director, staff and a budget. 
While the agencies, bodies and joint undertakings, in relation to the EUbudgetas a whole, pose a relatively low financial risk, the Union's reputational risk is high, as they are clearly visible in the Member States and have a significant impact on policy governance, decision-making and programme implementation in areas of paramount importance for European citizens.

Our activities 15 We gave the 41 Agencies and other directionsunrestricted audit opinions on thereliability of the 2013 accounts. 
The transactions underlying these accounts were legal and orderly for all agencies and other bodies, except for two in allmaterial respects. For the EIT (European Institute ofInnovation and Technology) and Frontex (European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union), the Courtissued a limited audit opinion. 
In addition, the 2013 accounts were reliable for all seven Joint Undertakings, but the Court issued a limited opinion on the legalityand regularity of the transactions underlying their annual accounts for threecompanies: for Artemis (embeddedICTsystems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and IMI (Innovative Medicines Initiative). 
As regards the European Schools, the Court was not in a position to conclude whether the conso-coveredfinancial statements for 2013 were free from material misrepresentation, as the schools continue to haveaccounting and control deficiencies. 
We examined the European Central Bank's handlingof its carbon footprintand noted that while the Bank has taken action to reduce the negative impact of its management on the environment, further efforts and measures are needed. 
In addition to its annual reports and special annual reports, the Court publishes special reports throughout the year containing the results of its economic performanceand compliance audits onspecific budgetary areas or management issues of its choice. 
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court is keen to achieve maximum impact and thusmake the most of its resources. 
In the selection of topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: • the risks of irregularity oreconomic efficiency in the expenditure or policy area; • the potential to achieve added value in the course of an audit by the Court; • political and public interest. 24 special reports in 2014

Our activities 17 Intelligent and inclusive growth Smart and inclusive growth covers two areas: Competitiveness for growth and jobs includes funding for research and innovation, education and training, trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, social policy, business development, etc. The EU's contribution to growth and jobs for the period 2014-2020amounts to 142 billion euro and 13 % of thetotal EU budget, at current prices. 
Economic, social and territorial cohesion includes regional policy aimed athelping the EU's most developed countries and regions to connect with the rest. The aim is to strengthen the competitiveness of all regions and developcooperation between them. 
The EUbudget earmarkedfor cohesion for the period 2014-2020amounts to EUR 367 billion, or 34 % of the EU'stotal budget, at current prices. 
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of EU-fundedpublic transport projects (No 1/2014) - In this special report, we assessed the implementation and effectiveness of projects co-financed by EUStructuralFunds in the field of public transport in order to determine whether the projects corresponded to users' needs and achieved their objectives. 
The audit found that two thirds of EUstructural funds co-financed local transport projects were insufficiently used. 
This development was primarily caused by weaknesses in project design and an inadequate mobility policy. 
However, this inadequacy was generally not pursued by project promoters or national authorities. 
As a rule, infrastructure and vehicles have been set up for most projects in accordance with the project specifications. 
Significant delays and costswere identified, but after completion, almost all audited projects corresponded to the needs of users. 
European cities need to improve mobility through localmobi strategies and reduce congestion, accidents and pollution. 
The co-financed projects provided support to cities in setting up local transport systems suchasunderground trains, trams and buses. 
Trams and buses are important means of transportof public transport. 
Our activities 18 • Have we achieved good results from the Cohesion Policy Funds to support renewable energy production? 
(No 6/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined whether the two main sourcesof financing for the promotion of renewable energy - the European RegionalDevelopment Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF) - had achieved good results. To this end, it was examined whether the funds had been allocated appropriately prioritised, cost-effective and mature renewable energy production projects during this period with meaningful objectives and to what extentgood results have been achieved with the help of these funds, which contributed to the achievement of the EU 2020 renewable energy target. 
The audit found that there is aneed for the EU'sfinancial resourcesto contribute as much as possible to the achievement ofthe objective. 
The audited projects delivered the outputs as planned and most projects were sufficiently mature and ready for implementation at the time of their selection. 
There were neither significant cost overruns nor major delays, and renewable energy generation capacity was installed as planned and operational as planned. 
However, the results in terms of energy production have not always been achieved or not measured properly. 
Overall, the use of funds was limited as cost-effectiveness in the planning and implementation of projects was not the guiding principle and expenditurehad limited EU added value. 
The Council of the EU has set a binding EUtarget of 20 % for the share of renewable energy in grossfinal energy consumption by 2020. 
For renewable energies,around EUR 4.7 million from the ERDF and CF was earmarked for the period 2007-2013. • Has the ERDF been successful in supportingthe development of incubators? 
(No. 7/2014) - In this special report, the Court analysed whether the incubators co-financed by the ERDF hadsuccessfully supported start-upswith great growth potential. 
The audit found that the EU made a significant financial contribution to the creation of an infrastructure of incubators, especially in Member States where this type of business support is relatively rare. 
However, the performance of the audited incubators left much to be desired. 
The provision of start-up services was rather limited due to the financial constraints and the limited scope of start-up-related activities. 
This situation was mainly due to lack of expertise in start-up support procedures and poor administrative systems. 
Incubators pursue the goal of supporting new companies in their successful start-up and further development. 
Support to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has become an ever- increasing politicalpriority over time. 
During the period 2007-2013, EU spending in this area amounted to EUR 38 billion. 
The'Delta' building co-financed by ERDF in theWroclaw Technology Park.
Our activities 19 • Is the ERDF effective in funding projects for the direct promotion of biodiversity undertheEU Biodiversity Strategy for 2020? 
(No 12/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined whether the ERDFfunding available for the direct promotion of biodiversity was used by Member States. 
The audit showed that Member States are lagging behind when using ERDFfunding to finance projects compared to otherERDF spending areas. 
In order to ensure that the ERDF can continue to be useful for the implementation of the EU strategy to reduce biodiversity loss by 2020, the Commission should step up its support to Member States in implementing specific protection and management plans for natural habitats and species.
The co-financed projects were generallyconsistent with biodiversity priorities set at national and EU level. 
However, the assessment of the effectiveness of these projects was affected by the fact that most Member States did not add anyresult indicators or monitoring systems to assess theevolution of natural habitats and species. 
Biodiversity protection is one of the EU's main priorities. 
The Council approved a new strategy for 2020 after the previous objective of curbing the loss of biodiversity in Europe by 2010 was missed. The direct promotion of biodiversity and nature protection was allocated toERDF resources of EUR 2.8 billion during the 2007-2013programming period. • Has the ERDF support beeneffective for SMEs in the field of e-commerce? 
(No 20/2014) - In this special report, we assessed whether the operational programmes provided a good basis for efficient support for e-commerceactivities for SMEs, whether the managing authorities properly selectedand monitored E-Com merce projects, and whether the ERDF co-financede-commerce projectshad been successfully implemented and provided measurable benefits. 
We found that the support provided by the ERDF to SMEs in the field ofe-commerce - purchasing and selling goods via the internet - helpedto increase the onlineavailabilityof services. 
However, due to shortcomings in monitoring, it was impossible to assess the extent to which ERDF supportcontributed to the achievement of the IT objectives of the Member States and the EU. 
Insufficient selection procedures in the Member States have the consequence that a good cost-cutting ratio is untrue for many projects. 
Programme managers focused more on the use of funds (outputs) than on achieving results. 
The Commission is promoting e-commerce through its Digi- tale Agenda for Europe. Under the ERDFbudget, EUR 3 billion of EU funds were allocated for better ICTuseby SMEs in the period 2007-2013. Court's video on Special Report No 20/2014 "Is the ERDF effective in financing projects for the direct promotion of biodiversity undertheEU Biodiversity Strategy for 2020?" - EUauditorsECA on Youtube. 
Our activities 20 Close-up of a performance audit: EU-funded airport infrastructure - insufficient cost-benefit ratio(No 21/2014) Closed part of the oversized terminal at Fuerteventura Airport. 
Although the EU's aviation policy is aimed at overcoming capacity problems - by building additional infrastructures, making better use of existing structures, optimising services at the airport and better connectivity to other modes of transport - Europe will not be able to meet a large part of this demand because of the lack of rollercoasters and ground infrastructure. 
In Europe, there are more than 500 commercial airports, where one million people are directly or indirectly employed and, together with Fluglinien, contribute more than EUR 140 billion to European economic performance. 
Airport-related infrastructure projects are a significant expenditure area of theEU budget: In the 2000-2013programming period, the EU allocated around EUR 4.5 billion to projects of this kind, of which more than EUR 2.8 billion was allocated from cohesion policy funds. 
As part of its performance audit of this support, the Court examined whetherinvestments were needed wisely, whether the respective time andcost limits were respected for the construction projects and whether the newly built or modernised infrastructures were fully used. 
The Court assessed whether the investments resulted in higher passenger numbers and improved customer service and whether the supported airports were financially viable. 
The auditors carried out their work between May 2013 and October 2014. The focus was on 20 EU-funded airports in Estonia, Greece, Italy, Poland and Spain. 
A total of more than EUR 600 million wasallocated to these airports in the period 2000-2013. 
The team carried out an examination of the relevant legislation, air transport planning in the five Member Statesandof the main interbranch organisations. 
In particular, the auditors carried out visits to the 20 airports in order to assess and obtain direct evidence of EUoutputs, uses, results and impacts and the economic situation of airports. 
The Court concluded that the cost-benefitratio of EU-fundedinvestments for airportswas not correct. 
Too many airports, often close to each other, received financial support for similar infrastructures, and in many cases it turned out that these infrastructures were oversized. 
Only half of the airports audited managed to increase their passenger numbers. 
Improvements in customer service or regional socio-economic benefits, such as the creation of additional jobs, were notmeasured or no evidence was available.
The audit also found that seven of the airports were not financially self-sustaining and will have difficulties to remain operational without further public support. 
At most airports, the auditors' team noted significant delays in the construction and provision of infrastructure. 
At almost half of the airports, costs were exceeded and Member States had to contributealmost 100 million euros more from their national budgets than originally planned. 
Our activities 21 The funding was not well coordinated by the Member States: In most countries, there was nolong -term plan for airport development. 
In addition, the Commission supervised the financing. In general, it is not known which airports receive funding or what amounts it is about. 
As a result, it does not have a full picture of all EUinvestmentsfor airports and has limited opportunities to monitor and ensure that strategies are properly designed and implemented. 
On the basis of these findings, the Court recommended to the Commissionto ensure, from the 2014-2020 programming period, that Member States apply EU fundsonly to airport infrastructures thatare financially viable and whose investment needs have been adequately assessed and proven.
A further recommendation was that coherent airport expansion plans should be available in the Member States at regional, national and supranational level in order toavoid overcapacity, duplication and uncoordinated investments in airport infrastructure. 
In its reply, the Commission has assured that lessons have been learned from these experiences. 
As a result, it has ensured thata fundamentally different approach is applied in the relevant legislation for the 2014-2020 programming period. 
The report was presented to the European Parliament, which fully supports the Court's conclusions and recommendations. 
The publication of the report attracted great media interest. 
The media reaction was the biggest in Spain, but also included headlines in important international newspapers, television and social media coverage. 
From left to right: Afonso de Castro Malheiro, Jasmine Mitterbuchner, Patrick Weldon, Mircea Radulescu, Pietro Puricella, Joël Costantzer, George Pufan (Member of the Court responsible for the report), Fernando Pascual Gil, Luc T'Joen, Tomasz Plebanowicz, Lorenzo Pirelli, Efstratios Varetidis, Jelena Magermane, Erki Must. 
Our activities 22 Sustainable growth: natural resources The EU has a high political responsibility in the areas of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. 
The planned budget for the period 2014-2020 amounts to EUR 420 billion, or 39 % of the EU'stotal budget, at current prices. 
Three quarters of the expenditure concerns direct payments to farmers and support to agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) - the "first pillar" of the common agricultural policy (CAP). 
Another fifth of the expenditure comes fromtheEU support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the 'second pillar' of the CAP. 
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States. 
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Integration of the objectives of theEUwater policy into the CAP: a partial success (No 4/2014) - In this special report, we assessed whether the objectives of the EUwater policy were successfully integrated into the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP). 
The audit showed that the EU can only have a partial success in integrating the objectives of water policy into the CAP. 
The two water-related integration tools (cross-compliance and rural development) have shortcomings and the implementation of the Water Framework Directive ischaracterised by delays and weaknesses.
The CAPinstruments have so far had a positive impact on supporting the policy objectivesof water supplyand quality. 
However, these instruments are limited compared to the ambitious objectives of the CAP. 
For example, neither of these two instruments allows full application of the polluter pays principle in the allocation ofCAP funding. 
Moreover, at EUinstitutionsand in the Member States, there is insufficient knowledge of the pressures on water resources caused by agricultural activities and the developments in these burdens. 
The EU places high priority on the protection of European waterresources. 
Agriculture as one of the largest consumers and polluters of water resources plays a key role in sustainable water management. 
Almost 40 % of the EU'sbudget will be allocated to the CAP (over EUR 50 billion for 2014). The EU is working under theCAP to influence agricultural practices affecting water resources. 
Our activities 23 • Has the Commissioneffectively managed the inclusion of coupled support in the single payment scheme? 
(No 8/2014) - In this special report, we assessed how well the Commission managed, following the 2008 CAP health check, the inclusion of EU support linked to production volumes (e.g. managed land or livestocknumbers) in the single payment scheme. 
The audit showed that during the2010-2012 period theCommission did not adequately monitor how Member States calculated farmers' entitlements toEUsupport payments for agricultural holdings under thedrive payment scheme. 
While most Member States had correctly used farmers' reference data, there were serious shortcomings in the correct application of the calculation rules andprinciples. 
The Commission did not use its mandate to ensure that the criteria for the allocation of available support were always in line with the EUprinciples, that they complied with the principle of soundfinancial management and had no potential impact on market conditions. 
In the framework established by the Commission, it was not clear enough for Member States to carry out controls and Member States' control systems were of varying quality. The main objective of the single payment scheme was to shift the focus of the CAP from market support to decoupled income support for farmers: Farmers shouldbe able to adapt their production to market demand and their incomeshould be stabilised. 
The so far introduced single payment scheme in 18 Member States accounts for 54 % of the total EUbudgetfor agriculture and rural development. • Is the EU's support for investmentand promotion in the wine sector well managed and there is evidence of results for the competitiveness of theEU wines? 
(No 9/2014) - In this special report, we assessed whether investmentand promotion measures were appropriately designed. We also examined the available monitoringand evaluation data in order to assess whether the Commission and the Member States achieved the desired results in an efficient manner. 
The audit found that the managementof support for investment and promotion in the wine sector was affected bydesign and implementation deficiencies and that impacts on the competitiveness ofEU wines could not always be demonstrated. 
The specific investment measure targeting the wine sector is not justified as support is alreadyprovidedunder the EU rural development policy. 
EUsupport for the promotion of wines was often more likely to consolidate existing markets than to open up new markets or recapture old markets. 
The impact of the investment measure cannot easily be separated from rural development investments. 
The EU is the world's largest wine producer. 
The EU's support is intended to ensure competitivenessand a better balance between supply and demand. 
Member States spent EUR522 million in EU funding in 2009-2013 for the promotion measure and EUR 518 million for the investment measure. 
For 2014-2018, the resources allocated to Member States under this measure have increased significantly. 
Our activities 24 • Effectiveness of support for aquaculture provided by the European FisheriesFund (EFF) (No 10/2014) - In this specialreport, the Court assessed whether the aquaculture support measures were well designed and implemented at EU and Member State level and whether the EFF achieved a reasonable cost-benefitratioand supported the sustainable developmentof aqua culture. 
The audit found that by 2013 the measuresto support aquaculture were not well designed and implemented at EU and Member State level, that the EFF did not achieve an adequate cost-benefit ratioand that the sustainable development of aquaculture was not effectively supported. 
The current framework was not suitable forconcrete implementation of the EU's objectives for the post-containing development of aquaculture and the results were not sufficient. 
Measures to support the sustainabledevelopment of aquaculture in the Member States were not well designed and implemented. 
The national strategic plans and operational programmes of the Member States were not sufficiently clear and Member States did not have a coherent strategy for the sector. 
The EFFfunds were often insufficiently targeted for aquaculture projects, and the audit showed that these projects did not normally yield the planned results or a good cost-benefit ratio. 
Around 1.3 million tonnes of fish are produced by aquaculture in the EU each year; the turnover amounts to 4 billion euros. 
One of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) for the period up to 2013 was to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture. 
By May 2013, the EFF has provided more than EUR 400 million to finance measures to promote productive investment, environmental and health policies in the field of aquaculture. • Economical economy: keep control over the costs of EU-funded aid for rural development projects (No 22/2014) - In this special report, the Court examines whether the approaches followed by the Commission and Member States were the most effective in keeping the costs of rural development aid under control. 
The audit showed that theEUMember States could achieve significant savings in aid for rural development projects while allowing formore efficient funding. 
The auditors identified practical and cost-effective approaches that could be more widely used in Member States' control of the costs of rural development aid. 
The Member States' control systems were aimed at controlling the prices of goods or works referred to in the aid applications, without thesame attention being paid to the question of whether the goods themselves were measured. 
Some price controls were time-consuming or provided little certainty that the approved costs were reasonable. 
At the beginning of the programming period, the Commission did not provide sufficient guidance, nor did it disseminate thelack of procedures. 
It did not ensure that Member States' systems were effective before granting such aid on a large scale. 
Around half of the total expenditure allocated by the EU to rural development in 2007-2013, amounting to EUR 100 billion, was implemented in the form of grants to the costs of investment projectsand other projects carried out by farmers, agricultural companies, associations and local authorities. 
Our activities 25 • Errors in rural development expenditure: What are the causes and what is done to eliminate them? 
(No 23/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined compliance with the applicable laws and other legislation in the implementation of rural development and described the main causes of the high level of errorin the area. 
The audit found that most of the errors in rural development policy are due to breaches of conditionsset at Member State level. 
The control authorities of the Member States could and should have detected and corrected most errors in investment measures in the area of rural development. 
Member States' control systems are deficient as the controls are not comprehensive and are based on insufficient information. 
The average error rate for rural development expenditure over the past three years was 8.2 %. 
Errors in investment measures accounted for two-thirds of the error rate, while area-relatedaids accounted for one-third. 
Only 16 % of the error rate resulted from non-compliance with provisions directly contained in EU Regulations, while the largest proportion of the Feh rate- 84 % - was due to breaches of conditionsset at Member State level. 
During the programming period 2007-2013, the EU and the Member States allocated over EUR 150 billion to rural development policy, which were used in almost equal proportions for investment measures and area-related aid.
These expenses are particularly flawed. • Will the EUbewell managed to prevent and remedy forest damage caused by Brän's and natural disasters? 
(No 24/2014) - In this special report, the Court assessed whether the support measure of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) for the reconstruction of forest potential and the introduction ofpreventive actions (measure 226) was well managed and whether the Commission and the Member States can demonstrate that the objectives of the aid have been achieved in a cost-effective manner. 
The audit found that the EU's financial resources for forest fire prevention and restoration of forests damaged by natural disasters and fires were not managed well enough. 
The Commission and the Member States cannot demonstrate thatthe results of the funding have been achieved in a cost-effective manner. 
In the last 30 years, an average of 480 000 hectares of forest land has been destroyed by fires in the EU. 
Preventive actions accounted for more than 80 % of theEU funding of 1.5million euros for the period 2007-2013. 
Our activities 26 Security and citizenship This policy area has been set up to ensure the free movement of persons and to provide citizens with a high level of protection. 
It extends from the management of the EU's external borders to judicialcooperation in civil and criminal matters and includes asylum and immigration policies, police cooperation and combating crime. 
Expenditure in this area for the period 2014-2020 is expected to amount to 18 million euro or less than 2 % of the total budget. 
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Lessons learned from the development ofthe European Commission's second generation information system ( SIS II) (No 3/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined why the Commission provided SIS II more than planned more than six years later and incurred eight times more costs than originally estimated. 
It was examined whether there was a viable business case for SIS II throughout the duration of the project, taking into account major changes in costs and expected benefits. 
The audit found that the delays and excessive costs were due to weaknesses in the Commission's management. 
The initial deadline was unrealistic and the Commission was unable to effectively manage the maincontract for development before 2009. 
The initial cost estimates significantly underestimated the actual level of investment required. 
The total cost of SIS II was EUR 189 million, compared to an initial estimated amount of 23 million euro. 
The Commission did not fully demonstrate that SIS IIoffered it the best cost ratio.
However, it has gained insights from her experience during the first projectsection and has already used some of these findings for other large-scaleIT projects. 
The Schengen Information System is used by border, police, customs, visa and judicial authorities throughout the Schengenarea. 
It contains informations (tenders) concerning persons who may have been involved in a serious criminal offence or who do not have the right to enteror reside in the EU. 
It also includes alerts on missing persons and lost or stolen property. • The External Borders Fund contributed to more financial solidarity, but the results need to beimproved and added EUadded value(No 15/2014) - In this special report, the Court assessed the effectiveness and EUadded valueof the External Borders Fund and highlighted the extent to which the objectives of co-financedprojects and programmes have been achieved. 
The audit showed that the External Borders Fund contributed to the management of the EU's external borders and increased financial solidarity between Member States. 
However, its additional EU added value was limited and the results could not bemeasured due to weaknesses in monitoring by competent authorities and serious deficiencies in assessments at Commission level and at Member State level. 
Member States' programmes were not embedded in national strategies for border controls and visa matters and did not containSMART objectives or measurable indicators. 
The project selection process did not ensure that the actual needs of the Member States were met. 
Non -net procurement procedures in the Member States pose a risk to the economicviabilityof housekeeping. 
In the mainly affected Member States (Greece, Spain, Italy and in the first years of support also Malta) there were four- end weaknesses in the management of the Fund. 
As the EU's main financial instrument to support the protection of the external borders, the External Borders Fund forthe period 2007-2013was EUR 1.9 billion.
Its overarching objective was to support current and futureSchengenstates in ensuring uniform, effective and efficient controls at their common external borders. 
Our activities 27 Europe in the world The EU's external relations activities focus on: Enlargement, stability, security and prosperity in their neighbourhood, active support for sustainable development at international level, promoting global policy "governance" and ensuring strategic and civil security. 
For the period 2014-2020,the EU has allocated EUR 66 billion in current prices and 6 % of its planned total expenditure to these objectives. 
Expenditure is manageddirectly by the Commission through its Headquarters or Delegations. 
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • The establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) (No 11/2014) - In this specialreport, the Court examined whether the establishment of the EEAS was adequately prepared, whether its resources were efficiently prioritised, organised and allocated, and whether it has effectively coordinated with the Commission and the Member States. 
The audit found that the EEAS should increase its efficiency and do more for the EU and its citizens. 
The establishment of the EEAS was rushed and was not well prepared. 
Inadequacies in prioritisation, organisation and allocation of resourcesstruggled with efficiency. 
Coordination between the EEAS and the Commission was only partially effective, mainly due to the lack of effective coordination mechanisms and a rigid financial and administrativeframeworkat Delega level.
Coordination with Member States can be further strengthened in order to exploit synergies in the area of information exchange or joint accommodation and to improve consular services, including the protection of EUcitizens. 
The EEAS has its headquarters in Brussels and comprises a worldwide network of 140 delegations. 
For 2014, the EEAS had a budget of EUR 519 million divided between Headquarters (41 %) and Delegations (59 %). • EU rehabilitation assistance after the Haiti earthquake (No 13/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined whether the EU'srehabilitation assistance was well designed and adequately implemented and whether the Commission ensured an appropriate link between emergency assistanceand rehabilitation and development. 
The audit found that EU rehabilitation assistance was overall well designed and geared to the country's urgent needs after the 2010 Haiti earthquake, but that the programmeswere not implemented effectively enough and that emergency assistance, rehabilitation and development were not sufficiently linked. 
For most of theprogrammes audited, outputs were delivered on schedule, or their delivery was apparent, despite delays in almost all programmes. 
Although the Commission was aware of the difficult situation, it did not sufficiently bear a number of significant risks which jeopardised the implementation and achievement of the objectivesof the programme. 
The programmes were monitored, but the Commission and the EEAS did not take timely action toincrease the EU Delegation's resources in Haiti. 
In March 2010, 55 donors pledged $5.4 billion for theperiod2010-2012 for rehabilitation and development and a further $3.0 billion for 2013 and beyond. 
The EU was one of the main donors with an individual amount of EUR 1.2 billion. 
Our activities 28 • Effectiveness of the combination of financial resourcesfrom regional investment facilities with loans granted by financial institutions (mixed financing) to support the EU'sforeign policy(No 16/2014) - In this specialreport, the Court dealt with the establishment and management of the investment facilities and examined whether blending was able to achieve the desired benefits. 
In the context of the audit, while the judgment on mixedfinancing, i.e. the combination of financial aid from regional investment facilities with loans granted by financial institutions in support of the EU'sexternal policy, was positive in terms of structure and overall effectiveness, the Court also pointsout some key issues that need to be addressed urgently. 
While the facilities were well structured, the potential benefits of blending were not fully real due to shortcomings in their management bythe Commission. 
Almost half of the projects examined did not have sufficient evidence that the grants were justified. 
In some cases,investment is likely to have been made without theEU contribution. 
The Commission should ensure that the allocation of funds is based on a thorough, documentedsharing of added value in order to achieve the objectives of the EU's development, neighbourhood and enlargement policy. 
Since 2007, the Commission has set up eight regional investment facilities. 
These combine grants from the EDFs and the EU's overall budget with loans mainly from European DevelopmentFinance Institutions. 
The aim of the blending is to make use of investment opportunities in the form of large infrastructure projects that could be financially viable,but for which sufficient funding cannot be mobilised in the financial sector. • Can the EUinitiativeof the Centres of Excellence contribute effectively to the containment of chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN)risksoriginating outside the EU? 
(No 17/2014) - In this special report, we assessed whether the initiative was based on a well-founded analysis of the pre-2010 situation, whetherthe organisation structure of the initiative was suitable to address the identified challenges and whether there was an appropriate management system and whether it was used. 
As part of the audit, the Court made a generally positive assessment of thecontribution of the Centresof Excellence to the mitigation of CBRN risks. 
The initiative is in line with the priorities set out in the European Security Strategyandthe EU Strategy against the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction. 
It intends to involve all the actors involved in the partner countries in orderto ensure that the measures takenare maintained. 
The organisational structure is generally appropriate, but its complexity has contributed to delays in the start-up of project activities. 
The Centres of Excellence initiative is geared towards setting up regional platforms in different regions of the world to address CBRN risks. 
It is the largest single measure of the long-term component of the Instrument forStabilisation and has been allocateda budget of EUR 100 million for the period 2010-2013. 
Our activities 29 • Systems set up at EuropeAid for evaluation and results orientedmonitoring (ROM) - In this special report, the Court examined whether these systems are reliable, whether their structure and resources are adequate, and whether they ensure that relevant and meaningful findings are made and that they havethe greatest benefit from the findings. 
As part of the audit, the Court found a critical assessment of thereliability of these systems. 
The bodies responsible for evaluationand nis-oriented monitoring are well organised, but more attention should be paid to the efficient use of resources. 
The systems do not provide sufficient information on the results achieved and they do not ensure that maximum benefit is derived from the findings. 
Evaluations of projects and programmes organised by the Commission's delegations and carried out in partner countries are not managed satisfactorily: Overall monitoring is not measured,there is ambiguity about the amount of resources used and there is a lack of access to the results. 
Two key elements of the framework for theaccounting obligation of the European Commission's Directorate-General for Development and Cooperation (EuropeAid) are theirsystems set up for evaluation and monitoring. 
The total annual cost of the systems is estimated at EUR 34 to 38 million. 
The annual development expenditure covered by these systems is estimated at around EUR 8 billion. • EU pre-accession assistance to Serbia (No 19/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined whether the Commissioneffectively managed pre-accessionassistanceto Serbia during the period 2007-2013, assessing its support for thekey of governance. 
Together with other forms of support, thefunds providedby the Instrucment for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) helped Serbia to implement social and economic reforms and improve public financial management. 
Based on itsexperience with other IPA beneficiary countries, the Commission is increasingly focusing on governance issues when planning financial and non-financial assistance to Serbia. 
The Commission has effectively managed non-finan assistance to Serbia in the areas of governance and anti-corruption. 
As regards Serbia's preparations for decentralised management of EUfunds, the Commission has also provided effective support, but only in the limited area of IPAadministrative structures. 
A quarter of the IPAfunding for Serbia has been channelled into the area of governance, which, according to the Commission, poses the biggest challenges for this country. 
The EU complements IPAfi- tion with a number of non-financial resources to help Serbia prepare for EU membership. 
Our activities 30 Administration The administrative expenditure of the EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on staff (salaries and pensions) as well as for buildings, equipment, energy, communication andinformation technology. 
The planned budget for the period2014-2020 is - at current prices - 70million euro and 6 % of the total EU budget. 
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: • How do EU institutions and bodies calculate, reduce and compensate for their greenhousegas emissions? 
(No 14/2014) - In this special report, the Court assessed whether the EU institutions and bodies had strategies to reduce the impact oftheir management on the environment and whether these strategies were effectively implemented. 
In the report, the Court called on the EU institutions todevelop a common policy approach to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions ('CO2 footprint'). 
The introduction of the eco-management and audit system is slowand the available information on theactual level of emissions is incomplete. 
Only a few institutions and institutions systematically use world-oriented procurement. 
While the EU institutions and bodies have succeeded in reversing the trend of rising greenhouse gas emissions linked to energy consumption in their buildings, no clear trends in reductionsinother emission sources such as missions could be identified on the basis of available data.
More than half of the EU's audited institutions and bodies had notset any quantified emissions targets. 
The EU's environmental policy aims at a high level of protection. 
The Treaty (TFEU) requires that environmental protection needs be integrated into the definition and implementationofUnion policies and policies to promote sustainable development. 
Our activities 31 Revenue/own resources Own resources are the EU's revenue to finance its expenditure. 
There are three types of resources: traditional own resources (on imports of customs duties levied outside the EU and production levies on sugar), own resources based on VAT and own resources derived from GNI (the largest source of revenue of theEU budget). 
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: • Are the preferential trade arrangementsmanaged to measure? 
(No 2/2014) - In thisreport, the Court assessed whether the Commission adequately assessed the economic impactof preferential trade arrangements and whether the controls effectively ensure that importscannot erroneously be subject to preferential customs duties as a result of a loss ofEU revenue. 
The audit showed that while the Commission has increased the quality of its impact assessments over time, the economic impact ofpre -frequency trade regimes is still not sufficiently analysed. 
The EU misses revenue due to weaknesses in Member States' customs controls: These checks do not prevent some imports from being subjectto erroneous preferential duties. 
Through unilateral preferential trade arrangements, the EU grants preferences to developing countries in order to provide them with duty-free access to the EUmarket, thereby contributing to the eradication of poverty and promoting sustainable development. 
In 2011, the value of goods imported intothe EU under preferential arrangements was more than EUR 242 billion; this represents 14 % of imports into the EU. 
Our activities 32 Financialand economic governance The European Union's economic governance framework aims at preventing or investigatingand correcting problematic economic developments, such as excessive government deficits or debt levels, which can hamper growth and expose the sustainability of public finances to a risk. 
In 2014, the Court adopted its first special report in this area: • European Banking Supervision takes shape - EBA in a changing environment (No 5/2014) - In this special report, the Court examined whether the Commission and the European Banking Authority (EBA)have satisfactorily exercised their responsibilities in establishing new regulatory and supervisory regimes in the banking sector and how effective these schemes have worked. 
The audit found that the reform of the banking sector legislation led by the Commission and the establishment of EBA were first important reactions to the financial crisis. 
The EBA has laid the foundations for anew regulatory and supervisory system for thebanking sector. 
The identified weaknesses related to cross-border banking supervision, the assessment of the resilience oftheEU banks and the promotion of consumer protection. 
In conjunction with the implementation of the 2011 stress test,which was carried out without financialbackstopmeasures at EU level, the EBA had limited legal mandates and scarce human resources.
Although the 2011 stress test resulted in the recapitalisation of many banks, it has also become clear that such stress tests are limited ifthey do not go hand in hand with the assessment of the quality of total assets. 
Issues remain as to the future role of EBA in banking supervision, as well as the respective roles and responsibilities of the EBA and the ECB. 
As a result of the financial crisis, the Commission has taken steps to stabilise the banking sector with a view to strengthening the regulatory framework and banking supervision, especially for cross-border banks. 
The EBA was created in 2011 as part of the detailed proposals for changes in the field of regulation. 
EBA plays a role in the supervision of European banking regulation and consumer protection. 
Our activities 33 Opinions and other statements adopted in 2014 With its opinions on proposals for new or amended legal acts with financial implications, the Court contributes to improvingEU financial management. 
These opinions are delivered at the request of the other EU institutions and used by the legislative authorities - European Parliament and Council - in their work. 
The Court can also, on its own initiative, issue position papers and analyses on other issues. 
At the Court's initiative, the position of the European Court of Auditors on the Commission's report on the fight against corruption was presented, while the investigation into possible savings in the EU budget was prepared by merging the European Parliament's activities in a single place at the request of the European Parliament.

Our activities 34Landscapeanalyses The year 2014 was marked by profound innovations for the European Union. 
Against the background of this change, the Court has designed and created a new product: the landscape analysis. 
Based on the Court's work results as well as its wealth of knowledge and experience, each analysis covers a wide range of topics. 
The analysis should serve as a basis for consultations and dialogue with theCourt's address, as well as to help the Court to make observations on important issues that are not subject to scrutiny. 
The first landscapeanalysis, published in September 2014, addressed EU accountability and public financial control issues (see box). This analysis was the main basis for the EU Accountability Conference, which took place in October 2014 (see page 42). 
The two -year analysis entitled 'Efficient use of EUfunds: A landscapeanalysis on risks to EUfinancial management was published in November 2014. 
It provides an overview of the EU's financial flows as well as a summary of the issues tobe addressed, inter alia, to ensure that EUtaxpayerscan be given a better cost-benefit ratio in terms of the EU budget (see box).
The opinions and landscape analyses areavailable in 23 official EU languages on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu). 
2 2 Landscape Analysis in 2014 
Our activities 35 gaps, overlaps and challenges: Alandscape analysis of theEU rules on accountability and public financial control This landscapeanalysisaims to raise awareness of an issue that is of paramount importance to the democratic legitimacy of the EU institutional system and tostimulate this issue. 
It describes the essential features of a accountability framework, the role of public financecontrol, the key elements for a solid chain of accountability and financial control, as well as six areas where there are challenges in terms of accountability and public financial control at EU level. It alsoanalyses the rules on accountability and financial control in relation to the various new EU and intergovernmental instruments developed in response to the financial crisis. 
Make the most of EU funds: A landscapeanalysis on risks to the EUfinancial management At a time when Member States' governments and taxpayers want the resources they contribute to achieving greater benefits, this landscapeanalysis summarises the Court's comments on all aspects of EU financial management. 
Based on the Court's35 years of experience in auditing EU revenue and expenditure, thislandscapeanalysis providesan overview of the EUfinancial management and a summary of the issues to be addressed to ensure that the EUbudgetachieves a better cost-benefit ratio. 
This analysis will be complemented by detailed data sheets on the main features and topics linked to thedifferent revenue and expenditure sectors, and proposals for improvementwill be made. 
Our activities 36 In the context of the analysis, a number of key points are identified that deserve particular attention: ? excessively complex eligibility schemes and other conditions for anEUsupport which complicate their understanding, management and control and lead to different interpretations; ? Public procurement rules and procedures that are not always complied with, either intentionally or because they are not properly understood, leading to higher costs or delays in EU-funded projects; ? the insufficient capacity of national authorities to manage and disburse EUfunds, which increases the risk of errors and the risk of low quality expenditure; ? the poor coordination of theEUbudget and national budgets, a lack of resources for co-financing by Member States and a stronger emphasis on compliance than achieving results; ? a high level of commitments from the previous expenditure period, which still need to be financed from the EUbudget.

Our activities 37 Relations with the addressees The value of the Court's contributionto the EU accountability depends to a large extent on the benefits of its key partners in theaccountability process from its work results and its productions. 
These partners are the political bodies responsible for public oversight of the use ofEU fiduciary resources (i.e. the EuropeanParliament, the Council of the EU and national parliaments). 
Through its 2013-2017 strategy, the Court is committed to stepping up arrangements to monitor external developmentsand to actively shape relations with our partners. 
The President and the Members of the Court have regular contacts with the committees of theEuropean Parliament, in particular with theBudget Committee. 
In 2014, President Caldeira attended two meetings of the Committee on Budgetary Control and a number of plenary sessions of the European Parliament. 
This included the presentation of the annual work programme and annual reports. 
The Court's objectives include strengthening partnerswith its main addressees, including the various specialised committees of the European Parliamentand the Council. 
In April 2014, the Ville Itälä Court transferred the newly created function of the member responsible for institutional relations. This helped to strengthen our institution's relations with other EU institutions in strategic terms and to increasethe chances of achieving greater impact with our work. 
In 2014, other ECA members responded to the Court's annual reports and special reports at 17 meetings 64 times before the Committee on Budgets. 
The resulting discussions resulted in reports drawn up by individual members of the Committee on Budgetary Control on special reports of the Court; this includes a draft report on the special reports inconjunction with the 2013 discharge procedure. 
In 2014, the Committee on Budgetary Control started systematically inviting the technical committees to the ideas of ourreports at its meetings and thus to contribute to the increased impact of our work. 
At the beginning of 2014, the European Parliament adopted a report on the future role of the European Court of Auditors. 
The Court welcomed theview expressed in this report that any reform should be considered in the broader context of the challenge of improving EU accountability. 
This applies in particular to the Court's work, its relations with the addressees and its use of resources. 
The progress made on these issues washighlighted in the 2014 peer review report (see "Important events").
Our activities 38 In many cases, as part of the implementation of its 2013-2017 strategy, the Court has already launched a number of initiatives for improvement. To thisend, the streamlining of theaudit and reporting process and a more flexible organisation of resources. 
As a result, more reports were drawn up over the course of the year and the average time needed to do so was reduced. 
Further efficiency gains and an increased effectiveness of the auditprocess expected of the internal reform project launched in 2014. 
In a November 2013 resolution, the European Parliament asked the Court to present a comprehensive analysis of the potential savings for the EU budget that would result if Parliament had a single seat. This should also takeaccount of the reduction in the loss of working time and greater efficiency. 
The Court presented the result of this work in July 2014 and concluded that a move from Strasbourg to Brussels could result in considerableone -offs, which were slightly higher dueto an additional move from Luxembourg to Brussels. 
In 2014, the Court continued regular cooperation with the Council in its various compositions and activities. 
President Caldeira presented the annualreports to the ECOFIN Council in December 2014, and the Court was regularly invited to present special reports to the various Council committees and working groups. 
Ensuring effective relations with the national parliaments is another priority for the Court. 
The European Affairs and Financial Control Committeesas standing committees of national parliaments are regularly informed of the Court's activities. 
Delegations from several national parliaments visited the Court during the year; this included the visit of a delegation from the French Senate in July 2014. 
In addition, the Court invitedthe main addresses to the annual seminar of its members in December2014 to present to them its position on the challenges of accountability in the EU. 
We work with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to combat fraudin the post-EU budget. 
It shall forward to OLAF any evidence of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity affecting the financial interests of the EU which it is investigating in the course of its audit work or communicated to it by third parties. 
In 2014, the Court informed OLAF of 16 cases where fraud, corruption or illegal activities were suspected as part of the audit work. 
Our activities 39 Cooperation with otherAudit Institutions The Court works with other SupremeAudit Institutions (SCAIs) mainly in thefollowing bodies: • Contact committee of the SAIs of theEUMember States; • Network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; • international organisations for public financecontrol bodies, in particular the International Organisation of the Supreme AuditAuthority (INTOSAI) and its European Regional Group (EUROSAI). 
In September 2014, the Court revised and updated its international cooperation strategy (see box). 
EUROSAI Congress, The Hague, June 2014. 
In line with its overarching strategy 2013-2017, the Court's strategy for cooperation aims to make the greatest possible contribution to the EU's public accountability, in particular through enhanced bi-and multilateral cooperation with relevant partners such as national Supreme Audit Institutions and international audit organisations. 
As the Court's audit obligations cover areas of Europe-wide (e.g. fiscal governance) and global (e.g. climate change) issues, our activities in the field of international cooperation are even moreimportant than in the past. 
As part of its cooperation strategy, the Court has the following priorities: cooperation at EUlevel within the Contact Committee and individual cooperation with the SAIs of the EU Member States will continue to be the main priorities. 
In thecontext of the EUenlargement, the Court will support the SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries intheiractions for the development of expertise. ?Asa member ofinternational audit organisations such as INTOSAI, the ECA will increase itsshareof cooperation activities on technical standards, as this organisation is of great importance for the development of expertise and for the exchange of knowledge in the fieldof public financial control.
Through its cooperation strategy, in conjunction with other recent actions such as the newly established high-level conferences and meetings, the Court will contribute to raising awareness ofthe EU's financial management and accountability. 
Our activities 40 Contact Committee of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EUMember StatesAccording to the EUTreaty, the European Court of Auditorsand the national auditbodies work closelytogether while respecting their independence. 
The Court actively cooperates with the SAIs of the EUMember States in the framework of the Contact Committee. This includes an annual meeting and the various working groups, networks and task forces set up to address specific issues of common interest. 
In October 2013, the Court took over the Headquarters of theContact Committee for one year. 
As Chair, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the Contact Committee, which took place in October 2014. 
The main day- to-day items included a seminar on strengthening cooperation, in particular in the areas related to the Europe 2020 strategy and the Banking Union, reporting on the activities of the Contact Committeeand its technical partners, as well as EU-related audits carried out by the Contact Committee. 
The Court also cooperates with the SAIs of EU Member States on a bilateral basis. 
A good example of this is a project jointly carried out by the Court and the SAI of Poland, Najwyzsza Izba Kontroli, in which the auditors of the Polish SAIs actively participated inour audit work in Poland on the eradication, control and monitoring of animal diseases.

Our activities 42 Important events International expert review by the Court in 2013 asked the SAIs of France, German countryand Sweden to carry out apeer review on its practice of performance audit. 
The peer review was based on the experience of all three partners and was a very useful exercise for both the Court and the expert verifiers. 
The methodology was based on generally accepted criteria for the work of the SAIs and took into account the guidelines laid down in international standards. 
The peer review was published in 2014 on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu). 
The peers concluded that the Court had made considerable progress since the last peer review in 2008. 
The Court examined the challenges arising from the complex institutional framework of the EU and had taken a number of steps to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of its audits and the quality of its audit reports. 
International audit principles encourage theconduct of international peer reviews. 
These allow Supreme Audit Institutions to obtain a voluntary assessment of the performance of their tasks based on international standards. 
In 2014, the Court led the Peer Review of the Lithuanian Supreme Audit Authority and wasrequestedto respect the Federal Financial Control and to participate in the peer reviews of the SAIs of Spain and Lett -land. 
High-level conference on improving accountability in the EU From left to right: Jacques Sciberras, Head of Cabinet, Kevin Cardiff, Member of the Court, President Vítor Caldeira and EPVice-President Olli Rehn. 
In October 2014, the Court held a high-level conference inviting a large number of people responsible for ensuring that the EuropeanUnion complies with its accountability with regard to the public funds used to achieve its objectives. 
The conference focused on gaps,cuts and challenges at EU and Member State level, as identified in the Court's landscape analysis on EUaccountability and public financial control schemes (see page 35). 
The conference gave an opportunity to discuss among the participants, including Members or representatives of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court, the European Central Bank, the European Investment Bank, the European Stability Mechanism, national auditors and science. It was discussed how these arrangements should be developed inresponseto developments in the area of economic, fiscal and monetary integration. 
The focus was on accountability within the EU, in particular with regard to central banks and supervisory authorities, structures of the crisis and post-crisis, increasing the leverage effect ofthe EU through external participation and a stronger focus on the EU's provision of services. 
The conference participants agreed that there is a need for greater cooperation between governmentalauthorities, parliaments and auditors at EU and Member State level in order to give the public a better picture of the achievements provided by EU policies and programmes. 
Our activities 43 Strengthen partnerships with the national authorities in Lithuania A high-level delegation of the Court visited Lithuania in September 2014 to strengthen partnerships with the country's parliament, government, central bank and SAI and to promote the best use and control of EUspendingthere. 
The Court and its partners in Lithuania exchanged views on priority actions to improve the EU'saccountabilityand considered how best to contribute to the added value of EUspendingthrough their cooperation and to help policy makers and Parliament in Lithuania make the best use of the Court's audit results.
During the visit, the Court's delegation actively participated in the conference ofthe Lithuanian Parliament, plus the challengesof accounting and auditing in the public sector. 
In addition, the delegation and its partnersdiscussed financial and economic governance issues and the benefits of Lithuania's accession tothe euro area on 1 January 2015. 
Lithuania was the first of a number of EU Member States to visit the Court in the coming years in order tostrengthen partnerships with the national authorities responsible for managing and controlling EU funds.
Our management 44 The College of the Court belongs to the College of the Court of Auditors from each Member State. 
According to the contract, the term of office of the members of the Court is six years and a reappointment is possible. 
The members are assigned to one of five chambers. 
The Chambers adopt audit reportsand opinions and take decisions on further strategic and administrative issues. 
In addition, each member is responsible for its own tasks, which are primarily audit-related tasks. 
The underlying audit work will be carried out by the Court's auditors and coordinated by the responsible member assisted by his cabinet. 
The Member then took over the presentation of the report for adoption by the Chamber and/or the entire College of Courts and later the presentation in the European Parliament, the Council and other interested parties, including the media. 
In accordance with the proposals of their Member States and after consulting the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union appointed six new Members of the European Court of Auditors in 2014. 
Four of these members - Alex Brenninkmeijer (Netherlands), Daničle Lamarque (France), Nikolaos Milionis (Greece) and Phil Wynn Owen (United Kingdom) - welcomed the Court on 1 January, while two others - KlausHeinerLehne (Germany) and Oskar Herics (Austria) - were welcomed on 1 March 2014. 
On 23 January 2014, the 28 members of the Court re-elected Vítor Caldeira as President of the Court for a third three-year period. 
The President is responsible for overseeing the performance of the Court's mandate and represents the institution externally.

Our management 46 strategy of the Court for 2013-2017: Progress made in 2014 was the second year in which the Court implemented its 2013-2017 strategy. 
During this period, the value of the Court's contribution to the EU's public accountabilitywill be maximised. 
In order to achieve this objective, the Court primarily pursues the following priorities: ? Orientation of the Court's products to improve the accountability of the EU; ? cooperation with other actors to strengthen the Court's contribution to the accountability of the EU; ? Further development of the Court as a professional audit body; ? optimal use of the knowledge available to the Court, as well as the expertise and expertise available to it; ? Evidence of the Court's performance and the performance of its accountability. 
In 2014, a profound restructuring of the Court's organisational structure was initiated with the help of the strategy. 
Two internal working groups dealing with the strategy ("Strengthening the audit process" and "better definition of tasks and responsibilities") presented their results. 
This coincided with the European Parliament's report on the future role of the ECA and the results of the peerreview process that the Court has undergone. 
The various recommendations have been summarised in a far-reaching reform project, the implementation of which started at the end of 2014 and will last until mid-2016. 
In the case of special reports, this means that they should be produced in a shorter period of time, in the case of the annual report, greater focus and resource savings will be sought. 
The farm is to be converted into a task-based organisation. 
This will make it better able to target resources for those audits and analyses that provide the most added value for the EUcitizens. 
Our management 47 Measurement of the Court's performance The Court has been applying central performance indices (ZLI) since 2008 to inform management of the progress achieved towards its objectives, to support the decision-making process and to provide information on performance to its addressees. 
The ZLIs reflect the Court's priorities and provide information on its performance and accountabilityas a professional audit body. 
The indicators are used to measure key parameters for the quality and impact of the Court's work, paying particular attention to the point of view of key addressees and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources. 
The ZLIs have beenupdated for the period covered by the 2013-2017 strategy.

Our management 50 preparation of special reports In order to have an impact on the Court's special reports, they must be submitted in a timely manner. 
In recent years, the Court has been able to reduce the time needed for the audits. 
The 2013- 2017 strategy aims to achieve further improvements and this strategy is expected to deliver measurable results in the coming years. 
In 2014, the Court produced 24 special reports, of which 42 % (2013: 37 %) were completed within the 18-month timeframe set by the Court. 
On average, 19 months were taken for the preparation of the special reports adoptedin 2014 (2013: 20 months).

In view of the difficult situation of public finances in Europe,the Court continued the staff reduction of 1 % per year for a period of five years (2013-2017), as set out in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and theeconomic management of December 2013. 
As a result, staffing was reduced from 891 to 882 officials and temporary staff in 2014 (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees). 
Out of the total posts, 561 are allocatedto audits (including 113 staff in members' cabinets). 
With a view to the goal of the bestpossible set of resources, in 2014 the possibilities for increasing efficiency were againidentified and implemented in all activities by the Association of Procedures. 
The redeployment of staff from support to audit services also continuedin 2014. 
However, this was offset by the redeployment ofcertain support services from Members' cabinets to an administrative pool and the transfer of the Communication and Institutional Relations Unit to the services of the President. 
51 Recruitment The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output. 
The ECA's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EUinstitutions, and the Commission consists of both civil servants and temporary agents. 
In 2014, an internal selection procedure for grade AST 1 and a selection procedure with a view to recruiting a spokesperson was conducted. 
In addition, the Court provided traineeships for 77 graduates for periods of three to five months during the year. 
In 2014, the Court recruited 78 staff, 31 officials, 29 temporary agents, 13 contract staff and five seconded national experts. 
The number of vacant posts has been close to 3 % since 2011 (on 31. In December 2014, 27 posts were vacant).

In order to further develop the Court as a professional audit body and to make the best use of the knowledge available to it, as well as the expertise and expertise available to it, permanent training of staff is necessary in order to be able to keep up with professional developments and acquire new skills. 
In 2014, the Court's staff (auditors and other staff) completed an average of eight days of professional training. 
The proportion of language courses in continuing vocational training continues to decline. 
In 2014, this accounted for 43 % of the total number of training days (compared to 46 % in 2013). 
In order to make the best use of existing resources and technologies, the Court has been offering its employees individually tailored e-learningcoursesand training courses in the form of integrated learning( blended learning) since 2014, in which participants complete the general theory inonline training prior to the attendance session. 
In addition, the objective of exchanging internal knowledge and providing the Court's auditors with the most up-to-date audit developments in the public sector has continued to be organised by internal andexternal experts on developments in the field of audit and other relevant areas. 
Translation Translation is an audit support activity that enables the Court to fulfil its mission and to achieve its communication objectives, which are to provide the results it presents in the languages oftheEU citizens. 
In 2014, the total translation volume was 4 % higher than in 2013. 
More than 98 % of translations were completed on time. 
In addition to normal translation work, the Translation Directorate further expanded the direct participation of translatorsin the Court's audit and core business: Translators provided linguistic support during 40 audit visits across the EU and indrafting audit reports. 
In 2014, the Directorate for Translation focusedon quality assurance. 
For this purpose, the first manual for quality assurance in the translation sector was adopted and a system for customerfeedback was developed. 
Finally, in order to make the services more efficient, the process of translation workwas reviewed and optimised. In cooperation with the Information Technologies Directorate, the automation of the process has started. 
Support for audit activities 56 All processes related to the development and provision of instruments were carried outunder the guarantee and continuity of the operation: For example, in 2014 after the new K3buildingwas moved, a comprehensive restart testwas carried out following a collapse of the IT systems(disaster recovery), and centralIT components were modernised (e.g. the migration of the Court's e-mail system). 
Management and Infrastructure The task of the Directorate for Finance and Support Servicesis to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and implement its strategic objectives, and to ensure that the necessary financing,internal controls andaccounting mechanisms are available to support allour activities. 
In 2014, the Directorate continued to focus onmaking its activities even more efficient and economic. 
An environmental management system for the Court is currently being developed, in line with the principles of the Community Environmental Managementand AuditSystem (EMAS) with a view to obtaining certification by the end of 2016. 
In 2014, several measures were successfully implemented, delivering concrete results and demonstrating the Court's commitment tothe environment. These included: • Adoption of an environmental policy; • Carrying out an environmental analysisand compliance with environmental law; • Increasing the number of environmentalworkers' awareness campaigns from four in 2013 to eight in 2014; • Obtaining BREEAM environmentalcertification(the world's leading method for design and promotionof sustainable buildings) for the K3 buildingandmaintaining the certification mark for exemplary waste management; • Promoting sustainable transport amongworkers by providing a new bicycle room with showers and changing areas for cyclists, by installing a charging station for electric cars and by booking good parkingplaces for car sharing.

The higher execution rate is mainly due to a better estimate and planning of expenditure for Title 1, which achieved an average execution rate of 98.8 %. 
For Title 2, the average execution rate was 98.4 %.
