59 Audit and accountability of the Court's internal audit The Internal Auditor advises the Court on riskcontrol issues by issuing opinions on the quality of managementand control systems and recommendations on improving the conditions for the management of transactions and promoting sound financial management. 
In addition, the Internal Auditor supports the work of the external auditor whose mission is to certify the Court's annual accounts. 
The Internal Auditor reported to the Court on the results of the audits carried out during 2014, the findings, the recommendations and the actions taken in response to these recommendations. 
The Court reports annually tothe European Parliament and to the Council on the results of the internal auditor's work. 
In October 2014, the Court's internal audit was certified to comply with the definition of internal audit, code of conduct and standards drawn up by the Institute of Internal Auditors (IAA). 
This certification was the result of a comprehensive quality assessment of the Court's internal audit carried out at the request of the Internal Auditor and the Internal Audit Committee by an external evaluator, Deloitte SARL. It also complied with the IIA's international standards for the professional practice of internal auditing. 
External audit of the Court The Court's annual accountsare audited by an independent auditor. 
This is an important aspect in the Court's approach to applying to ourselves the same principles of transparency and accountability as for the bodies we audit. 
The auditor's report - Pricewaterhouse CoopersSARL - on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2013 was published on 18 September 2014. 
Audit opinions of the independent auditor - financial year 2013 To the annual accounts: "In our opinion, the end ofthe year gives a true view ofthe assetsand financial position of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December. December 2013, its performance and cash flows for the year ending that reference date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union and CommissionRegulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules of application of the Financial Regulation.' "In our work described in this report, wehave not encountered situations from which we would have to conclude that, in all material respects and taking into account the above-mentioned assessment criteria, the resources allocated to the Court were not used for thepurposes set out above and • the control procedures put in place do not provide theassurance that the financial transactions were carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations."

European Court of Auditors HOT THEEU FINANCIALS 
European Court of Auditors 02 About the Court The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg. 
It has 28 members - one from each EU Member State - and employs around 900 staff from all EU Member States in the area of auditing and administration. 
Since its inception in 1977, the Court has been committed to improving EU financial management and accounting. 
We check that the EU funds have been correctly accounted for, collected and spent in accordance with the relevant rules and regulations and whether there is an optimal use of funds. 
It warns about risks, provides security and provides guidance to EU policy makers on how to improve public financial management and ensure that European citizens know how their funds are used. 
Through its audit work and other activities, the Court contributes to strengthening the democratic legitimacy and sustainability of the European Union.

Foreword by President 04 Dear reader, in 2015 to which this activity report refers, the European Union was again faced with major challenges. There have been significant developments in EU governance, policy and financial management, including the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the establishment of the Single Resolution Mechanism for banks in the euro area. 
These and other developments have led to new audit tasks for the Court. 
In 2015, we reviewed the activities of the EU institutions and other bodies, as well as all EU funds paid to Member States, countries outside the EU, international organisations and other beneficiaries. 
In accordance with our obligations under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we have prepared annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds, as well as specific annual reports on the accounts of more than 50 EU agencies and other bodies. 
In addition, we produced 25 special reports on numerous topics, the results of which are summarised in this activity report. 
In particular, we would like to draw your attention to two special reports: our report on the emissions trading system, which shows that our work goes beyond purely financial matters, as well as our report on financial assistance to countries in difficulty, which is part of a series of new special reports on fiscal and economic governance. 
Last year, we also delivered eight opinions on new or amended EU legal acts with significant financial implications, including an opinion on the regulation establishing the EFSI. 
In order to make a difference in our work, we need to pass on the lessons learned to stakeholders at EU and national level. 
Throughout the year, we further deepened our cooperation with the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union - our key partners in ensuring the EU's accountability. 
We presented the results of our audits to an increasing number of specialised committees of these bodies, and we took into account their concerns when planning future audits. 
We also provided high-level visits to Member States to strengthen partnerships with national authorities, parliaments and audit bodies. 
In 2015, we organised two notable conferences: one in Brussels on EU energy security and the other in Luxembourg on the future of development aid in the light of the new Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations. 
We also prepared an extensive internal reform in order to better respond to the continuous developments within the European Union. 
This report sets out some important changes that we have made in relation to our stakeholder relations, our audits and our resources. 
In addition, you will receive important information about our human resources management, finances and achievements and the results of our internal and external audits last year, as well as on the latest annual discharge procedure. 
I hope this report will give you a useful and interesting overview of the Court's activities in 2015. With these activities, we want to fulfil our mission, which consists of improving EU financial management, promoting accountability and transparency and protecting the financial interests of EU citizens. 
05 Our management • Annual reports on the general budget of the EU • and on the European Development Funds for the financial year 2014, which mainly include the statements of assurance and audit results. • 52 specific annual reports containing the Court's audit opinions on the accounts of individual EU agencies and bodies and two summary reports. We carried out an internal reform to streamline our audit and reporting procedures and provide greater flexibility in managing our resources. • 25 special reports on certain management issues and budgetary areas, including the emissions trading system, youth employment programmes and assistance during the financial crisis. • • 8 opinions on new or amended EU acts and other decisions affecting financial management, from the proposed Regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the amended Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation. • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our addressees, including two high-level conferences on EU accountability, one on energy security and the other on the future of development aid. 
With regard to recruitment and human resources management, we continued our policy of equal opportunities. • We have made considerable progress in integrating information systems for audit management and audit documentation. In addition, we made audit-related information accessible on mobile devices. The European Court of Auditors' buildings in Luxembourg. 
Our activities 06 Audits Our audit reports and opinions form an important link in the EU accountability chain as they are used to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's budgetary management accountable, especially in the context of the annual discharge procedure. 
These bodies are primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies. 
In areas under shared management, Member States also play an important role, such as expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures. 
Our three most important products are: • Annual reports containing mainly the results of the audits of the accounts and compliance audits on the budget of the European Union and on the European Development Funds (EDFs), but also on budgetary and performance aspects. 
Special annual reports on the EU Agencies, decentralised bodies and Joint Undertakings are also published separately. • Special reports presenting the results of selected cost-effectiveness or compliance audits on specific expenditure or policy areas or on budgetary or management issues. • Opinions on new or amended acts affecting financial management and other analytical products produced either at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative. 
We strive to manage our resources in such a way as to ensure an appropriate relationship between our various activities. At the same time, the various areas of the EU budget will be well covered and solid results will be achieved. 
In 2015, we used a significant share of our resources to prepare the annual statements of assurance, which were then presented in our annual reports. 
The work underlying the Statement of Assurance covers the two aspects on which we have to issue an annual audit opinion under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. 
In addition, as far as possible, we take into account the work results of other auditors (see section on the audit of EU agencies on p. 14) and the management declarations in the form of the annual activity reports of the Directors-General of the Commission. 
In addition to the legally required audits, we select specific expenditure or policy areas at our discretion. This is based on criteria such as the risk of irregularities or inadequate performance, potential for improvement and public interest. 
We search for these topics completely independently, but take into account the views of our audience. 
In 2015, we produced 25 special reports, which are in particular the result of our performance audits. 
The summaries of the special reports are presented in this activity report (p. 15-33). 
In 2015, we issued eight opinions on proposals for new or amended rules and regulations (p. 34). 
In particular, we refer to our opinion on EFSI in order to clarify both the issue and the impact of our opinions. 
All audit reports and comments are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Our activities 08 audit visits in 2015 While most of the audit work took place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, auditors also carried out audit visits to Member State authorities, other beneficiaries of EU funds inside and outside the European Union (including organisations involved in the allocation of EU funds, such as the European Investment Bank's regional offices in Kenya and Uganda) and other EU institutions, agencies and bodies. 
Through these visits, we obtained direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the authorisation, management, collection and disbursement of EU funds, as well as from the respective final recipients. 
Our audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the duration of an audit visit can be a few days, but also several weeks. 
The frequency and intensity of audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country depends on the type of audit and, where appropriate, sampling. 
The number of audit visits may therefore vary from country to country and year to year. 
Within the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited. 
In 2015, the Court's auditors spent 4 310 days of on-the-spot audits in Member States and outside the EU and obtained audit evidence for annual reports and selected audit tasks (special reports). 
They also spent a lot of time at the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as decentralised agencies and bodies across the EU. 
On-site inspections took less days than in 2014. 
This is due to more efficient working methods and an increasing use of technologies such as the secure exchange of data and documents and videoconferencing. 
Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activities in our audit work. 
In combating fraud at the expense of the EU budget, the Court cooperates with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF). 
We will forward any suspicion of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity to the detriment of the EU's financial interests that arise during our audit work. 
These cases will then be followed up by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and, where appropriate, cooperates with Member State authorities. 
In 2015, we forwarded 27 cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2014: 16 cases).

Our activities 10 Annual Reports for the financial year 2014 The majority of our audits on accounting and compliance audits were devoted in 2015 to the implementation of the EU budget for 2014. 
The 2014 Annual Report, which emerged from this work, was published on 10 November 2015 and presented to our addressees, including the European Parliament and its Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (Economic and Financial Affairs Council), national parliaments and governments, and the media. 
The main objective of our annual report is to support the European Parliament, the Council and citizens in assessing the quality of EU financial management by presenting findings and conclusions. 
In the 2014 Annual Report, we provide assurance on the use of EU funds in the financial year under consideration, highlighting the areas where the risk of improper use of EU funds was greatest. 
In addition, we analyse why errors have occurred and provide useful and cost-effective recommendations on possible improvements. 
We have revised the structure of our 2014 annual report to make the report more reader-friendly. 
The headings of the chapters now correspond to those of the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020. 
The key element of the report remains the Statement of Assurance, in which we deliver our audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and on compliance with revenue and expenditure rules. 
In addition, we have specifically assessed all of the EU's key areas of activity and provided extensive information on budgetary and financial management. 
The report also provides information on the performance of the EU budget and the Commission's performance reporting, in particular with a view to progress towards the Europe 2020 objectives. 
President Vítor Caldeira presented the 2014 annual report of the European Court of Auditors to the European Parliament. EU spending in 2014 amounted to EUR 142.5 billion = almost EUR 300 per citizen 
Our activities 11 The key statements of the 2014 Annual Report The European Court of Auditors calls for a new approach to EU investment and expenditure. The reliability of the EU accounts has been confirmed for 2014. Revenue was legal and regular in 2014. Payments were materially affected by errors in 2014. 
Conclusions and recommendations The 2014 EU accounts have been duly drawn up in accordance with international principles and provide a true and fair view. 
Therefore, we were once again able to give an unrestricted opinion on its reliability. 
However, we issued a failed audit opinion on the regularity of payments. The estimated level of error measuring the level of irregularities is 4.4 % for the 2014 payments. This is close to the error rate for 2013 (4.5 %) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2 %. The estimated error rates we found were the same for expenditure under shared management with Member States and expenditure directly managed by the Commission (4.6 %). 
The highest error rates were determined for expenditure under the headings "Economic, social and territorial cohesion" (5.7 %) and "Competitiveness for growth and jobs" (5.6 %). 
For administrative expenditure, the lowest estimated error rate was established (0.5 %). There is a clear link between types of expenditure and error rates. 
The estimated error rate for cost reimbursement schemes (5.5 %) for which the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities on the basis of cost statements prepared by beneficiaries is twice as high as the estimated level of error for schemes based on payment entitlements (2.7 %) where costs are not reimbursed but the payment depends on the fulfilment of certain conditions. Corrective action by the authorities in the Member States and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate. 
Without these measures, the estimated total error rate would have been 5.5 %. 
The Commission needs further improvement in the risk assessment and the impact of corrective measures. If the Commission, the Member State authorities and the independent auditors had used all the information available to them, they could have prevented, detect and correct a significant part of the errors before they were created. The amounts to be paid in the current and coming years remain very high. 
It is essential that the Commission take action to address this ongoing problem. 
The Partnership Agreements and Programmes do not sufficiently take into account the objectives of Europe 2020 by Member States. 
These two aspects allow the Commission to monitor and report on the performance and contribution of the EU budget to Europe 2020 only to a limited extent. The upcoming mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework is crucial for managing EU spending. 
It is important that the Commission analyses the areas with persistently high error rates as soon as possible, assesses the possibilities to reduce these levels of error while paying greater attention to the performance of expenditure.

Our activities 13 Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDF) for 2014 revenue was not affected by errors. The payments were materially affected by errors. Under the EDF, the European Union grants funding for development cooperation with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) and Overseas Countries and Territories (OCTs). 
The EDFs are financed by Member States and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and, in the case of some aid, by the European Investment Bank. 
Their revenues were not materially affected by errors, while there was an estimated error rate of 3.8 % in payments. 
As in previous years, we found weaknesses in ex ante controls. 
The estimated error rate is almost two-thirds due to errors related to non-compliance with procurement rules and lack of supporting documents justifying expenditure. 
Our annual report on the EDFs is published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca.europa.eu). 
Our activities 14 Special Annual Reports for the financial year 2014 totalled around EUR 4 billion for all EU agencies, bodies and joint undertakings in 2014. 
EU agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings perform certain tasks on behalf of the EU and are based in different EU Member States. 
They operate in many areas, such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and transport, and each have their own mandate, management board, director, staff and budget. 
In 2015, we produced 52 special annual reports for the financial year 2014. 
They covered 41 decentralised agencies, executive agencies and other EU bodies, eight European Research Joint Undertakings, the European Schools, the Galileo Joint Undertaking in Liquidation and the Sisnet Communication Infrastructure. 
In addition, we published two summaries giving an overview of the results of our audits in this area (a summary of the EU agencies and other bodies and the other on the Joint Undertakings). 
These reports were submitted to the President of the European Parliament and the Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets. 
In 2014, the individual financial statements of the 33 EU decentralised agencies and other bodies were audited independently by a private audit firm for the first time. 
When preparing our audit opinions on these financial statements, we took into account this audit work and the measures taken by the audited bodies on the basis of the auditor's findings. 
The annual accounts of the other agencies and Joint Undertakings have been fully audited by us. 
We found the accounts of all agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings to be reliable in 2014. 
The transactions were legal and regular, except for Artemis (embedded ICT systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and ECSEL (electronic components and systems). 
In general, agencies have further improved their procedures by taking corrective action following our comments from previous years. 
Our special annual reports as well as the two summaries of the results of our 2014 audits on the Agencies, Other Bodies and Joint Undertakings are available on our website (eca.europa.eu). 
52 Special Annual Reports on the EU Agencies, Other Bodies and Joint Undertakings, with headquarters throughout Europe, Europol, The Hague, Netherlands. 
Our activities 15 Special Reports prepared in 2015 In addition to our annual reports and special annual reports, we publish special reports throughout the year, which contain the results of the profitability and compliance audits we conduct on specific budgetary areas or management topics of our choice. 
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, we are keen to achieve maximum impact and thus use our resources in the best possible way. 
Our performance audits often cover several financial years, and their subject matter is complex, so it can take longer than a year to complete these audits. 
In 2015, the special reports focused in particular on the following topics: the overall EU objective of creating added value and growth, as well as the EU's response to global challenges such as the sustainability of public finances, the environment and climate change. 
Under the respective headings corresponding to the headings of the multiannual financial framework, the 25 special reports drawn up in 2015 are briefly presented.

Our activities 16 100 80 60 40 20 0 Competitiveness for growth and jobs EUR 143 billion 13 % Smart and inclusive growth The "Smart and inclusive growth" heading accounts for most of the expenditure of the EU budget. 
This area covers the two sub-headings "Competitiveness for growth and jobs" and "Economic, social and territorial cohesion". 
The sub-heading "Competitiveness for growth and jobs" includes financial resources for trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, business development, research and innovation, education and training, social policy, etc. The planned expenditure in this area for 2014-2020 represents 13 % of the total EU budget for the programming period, i.e. EUR 143 billion. 
A budget of EUR 15.7 billion was earmarked for 2015. • Inland waterway transport in Europe: no significant improvements in transport mode share and navigability conditions since 2001 (No 1/2015) - This special report examines whether the projects co-financed by the EU budget have effectively contributed to increasing the transport mode share of freight transport by inland waterway vessels and improving navigability, and whether EU policies for inland waterway transport were coherent and based on relevant and comprehensive analyses. 
Projects co-financed by the EU have not been implemented effectively. As a result, inland waterway transport could not be established as an alternative to road freight or improved navigability. 
Although the Commission had made inland waterways a priority, Member States have paid little attention to inland waterways. 
There is no coherent overall strategy among Member States linked by the main shipping corridors, and river maintenance and political and environmental considerations are not sufficiently taken into account in EU strategies. 
Member States should prioritise inland waterway projects with the greatest and most immediate benefits, and the Commission should focus its resources on those projects that have advanced plans for the elimination of bottlenecks. 
The TEN-T programme, the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund provided EUR 1.3 billion for EU inland navigation projects over the period 2007-2013. 
Our activities 17 • Is it appropriate to meet the needs of micro-entrepreneurs through financial support from the EU? 
(No 8/2015) - This special report analyses whether the needs of microenterprises are met by the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Progress Microfinance Facility. 
The auditors noted that the programming and design of the financial support provided by the ESF had weaknesses and that the provision of services was not adequately and reliably monitored. 
Neither the Commission nor the Member States had comparative information on the administrative costs of each Member State and financial mechanisms. 
These circumstances could affect the effectiveness of the EU's financial support to microenterprises. 
Member States should carry out needs assessments in the design of financial instruments and the development of operational programmes, which also provide for EU financial support to microenterprises. 
The Commission should make the use of ESF financial instruments by Member States conditional on the existence of robust risk management systems. 
In the case of microfinance, loans of less than EUR 25 000 are usually granted, often of less than EUR 10 000. 
The total demand in EU Member States for such financing is estimated at more than EUR 12 billion. 
Examples included in the report include the provision of EUR 5 000 for the development of a city kiosk and the provision of EUR 9 500 to support the creation of a playground and a clothing store. • Improving security of energy supply through the development of the internal energy market: Greater efforts are needed (No 16/2015) - This special report looks at whether the implementation of internal energy market policies and EU spending on energy infrastructure have effectively contributed to achieving benefits in the field of energy security. 
The audit found that in general, energy infrastructure in Europe is not yet geared towards fully integrated markets and therefore does not currently provide effective security of energy supply. 
Therefore, the Commission should identify energy infrastructures in the EU that are not actively used and work with Member States to remove the barriers to their use for the purposes of the internal energy market. 
In addition, the Commission should consider new ways to make energy from one Member State available to customers in another. 
The internal energy market should allow the free movement and trade of natural gas and electricity throughout the EU. 
Under the EU budget, EUR 3.7 billion was earmarked for the financing of energy infrastructure from 2007 to 2013, and a further 7.4 billion euros are expected between 2014 and 2020. 
However, the report points out that the EU's objective of completing the internal energy market by 2014 has not been met. 
Our activities 18 Economic, social and territorial cohesion Smart and inclusive growth The sub-heading "Economic, social and territorial cohesion" covers regional policies aimed at helping the least developed countries and regions of the EU to follow up with the rest. The aim is to strengthen the competitiveness of all regions and to promote cooperation between them. 
Cohesion expenditure for 2014-2020 represents 34 % of the EU budget for the entire programming period, i.e. EUR 367 billion. 
EUR 100 80 60 40 20 0 367 billion Euro 34 % • efforts to solve public procurement problems in EU cohesion spending should be stepped up (No 10/2015) - This special report examines whether the Commission and the Member States take appropriate and effective measures to address the problem of public procurement errors in cohesion policy. 
The audit found that there are still widespread problems in public procurement across the EU. 
Although the Commission and the Member States have begun to address the issue, much remains to be done. 
Serious errors resulted in a lack of fair competition and that contracts were not awarded to the best bidders. 
Systematic analysis takes place only to a very limited extent and there is a lack of sufficiently accurate, reliable and coherent data on the nature and extent of errors. 
In the event that the situation does not improve by the end of 2016, it is recommended to suspend the payments of the 2014-2020 period to the Member States concerned. 
In the period 2007-2013, EUR 349 billion was earmarked for regional policy expenditure to be disbursed through the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), the Cohesion Fund and the European Social Fund. 
A substantial part of these funds will be spent through public procurement. 
Errors were found in around 40 % of the projects we audited in relation to our annual reports on the financial years 2009-2013 from the point of view of public procurement. 
Our activities 19 • EU financing of urban wastewater treatment plants in the Danube basin: In order to achieve the objectives of the EU wastewater policy, Member States need further support (No 2/2015) - This special report assesses the effectiveness of supporting Member States in the Danube basin with funding from the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund in achieving the objectives of EU wastewater policy. 
The audit found that while the EU spending programmes had a significant share of the progress made in the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia, there were delays in compliance and use of available EU funds in all countries. 
Although the waste water in these countries' plants was generally adequately treated, the handling of sewage sludge and rain overflows was sometimes inadequate. 
One third of the plants were oversized and potentially unsustainable in the long term. 
The countries used the available EU funds only slowly, so that they were at risk of losing EU funding or requiring additional funding from national budgets. 
The Commission should tighten reporting requirements and Member States should establish legislation to ensure immediate access to public sewerage. 
The Commission and the Member States should establish criteria for all types of use of sewage sludge and ensure reliable monitoring of pollutants. 
The Danube catchment area is Europe's largest catchment area. 
The EU's contribution to wastewater treatment projects in the four Member States audited • amounted to 7.9 billion euro in the 2000-2006 and 2007-2013 programming periods. Water quality in the Danube catchment area: Progress in the implementation of the Water Framework Directive but still needs for further action (No 23/2015) - This special report examines whether the implementation of the Water Framework Directive by the Czech Republic, Hungary, Romania and Slovakia has led to a better quality of surface waters in the Danube River Basin. 
The audit revealed that there have been few improvements since 2004. 
The main reason for the limited progress was that Member States' plans were not ambitious enough. 
Targeted measures were lacking for water bodies with insufficient quality status. 
In addition, shortcomings in the monitoring systems led to a lack of data, both in terms of the type of pollution and sources of pollution, which caused a negative assessment of the status of water bodies. 
In addition, Member States took out a significant number of water bodies without sufficient justification for important deadlines. 
In the period 2007-2013, Member States in the Danube river basin received EUR 6.35 billion from the European Regional Development Fund and the Cohesion Fund for wastewater treatment. 
During the same period, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development provided EUR 6.39 billion to compensate farmers for agri-environmental measures. 
Our activities 20 • EU Youth Guarantee: The start is made, but implementation risks are foreseeable (No 3/2015) - this special report examines whether the Commission has adequately supported Member States in setting up the Youth Guarantee and whether there were potential implementation risks. 
The audit identified three risks that could prevent the effective implementation of the Youth Guarantee: the adequacy of the overall budget, the definition of a "high quality" job and the way the Commission monitors the Youth Guarantee and reports on the results. 
The auditors concluded that the Commission provided timely and appropriate support to Member States in implementing the Youth Guarantee. 
However, the Commission has not carried out an impact assessment indicating the expected costs and benefits, although this is a standard procedure. 
While the Commission had asked Member States to provide cost estimates when submitting their Youth Guarantee implementation plans, some did not provide the information needed. No Member State indicated the estimated cost of the required structural reforms. 
The Youth Guarantee was established in June 2013 in response to the deterioration of the situation of unemployed young people, aggravated by the economic and financial crisis. 
In the 2014-2020 period, the Youth Guarantee - through the European Social Fund and a dedicated Youth Employment Initiative - will be co-financed by the EU budget for a total of EUR 12.7 billion. • Commission support for youth action teams: Redeployment of ESF funds successfully but insufficient focus on results (No 17/2015) - This special report examines whether youth action teams made proposals in 2012 on how ESF funds can achieve faster and more effective results for unemployed young people, and whether these proposals have contributed to the redeployment of ESF funds. 
The auditors noted that although the youth action teams set up by the Commission succeeded in reallocating funds into projects to support young people, they submitted only limited proposals. 
The Commission provided advice to the Member States but was limited by the scope and quality of the information available. 
While the initiative led to reprogramming and reallocating funds from the European Social Fund, the Commission's assessment of the changes to the operational programmes focused mainly on their budgetary impact. 
If discrepancies arise between the promises made and the objectives actually achievable by the Commission, there should not be too high expectations for such initiatives. 
As part of its Youth Opportunities initiative, the Commission set up youth action teams in 2012. 
The teams were composed of experts from the eight Member States with the highest youth unemployment figures as well as experts from the Commission. 
The initiative concerned almost EUR 10 billion from the European Social Fund, which were still available in the Member States concerned. 
Our activities 21 Natural resources EUR 417 billion Sustainable growth: this heading covers the Common Agricultural and Fisheries Policy, Rural Development and EU environmental measures. 
Three-quarters of the expenditure relates to direct payments to farmers and support to agricultural markets. 
The expenditure planned for 2014-2020 accounts for almost 39 % of the total EU budget for this programming period, i.e. EUR 417 billion. 
A budget of EUR 56 billion was earmarked for 2015. 
100 80 60 40 20 0 39 % • Technical assistance: What contribution has it made in agriculture and rural development? 
(No 4/2015) - This special report examines the use of financial resources for technical assistance in agriculture and rural development during the 2007-2013 programming period. 
The audit focused on the regularity, effectiveness and efficiency of financing at the level of the Commission and the Member States. 
The audit found that neither the European Commission nor the Member States could demonstrate how well the use of technical assistance in agriculture and rural development has contributed to the economic use of the budget and to the objectives of the common agricultural policy. 
Rural networks aimed at promoting cooperation, knowledge sharing and innovation in the agricultural sector are very well suited as beneficiaries of technical assistance. 
However, in most cases, capacity building funding has been used to support general management budgets. 
For rural development, the Commission should clarify the scope and use of technical assistance in Member States and closely monitor its implementation. 
For the period 2007-2013, Member States had planned to use the EU budget of EUR 1.5 billion for technical assistance. This was subject to a ceiling of 4 % of the national financial framework available for rural development. 
For the period 2014-2020, this amount increased to around 1.9 billion euros. 
Our activities 22 • Are financial instruments in the field of rural development a successful and promising instrument? 
(No 5/2015) - This special report looks at whether the financial instruments (credit and guarantee funds) used under rural development policy have been well designed and managed during the 2007-2013 programming period. 
The audit revealed that the financial instruments have not yet been successful. 
This is mainly due to the fact that the financial instruments were overcapitalised and could not develop their potential in terms of the desired leverage and the revolving effect. 
There were no clear arguments for the introduction of financial instruments in the 2007-2013 programming period. 
Moreover, there was no reliable quantifiable information to justify the nature of the financial instruments set up, to determine the demand for financial instruments in the agricultural sector and to demonstrate that the amount of capital allocated to a fund was appropriate. 
Increased incentives should be provided for Member States to set up financial instruments in the field of rural development and to increase demand from farmers or other beneficiaries. In addition, adequate standards and targets regarding leverage and revolving effect should be established for the period 2014-2020. 
By the end of 2013, the EU and its Member States had invested around EUR 700 million in the guarantee and loan funds for rural development. 
The Commission wants Member States to commit to at least doubling the use of these instruments for the period 2014-2020. 
Close-up of an efficiency test: Integrity and implementation of the EU ETS (No 6/2015) The European Union Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) differs to some extent from other policies and programmes that we consider as it does not receive significant funding from the EU budget. 
However, it has a very large impact on the implementation of policies in the EU and on the quality of life of citizens. 
The EU ETS was introduced in 2005 and is often referred to as a reference model for the development of climate change strategies and emissions trading systems elsewhere in the world. 
Therefore, an appropriate framework would be expected to ensure market regulation and supervision, legal certainty and systems for the management of essential information. 
The basic structures of the implementation systems should also be sufficiently sound. 
At the end of 2013, our auditors examined the framework for protecting the integrity of the EU ETS and the systems for the effective implementation of the programme at the Commission and in the Member States by Phase II (end of 2012). 
The audit was carried out on the basis of the risks involved in the creation of a functioning market for the implementation of the EU climate change policy and the difficulty of controlling an activity that is not tangible ("How to measure hot air?". 
Our auditors examined whether the EU ETS was adequately managed. 
To this end, they not only conducted desk checks and interviews with officials involved in the management of the EU ETS at the European Commission in Brussels, but also visited the competent authorities in five Member States (Germany, France, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom). 
In addition, documents were reviewed and experts consulted in two other countries (Greece and Spain). 
The auditors obtained further evidence by reviewing the documents of national authorities on 150 installations selected in these seven Member States. In addition, data from the EU Transaction Protocol 
Our activities 23 are analysed. The auditors were unable to inspect the installations on the ground, as they do not receive EU funding in the context of the ETS and therefore the Court does not have the access rights necessary for the audit. 
The evidence obtained by our auditors indicated a lack of supervision of the emission market and insufficient cooperation between regulators. 
For example, our auditors noted that the legal definition of certificates should be clarified and that the procedures for opening ETS accounts in the Union Registry and for monitoring transactions were not suitable to ensure sufficient controls against abuse. 
However, the initial situation was difficult: Member States were unable to effectively monitor cross-border transactions as they did not have direct access to the central database, and the Commission could not monitor the transactions because there was no legal basis to do so. 
In addition, our auditors noted that the systems for monitoring and reporting on emissions were not harmonised and that there were weaknesses in the control. In addition, the Commission's support and reporting by the Commission and the Member States were insufficient. 
From their findings, the auditors concluded that the framework for safeguarding market integrity is not sufficiently robust and that there have been significant weaknesses in implementation in the last phase, some of which require further action at this stage. 
However, our report also clearly shows that this innovative system has been continuously improved. 
At the time of publication of the report, the debate on possible reforms of the EU ETS focusing on the effectiveness of the system and on the management of excess allowances was still ongoing. 
However, in our report, we point out that consideration must also be given to the fundamental issues of market integrity and implementation, so that the EU can trust that this core instrument is sufficiently appropriate to meet the expectations of emission reductions and low-carbon technologies. 
We made some practical recommendations to the Commission and the Member States' authorities to improve market integrity and the implementation of the system in order to make the EU ETS a more powerful tool to achieve the climate targets by 2020 and beyond. 
The Commission agreed with the report's recommendation that significant remaining issues regarding the regulation and supervision of the emission market should be addressed in order to improve market integrity where appropriate. It also assured that many improvements have already been made for Phase III (2013-2020), taking into account in particular our comments. 
The report sparked great media interest and was presented to journalists accredited by the EU at a press conference in Brussels. 
In the EU and worldwide, the press reported that the EU ETS needs to be more closely supervised in order to improve the carbon market. In addition, the system needs to be more protected against market abuse, including the still high risk of VAT fraud. 
As is customary for all special reports, the Member responsible for the report - in this case Kevin Cardiff - presented the report to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and, in addition, to the Committees on the Environment of the European Parliament and of the Council, in order to inform them of the findings of the Court that could serve as a basis for future decisions on relevant rules and regulations. 
The Parliament and the Council welcomed our comments and recommendations and will take into account future proposals in order to improve the integrity and implementation of the system. 
Team of auditors (from left to right): Stefan Den Engelsen, Emese Fésňs, Kevin Cardiff and Colm Friel. 
Our activities 24 • Will the Fisheries Partnership Agreements be well managed by the Commission? 
(No 11/2015) - This special report examines whether the agreements are well managed. 
The auditors assessed the negotiation and implementation of the agreements, the monitoring of catches by the Commission and the selection and control of the measures financed. 
The audit found that while the agreements were generally well managed, the quantities negotiated were often higher than those reported for earlier periods. 
This regularly leads to incomplete use. 
As the EU makes full payments regardless of the de facto fishing activity, the actual costs were often higher than the negotiated price. 
There was also a lack of reliable, uniform and complete data on the actual catches of the EU fleet. 
When negotiating new schemes, the Commission should take into account previous utilisation rates, make payments more tied to actual catches and ensure that the new catch database is fully used by flag Member States and contains reliable catch data that can be monitored and kept up to date. 
The agreements aim to ensure the sustainability of the fisheries concerned by only allowing EU vessels to catch the surplus resources of partner countries. 
However, the auditors doubt that the so-called "surplus" can be reliably calculated because reliable information is missing. • The EU priority of promoting a knowledge-based economy in rural areas has been undermined by insufficient management of knowledge transfer and advisory measures (No 12/2015) - this special report examines in particular whether there are management and control systems to effectively implement knowledge transfer and advisory measures in the area of rural development. 
The audit found that the implementation of EU-funded VET and advisory programmes in rural areas is too expensive, often leads to duplication of existing programmes and favours incumbent training providers. 
The auditors identified poor administrative procedures in the Member States and insufficient monitoring by the European Commission. 
Member States relied too much on trainers' proposals and considered any type of training to be 'good' and eligible for public support. 
The lack of a fair and transparent selection resulted in long-standing and incumbent suppliers being repeatedly selected and receiving the majority of the funding. 
Member States should select training projects that meet skills needs identified in the context of a periodic analysis and should avoid the selection procedures being determined by the providers. 
The EU supports training and advisory projects in rural areas with funding from the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development. 
For the period 2007-2013, EUR 1.3 billion has been allocated to these projects. 
Together with the co-financing of the Member States, the total public support amounted to 2.2 billion euros. 
In the 2014-2020 period, the corresponding amount could be more than EUR 4 billion. 
Our activities 25 • The cost-effectiveness of EU rural development aid for non-productive investments in agriculture (No 20/2015) - This special report identifies in particular whether non-productive investments in agriculture (NPIs) are cost-effective and contribute to achieving the objective of the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development to sustainably manage agricultural land during the 2007-2013 programming period. 
The auditors concluded that although NPI aid contributed to the achievement of the objectives, it was not cost-effective, as the costs for 75 % of the projects visited were unduly high. 
Many of these projects were fully funded by public funds, although they were clearly profitable. The auditors visited four Member States, which spent a total of 80 % of the total EU budget on NPIs: Portugal, Denmark, the United Kingdom (England) and Italy (Apulia). 
Only five of the 28 audited projects proved cost-effective. 
The report warns that lack of cost efficiency may not be limited to the sample as the identified problems were due to deficiencies in Member States' management and control systems. 
Non-productive investments are investments that do not generate significant revenues or revenues or significantly increase the value of the beneficiary's operations but have a positive impact on the environment. • EU rural infrastructure support: The funds could be used much more efficiently (No 25/2015) - This special report examines whether the European Commission and the Member States have achieved a good cost-benefit ratio by financing roads, water supply systems, schools and other institutions through rural development programmes. 
The audit found that while some infrastructure projects made a positive contribution in rural areas, Member States and the Commission achieved insufficient cost-benefit ratios under shared management. 
With the resources available, much more could have been achieved. The need for EU funding for rural development has not always been clearly justified by Member States. 
The risk of supporting projects that would have been implemented without EU funding has not been effectively managed. 
Since 2012, the Commission has taken a more proactive and coordinated approach. 
If implemented properly, this should lead to better financial management in the 2014-2020 period. 
Under rural development programmes, EU funds of EUR 13 billion were allocated to rural infrastructure between 2007 and 2013. 
Our activities 26 100 80 60 40 20 0 Foreign policy EUR 65 billion 6 % Europe in the world The heading "Europe in the world" covers the EU's external relations (the "external policy"), including enlargement matters, as well as the EU's development and humanitarian aid. 
For the 2014-2020 programming period, the EU allocated 6 % of its total planned expenditure, i.e. EUR 65 billion, to these objectives. 
For 2015, the budget amounted to 7.5 billion euro. 
Additional appropriations will be made available through the European Development Fund, which is not part of the EU budget and is therefore not covered by the multiannual financial framework. • EU Police Mission in Afghanistan: mixed results (No 7/2015) - This special report assesses whether the EU Police Mission (EUPOL) has been well planned and coordinated, whether it has received adequate operational support and appropriate guidance, whether it has contributed to progress in the Afghan National Police and whether its exit has been adequately prepared. 
The audit revealed that EUPOL has met conditionally the objective of contributing to the development of a sustainable and efficient civilian police force under Afghan ownership. 
In an environment characterised by the lack of a trained, fully functioning Afghan police force, high illiteracy rate and widespread corruption within the Afghan police and justice systems, EUPOL has succeeded in contributing to the reform of the Ministry of Interior and the professionalisation of the National Police. 
However, given the persistent systemic weaknesses in the police and judiciary sectors in Afghanistan, there is a risk that the results achieved by EUPOL and more generally in the Afghan police sector after the end of the mission will not be maintained at the end of 2016. 
EUPOL's total costs for the period May 2007 to December 2014 amounted to almost EUR 400 million, with security costs accounting for almost one third of this amount. 
At the end of 2014, the EU deployed a total of 32 Common Security and Defence Policy missions, 16 of which were completed and completed and 16 still ongoing. 
Our activities 27 • EU support for the fight against torture and the abolition of the death penalty (No 9/2015) - This special report assesses the effective promotion of the prevention of torture, the rehabilitation of victims of torture and the abolition of the death penalty under the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. 
The audit showed that although EU-funded projects have an impact, the projects are often not targeted enough and have a limited range of actions, as the funds are distributed according to the watering can principle. 
While the allocation of funds was generally appropriate, the Commission did not take sufficient account of the priorities of each country in the field of human rights. 
Projects were often not well coordinated with other EU policies such as development aid and political dialogue. 
They were generally carried out by dedicated and competent organisations. 
The auditors' recommendations related to the targeting of financial resources, better coordination with other EU actions, selection and improvement of project proposals, performance measurement and sustainability of the beneficiary organisations. 
The European Union operates through diplomatic channels and grants to non-governmental organisations through the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights. 
Over the period 2007-2013, around 180 grants totalling more than EUR 100 million were awarded to projects to combat torture and abolish the death penalty. • EU support to timber producing countries under the FLEGT Action Plan (No 13/2015) - This special report examines whether the Commission has well managed the support provided under the EU FLEGT Action Plan to combat illegal logging. 
The auditors noted that while the Action Plan is a welcome initiative, the results are generally leaner. 
Aid has not been granted to wood-producing countries on the basis of clear criteria and its impact has been diluted due to the large number of competing countries. 
The countries concerned made very different progress. 
The lack of progress is due in particular to the lack of adequate planning by the Commission and no clear priorities in the allocation of timber-producing countries. 
The auditors recommended that the Commission set clear objectives and set the means to achieve them. 
Four Member States still need to fully implement the EU Timber Regulation, which was introduced to prevent the import of illegal timber into the EU market. 
Over the period 2003-2013, 35 countries received EUR 300 million under the Action Plan. 
Two of these countries, Indonesia and Ghana, made good progress towards a complete permit system for their timber. 
In general, however, there was little progress and many countries had difficulties in overcoming the hurdles that hindered responsible policy making. 
In the 12 years since the Commission's implementation of the Action Plan, no partner country has succeeded in establishing a fully recognised licensing system. 
Our activities 28 • The ACP Investment Facility: Does it offer added value? 
(No 14/2015) - This special report assesses whether the Investment Facility has added value to EU development cooperation with African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries. 
The audit showed that the Investment Facility actually provides added value for EU development cooperation with ACP countries and fits well into the EU's policy objectives. 
At the end of 2014, credit lines accounted for 28 % of the Facility's portfolio, compared to 14 % at the end of 2010. 
The increased share reflects the continued importance of the long-term financing provided by the Facility. 
In a positive sense, the Facility also acted as a catalyst by mobilising additional funds. 
However, the auditors noted that the contractual obligation to inform final beneficiaries about the financing by the European Investment Bank (EIB) or the Investment Facility is not always met and technical assistance is not always targeted at small and medium-sized enterprises. 
They made recommendations to address these problems. 
The ACP Investment Facility, established in 2003, receives its capital from the European Development Fund and is managed by the EIB. 
Under the Facility, development projects worth EUR 5.7 billion have been approved over the past decade. 
The Facility provides medium to long-term financing with the objective of achieving sustainable economic, social and environmental benefits. • Promotion of renewable energy in East Africa from the ACP-EU Energy Facility (No 15/2015) - This special report examines whether the Commission has successfully deployed the Energy Facility to improve access for poor populations to renewable energy in East Africa. 
The audit showed that some significant achievements were achieved, but that the Facility still needs to be better monitored. 
Although the Commission has made a good selection among the proposed projects, the project progress has not been closely monitored. 
Project managers' reports were of varying quality and the Commission did not make efforts to enforce reporting obligations. 
For projects known to have been affected by serious problems, Commission staff carried out too few on-the-spot visits and monitoring inspections to complete the information provided by the controllers. 
The report made recommendations with a view to tightening the selection, monitoring and sustainability of future projects. 
By mid-2014, a total of 268 million euros were granted, of which 106 million euros for projects in East Africa, which had by far the lowest access to electricity in Africa. 
Our activities 29 • Analysis of risks related to a result-oriented approach to EU action in the field of development and cooperation (No 21/2015) - The Special Report was drawn up in view of the increased interest recently in shifting the focus of EU development and cooperation policy away from activities to results. 
The auditors identified nine major risk activities: an inconsistent outcome-based terminology or no logical chain between measures, outputs, effects and impacts; increased complexity due to the inclusion of cross-cutting issues in EU programmes; the lack of harmonisation of aid delivery tools, outcome frameworks and accountability structures of development partners; Weaknesses in evaluation and results reporting; a lack of consolidated reports or an overview of the results of EU assistance; a lack of sufficient, relevant, reliable and up-to-date data; focusing on the budgetary outcome as an objective; Changes in the context of measures. 
The audit showed that these risk areas have been correctly recognised by the Commission in numerous different documents. 
However, further action is needed to exploit the full potential of the Commission's initiatives and to improve the EU's development and cooperation results. 
Against this background, a number of recommendations have been made which the Commission should take into account. 
Our activities 30 100 80 60 40 20 0 Financial and economic governance The EU economic governance framework aims to address problematic financial and economic trends, such as excessive government deficits or sovereign debt that can dampen growth and jeopardise the sustainability of public finances. 
Part of this framework is the establishment of the EU Banking Union. 
Following the 2014 report on the European Banking Authority, this special report was the second one we published on the subject. 
In 2008, Europe faced a financial crisis that turned into a sovereign debt crisis. 
The sovereign debt crisis was a consequence of different factors. These included weak banking supervision, insufficient fiscal policies and the difficulties encountered by large financial institutions (and the resulting costs of rescuing them, which were borne by the general public). 
The crisis broke in two waves across the EU Member States. It first met non-euro area countries in 2008-2009 and later spread to the euro area itself. 
Our auditors examined how the European Commission managed, during the crisis, the financial assistance provided under the Balance of Payments Facility and the European Financial Stabilisation Mechanism, for which the Commission received funds in the capital markets, with the EU budget serving as a guarantee. 
The audit related to the financial assistance granted to Hungary, Latvia, Romania, Ireland and Portugal. Particular attention was paid to the Commission's role in these programmes. 
In addition, our auditors analysed the Commission's cooperation with its partners - the European Central Bank (ECB) in Frankfurt and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) in Washington. 
They obtained audit evidence through in-depth reviews and analysis of documents, as well as through discussions with Commission staff, national authorities, the ECB and the IMF. 
The partners and the decisions taken at EU political level were not the subject of the audit. 
The audit revealed that the European Commission was not prepared for the first requests for financial assistance during the 2008 financial crisis, as warning signals were overlooked. This explains to a large extent the initially clear weaknesses in their administrative processes. 
The auditors identified four main problem areas of the Commission's crisis management: different approaches, limited quality control, insufficient monitoring and deficiencies in documentation. 
For example, they found several examples where countries were not treated equally in similar situations. In some programmes, overall conditions for assistance were less stringent and therefore easier to meet. 
They also noted that the Commission's teams had insufficiently reviewed key documents, the underlying calculations were not reviewed by anyone outside the team, the work of the experts was not thoroughly checked and the verification process was not sufficiently documented. 
Our activities 31 In the opinion of the auditors, however, despite lack of experience, the Commission has succeeded in carrying out its new administrative tasks and launching the grant programmes relevant to the reform process, which is to be regarded as a success given the time constraints. 
Furthermore, the auditors noted that the Commission was increasingly building up internal expertise in the further course of the crisis and working with a wide range of stakeholders in the countries concerned. Improvements in macroeconomic surveillance have also been introduced in subsequent reforms. 
For example, the programme's targets were met, the adjusted deficit targets were broadly met, structural deficits improved and Member States met much of the conditions of their programmes, albeit with some delays. 
In most cases, countries continued the reforms imposed on the basis of programme conditions and in four out of the five countries the current account adjustment was faster than expected. 
Our auditors pointed out that there are still a number of weaknesses and that the Commission needs to improve its procedures for managing financial assistance. 
We have made a number of recommendations to the European Commission to ensure that financial assistance will be managed more solidly in the future when Member States experiencing difficulties ask for assistance. 
The report found a broad echo, especially in the European media, but also in the United States and Australia. 
Like our other special reports, he is presented by our member Baudilio Tomé Muguruza responsible for the report to the addressees in the European Parliament and the Council. 
Team of auditors (from left to right): Didier Lebrun, Ignacio García de Parada, Kristian Sniter, Josef Jindra, Giuseppe Diana, Baudilio Tomé Muguruza, Adrian Savin, Daniela Hristova, Zacharias Kolias, Marco Fians and Daniel Costa de Magalhăes. 
Our activities 32 • EU supervision of credit rating agencies is based on sound foundations, but is not yet fully effective (No 22/2015) - This special report examines whether the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) has successfully established itself as a supervisor through the credit rating agencies in the EU. 
As a result of the financial crisis in 2008, credit rating agencies and their influence on financial markets have become increasingly prominent. 
At that time, credit rating agencies in Europe were hardly regulated. 
The audit found that while ESMA has established good foundations, its rules and guidelines are not complete and that there are still significant risks to be addressed. 
The auditors noted that ESMA was able to shorten the average duration of the registration procedure, but the procedure remains complex. 
Although the rating methods should be rigorous, systematic, consistent and subject to validation, ESMA's activities focus mainly on whether the methodologies are strict. 
The current framework for credit assessments in the Eurosystem does not ensure that all credit rating agencies registered with ESMA operate on an equal footing. This creates a two-class market structure that puts small credit rating agencies in an unfavourable situation. 
The auditors submitted some recommendations to ESMA regarding the registration procedure, the traceability of the risk identification process, supervisory procedures and IT systems. • Technical assistance for Greece: Improved delivery requires a stronger focus on results (No 19/2015) - this special report examines whether the Task Force for Greece has fulfilled its mandate and whether technical assistance to Greece has effectively contributed to the reform process. 
The Task Force was set up by the Commission in 2011 to support Greece's economic adjustment with numerous technical assistance measures. 
The auditors examined whether the Task Force has fulfilled its mandate and whether technical assistance has effectively contributed to the reform. 
They obtained evidence from the Commission, service providers, Greek ministries and other stakeholders. 
The audit showed that the Greek authorities received technical assistance under the mandate, but this has not always been sufficiently advanced by the reforms. 
Due to the urgency of the situation, the task force was set up in no time and without full analysis of other options or a separate budget. 
The Task Force did not have a bundled, comprehensive strategy document to provide technical assistance or set priorities. 
The assistance provided was relevant and broadly met the programme requirements, and the Task Force developed a flexible and diversified implementation system. However, there were weaknesses at project level. 
Greek Parliament Building, Athens, Greece. 
Our activities 33 Other 8.2 % 100 80 60 40 20 0 VAT 12.8 % TOR 13.3 % GNI 65.7 % Revenue The EU budget is mainly financed by revenue from three types of own resources. 
These include own resources based on gross national income (GNI) and value added tax (VAT) and traditional own resources (TOR), in particular customs duties on products imported into the EU and sugar levies. 
In addition, the EU receives taxes levied on EU staff salaries, contributions from third countries to certain EU programmes and fines from companies that violate EU rules and regulations. 
EU expenditure must be fully covered by revenue. 
In 2015, revenues amounted to 141.3 billion euros. • Fight against intra-Community VAT fraud: Further action is needed (No 24/2015) - This special report examines whether the EU effectively combats intra-Community VAT fraud. 
As a result of organised crime, the European Union misses annual VAT revenues of between 40 billion and 60 billion euros. 
Since the export of goods and services from one EU Member State to another is exempt from VAT, criminals in both countries can fraudulently evade taxes. 
As a result, both the countries concerned and the EU are deprived of revenue. 
The audit identified significant weaknesses indicating insufficient effectiveness of the current system. 
In order to combat intra-Community VAT fraud, the EU has a wide range of instruments, but some of these instruments need to be improved or applied more uniformly. 
In most Member States visited, there are no effective cross-checks between customs and tax data; Member States' tax authorities exchange VAT information, but there are problems in terms of accuracy, completeness and timeliness of the data; there is a lack of cooperation and there are overlaps of competence between administrative, judicial and law enforcement authorities. 
In order to improve the system, action must be taken by Member States, the European Parliament and the European Commission. 
Our activities 34 opinions in 2015 Also with our opinions on proposals for new or amended legal acts with financial implications, we contribute to improving EU financial management. 
These opinions are delivered at the request of the other EU institutions and used by the legislative authorities - Parliament and Council - in their work. 
We can also issue position papers and analyses on other issues on our own initiative. 
In 2015, we published eight opinions on a number of key areas: • Opinion No 1/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Regulation on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union; • Opinion No 2/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the financial rules of the Community Plant Variety Office; • Opinion No 3/2015 on a proposal for the Financial Regulation of the Single Resolution Board; • Opinion No 4/2015 on the proposal for a regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) (further details in the box); • Opinion No 5/2015 on a proposal for an amendment of the Regulation of the Committee on Budgets of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market; • Opinion No 6/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Financial Regulation of the Single Resolution Board; • Opinion No 7/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Regulation on traditional, VAT and GNI own resources and measures to make the necessary cash available; • Opinion No 8/2015 on a proposal for an amendment to the Financial Regulation for the 11st European Development Fund. 
In focus: Opinion on EFSI In response to the fall in investment since 2007, the Commission launched an "In-vestition offensive for Europe" in November 2014. 
The Investment Plan is based on the intervention logic that there is high investment needs in Europe and numerous economically viable projects for which funding sources are sought. 
The challenge is to make productive use of savings and financial liquidity to promote sustainable employment and growth in Europe. 
The Investment Plan is to be implemented without burdening national budgets and new debt. 
From this Investment Plan to its full implementation, the Commission expects the creation of 1 million to 1.3 million new jobs and the mobilisation of additional (mainly long-term) investment funds of at least EUR 315 billion over the period 2015-2017. High expectations are placed on the Commission's initiative. 
In order to contribute to the success of this initiative, our opinion drew attention to issues related to governance and legal frameworks, accountability and external audit arrangements, as well as financial liabilities to the public budgets. 
We also pointed out that an adequate level of transparency and accountability for public funds should be ensured for instruments where the EU cooperates with the private sector. 
The performance of these instruments should also be measured by the extent to which the objectives pursued by the activities financed are achieved. 
We drew attention to the fact that the proposal does not clearly describe the agreements between the Commission and the European Investment Bank. 
Our opinion has been taken into account by the legislators in Regulation (EU) 2015/1017 on EFSI. 
Our activities 35 contribute to EU accountability through high-level events and conferences We organise conferences on topics where we have identified risks and can contribute to the EU's accountability through our auditing expertise. This will raise awareness of the importance of sound financial management and control of EU finances. 
In 2015, we organised the two conferences described below, which are in line with our strategic goal of working with our partners in the process of EU accountability. 
During the year, we also organised seminars with internal and external experts on our premises to share knowledge of recent developments in EU policy and to use information for the planning and implementation of our audits.

Our President Vítor Caldeira opened the conference and Maroš Šefcovic, one of the Vice-Presidents of the Commission, gave an introductory presentation. 
Our members Szabolcs Fazakas and Phil Wynn Owen From left to right: Szabolcs Fazakas, Maroš Šefcovic, Vítor Caldeira and Phil Wynn Owen led the conference, which included panel discussions on the following two main areas: Obstacles to the completion of the internal energy market and Ukraine's important contribution to European energy supply as a significant transit country. 
We organised this conference as the EU faces a number of major challenges linked to each other in this area. 
These include the creation of an internal energy market to improve the competitiveness of the European economy, combat climate change and increase energy security. 
In our tests, we are increasingly focusing on energy and climate issues.

Our goal is to create added value for the EU's energy policy. With this conference, we have shown that we also want to support a democratic debate on these issues. 
Our activities 36 ECA Conference on the Future of Development Assistance From 20 to 21 October 2015, we organised an international conference on European development assistance in Luxembourg on the occasion of the European Year for Development, the adoption of the new Sustainable Development Goals of the United Nations and the Luxembourg Presidency of the Council. 
At the beginning of the two-day conference chaired by our Member Daničle Lamarque, our President Vítor Caldeira took the floor, followed by the Luxembourg Minister for Development Cooperation and Humanitarian Affairs Romain Schneider on behalf of the EU Presidency, the Chair of the European Parliament's Committee on Development Linda McAvan, EU Commissioner for Development Neven Mimica and UN Under-Secretary-General Grete Faremo. 
The conclusions of the conference were summarised by Marc Angel, Chair of the Committee on Foreign and European Affairs and on Defence of the Luxembourg Chamber of Deputies. 
The EU is the world's largest donor of development aid and works with many public and private partners, including international organisations, foundations, non-governmental organisations and states. 
It is becoming increasingly important to ensure the effectiveness of the aid, which can be achieved by paying close attention to the criteria for its allocation and evaluation. 
In this context, the Court plays an important role. 
The United Nations' new Sustainable Development Goals for the period 2015-2030 are more ambitious than the previous Millennium Development Goals and encourage the addressees to "think and act differently". 
Participants agreed on the need to align development aid with environmental, energy and migration policies and other policy areas and involve new stakeholders. 
In addition, development agencies need to adapt to the increasing diversification of financing and financial instruments: Innovative financial instruments contribute to greater leverage and convergence with market conditions, but at the same time make it more difficult to make financial decisions and determine the added value of aid. 
The European Commission gave a presentation on what a result-oriented budget should look like, specifying more clearly how EU funds will be spent and what results will be achieved. 
The Court also participates in the joint inter-institutional working group set up for this purpose.

Our activities 39 Cooperation with Supreme Audit Institutions The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (SCAIs). This cooperation is mainly carried out through • the Contact Committee of the SAIs of the EU Member States; • the network of SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; • international organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI) and their European Regional Group (EUROSAI). 
In accordance with the EU Treaty, the ECA and the national audit bodies cooperate with confidence while respecting their independence. 
Cooperation with the SAIs of the EU Member States is actively carried out within the framework of the Contact Committee. This includes an annual meeting and various working groups, networks and task forces dealing with specific issues of common interest. 
In 2015, the Contact Committee met in Riga. 
At their meeting, the members of the Contact Committee spoke about the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), preventing and combating irregularities and fraud, and the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. 
Questions on the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) were also addressed. 
The Contact Committee adopted a declaration on the accountability and financial control arrangements of the Single Supervisory Mechanism addressed to national parliaments and governments as well as to the EU institutions and bodies concerned. 
In addition, the Contact Committee agreed with the proposal to carry out parallel audits on the introduction of the SSM and the contribution of the Structural Funds to the Europe 2020 strategy and to the underlying risks to the sustainability of public finances. 
In November 2015, the Court invited to a kick-off meeting of the Structural Funds Working Group VII, where a work plan for a new multilateral parallel audit should be drawn up to identify the extent to which EU grants in the fields of education and employment make an effective contribution to the Europe 2020 strategy.
