Since November 2013, Kosovo* has participated as an observer in the network. * This designation is without prejudice to positions on status and is in line with UN Security Council Resolution 1244/99 and the ICJ Opinion on the Kosovo Declaration of Independence. 
Our activities 40 Multilateral (INTOSAI - EUROSAI) and bilateral cooperation In 2015, we continued our active participation and participation in the activities of INTOSAI and EUROSAI, especially in the respective working bodies. 
In November, with effect from the International Congress of Supreme Audit Institutions (INCOSAI), the Vice-Chair of the Technical Standards Committee of INTOSAI was delegated to the Court at the end of 2016. 
We also responded to the request of the SAI of Ukraine, which chaired the Working Group on Disaster Assistance Review, to host the first meeting of this working group. 
The Court is also an active member of the EUROSAI Task Force on Audit and Ethics, which aims to promote ethical behaviour and integrity in SAIs and public institutions. 
The main objective of the Task Force is to create and strengthen a framework for the promotion of ethical behaviour by providing the SAIs with appropriate practice-oriented guides and tools to support the day-to-day audit work. 
We participated in the 5th joint EUROSAI-ARABOSAI conference, which dealt with the supervision of state rescue plans, as well as in the 2nd joint EUROSAI-ARABOSAI conference. Young EUROSAI conference, which gave young examiners the opportunity to discuss questions on current issues. 
In addition, we visited the ORKB's Global World Leadership Forum, whose main topic was the role of public sector auditors in 2030. 
The Court maintains good bilateral relations with other SAIs. 
In 2015, for example, our delegation participated in an international seminar organised by the SAI of Poland for auditors from Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine in Warsaw. 
The members of the delegation spoke to the SAIs of the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania and the Slovak Republic about their experience with further development and capacity building to prepare for accession to the EU and provided training on our compliance and performance audit methodologies. 
Working with SAIs as part of international peer reviews is a common method to support best practices and promote quality assurance. 
INTOSAI's peer reviews subcommittee is responsible for keeping up to date the ISSAI 5600 peer review guide (ISSAI stands for International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions). 
In 2015, we contributed decisively to the revision of this guide, which will be submitted for adoption to the INCOSAI Congress in 2016. 
In addition, we played a leading role in the international peer reviews of the SAIs of Latvia, Spain and Switzerland. 
The expert assessment of the SAI of Latvia was very comprehensive and focused on methods and procedures for auditing accounting, compliance and performance audit and the efficiency of the support functions. 
The expert assessment of the SAI of Spain, led by the SAI of Portugal, also covered many aspects of the functioning of this institution. 
We were the sole assessor in the expert assessment of the SAI of Switzerland. 
As part of the evaluation, the appropriateness of the SAI's strategy as well as its planning and quality control processes were assessed. 
Our management 41 The College of the Court belongs to the College of the Court of Auditors from each Member State. 
Members shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, in accordance with the proposals of each Member State for a term of office of six years. 
In accordance with the Treaty, Members shall carry out their activities in full independence and for the general good of the European Union. 
The President shall be elected by members from among them for a period of three years. 
The terms of office of the President and Members are renewable. 
Most members are assigned to one of the five chambers. The boards adopt audit reports, opinions and position papers and take decisions on further strategic and administrative issues. 
In addition, each member is primarily responsible for his or her own duties in the area of examination. 
The member, with the support of his cabinet, coordinates the respective auditors' teams. 
It then takes over the presentation of the reports, opinions or position papers for adoption by the Chamber and/or the entire Court College and subsequently in Parliament, the Council and other relevant addressees, including the media. 
In selected cases and at the initiative of the members, a report may also be presented to the authorities of the Member States concerned. 
One of the members - Ville Itälä - is responsible for institutional relations. 
In 2015, on a proposal from the Member State and after consulting the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union appointed Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) as a member of the Court. 
The mandate shall apply from 1 September 2015 to 28 February 2018, i.e. the remainder of the current term of office of the previous Danish member Henrik Otbo, who died suddenly in February 2015. 
The College of the Court at 31. December 2015.

Our management 45 Flexible response in a rapidly changing environment We have developed a new work planning process that allows us to plan our work on the basis of our overall priorities and a comprehensive risk assessment. 
When planning our work, we now systematically take into account the points of view of the addressees in order to ensure the greatest possible relevance of our reports. 
With the support of our Member responsible for institutional relations, our President and Members cooperate with EU addressees, including the European Parliament committees. 
Flexible provision of resources for priority audit tasks We have organised our staff in flexible teams around specific tasks rather than in units to make it easier to assign priority tasks. 
This means that we can now use "the right person for the right job" and thereby make full use of their skills and potential. 
The reform also led to a more streamlined administration of the Court: Head of Unit became Senior Managers who share management tasks under the leadership of the respective Director and contribute their expertise in the areas of quality and supervision. 
We also strengthen our expertise in audit areas and introduce knowledge transfer tools to further improve our knowledge management processes. 
Timely delivery of products We have streamlined our testing procedures and simplified our task management so that we can deliver products in a timely manner. 
In recent years, we have steadily reduced the average time needed to produce our special reports and the reform will allow a further shortening. 
This is particularly relevant in the context of the entry into force of the new Financial Regulation. 
Better communication about our role and work We have revised our annual report to refer to the headings of the multiannual financial framework, making it easier to use and reader-friendly. 
In the annual report, we now report on the largest spending areas and performance over several years. 
In addition, we have strengthened the functions in the areas of communication and relations with the addressees and hired a speaker. 
Since 2008, we have been using key performance indicators (ZLIs) to inform management of the progress achieved towards our goals, to support the decision-making process and to provide our addressees with information on performance. 
They reflect our priorities and provide information about our performance and accountability as a professional audit body. 
The indicators are used to measure core parameters for the quality and impact of our work, paying particular attention to the point of view of important addressees as well as the efficiency and effectiveness of our use of resources. 
The ZLIs have been updated for the period covered by the Strategy 2013-2017. 
Quality and impact of our work We evaluate the quality and impact of our reports based on assessments by addressees and expert reviews. 
We also measure our presence in the media. 
We asked our main addressees - the Committee on Budgetary Control and the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets, the Council's Budget Committee, the main audited bodies at the Commission and the EU Agencies, as well as the Presidents of the EU-ORKB - to assess the relevance and impact of our reports published in 2015 on a five-step scale from "very low" to "very high". 
The responses show that 90 % of our main addressees assess the value of our reports as relevant to their work (compared with 94 % in 2014). 92 % believe that our work is effective (91 % in 2014). 
Assessment by addressees 10 % 21 % 45 % 24 % 2 % 0 % very low 20 % medium high 40 % very high Relevance of reports Probable effect of reports 60 % 80 % 100 % 6 % 23 % 45 % 24 % 
Our management 47 reviews by experts Every year independent external experts review content and presentation of a sample of our reports to assess the quality. In 2015, the auditors assessed four special reports and the 2014 annual reports. 
They assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale from "significantly impaired" (1) to "high quality" (4). 
Experts' assessments in 2015 were higher than ever in the last four years, with an overall average of 3.3 for both types of reporting. 
Follow-up of recommendations We contribute primarily to improving the financial management of the EU by making recommendations to the Commission and other audited bodies in our reports. 
Some recommendations can be implemented quickly, while others require more time due to their complexity. 
We regularly review the extent to which our recommendations have been implemented by the audited bodies. 
By the end of 2015, 73 % of over 600 recommendations we had formulated in 2012-2015 had been implemented. 
This represents an increase in the implementation rate of 69 % for the recommendations made in 2011-2014 compared to the implementation rate recorded in 2014.

It concerns the strategic objective of raising awareness of the Court, its products, as well as its audit findings and audit conclusions. 
In 2015, we identified around 3,400 online articles related to our special reports, annual reports and the Court in general. 
54 % of them concerned our audit reports; the other articles referred to the Court and its work in general. 
In 2015, the media reported almost twice as much on our annual reports as in 2014. 
On the other hand, the number of media reports on our special reports has decreased compared to 2014, largely due to the interest in a particular report from this year (EU-funded airport infrastructures (No 21/2014), for which more than 800 articles have been published). 
Efficiency and effectiveness of the use of resources We evaluate the efficiency and effectiveness of our use of resources based on the extent to which we are able to implement our work programme, carry out audits in a timely manner and ensure the expertise of our employees. 
We plan our audit and other tasks based on the annual work programme and monitor progress during the year. 
In 2015, we implemented our work programme to 88 %. 
While work on annual reports and special annual reports was carried out as planned, this was 69 % for special reports compared to our very ambitious planning. 
The completion of the remaining special reports, which was delayed due to audit evidence or unexpected complexity, was transferred to early 2016. 
These special reports mainly concern new or innovative audits, the completion of which may, by nature, take more time. 
The Court's reform project, which will be assessed under the heading "other tasks", progressed as planned.

Our management 49 preparation of the special reports In order for our special reports to have an impact, they must be submitted in a timely manner. 
In recent years, we have been able to shorten the time needed for exams. This was largely based on initiatives stemming from the 2013-2017 strategy. 
In 2015, we produced our 25 special reports over an average period of 17 months (19 months in 2014), for the first time in less than 18 months. 
We will continue to strive to reduce the time needed to prepare our special reports, in particular to respond to the new principle introduced in the amended Financial Regulation. 
In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we strive to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training (excluding language courses). 
The objective for the professional training of auditors was again exceeded, which shows the importance we attach to personnel development. 
If the language courses were taken into account, one examiner averaged 9.4 days of training in 2015.

In 2015, we continued the staff reduction of 5 years (2013-2017) by 1 % per year, as set out in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013. 
As a result, staffing was reduced from 882 officials and temporary staff to 872 in 2015 (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees). 
The auditors included 562 employees, including 113 employees in the members' cabinets. 
Attitude The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output. 
Our recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions. Staff shall consist of both officials and temporary staff. 
In 2015, we hired 63 employees: 30 officials, 17 temporary agents, 11 contract agents, four seconded national experts and one adviser. 
In addition, we provided internships for 74 graduates for periods of three to five months. 
On 31. In December 2015, only 15 vacancies were vacant (1.7 % of the total number of posts).

51 Equal relationship between men and women As with the rest of the EU institutions, we pursue an equal opportunities policy in terms of human resources management and recruitment. 
For several years, we have been able to maintain a balanced proportion of men and women among our employees. 
The graph shows the proportion of men and women by level of responsibility at 31. December 2015. These shares have hardly changed in recent years. 
Our Action Plan on Equal Opportunities aims to achieve a balanced proportion of men and women at all levels. 
According to the latest recruitment waves, 50 % of staff in grades AD 5 to AD 8 are women (an increase from 48 % in 2014). 
The renewal in the upper and middle management levels and the growing proportion of women in function group AD are expected to increase the proportion of women in management positions in the future.

Support for Examinations 53 Age profile Age group 20-24 25-29 30-34 35-39 40-44 45-49 50-54 55-59 60-64 65+ 0 % 0.3 % 3.0 % 8.0 % 13.7 % 9.6 % 20.3 % 20.9 % 19.6 % 20 % 25 % 4.1 % 0.6 % 5 % 10 % 15 % The age profile of the 31st century December 2015 shows that 52 % of our employees are 44 years old or younger. 
32 of the 69 directors and senior managers (46 %) are 55 years old or older. 
As a result, in the next five to ten years, when these employees retire, there will be a renewal in senior management positions. 
The examiner's profession requires continuous training in order to be able to keep up with career-specific developments and acquire new skills. 
In 2015, our employees completed an average of 7.3 days of professional training. 
The share of language courses in the total number of training days continues to decline. 
Language courses accounted for 35 % of the total number of training days in 2015 (compared to 43 % in 2014). 
Our main professional training activities concern the modernisation of our training programmes and greater cooperation with learning opportunities within and outside the EU institutions and bodies. 
We established a cooperation with the University of Lorraine (Nancy, France) to offer a postgraduate degree program "Audit of public organisations and policies" and a Master's programme "Management of public organisations". 
Cooperation with the European Commission, which offers language courses for our staff, and the European Administrative Academy, which helped us organise soft skills and ECA training day, has continued. 
In addition, we have expanded our range of courses even more through individually tailored e-learning courses and training courses in the form of integrated learning (blended learning). 
In addition, we continued our successful series of presentations held by internal and external experts on developments in the field of audit and other topics relating to the work of our auditors. 
Finally, we introduced a "Performance Recognition Awards" framework to honor the performance of non-executive staff with special training outside the Court. 
54 Translation Translation is an audit support activity that enables us to fulfill our mission and achieve our communication goals. 
In 2015, the total translation volume was higher than ever: almost 200 000 pages, an increase of almost 3 % compared to 2014. 
Around 99 % of the translations were completed on time. 
In addition to normal translation work, our translators provided linguistic support and interpretation at internal events and meetings during 26 audit visits across the EU. 
They also assisted in drafting preliminary observations and special reports and were thus more involved in the Court's key audit processes. 
Following the review of the translation workflow and the Court's reform, the Directorate for Translation improved its structures in 2015 by introducing assistant pools. 
A major project of the Directorate, GroupShare, will lead to significant improvements by further streamlining the work of the assistant pools to create space for efficiency gains and automation. It also unifies the procedures of all language teams. 
In 2015, the Directorate for Information Technologies focused its efforts on adapting our administrative information systems to support the successful implementation of the Court's reform and on preparing developments in the field of knowledge management to support the new organisational structure of the Court. 
In addition, all functions of the full version of the Assyst2 audit documentation system were introduced for work related to the declaration of assurance, performance audits and related reports. This is the end of this major project. 
Our new audit management system (AMS) has been put into operation: More than 300 plans were drawn up in the system and 180 audit tasks were defined and monitored with the instrument. 
Building on the technical foundations for mobility introduced in recent years (provision of the Wi-Fi network in all the premises of the Court, equipment of all staff with laptops), the Directorate is currently focusing on global mobility, i.e. access to all content at any location, at any time and on all devices. 
The project in terms of developing a solution that ensures that employees can access our information on all devices will help maintain the Court's business operations and increase efficiency and effectiveness. 
Maintaining business operations during the development and deployment of IT solutions was ensured, making critical systems available to 99.82 %. 
55 Management and Infrastructure The task of the Directorate for Finance and Support Services is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure to enable the Court to fulfil its mission and achieve its strategic objectives. 
The Directorate shall also ensure that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all our activities. 
In 2015, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and economic. 
Due to the exceptional situation following the Paris terrorist attacks in November and the subsequent crisis situation in Belgium, we tightened our security measures and acquired the necessary security equipment through public procurement procedures. 
Information on public procurement can be found on our website (eca.europa.eu). 
Buildings The farm currently owns three buildings ("K1", "K2" and "K3") and rents small space for its IT centre for data recovery and a meeting room. 
He also rents three offices in Brussels from the European Parliament and one office in Strasbourg. 
To ensure the cost-effectiveness of our building policy, we take into account three factors: Purchase or rental, follow-up costs and interinstitutional cooperation. 
In the development and implementation of our building policy, as in all our areas of activity, we strive to establish and meet the highest standards of transparency and accountability. 
The Eco-Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS) is a management tool developed by the European Commission for companies and other organisations to evaluate, report and improve their environmental performance. 
We started in 2014 with the development of an environmental m-nagement system2 that is in line with the principles of the European EMAS standard set out in the 2009 Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council3. 
Our goal is an EMAS certification by the end of 2016. 
In 2015, the EMAS project made the planned progress. 
2 The EMAS project at the Court was launched in July 2013.

Support for audit activities 58 Audit and accountability Discharge As the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure. 
In April 2015, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2013, which means that our annual accounts for 2013 have been finalised. 
We have carefully analysed the issues raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility and have also taken appropriate action in the context of our reform. 
We have reported on our follow-up to the European Parliament. 
Internal and external audit Our Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk control issues by providing opinions on the quality of management and internal control systems and recommendations to improve the management of our operations and to promote sound financial management. 
In addition, the Service supports the work of the external auditor whose mission is to certify the Court's annual accounts. 
Finally, the Internal Audit Service provides information on significant risks and corporate governance issues. 
The work of the Internal Audit Service is supervised by a Committee on Internal Audit, composed of three members of the Court and an external expert. 
The Committee regularly monitors progress on the various tasks set out in the Internal Audit Service's work programme. 
The Committee also ensures the independence of the Internal Audit Service. 
In 2015, the Internal Audit Service prepared specific reports on strategic issues such as changes in our annual report, mid-term review of the implementation of our strategy for the period 2013-2017 and follow-up on the implementation of the recommendations from the peer review process and the European Parliament. 
Taking into account the recommendations of the Internal Audit Service in 2014 that the internal control cycle should be strengthened, we updated our IT security system and formalised the existing risk management framework and existing guidelines. 
The Internal Audit Service monitored the implementation of the new guidelines and ensured that its recommendations were taken into account. 
We report annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit. 
External audit of the Court Our annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor. 
This is an important aspect in the Court's approach to applying to ourselves the same principles of transparency and accountability as for the bodies we audit. 
The report of the auditor - PricewaterhouseCoopers S.ŕ r.l. - on our annual accounts for the financial year 2014 was published on 15 September 2015.

This guarantee is based on the assessment of the undersigned and the information available to him, such as the reports and declarations of the authorising officers by subdelegation, the internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's audit reports on previous financial years.

01 With pictures it is best to bring the past 40 years to life. 
The photos above show the day-to-day work of the many hundred employees who have worked at the farm in recent decades. 
A selection of these photos was published in the course of 2017 on our website (eca.europa.eu) and on social media (@EUauditors). 
The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the external auditor of the EU and one of the seven institutions of the Union. 
The Court's College consists of 28 members, one from each EU Member State. 
The Court employs around 900 staff of all EU nationalities, composed of auditors and administrative staff. 
It was built in 1977 and is based in Luxembourg. 
We verify that the EU ensures proper accounting, ensures proper compliance with its financial rules, and whether EU policies and programmes are optimally used. 
Through its audit work, the Court contributes to improving the EU's financial management and promoting accountability and transparency. 
It warns against risks, provides audit certainty, points to weaknesses and successes, and provides guidance to EU policy makers and legislators. 
The Court makes its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, the national parliaments and the general public. 
The European Court of Auditors' buildings on the Kirchberg Plateau in Luxembourg, 2017

Foreword of President 04 Dear reader, dear reader! 
In 1977, the European Court of Auditors started its operations - 40 years later, we look back on many successful contributions to public accountability and EU financial management. 
An official ceremony took place in October 2017 on the occasion of the Court's Jubilee, attended by your Royal Highnesses of the Grand Duke and Grand Duchess of Luxembourg, President of the Republic of Estonia Kersti Kaljulaid, President of the European Parliament Antonio Tajani and European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. 
Their participation in the event demonstrates to a great extent the importance of the Court as a "financial certainty" of the European Union. 
Over the course of the year, however, we also looked forward. 
We discussed and agreed on a strategy for the remaining three years of the current Multiannual Financial Framework until the end of 2020. 
Our citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that they do not lose their trust in the EU and its institutions. 
People must be able to see that the EU acts with integrity, respects the rule of law, uses public funds prudently, pursues clear policy objectives and achieves the results it has promised. 
As an external auditor of the Union, we are well positioned to examine and report on these aspects accordingly. 
Throughout the year, we have published special reports on a wide range of EU policies and programmes, as well as analysis-based publications such as landscape analysis and rapid analysis. 
In addition, we have drafted several opinions on legislative proposals and, as every year, we have prepared our annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds, as well as on the EU agencies and many other Union bodies. 
This activity report provides a comprehensive overview of our activities in 2017 and provides important information about the Court, its budget and its staff. 
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President 
2017 at a glance 05 Our activities Our management • 28 special reports examining the effectiveness and • added value of EU policies and programmes in areas such as youth unemployment, environment, migration and banking union; • a landscape analysis of EU action in the fields of energy and climate change and a rapid analysis on staff reductions in the EU institutions; • • five opinions on new or amended EU acts with a significant impact on financial management, including an opinion on the Financial Regulation for the • EU budget and an opinion on the financing of European political parties; • Annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and on the activities under the European Development Funds with the related summary report "2016 - brief information on the EU audit"; • • 55 specific annual reports on the annual accounts of individual EU agencies, bodies and joint undertakings established in different Member States, including two summary reports; • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our institutional addressees and peers, such as the meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States, as well as conferences on youth unemployment and energy, climate change and impact assessment. 
We welcomed two new members: Juhan Parts (Estonia) on 1 January 2017 and Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary) on 1 September 2017. • We issued a new multi-annual strategy that serves as a guide to our work and management over the period 2018-2020. We also revised our work planning to ensure a more strategic, coherent approach to the planning of our audit priorities across the Court. We also reviewed our risk management policy and strengthened our financial procedures. • We continued the reduction of posts agreed between the EU institutions while implementing equal opportunities policy in recruitment and human resources management. 
Our activities 06 Audits We carry out various types of audits in the different budgetary areas of the EU: • Performance audits - the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes are considered here. 
The focus of these audits on the best use of funds is on specific management or budgetary issues, which we select on the basis of criteria such as public interest, potential for improvement, risk of inadequate performance or irregularities; Audits of accounts and compliance audits - consider the reliability of the annual accounts as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions (in particular in relation to the statement of assurance) and whether the systems or transactions in specific budgetary areas comply with the relevant rules and regulations. 
Based on the evidence obtained from our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the extent to which the EU's policy objectives have been achieved, as well as on the situation of the Union's budgetary and financial management. 
This information helps us to make appropriate recommendations that are relevant from the point of view of cost efficiency. 
Audit visits in 2017 The majority of the audit work takes place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg. 
At the same time, over the course of 2017, our auditors also carried out numerous audit visits to the other EU institutions, agencies and bodies, EU delegations, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, as well as to international organisations such as the United Nations involved in the allocation of EU funds. 
We also carry out on-the-spot checks on recipients of EU funds both inside and outside the European Union. 
Through these checks, we obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of EU policies and programmes as well as the collection and disbursement of EU funds, as well as from the respective beneficiaries. 
Audits are our core activity, frequency and intensity of our audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country, depending on the type of audit we carry out. 
In 2017, our auditors spent 3 670 days of on-the-spot audits in Member States and outside the EU (2016: 4 246 days). 
Within the EU, our on-the-spot checks are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCs) of the Member States visited. 
3 670 days on-the-spot audits in the Member States and outside the EU in 2017 and our auditors spent 2 300 days (2016: 2 510 days) at the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg as well as decentralised agencies and bodies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations or the OECD, and audit firms. 
To obtain and validate audit evidence, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies (such as the secure exchange of data and documents).

We work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to combat fraud at the expense of the EU budget. 
These cases will then be followed up by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and, where appropriate, cooperates with Member State authorities. 
In 2017, we continued to direct 13 suspected fraud cases identified in our audits to OLAF, although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activities in our audit work. 
In 2017, we led 13 such cases (2016: 11 cases), in which there was suspicion of fraud, to OLAF. The suspicion of fraud emerged as part of our audit work for the Statements of Assurance for the financial years 2016 and 2017 as well as other audit tasks. 
Publications Our publications: Special Reports, Annual Reports, Opinions and Analysis-Based Publications Our audit reports and opinions form an important link in the EU accountability chain as they are used to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's budgetary management accountable, in particular through the annual discharge procedure. 
In areas under shared management, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States also play an important role, such as expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures. Around 80 % of the EU budget is implemented in this way. 
Our range of publications includes • Special Reports setting out the results of selected audits on specific policy or expenditure areas or on budgetary or management issues; • Annual reports containing mainly the results of the audits of the accounts and compliance audits of the budget of the European Union and on the European Development Funds, but also on budgetary and performance aspects; • special annual reports on EU agencies, decentralised bodies and Joint Undertakings published separately; • Opinions on new or amended acts with a significant impact on financial management, drawn up either at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative; 
Our activities 09 • Analysis-based publications: • Landscape analyses are descriptive and analytical documents on complex, broad policy areas or management issues in which - often from a cross-cutting perspective - we present our experience and our accumulated knowledge on the selected topic; • Subject papers are similar to landscape analyses, as they are also descriptive and analytical documents on policy or management, but their topics are more limited; • in the Rapid Case Reviews, facts are compiled and presented related to very clearly defined specific topics or problems. 
All publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu). 
In addition, all special reports, opinions and analysis-based publications from 2017 are listed at the end of this report.

Our activities 10 Annual Reports Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2016 In our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2016, we examined how the EU funds had been used in the financial year under consideration and highlighted the areas where the risk of incorrect use of EU funds was greatest. 
In addition, we have specifically assessed all important areas of the EU budget on the basis of the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020 and provided information on budgetary and financial management as well as performance information. 
We also analysed why errors had occurred and made recommendations on possible improvements. 
Audit of around 1 000 payments made from the 2016 EU budget to beneficiaries Our auditors examined some 1 000 payments to beneficiaries made in the various spending areas of the EU budget. 
This means that we analysed around 1 000 different cases where EU funding had been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in the EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries. 
With the presentation of our annual report on the financial year 2016, the discharge procedure starts with the publication of our annual report at the beginning of the discharge procedure for the implementation of the EU budget carried out by the European Parliament. 
On 28 September, we presented our annual report to the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) of the European Parliament and subsequently to the plenary of the European Parliament, the ECOFIN Council and the national parliaments of the Member States. 
Our activities 11 EU annual accounts provide a true and fair picture; Main conclusions The annual accounts for 2016 have been drawn up in accordance with international principles and convey a true and fair view of EU finances in all material respects. Revenue in 2016 was not materially affected by errors. In recent years, the estimated level of error regarding payments made from the EU budget has continuously improved: 2016: 3.1 %, 2015: 3.8 % and 2014: 4.4 %. 
In 2016, a significant part of the audited expenditure - entitlement-based payments (as opposed to reimbursement-based payments) - was not materially affected by errors. The Commission's reporting on regularity is largely in line with our findings in most areas. 
However, the Commission should simplify performance measurement, for example by reducing the number of targets and indicators. Corrective action by Member States and the Commission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate. 
Without these measures, the estimated overall error rate would have been 1.2 percentage points higher. 
However, sufficient information was available to prevent, detect and correct a significant part of the errors. The total amount of payments to which the EU committed itself under future budgets has been higher than ever before and is expected to continue to increase.

Our activities 13 Our institutional addressees also need information on the results of the EU spending "This year's limited audit opinion shows significant improvements in EU finances." 
In the future, we will reconsider how we examine the EU budget: We will take greater account of the internal controls carried out at the level of the European Commission and the Member States so that we can better promote accountability and further improve EU financial management. - We will also focus more on performance aspects in order to ensure the optimal use of EU citizens' resources." How important it is to focus on the performance of EU spending and the results achieved has also been emphasised by Joachim Zeller, Member of the European Parliament and rapporteur for the 2016 discharge: Klaus-Heiner Lehne, President of the European Court of Auditors, at the presentation of the annual report at the plenary session of the European Parliament on 4 October 2017 in Strasbourg "Information such as error rates or, for example, information on whether funds from the Structural Funds have been used correctly are important, but we should also look at what has been achieved with these appropriations." Joachim Zeller, Member of the European Parliament, Rapporteur for the 2016 discharge 
Our activities 14 Annual Report on the European Development Funds The European Development Fund (EDF) provides financial support to African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) countries and overseas countries and territories. 
The EDFs are financed by Member States and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and, in some cases, by the European Investment Bank (EIB). 
Around one third of the total EDF error rate is due to non-compliance with procurement rules. 
Other major types of errors concern, inter alia, expenditure that is either not actually incurred or not eligible. 
Our annual report on the EDFs is published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca. europa.eu). 
The EU Agencies and other bodies as well as the European Joint Undertakings are based in various EU Member States. They carry out specific tasks in areas of utmost importance for EU citizens, such as health, security, freedom and justice and research. 
In 2017, the Court examined whether the agencies' annual accounts were reliable and whether the underlying transactions complied with the rules. 
When forming our audit opinions on the agencies' annual accounts, we took into account, where available, the audit work carried out by auditing firms. 
We also examined the communication infrastructure Sisnet, the European Schools, the contingent liabilities of the Single Resolution Board and the liquidation of the Galileo Joint Undertaking. 
We have worked on consolidating the results and are expected to issue a single report for the agencies in 2018. i Key data EDF budget 2016 3.4 billion euro Audited amount 2.8 billion euro Accounting Reliable Revenues Not affected by errors materially affected by errors (estimated error rate of 3.3 %) i Core data Audited by the Court 45 Agencies and other EU agencies, 8 Joint Undertakings Budget 2016 totalling 5.2 billion Euro staff A total of around 11 000 staff The Court publishes 55 special annual reports, including two summary reports 
Our activities 15 agencies (budget of EUR 3.4 billion, 10 364 employees) Our audit found that the annual accounts of all 41 agencies provide a true and fair picture. 
The financial transactions underlying the accounts were legal and regular for all agencies, except for the European Asylum Support Office, for which we issued a limited opinion on account of non-compliance with the public procurement principles. 
Joint Undertakings (budget of EUR 1.8 billion, 633 staff) The annual accounts of all eight Joint Undertakings were reliable. 
They represented the assets and financial position of the Joint Undertakings as well as the results of their operations and cash flows for 2016 in all material respects. 
In addition, the transactions underlying the accounts for seven Joint Undertakings complied with the relevant legislation, except for the ECSEL Joint Undertaking, for which we made a limited audit opinion, as we were unable to obtain sufficient assurance regarding the reliability of its internal controls on grant payments under FP7. 
All special annual reports and the two summary reports are available on our website (eca. europa.eu). 
In 2017, we published 28 special reports. 
In these reports, we examined in particular whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes were achieved, whether the results were achieved in an effective and economic way, and whether the EU funds created added value. 
We also made recommendations for improvements in terms of financial savings, better working methods, avoidance of waste or a more cost-effective achievement of the policy objectives pursued. 
The special reports focus in particular on the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes The focus of our special reports was on issues that reflected relevant issues for the EU, such as the sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, the creation of growth and the promotion of inclusion, migration and global development challenges, the Single Market and Banking Union, as well as ensuring the accountability and profitability of the European Union. 
At this point, we will take a closer look at two of these 28 special reports: a special report on food waste addressing the potential of EU policies to tackle this issue throughout the food supply chain, as well as a special report on the Greek financial crisis, which examined how the EU reacted with the economic adjustment programmes to the financial and debt crisis in one of its Member States.

Our activities 17 Special Report: Combating food waste: an opportunity for the EU to improve the resource efficiency of the food supply chain is a global problem of food waste, which has been increasingly at the heart of public and political debate in recent years, especially given the need to feed the growing world population. 
According to current estimates, around one third of the food produced for human consumption worldwide is wasted or lost, resulting in high economic and environmental costs. 
The EU auditors examined the role the EU can play in combating food waste Our auditors examined in particular the measures taken so far and the impact of the various EU policy instruments to reduce food waste. 
The focus was on the prevention of food waste and the facilitation of food donation, as these two aspects are given the highest priority in the fight against food waste. 
Our auditors interviewed Commission services' staff responsible for the policy concerned, carried out desk checks and carried out audit visits in five Member States: Italy (Lazio), Netherlands, Portugal, Romania and Finland. 
They visited the ministries concerned and carried out on-site visits. 
They also consulted relevant stakeholders in the areas of food manufacturing, retail, research and charities. "The EU can and should do more to combat food waste effectively," EU auditors concluded that while food waste could be tackled through a number of EU policies, this potential is not exploited. 
The current approach remains fragmented and incoherent, and coordination at Commission level is lacking. 
Our report identified a number of unused opportunities and potential improvements that would not require new legislation or additional public funding. In addition, the auditors recommended that existing policies be better adapted and set a clear policy objective of reducing food waste. 
The report was presented to the European Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the EU and a number of national parliaments across the EU. 
Both the European Parliament and the Council welcomed the report and agreed with the conclusions contained therein. 
The report also found a considerable echo on the media, especially on social media. 
Our activities 18 Special Report: The Commission's role in the Greek financial crisis Greece needed to ensure its financial stability After the 2008 financial crisis followed an economic downturn and a debt crisis in Europe, which made the weaknesses of the Greek economy obvious. 
In April 2010, Greece was no longer able to finance itself on financial markets and therefore requested financial assistance from the euro area Member States and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). 
Since then, Greece has participated in three economic adjustment programmes managed by the European Commission, the European Central Bank and the IMF - the so-called "troika". 
The third programme also involved the European Stability Mechanism (ESM). 
The total support amounting to EUR 368.6 billion was linked to political constraints set jointly by the Greek authorities and the lenders. 
These programmes aimed at stabilising the economic situation in Greece by meeting the financial needs of the Greek economy. This should prevent the crisis from spreading to the rest of the euro area. 
In return, Greece committed to implementing far-reaching structural reforms. 
The EU auditors examined whether the Commission had adequately managed the economic adjustment programmes. 
Our auditors assessed the Commission's approach to the first two programmes for Greece and designed the third programme. 
They reviewed the documents on EU grant programmes, analysed programme conditions and interviewed Commission staff, staff of national authorities (such as specialist ministries), the Bank of Greece, business and business stakeholders, and IMF, ESM and OECD staff. "Economic adjustment programmes for Greece: despite shortcomings, progress in the reform process", said the EU auditors Our auditors concluded that the economic adjustment programmes for Greece had provided financial stability in the short term and enabled progress in the reform process. 
However, the programmes in Greece have only led to a limited recovery. 
In addition, the auditors noted that the Commission had no experience in managing such a process, that the conditions of the programmes were neither sufficiently prioritised by importance nor embedded in a broader strategy for Greece, and that the macroeconomic assumptions of the programmes were sound. 
This special report was submitted to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and institutional stakeholders in Greece. 
The report was the subject of extensive media coverage and achieved the largest media echo of all the special reports we published in 2017.

Our management 26 The College of Members of the Court The term of office of the members of the Court is six years; Reappointment is permitted. 
Members shall carry out their activities in full independence for the general good of the EU. 
When taking office, they shall take an oath before the Court of Justice of the European Union. 
The College consists of 28 members, one from each Member State. 
The individual members are appointed by the Council of the EU, after consulting the European Parliament, in accordance with the proposals of the respective national government. 
In 2017, the Council appointed two new members: • Juhan Parts (Estonia), who took office on 1 January 2017; • Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (Hungary), who took office on 1 September 2017. 
President Members elect a president from among them for a period of three years; Re-election is permitted. 
The role of the president is that of a Primus inter pares ("first among equals"). 
In addition to his other responsibilities, the President oversees the performance of the Court's duties and represents him to the outside world. 
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany) was elected president. 
Audit chambers and committees The members are assigned to one of the five audit chambers of the Court. The boards adopt audit reports, opinions and other analysis-based publications. 
The chambers are under the direction of a doyen elected by the members from among them. 
Each member is responsible for his or her specific audit tasks. 
Members are supported by their cabinet. 
As of December 2017, the five examination chambers were headed by the following Doyens: Phil Wynn Owen (United Kingdom), Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria), Karel Pinxten (Belgium), Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain) and Lazaros S. Lazarou (Cyprus). 
Daničle Lamarque (France) chaired the Audit Quality Control Committee. 
Rimantas Šadžius (Lithuania) was responsible for coordinating the Court's inter-institutional relations. 
Decisions on further strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President. 
The members of the Court of Auditors met in 2017 for 21 college meetings.

Our Management 28 Strategy The next three years will be a crucial period for the European Union in which essential decisions must be made. 
We are aware that EU citizens need access to clear and reliable information so that the EU can successfully address the challenges that arise. 
Citizens must be able to see that the EU acts with integrity, respects the rule of law, uses taxpayers' money prudently, pursues clear objectives and achieves the results it has promised. 
As an external auditor of the EU, we can contribute to this. 
Our strategy for 2018-2020: In July 2017, we published our strategy for the period 2018-2020, in which we set four strategic objectives: • Provision of clear statements for our addressees; • greater focus on the performance aspects of EU action; • Improving the added value of the Statement of Assurance; • Directing our entire organisation to our products. 
After all, the EU is not about figures, but about people Through its external financial control, the Court can show what works in the EU's spending and activities and what is not, it can assist EU citizens in answering the question whether the EU institutions deliver results, thereby helping to strengthen trust in the EU. 
In this sense, the Court's audits must also address what concerns European citizens, its most important addressees at last instance. 
The 2018-2020 strategy identifies five priority areas for the Court's work in the coming years. 
Sustainable management of natural resources and combating climate change Investments for cohesion, growth and integration challenges related to migration, security and global sustainable development A functioning single market and stable monetary union financing and management of the Union while respecting accountability and economic viability 
Our management 29 As part of the development of our strategy, we placed a strong emphasis on internal and external consultation. 
We discussed the strategy with our staff and addressed Members of the European Parliament, representatives of EU Member States, the European Commission, other Supreme Audit Institutions and non-institutional stakeholders such as academics, think tanks, non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and private sector auditors. 
The Court's strategy for 2018-2020 is available on our website (eca.europa.eu). 
In January 2017, we decided to introduce new planning procedures, which we applied for the first time to our annual work programme for 2018 which was published in October last year. 
The most important changes in our work planning: • Drawing up a list of audit tasks for the Court as a whole; • centralised procedure for the selection of audit ideas, possible audit tasks and final audit proposals; • more flexible allocation of resources to and distribution of resources between the individual audit chambers, taking into account the workload; • Extension of the product range to include testing tasks that result in analysis-based publications; • Definition of high-priority audit tasks for which shorter deadlines apply. 
We have also agreed with the Conference of Committee Chairs of the European Parliament a procedure whereby all Parliament's standing committees can propose potential audit topics to the Court. 
The Court's work programme for 2018 is available on our website (eca.europa.eu). 
In the period 2013-2017, we applied seven Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform management about the progress achieved towards our goals, to support the decision-making process, and to provide our addressees with information about our performance. 
The indicators were used to measure core parameters regarding the quality and impact of our work, taking particular account of the point of view of key addressees and the efficiency and effectiveness of our use of resources. 
A revised set of performance indicators will be introduced in 2018, valid for the period 2018-2020. 
Quality and impact of our work We assessed the quality and impact of our reports on the basis of assessments by addressees and expert reviews. Another evaluation criterion was the follow-up to our recommendations to improve EU financial management. 
We asked our main institutional addressees and peers - the Committee on Budgetary Control and the European Parliament's Committee on Budgets, the Council's Committee on Budgets, the main audited bodies at the Commission and the European Agencies, and the Presidents of the EU-ORKB - to assess our reports. 
Similar to previous years, the vast majority of respondents rated the relevance and impact of our reports as "high" or "very high" in 2017. 
Each year, independent external experts review the content and presentation of a sample of our reports to assess their quality. 
In 2017, the auditors assessed six special reports* and the 2016 annual reports. 
They assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale from "significantly impaired" (1) to "high quality" (4). 
The results have changed only slightly in recent years, with the quality of our reports being assessed as "satisfactory". * In 2017, the verifiers assessed our special reports No. 3/2017, No. 4/2017, No. 5/2017, No 10/2017, No 14/2017 and No 17/2017.

In 2017, 65 % of the references in the online media related to our work and our institution were related to special reports.

The Court's reports, which received the largest media echo in 2017, were the special reports on the Greek financial crisis, registration centres for migrants (hotspots), fisheries control, greening and the Natura 2000 network. 
Our management 32 140 120 100 80 60 40 20 Special Reports of the Court - average number of online articles per special report 2013 2014 2015 2016 2017 The increase in media reports on our special reports in 2017 corresponds to a trend that has been observed for several years. 
While fewer than 1,500 online articles were published in 2013, this figure has risen to almost 7 000 in 2017. The average number of articles drafted per special report has increased from an average of less than 30 in 2013 to almost 130 in 2017. 
As part of our performance measurement, we also assess our use of resources, in particular our ability to carry out audits in a timely manner, implement our work programme and ensure the expertise of our employees. 
In 2017, an average of 14.6 months passed from the start of an audit task to the adoption of a special report. 
This is the shortest processing time since the beginning of the period 2013-2017. 
For the preparation of eight reports (29 %) published during the year, we took less than 13 months. 
It took an average of 16 months to publish the reports, about two months less than in 2016. 
This positive trend indicates that the measures aimed at achieving the 13-month target set out in the Financial Regulation are bearing fruit.

In 2017, 65 % of our special reports were published according to the original plan. 
The remaining reports have been postponed and will be published in 2018. 
In addition, our annual reports and all special annual reports have been published as planned. 
In line with the recommendations published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we strive to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training per year. 
In 2017, we were again above this target with 6.7 training days per examiner. 
If the language courses required for the efficient work of our auditors in all EU Member States are also taken into account, one examiner spent an average of 8.3 days of training in 2017. 
For the other employees, we have set ourselves the goal of providing an average of 16 hours (two days) of professional training (without language courses). 
In 2017, this target was met with an average of 2.3 training days.

Our staff 34 Staff allocation In 2017, we completed the 5 % reduction in staff for a period of five years (2013-2017), as set out in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013. 
At the end of 2017, 853 officials and temporary staff worked at the Court. 548 of them worked in the examination chambers, including 118 employees in the members' cabinets. 
Attitude The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background. 
With our recruitment policy, we follow the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and promote equal opportunities at all levels. 
Staff members include both officials and temporary staff. 
Open competitions are usually organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). 
In 2017, the Court hired 72 employees: 29 officials, 13 temporary agents, 24 contract staff (seven of whom left the Court by the end of the year) and six seconded national experts. 
In addition, we provided 71 university graduates with internships for periods of three to five months.

Our employees 35 Age profile The age profile of the 31st December 2017 in active employment shows that nearly half of our employees are 44 years old or younger. 
31 of the 68 directors and senior managers of the Court (46 %) are 55 years of age or older. 
As a result, in the next five to ten years, when these employees retire, there will be a renewal in senior management positions. 
Balance between men and women The Court pursues an equal opportunities policy covering all stages of the career of its employees. 
Overall, we have achieved a balanced proportion of men and women among our employees; 43 % of our auditors and boards are women. 
In recent years, we have succeeded in increasing the proportion of women in management positions in our examination chambers from 7 % in 2015 to almost 20 % in 2017. 
We continue to work towards achieving a balance between men and women at all levels of management. 
In addition, our Equal Opportunities Policy for the period 2018-2020 concerns issues related to age and disability.

In 2017, we further expanded our training offer; among other things, the number of courses in the fields of e-learning and integrated learning (Blended Learning) has been increased. 
We continued our successful series of presentations held by internal or external experts on developments in the field of audit and other topics related to the work of our auditors. 
We also organised several trainings and events where experts from other Supreme Audit Institutions presented knowledge and best practices on performance audits and audits of accounts. 
A good example of this is the annual "Training Day", organised in November 2017 in cooperation with the University of Luxembourg and attended by over 300 employees. 
We work closely with the European Commission, the European Institute of Public Administration (EIPA) and the European Administrative Academy (EUSA) to offer a wide range of training courses to our staff: This includes both specialist courses in the field of examination and courses for the development of personal competences as well as work-related language courses. 
In addition, we supported our employees in acquiring or maintaining professional qualifications and degrees in the areas relevant to the Court's role and work. 
In particular, we continued our cooperation with the University of Lorraine (Nancy, France), in which the postgraduate course "Audit of public organisations and policies" and the Master's programme "Management of public organisations" are offered. 
We also signed a cooperation agreement with the European University Institute (ECI) in Florence (Italy). 
In 2017, we established a partnership with the University of Pisa (Italy) and the Association of Chartered Certified Accoun-tants (ACCA) to organise a summer course in public financial control and accountability. 
Last year, we awarded the best submitted contribution with the Court's 2016 award for scientific work in the field of public sector auditing. 
37 We continued our Performance Recognition Awards program, which allows non-executive employees to participate in specific external training. 
Translation The Court's Directorate for Translations, Language Services and Publication has translated and revised over 211 000 pages. 
We continued our efforts to streamline translation processes and reduce the associated costs. 
For example, all our translation teams now use a collaborative work platform to increase efficiency. 
We strive to increasingly involve our translators in our core activities and to create further synergies with our auditors. 
In particular, translators in 2017 increasingly supported the auditors in the linguistic preparation of the special reports and the annual report. 
They also provided linguistic support to our auditors during 38 audit visits. 
Information Technology Our IT Directorate makes a decisive contribution to our auditing processes by optimising information flows using modern and secure technologies. 
We made further progress in document management and were able to fully digitise the processes in the area of production, acceptance and publication. 
We introduced a simplified tool to facilitate remote access via mobile devices. 
In addition, we performed a system upgrade (installation of Windows 10 and SharePoint 2013). 
In order to make better use of inter-institutional synergies, we introduced new systems for managing audits, missions and training, which are currently being used by other EU institutions. 
Support for audit activities 38 buildings The Court currently owns three buildings ("K1", "K2" and "K3") and rents office space for its data recovery centre in Luxembourg. 
K1 The K1 building, which opened in 1988, has offices for up to 310 employees and meeting rooms. 
In the basement there are parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, the library and the main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical facilities. 
The K1 building was modernised in 2008 to bring it into line with national health, safety and environmental requirements. 
As far as possible, the technology in the K1 building has been adapted to achieve compatibility with the K2 and K3 buildings. 
As a result, the three buildings form a single integrated technical unit. 
K2 The K2 building was opened in 2003. 
In the basement there are parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms and the fitness centre. 
The entire top floor is used for technical installations. 
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees; they also have meeting rooms, a conference room with interpreting booths, video conference rooms, a cafeteria and a basic kitchen area. 
The Court commissioned a study to assess the feasibility of setting up activity-related work areas and the modernisation of K2's technical installations. 
According to the study, the design of work areas could be improved and some technical installations need to be modernised. 
A detailed study on this project will be carried out in 2018; work is expected to start in 2019. 
As approved by the Council and the European Parliament in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining funds of the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation.

Environmental management As an institution of the European Union, we consider it our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all activities and we strive to continuously reduce the environmental impact of the Court. 
In 2017, we received the Eco Management and Audit Scheme (EMAS). 
We now successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015. 
Our goal is to systematically reduce our CO2 emissions. 
In 2017, for the third year in a row, we analysed the greenhouse gas emissions caused by our activities (i.e. our carbon footprint). 
The results of this study are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

In 2017, the Court's budget amounted to around 141 million euro. 
This represents less than 0.1 % of the EU's total expenditure, or around 1.5 % of the EU's total administrative expenditure. 
The share of appropriations used in the 2017 budget amounted to 98 %.

Accountability of the Court 42 Risk Management During the year, as required by the Financial Regulation, we reviewed the risk assessments prepared for each Directorate. 
The results of these checks shall be reflected in the annual statement by the authorising officer by delegation contained in the Annual Activity Report and shall be used for the risk assessments of the following year. 
Where necessary, we prepared action plans for ex ante and ex-post controls. 
In September 2017, following the implementation of these checks, we strengthened internal controls and financial procedures related to travel expenses and the management of service vehicles. 
Internal and external audit Internal Audit The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk management issues. 
It shall deliver opinions on the quality of management and internal control systems and report to an Internal Audit Committee composed of three members of the Court and an external expert. 
The Committee regularly monitors progress on the various tasks laid down in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Service and ensures the independence of the department. 
In 2017, the Service examined the implementation of the Court's 2013-2017 strategy, the operational structure of the President's Services Directorate and the management of our software licenses and products. 
It also examined the implementation of the Court's risk management policy and monitored the implementation of its recommendations to ensure that the Action Plans take shape. 
The Internal Auditor considers that in 2017 the existing governance, risk management and internal control procedures provide sufficient assurance that the Court's objectives are met. 
We report annually to Parliament and the Council on the results of internal audit work. 
External audit Our annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor. 
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying to ourselves the same principles of transparency and accountability as for the bodies we audit. 
The auditor's report - PricewaterhouseCoopers S.ŕ r.l. - on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2016 was published on 31 October 2017. 
Discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is subject to the discharge procedure. 
In April 2017, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2015. 
This means that our financial statements for 2015 have been finalised. 
As every year, we have carefully analysed the issues raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility, took appropriate action and reported to the European Parliament on our follow-up.

European Court of Auditors 4 About the Court The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the external auditor of the European Union. 
It was established in 1977 and is one of the seven institutions of the EU. 
The Court is based in Luxembourg and employs around 900 staff of all EU nationalities, composed of auditors and staff in horizontal services and administration. 
One member from each EU Member State belongs to the Court's College. 
We check whether the EU ensures proper accounting, correctly implements its financial rules, and whether its policies and programmes achieve the objectives pursued and ensure optimal use of funds. 
Through its audit work, the Court contributes to improving the EU's financial management and promoting accountability and transparency. 
The Court makes its observations and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council of the EU, national governments and parliaments and the general public. 
President's foreword 5 Dear reader, dear reader! 
We are now increasingly focusing on assessing the performance of EU action, communicating our statements to the Court's audience in a clear form and increasing the value of our work for our stakeholders. 
In this activity report, we provide an overview of our work in 2018 in which we published the highest number of special reports, analyses and opinions so far. 
You will also find information about our employees, our management and our finances. 
Our reports provide an impartial assessment of the Union's policies and programmes and the quality of EU financial management within and outside the European Union. 
We examine whether EU spending complies with the rules and whether Union policies and programmes ensure optimal use of funds. 
We will be delighted to work with the newly elected European Parliament and the new European Commission to further improve EU financial management and ensure that the EU achieves results. 
This report manifests our determination to continue to adapt the Court's organisation in order to "prepare us for the future" and continue to shape developments in the field of public sector audit.

Our activities Strategy 2018 is the first year of our current strategy, which covers the period up to and including 2020. 
Our strategic objectives for this three-year period are: O Improving the added value of the Statement of Assurance with regard to the current EU financial management, o stronger focus on the performance aspects of EU action, o communicating clear statements to our audience. 
In addition, we have agreed to align our overall organisation even better with our products. 
In order to implement our strategy, we have agreed on an action plan for these objectives in order to remain among the leaders in public sector audit developments. 
At the end of 2018, all these measures were underway. 
At the same time, we have already commissioned an independent peer review process to implement our strategy. The expert assessment is expected to be completed by the end of 2019 - further information in the Court's accountability chapter. 
Progress towards achieving our strategic objectives 7 
In focus - the communication activity around our products Making clear statements for our target group Communication is crucial if we want to achieve our strategic goal of communicating clear statements for our target group. It consists of the political institutions of the EU and the Member States responsible for the control and management of the Union's policies and programmes, the other Supreme Audit Institutions, companies and industrial organisations, scientists and, last but not least, the general public - our main stakeholder. 
In 2018, we saw the media's interest in our work. 
Our special reports in particular attracted great interest in the media and were also discussed more and more in national and EU-oriented media channels - further information in the chapter on the media presence. 
In 2018, we published 12 audit previews (previously referred to as "background papers"). These are intended to serve as a source of information for all those interested in specific policy areas or programmes for which audits are underway. 
The information presented in it is based on the preparatory work before the start of an ongoing audit task. 
Audit projections have contributed to the stable and balanced output of the Court's publications throughout the year: 2018 was the first year in which there was no single month without a ECA release. 
We will continue to publish this type of communication products in 2019. 8 
Journal While our findings and recommendations for improving EU financial management are set out in our audit reports, the Court's journal focuses on our way of working and our staff who produce reports on different areas. 
Now each issue is dedicated to a different overarching theme. 
In 2018, the Court's journal focused on a wide range of issues such as EU pre-accession assistance, Parliament's financing and audit and EU financial and economic governance, as well as our special reports, our work programme, our international cooperation and our forward-looking actions with the aim of "preparing the Court for the future".
