Audits Stronger focus on performance We carry out different types of audits in the different areas of the EU budget: O Performance audits - the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes are considered here. The focus of these audits on optimal use of funds is on specific management or budgetary issues. 
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court weighs the risks to profitability or compliance, the level of revenue or expenditure concerned, and the political and public interest; O Audits of accounting and compliance audits - consider the reliability of the annual accounts as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying financial transactions - in particular in relation to the statement of assurance - and whether the systems in specific budgetary areas comply with the rules. 
Our random sampling procedure ensures the same probability of testing for each euro spent. 
Our audits focus on issues that reflect relevant issues for the EU, such as sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, migration and global development challenges, Single Market and Banking Union, and ensuring the accountability and profitability of the European Union. 
Based on the evidence obtained in our audit work, our reports draw clear conclusions on the extent to which the EU's policy objectives have been achieved, as well as the state of the Union's budgetary and financial management. 
Our audits comply with internationally recognised public sector audit principles. 
The audit work is divided into the following phases: 10 
Planning Determination of the expediency and feasibility of a proposed audit. 
Multidisciplinary teams shall gather on-the-spot audit work in the Commission's Headquarters as well as in Member States and beneficiary countries. 
Drafting 03 04 05 06 11 01 02 Clear, structured presentation of the main findings and conclusions. 
Confirmation of the facts and findings by the audited body. 
Adoption of the report by the Audit Chamber or the entire Court College. 
Publication of the special report in 23 official languages together with the reply of the audited body. 
Work planning audit priorities are based on the EU's main concerns Our work programme is decided annually by the members of the Court. 
In January 2018, President Lehne presented the 2018 Work Programme to the Conference of Committee Chairs of the European Parliament and invited all Parliament's committees to propose potential audit topics for the 2019 Work Programme as part of the annual stakeholder consultations. 
12 In October 2018, we published the first work programme prepared in accordance with the new strategy. In this work programme for 2019, we presented in detail our audit priorities and the 36 reports and analysis-based products planned for this year. 
These tasks covered, at least in part, 29 of the 69 proposals submitted by Parliament (42 %) (2017: 32 %. 
Our audits will continue to address key issues such as the sustainable use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, migration, security and global development, the Single Market and the EU's accountability and profitability to determine whether the EU achieves what it has promised. 
On-site audits 3 761 days of audit work - inside and outside the EU The majority of our audit work takes place at the Court's premises in Luxembourg. 
At the same time, our auditors also carry out numerous audit visits to the European Commission, the main body audited by the Court; this also applies to the other EU institutions, agencies and bodies and the EU Delegations, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, as well as international organisations, to which EU funds are channelled. 
In addition, we carry out on-site audits within and outside the European Union with beneficiaries of EU funds. 
Through these audits, we can trace the audit path and obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of Union policies and programmes, as well as the collection or disbursement of EU funds, as well as from the respective beneficiaries. 13 
The frequency and intensity of our audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country depends on the type of audit we carry out. 
In 2018, our auditors spent 3 761 days (2017: 3 670 days) with on-site inspections in Member States and outside the EU. 
Within the EU, our on-the-spot audits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited. 
In addition, our auditors spent 2 723 days (2017: 2 300 days) at the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg as well as decentralised agencies and bodies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations or the OECD, and audit firms. 
To obtain and validate audit evidence, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies, such as the secure exchange of data and documents. 14

We work closely with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to combat fraud at the expense of the EU budget. 
These cases will then be followed up by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and, if necessary, cooperates with the authorities of the Member States. 
Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activity. 
In 2018, we led nine such cases (2017: 13 cases), in which there was a suspicion of fraud, to OLAF. 
Additional information on the nature of suspected fraud reported to OLAF and related recoveries, as recommended by OLAF, can be found in our annual reports on the general budget of the EU. 16 
Publications New record: highest number of publications in 2018 Our audit reports, analyses and opinions form an important link in the EU accountability chain. 
They help the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union to monitor and verify the EU's achievement of its policy objectives and to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's budgetary management accountable, in particular in the context of the annual discharge procedure. 
These are primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies. 
National, regional and local authorities in the Member States also play an important role in areas under shared management where most of the EU budget is spent; these include, among others, agricultural and cohesion measures.

To our publications: Special and annual reports setting out the results of selected audits on specific policy or expenditure areas or on budgetary or management issues; O Annual Reports containing mainly the results of the audits of the accounts and compliance audits of the budget of the European Union and on the European Development Funds, but also on budgetary and performance aspects; O Special Annual Reports on EU Agencies, Decentralised Bodies and Joint Undertakings published separately. 
Opinions and analysis-based publications o Opinions on new or amended acts with a significant impact on financial management, either mandatory under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU) or produced at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative; O Topic papers are descriptive and analytical documents on policy or management with a focus on specific issues; O Landscape analyses are similar to thematic papers, but they focus on complex, broad policy areas or management issues, often from a cross-cutting perspective; rapid Case Reviews, which compile facts related to very clearly defined specific topics or problems. If necessary, they include an evaluation that allows a better understanding of these facts. 
Finally, we present background information on future or ongoing audit tasks in the form of audit previews - further information in the chapter on communication activity around our products. 
All our publications are available on our website (eca.europa.eu) and listed at the end of this report. 18

Special Reports We assess the performance of EU actions in our special reports In line with our strategy for 2018-2020, we are increasingly focusing on assessing the performance of EU action in order to ensure that the resources of EU citizens are optimally used. 
In 2018, we published 35 special reports (2017: 28 special reports) on the different areas of EU spending, where we addressed the challenges facing the EU, such as air pollution, the high-speed rail network, the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, banking supervision and the financing of non-governmental organisations (NGOs). 
In these special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved in an effective and economic way, and whether EU funds have created added value - i.e. whether they have achieved more than can be achieved by action at national level alone. 
We also make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste or achieving the policy objectives more cost-effectively. 
At this point, we will examine two of our special reports from 2018: a special report on high-speed rail transport in the EU and one on the Facility for Refugees in Turkey. 
In line with the EU Financial Regulation, we strive to prepare our special reports within 13 months. 20

Special report in focus European high-speed rail network: not a reality, but an ineffective patchwork The high-speed rail transport has numerous advantages for passengers. 
It is a convenient, safe, flexible and environmentally sustainable mode of transport. 
Improved links between regions in the EU will also make them more competitive and contribute to European integration by bringing people closer together. 
In this way, we analysed the different connections, travel times and prices for business and private travellers. 
We also examined whether the co-financed investments in high-speed railway lines were cost-effective and effective, well thought out and planned. 
The Court concluded that the European high-speed rail network is merely an inefficient patchwork of individual Member States lines which are insufficiently connected. 
There is no realistic long-term plan for connecting the various parts of the existing EU network; High-speed lines crossing national borders are not one of the priorities of each Member State and the European Commission does not have the powers to force Member States to do so. 
In such circumstances, EU co-financing for high-speed rail will generate low added value. 
However, there is also a good news: The number of passengers using high-speed rail in Europe is growing steadily. For example, there has been an increase of about 15 billion passenger kilometers in 1990 to over 124 billion in 2016. 
Both institutions welcomed the report and agreed with our conclusions. 
We also presented it to numerous national authorities and SAIs, as well as researchers, industry stakeholders and the media. 
Across the EU, the media, in particular EU-oriented media and financial media, dealt extensively with this report, especially in Spain and Germany.

Special report in focus The Facility for Refugees in Turkey: While support is helpful, optimal use of funds can only be achieved with improvements Turkey has welcomed with almost 4 million people as many refugees as no other country in the world. 
About 3.5 million of these refugees are Syrians, most of whom live outside refugee camps. 
The support under the Facility for Refugees in Turkey, endowed with a total of EUR 6 billion by the EU and its Member States, covers humanitarian and non-humanitarian activities for refugees and host communities. 
As part of the political agreement, Turkey was required to end irregular migration from Turkey to the EU. 
Humanitarian projects have been able to meet the basic needs of refugees, but in some cases the expected optimal use of funds or the Facility's objective of ensuring effective coordination of this support has not been achieved. 
The audited humanitarian projects provided helpful support for the refugees. 
An example: The social safety net for emergencies helped 1.3 million refugees with cash assistance. 
However, half of the projects have not yet achieved the expected effects - a lasting positive impact that can be maintained without further financial support - and for nine out of ten projects the duration had to be extended. 
The timely implementation of projects managed by NGOs has been hampered primarily by the difficult working environment. 
tracking. This was due to the Turkish authorities' refusal to grant access to the data of the eligible beneficiaries of the two cash aid projects in our sample, totalling EUR 1.1 billion. 
We presented our report at a joint meeting attended by the Committee on Development, the Committee on Foreign Affairs and the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament, and subsequently also the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. 
He was also presented to the Council of the EU Council Working Party on Enlargement and Accession Countries as well as to the press. 
Particularly in Germany, this report has attracted a great deal of media interest, but also in Denmark, Austria, the Benelux countries and the Mediterranean countries, as well as in the EU-oriented media.

Annual Reports Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2017 signed accounts, full audit opinion on revenue, limited opinion on expenditure Each year we examine the revenue and expenditure of the EU budget and examine whether the annual accounts are reliable and that revenue and expenditure transactions are in line with financial rules at EU and Member State level. 
In addition, we specifically assess all important areas of the EU budget, based on the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020, and provide information on budgetary and financial management as well as performance information. 
Furthermore, we analyse why errors have occurred, make recommendations on possible improvements and examine whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been put into practice. 
As part of our most recent annual report on the EU budget for the financial year 2017, our auditors examined a sample of around 700 payments totalling EUR 100 billion to beneficiaries made in the various areas of expenditure of the EU budget. 
This means that we analysed around 700 different cases where EU funding had been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in the EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries.

This extensive work forms the basis for our Statement of Assurance, which we must submit to the European Parliament and the Council in accordance with our mandate set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. 
As in previous years, the Court delivered a full audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's accounts and revenues. 
In addition, for the second year in a row, we were able to present a limited (and no failed) audit opinion on EU spending. 
A significant part of the audited expenditure in 2017 did not show a material error rate. 
In addition, the estimated error rate for payments in 2017 was 2.4 %, after remaining 3.1 % in 2016 and 3.8 % in 2015. 
The publication of our annual report is at the beginning of the discharge procedure carried out by the European Parliament, in which the EU legislative and budgetary authority, on a recommendation from the Council, decides whether the management of the EU budget by the Commission and other bodies has been satisfactory. 
We presented our annual report to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament on 4 October at the same time as its publication and subsequently also to the plenary of the European Parliament and the ECOFIN Council, as well as to the national parliaments and authorities of 14 Member States.

For cohesion expenditure, we assessed the control and reliability framework 2014-2020 and the reliability of the information provided by the Commission to demonstrate regularity. 
This was a first step on the way to the potential design of the Statement of Assurance as a testat-oriented audit. 
With the changed approach and the transition to a testat-oriented audit, we generally intend to take greater account of the different levels of internal control at the European Commission and the Member States' authorities responsible for managing EU spending. 
This makes it clearer where weaknesses remain in both the European Commission and the Member States, allowing us to contribute to the promotion of accountability and further improvement of EU financial management. 
This approach shall only apply if the relevant conditions laid down in the international audit principles are complied with. 29

Opinions In addition, we also contribute to improving the EU's fiscal governance by publishing opinions on Commission proposals for new or amended legislative acts. 
In the case of acts with significant financial implications, the Court's opinions are required under EU law. 
These are mainly used by the legislative authority - the European Parliament and the Council - in their work. 
Opinions may also be launched at the request of other institutions or at the Court's own initiative. 
In 2018, we published ten opinions - the highest number so far - on different areas of EU governance. 
On the one hand, these concerned mainly the Commission's legislative proposals for the new MFF, such as the reform of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), the effectiveness of the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) and its cooperation with the future European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO), and the linking of EU funding with respect to the rule of law and the protection of whistleblowers. 
Focus - Opinion on CAP reform There is a need for a greener and consistently performance-based CAP that focuses more on accountability When the European Commission published its legislative proposal for the new CAP post-2020, it stressed that environmental and climate objectives would be a very high priority. 
However, in our opinion on CAP reform, we pointed out that many of the policy options proposed differed only marginally from the current CAP regime. 
In particular, most of the budget will still be direct payments to farmers on the basis of the number of hectares owned or used. 
We also noted that this instrument is not the most economical way to support an adequate income and that it does not take into account a large number of environmental concerns. 
Furthermore, the Commission's assessment of the CAP's contribution to the EU's climate objectives seemed unrealistic; for this reason, the Court recommends greener and consistently performance-based plans for the next CAP, which should also focus more on accountability. 34 
In accordance with the procedure we apply in our reports, this opinion has been presented to the European Parliament's committees, in particular the Committee on Agriculture and the Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council, the environmental and agricultural stakeholders and the press. 35 
Analysis-based publications: Landscape analyses, topic papers and rapid case reviews (Rapid Case Reviews) Analytical overview of publicly available information and our own work of the Court Landscape Analysis In 2018, we prepared two landscape analyses. 
In the first, the Court dealt with the application of Union law in practice and stated that the Commission's supervisory activities with regard to the application of Union law by Member States should be strengthened. 
In the second landscape analysis, we looked at mobility and transport and valued them as the cornerstones of European integration. 
However, we expressed concerns about the investment lag as the modernisation of the EU transport network is hampered by the decrease in investment in transport infrastructure. 
In 2018, we published a total of six topic papers: five on the Commission's proposals for the future MFF and one on the integration of migrants in the EU. 
The Court's comments on the MFF focused in particular on the proposed procedure for setting the spending priorities for the EU, flexibility of the EU budget, performance orientation and administrative simplification, as well as accountability and auditing arrangements. 
We welcomed the Commission's efforts to modernise the post-2020 EU budget, but at the same time showed several potential risks, identified a number of weaknesses and proposed concrete improvements. 
We pointed out that effective parliamentary scrutiny requires sound accountability arrangements and that the Court should, in principle, be designated as an external auditor for all EU-created bodies. 
In the only rapid analysis we presented in 2018 on cohesion, we found that the refund of VAT (VAT) is error-prone and is not always an optimal use of EU funds. 
We considered that the reimbursement of VAT to public authorities should no longer be possible in the post-2020 period of expenditure co-financed by the EU. 36

Cooperation with EU Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (SAIs) In active cooperation with the EU SAIs: joint call to address weaknesses in the rules on accountability and audits for EU banking supervision Our cooperation with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States takes place primarily within the framework of the Contact Committee of the EU-ORKB Presidents. 
In October 2018, we actively participated in the annual meeting of the Contact Committee, hosted by the SAI of Croatia under its own chairmanship. 
The discussions focused on interacting with EU citizens and making SAIs available to the public. 
Court President Klaus-Heiner Lehne speaks to the Presidents of the EU-ORKB at the annual meeting of the Contact Committee in Dubrovnik, Croatia, in October 2018 Together with the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the 28 Member States, we appealed to national governments and parliaments as well as the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission to address a number of weaknesses in the rules on accountability and audits for EU banking supervision. 
We also participated and participated in the activities of several working bodies of the Contact Committee, including the VAT Working Group, the Financial Policy Audit Network, the Europe 2020 Strategy Review Network and the European Banking Union Task Force, and in other activities in the areas of public sector financial reporting and public procurement audit. 
We also coordinated the preparation of the Contact Committee's first Audit Compendium (Youth Unemployment and Young People's Vocational Inclusion) based on audit reports prepared by 14 EU-ORKBs between 2013 and 2017. 
With the publication of the Examination Compendium, the Contact Committee presents a new product 44 
INTOSAI/EUROSAI In 2018, we continued our active participation and participation in the activities of the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI), in particular in our role as Deputy Chair of the Committee for Technical Standards (since December 2016) and as a member of the Subcommittee for Audit of Accounting and Accounting, the Subcommittee for the Audit of Legal Standards and the Subcommittee for Performance Audits. 
We also actively participated in the activities of other INTOSAI working bodies, including the peer reviews subcommittee, the Environmental Audit Working Group, the Financial Modernisation and Regulatory Reform Working Group, and the Task Force on Professionalisation of Auditors. 
We also actively participated in the activities of the European Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI), the European Regional Group of INTOSAI, in particular the Working Group on Environmental Audit, the IT Audit Working Group, the Audit & Ethics Task Force and several workshops and seminars. 
In addition, we support the SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries (Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo1, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia and Turkey). This support is primarily provided through a network comparable to the Contact Committee and through our promotion of activities coordinated by the OECD. 
In 2018, seven ORKB auditors from the network participated in our internship program. 
We also actively contributed to the meetings and activities of this network. This included dealing with issues such as auditing of accounts and IT audit. 
Our management The College of Members of the Court The term of office of the members of the Court is six years, with reappointment allowed. 
The College shall be composed of one member from each Member State. 
The ECA does not play a role in the appointment and appointment of members. 
In 2018, the Council appointed four new members of the Court: O Eva Lindström (Sweden), Tony Murphy (Ireland) and Hannu Takkula (Finland) on 1 March 2018 and Annemie Turtelboom (Belgium) on 1 May 2018. 
In addition, the Council extended the terms of office of five members in office: O Pietro Russo (Italy), Baudilio Tomé Muguruza (Spain), Bettina Jakobsen (Denmark) and Joăo Figueiredo (Portugal) until 29 February 2024 and Iliana Ivanova (Bulgaria) until 31. December 2024. 
In 2018, the College of Members of the Court is 18 times (2017: 21 times) met. 
46 Meeting of the College of Members of the Court, held in Luxembourg on 28 February 2019 
The role of the president is that of a first among equals (Primus inter pares). 
His responsibilities include the institution's strategy, planning and performance management, communication and media work, legal issues and internal auditing. 
He also represents the Court in all its external relations. 
In September 2016, Klaus-Heiner Lehne was elected president. 
Klaus-Heiner Lehne, President of the Court, at his speech at the annual meeting of the College of Commissioners and the College of Commissioners in February 2018 in Luxembourg 47 
The President and Members 48 
Audit chambers and committees The members are assigned to one of the five audit chambers of the Court. 
They are under the direction of a doyen or a doyenne elected by the members from among them. 
Each member is responsible for his or her specific duties and is assisted by his/her cabinet. 
The audit work is carried out by professional auditors working for the directorates of the audit chambers. 
As of December 2018, the five examination chambers were headed by the following Doyens/Doyennes: Nikolaos Milionis, Iliana Ivanova, Bettina Jakobsen, Neven Mates and Lazaros S. Lazarou. 
Daničle Lamarque was chaired by the Committee on Quality Control, Oscar Herics headed our Ethics Committee and Samo Jereb was our Audit Committee, while Rimantas Šadžius was the member responsible for institutional relations. 
Decisions on further strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President. 
The European Court of Auditors comprises ten directorates for all its fields of work, five of which are the audit chambers, one for audit quality control, another to the President and three to the Secretary-General.

Performance Measurement Our new key performance indicators as part of the 2018-2020 Strategy Since 2008, we have been applying Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform management about the progress achieved towards our goals, to support the decision-making process and to provide our addressees with information about our performance. 
We have not only defined our strategy for 2018-2020, but also adjusted our KPIs for this period. 
Thus, 2018 is the first year in which we can report on these indicators. 
These five KPIs provide a comprehensive overview of how we are organising our work on dissemination, impact and perception. o KPI 1 - Implementation of our recommendations o KPI 2 - Stakeholders feedback on our work o KPI 3 - Our appearances in the European Parliament, Council and national parliaments in the Council and national parliaments) o KPI 4 - Number of special reports (and similar products) published (Number of special reports [and similar products]) o KPI 5 - Our presence in the media

In addition, most of the Court's members present our annual reports to the national parliament of their respective Member States.

Performances of the Court in 2018: European Parliament, Council and National Parliaments 52 European Parliament 91 Council of the EU 47 133 65 50 National Parliaments 19 2017 2018 Media presence Number of online articles and contributions on social media almost tripled Since 2018, we have a closer contact with the media and non-institutional stakeholders and are much more active in social media. 
We have published 76 press releases in 23 EU languages (2017: 57) and o 20 press briefings held in Brussels (2017: 16), including press briefings for the annual report, including briefings regarding both the sector and the Member States concerned. 
We also received journalists from Brussels and the Member States and offered industry stakeholders, NGOs and think tanks several briefings on selected reports. 
53 visits by journalists from Member States to Luxembourg in November 2018 We follow the media coverage of our work and institution, which can vary significantly depending on the topic and complexity of a report. 
At the same time, we must take into account that external factors can greatly influence the interest of the media in our publications. 
For example, if the date of publication coincides with an important event or political development, the public interest in the subject can increase significantly. 
The total number of media reports, including on social media, has almost tripled: While there were around 15,500 online articles and social media posts in 2017, their number increased to more than 44,000 in 2018. 
Social media posts posted by the Court's official accounts in relation to our publications were displayed around 11 million times in 2018, almost 18 times more than in 2017. 
With regard to media coverage, special reports are clearly our flagship product In terms of communication and media reporting, the special reports have clearly become our flagship product. Twelve of the Court's 15 most successful publications in 2018 were special reports. 
In the year there were more than 11,000 online articles on our special reports, which means that the number has increased by more than twice as compared to 2017. 
By contrast, the total number was 1,500 online articles in 2013 - the year we started following media coverage. 
Compared to 2017, there was an increase of 60 % of the average number of media reports per special report at the same time. 
This means that our presence in the media has increased not only because of a higher number of reports, but also through a greater interest in our publications.

Impact and perception of our work Our reports - purposeful and effective We evaluate the impact and perception of our work on the basis of assessments by addressees. Another evaluation criterion is the follow-up to our recommendations to improve EU financial management. 
At the beginning of 2018, we began to ask our stakeholders (from the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, from EU agencies, permanent representations of Member States, Member State public bodies, national SAIs, NGOs, science, the media, etc.) for feedback on the usefulness and likely impact of our reports. 
This feedback concerns selected special reports and analyses, as well as the Court's annual reports, and will be collected through anonymous electronic surveys from all those who have previously received a copy of those reports. 
Through this survey, stakeholders can also provide qualitative feedback on reports and provide general suggestions on the Court's work. 
Overall, 87 % of respondents confirmed the usefulness of our reports for their work and 78 % gave them an impact.

Most of our recommendations have been implemented Since 2018, instead of the European Commission's management declaration, we have been using follow-up by our auditors as the basis for this indicator. 
For 2018, we analysed the recommendations made in our 2014 Special Reports and the Annual Report from the same year. 
This analysis shows that 74 % of the recommendations we made in our 2014 Annual Report and 94 % of the recommendations in our 2014 Special Reports were fully, largely or partially implemented.

At the end of 2018, our staff were 834 officials and temporary staff at the European Court of Auditors. 
The Court's establishment plan included 853 permanent and scheduling posts - including 541 in the audit chambers - including 112 posts in members' cabinets. 
Areas of activity of our employees: Audit services, translation, administration and services of the President 58 audit services 541 Translation Administration Services of the President 135 Total 853 129 48 In addition, 76 contract agents and 15 seconded national experts were employed at the Court at the end of the year. 
The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background. 
With our recruitment policy, we follow the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and promote equal opportunities at all levels. 
In 2018, the Court hired 79 employees: 15 officials, 32 temporary agents, 22 contract staff and 10 seconded national experts. 
In addition, we provided 60 university graduates with internships for periods of three to five months.

Support for the examination activities Vocational training training: In line with the recommendations published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), we strive to provide each auditor with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training per year. 
In 2018, we were again above this target with 6.9 training days per examiner. 
We have continued to expand the range of training we offer to employees both inside and outside the scope of the exam and helped auditors obtain various certifications. 
We continued our successful series of presentations held by internal or external experts on developments in the field of audit or other topics relating to the work of our auditors. 
We continued our Performance Recognition Awards program, which allows non-executive employees to participate in specific external training. 
Average number of training days per year 7.0 6.7 6.9 Goal = 2 days 2016 2017 per examiner 4,0 2016 2.3 3.1 2017 2018 Goal = 5 days per non-examiner 62 days 
Successful cooperation with educational institutions We have signed a partnership agreement with the College of Europe (Bruges, Belgium), which provides for cooperation in several areas, including training, traineeships and the drafting of reports. 
In addition, we have entered into cooperation agreements with the European Institute of Public Administration and other organisations that enable our staff to attend training courses organised by these institutions. 
We have continued and expanded our cooperation with the University of Lorraine: Once again, we offered the postgraduate program "Audit of public organisations and policies" and the Master's programme "Management of public organisations". In addition, we have developed a new postgraduate programme called "Fundamentals of statistics applied to audit". 
Finally, auditors from other SAIs took part in our internal training courses. Some of them shared their experience in the field of illustrating reports at the Court's annual training day, which involved more than 450 people. 
We made our online performance audit training available to the public and held two interactive seminars with a capacity of more than 150 participants from around the world. 
Translation The Court's Directorate for Translations, Language Services and Publication translated and revised over 251,000 pages in 2018. This represents an increase of more than 18 % compared to 2017. 
This increase also led to a higher outsourcing rate. 
In addition, all our translation teams now use harmonised working methods. 
Translators were increasingly involved in the Court's audit activities by providing linguistic support during audit visits and the preparation of most of the reports. 
This enabled us to create further synergies with our auditors. 
The publication team is now a full part of the Directorate. 
Review the originals for translation and finally for publication, integrated into a single, optimised workflow. 
Information, work environment and innovation Our Directorate for Information, Work Environment and Innovation supports our employees in the effective and efficient use of information technologies by promoting innovation and knowledge management. 
Information Management We have launched a new initiative called tECAway, which gives our employees access to the network on the go. 
This will allow them to access the Court's digital resources and services on all devices, anywhere and at any time. 
The Court has created a new harmonised document management system and introduced multifunctional devices for printing, photocopying and scanning. 
We expect these devices to have a beneficial impact on information security and paper consumption. 
We have alsointroduced a new cybersecurity governance model and are currently working on implementing the cybersecurity plan. 
In all IT projects and ITsolutions, the maintenance of business operations has been duly taken into account. This ensured the unrestricted availability of critical systems. 
Innovation We have also set up the ECAlab, an interdisciplinary innovation laboratory whose focus is on the digitisation of the test area through the use of data and technology use. 
ECAlab tests the use of technologies such as artificial intelligence, natural language processing (Natural Language Processing) and text mining in real exam tasks. 
This support has already benefited from several tasks and publications. 
In addition, we carried out a pilot project on the application of blockchaintechnologiesfor the notarial certification of audit evidence and publications. 
The resulting prototype, the ECA registry, was selected by the European BlockchainPartnership, set up by EUMember Statesand the Commission, as part of the Europeanblockchaininfrastructure for services to be developed from 2019 onwards. 
Knowledge Management In July 2018, our first annual summer course in public financial control was organised jointly with the University of Pisa and the Association of Chartered Certified Accountants (ACCA). 
45 people from SAIs, EU institutions and universities took part in the summer course focusing on data analysis for examinations. 
We also held a conference on blockchain where we explored the opportunities offered by this technology and its practical applications for controlling EU spending. 
This conference was primarily aimed at participants from other EU institutions. 
Buildings The courtyard currently has three buildings ("K1", "K2" and "K3") which form a single integrated technical unit. 
In addition, the Court rents office space for its Centre for Data Recovery in Luxembourg. 
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees; they also have meeting rooms, a conference room with interpreting booths, video conference rooms, a cafeteria and a basic kitchen area. 
A detailed study on this project will be carried out in 2019; work is expected to start at the end of this year. 
As approved by the European Parliament and Council in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining funds of the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation. 
K3 The K3 building was opened in 2012. 
Based on the world's leading Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method (BREEAM), the K3 building was rated as "very good". 
A new security control centre and an external accreditation and access control centre for employees and visitors were put into operation in September 2018. 
The ECA main building "K1" and the new Security Control Centre at Rue Alcide De Gasperi, Luxembourg Environmental Management As an institution of the European Union, it is our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all activities. 
We are therefore striving to continuously reduce the environmental impact of the Court. 
We now successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015. 
In the course of our goal of systematically reducing our CO2 emissions, we regularly examine the greenhouse gas emissions caused by our activities. 
Our total greenhouse gas emissions in 2017 amounted to 10 451 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), which represents a 3 % reduction compared to 2016. 
2018 was the fourth consecutive year for which the Court examined its carbon footprint. 
67 ECA Financial Information The Court is financed from the general budget of the European Union, with its budget falling within the area of administrative expenditure. 
In 2018, the Court's budget amounted to around 146 million euro. 
This represents less than 0.1 % of the EU's total expenditure, or around 1.5 % of the EU's total administrative expenditure. 
The share of the 2018 budget used amounted to 96 %.

Internal and external audit Internal Audit The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk management issues. 
It provides independent and objective assurance and provides advisory services designed to increase and improve the Court's activities. 
It shall also report to the Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and an external expert. 
The Committee regularly monitors progress on the various tasks laid down in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Service and ensures the independence of the department. 
In 2018, it carried out an audit on the Court's cybersecurity systems and construction work related to its perimeter protection. 
The Service also examined the implementation of the Court's risk management policy and the annual statements made by authorising officers by delegation. 
In addition, it monitored the implementation of its previous recommendations to ensure that the agreed action plans had taken shape. 
In 2018, the department's audits did not reveal any shortcomings which, due to their nature or scale, would seriously jeopardise the reliability of the internal control systems as a whole; these control systems had been introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations. 
We report annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal audit work. 
External control Our annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor. 
This is an important aspect in the Court's approach to applying to ourselves the same principles of transparency and accountability as for the bodies we audit. 
The report of the auditor - PricewaterhouseCoopers Sŕrl. - the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2017 were published on 17 May 2018. 70 
Audit opinions of the independent auditor - financial year 2017 71 To the Court's annual accounts: According to our assessment, the annual accounts give a true and fair view of the assets and financial position of the European Court of Auditors (hereafter "Court") at 31. December 2017 and the results of its operations, cash flows and changes in net assets for the year ended that reference date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002. 
L 298, 26.10.2012, p. 1) and its ex post amendments, hereinafter referred to as the 'Financial Regulation', and Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the rules of application of the Financial Regulation and its subsequent amendments.' 
On the use of resources and the Court's control procedures: "In our work steps described in this report, we have not encountered situations from which we would have to conclude that, in all material respects and taking into account the above-mentioned assessment criteria, the resources allocated to the Court were not used for the intended purposes and the control procedures put in place do not provide the requisite assurance that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations." 
Discharge Like the other EU institutions, the Court is also subject to the discharge procedure. 
In April 2018, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2016. 
As every year, we have carefully analysed the issues raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility, took appropriate action and reported in detail to the European Parliament on our follow-up. 
On 26 March 2019, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge for the financial year 2017. 
This means that our annual accounts for 2017 have been finalised. 
Peer Reviews Peer Reviews mean independent and transparent expert assessments of the capabilities of a particular SAI carried out by other SAIs. 
Each SAI participating in the peer review will continue to respect the independence of the other SAIs during its implementation. 
In 2018, we asked the SAIs of Estonia (leading SAIs), Denmark, the Netherlands and the United States of America to assess whether the Court is on its way to achieving its strategic objectives at the mid-term of the 2018-2020 period and whether it is likely that the measures we have undertaken to implement the strategy will achieve the desired impact. 
The peer review report is expected to be published in early 2019. 
At the same time, together with the SAIs of Poland and the United Kingdom, we started preparing the SAI's peer review. 
The main objective of this expert assessment will be to assess whether the SAI's audit approach is in line with international standards. 
We also commissioned an external and independent review of the Court's ethical framework during the year. 
This peer review is carried out by the auditors of Croatia and Poland. 
The audit report is expected to be available in 2019. 72

Our activities in 2019 Annual activity report of the European Court of Auditors
