European Court of Auditors 5 Who we are the external auditor of the European Union; O established in 1975 by the Treaty of Brussels; Commencement of office in October 1977; full-fledged EU institution since the 1993 Maastricht Treaty; O Headquarters in Luxembourg; O one member per EU Member State, appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament; approximately 900 employees of all EU nationalities. 
Our role o We ensure that the EU ensures proper accounting, correctly implements its financial rules and achieves its objectives and programmes through its policies and programmes and ensures optimal use of funds. o We contribute to improving the financial management of the EU and promoting accountability and transparency. o We warn about risks, provide assurance, point to weaknesses and achievements and provide guidance to Union policymakers and legislators. o We present our comments and recommendations to the European Parliament, the Council, national governments and parliaments and the general public. Foreword of the President Dear reader, dear reader! 
The year 2019 was associated with a number of changes for the Union: Elections to the European Parliament took place and a new European Commission took office. 
The strategic priorities have been redefined and key action packages such as the European Green Deal or the Digital Future of Europe (early 2020) have been launched. 
Towards the end of the year it became clear that we would now be a Union of 27 Member States. 
At the same time, the EU is at a significant crossroads in terms of its finances. 
We are about to conclude the negotiations on the next Multiannual Financial Framework, the outcome of which will be decisive for the Union's financing capacity over the next seven years. 
All EU institutions now need to build on past efforts to further improve the Union's financial management and ensure that the EU delivers results. 
As an external auditor, we provide an impartial assessment of Union policies and programmes and the quality of EU financial management within and outside the Union. 
We examine whether EU spending complies with the rules and whether the Union's policies and programmes ensure optimal use of funds. 
This activity report provides an overview of our work in 2019, in which we published a large number of highly up-to-date special reports, analyses and opinions. 
You will also find information about our employees, our management and our finances. 
We hope that this information is useful to you. 
We publish our Annual Activity Report this year at a time when public health is facing an unprecedented challenge in the EU and its Member States due to the COVID-19 pandemic. 
In line with the health and safety instructions of the Luxembourg Government, our institution has responded quickly to this situation. 
I would like to thank all colleagues for their good work and willingness to adapt flexibly to the current situation. 
We need to stand together now and make every effort to continue to fulfil our role as an external auditor of the EU in these difficult times. 
Klaus-Heiner Lehne President 6 
7 2019 at a glance 
8 Our activities Strategy In order to continue to help shape developments in the field of public financial control, we rely on multi-annual strategies to make long-term decisions for our audit work and to drive forward organisational change initiatives with a view to continuous improvement. 
At the end of 2019, we had completed the second year of our current strategy for 2018-2020. 
During this three-year period, we have set ourselves the following strategic objectives: Improving the added value of the Statement of Assurance; greater focus on the performance aspects of EU action; Conveying clear statements for our addressees. 
In order to implement our strategy in practice, we have agreed on an action plan covering these objectives. 
Over the past two years, we have made good progress in implementing our strategic goals. 
In the context of all targeted areas, a number of initiatives and projects have been launched, which sometimes go beyond the objectives of the Action Plan, in particular: O a pilot phase of the testat-oriented audit approach for the preparation of the Statement of Assurance, which has led to useful findings; O a significant increase in the number of performance audits and analytical products, as well as a more diverse range of topics covering both EU spending and regulatory measures; O better contact with the European Parliament and greater visibility on traditional and social media. 
During the year, a group of four Supreme Audit Institutions (Estonia, Netherlands, Denmark and United States) conducted a peer review of our strategy. 
Our peers' report was published in March 2020, just in time to provide valuable impetus for our next strategy from 2021. 
Good progress in the implementation of our strategy 9 
Performance audits, audits of accounting and compliance audits Our performance audits consider the effectiveness, efficiency and economy of EU policies and programmes. 
The focus will be on issues that reflect relevant issues for the EU, such as sustainable and environmentally friendly use of natural resources, growth and inclusion, migration and global development challenges, Single Market and Banking Union, and ensuring the accountability and profitability of the European Union. 
These audits are designed to help the EU achieve its policy objectives better. 
Our audits of the accounts and our compliance audits result in our statement on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. 
We can also carry out selected compliance audits to examine the financial management and financial management of the Union or to assess whether the management and control systems set up for the collection and use of EU funds comply with the applicable EU and national rules. 
Our audits are in line with internationally recognised public sector audit principles. 10 
In 2019, we continued to embed the strategic foresight in our audit work in order to better address the key future challenges for the EU through a forward-looking approach. 
To this end, we have set up an Advisory Committee on Strategy and Foresight. 
One of the current tasks of this Committee, composed of five members, is to monitor the preparation of the post-2020 strategy. 
Audit priorities with regard to topics relevant to the future of the EU Our work programme was published in October 2019. We present in detail our audit priorities for the coming years and the 41 reports and analyses planned to be published in 2020. 
With our 2020 and beyond audits, we will continue to provide Union citizens and policy makers with independent reports on issues relevant to the future of the EU. 
We prepare the work programme for our audits in an independent way, but not in complete isolation from our environment. 
It is therefore of utmost importance for us to work with our institutional stakeholders, in particular the European Parliament. 
As usual, at the beginning of 2019, we asked all parliamentary committees to propose possible audit topics for our work programme. 11 
The majority of our examination work takes place in our premises in Luxembourg. 
Our auditors also carry out numerous audit visits to the European Commission - our main audit body; this also applies to the other EU institutions, EU agencies and bodies, national, regional and local authorities in the Member States, EU delegations to third countries and international organisations. 
In addition, we carry out on-the-spot audits within and outside the EU with beneficiaries of EU funds. 
Through these audits, we can trace the audit trail and obtain direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in the management of Union policies and programmes, as well as the collection or disbursement of EU funds, and also from the beneficiaries of such funds. 
In line with the target set out in the EU Financial Regulation, we strive to complete our selected audits within 13 months. 12 
3 605 days of on-the-spot audit work - inside and outside the EU Our audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the duration of an audit visit can be a few days, but also several weeks. 
Within the EU, our on-the-spot audits are generally coordinated together with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States concerned. 
The frequency and intensity of our audit work in each Member State and beneficiary country depends on the nature of the audits we carry out. 
In 2019, our auditors spent 3,605 days (2018: 3 671 days) with on-the-spot checks - in the Member States and outside the EU. 
In addition, our auditors spent 2 504 days (2018: 2 723 days) at the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg as well as decentralised agencies and bodies across the EU, international organisations such as the United Nations or the OECD, and audit firms. 
To interact with our audited bodies, we are increasingly using video conferencing and other information technologies, such as secure exchange of data and documents. 14 
Audit reports, analyses and opinions Our audit reports, analyses and opinions form an important link in the EU accountability chain. 
They help the European Parliament and the Council to monitor and verify whether the EU is achieving its political objectives and to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's budgetary management accountable, in particular in the context of the annual discharge procedure. 
In line with our strategy for 2018-2020, we have focused more on assessing the performance of EU action in recent years. 
In 2019, we published 36 special reports and analyses addressing many of the challenges the Union faces in the various EU spending areas, such as food safety, renewable energy, e-commerce, border controls, fiscal governance and ethical frameworks in selected EU institutions, to name a few. 15 
16 In our special reports, we examine whether the objectives of selected EU policies and programmes have been achieved, whether the results have been achieved in an effective and economic way, and whether EU action has created added value - i.e. whether they have achieved more than would be possible by action at national level alone. 
We also make recommendations on financial savings, better working methods, avoiding waste or achieving the policy objectives more effectively. 
Our analyses - often from a cross-sectional perspective and based on previous audits or other publicly available information - are intended to provide introductory descriptions and analytical considerations. 
In addition, they can serve us to present our analysis of areas or issues that have not yet undergone an examination, or to compile facts on specific topics or problems. 
Unlike audits, they neither address evaluation questions nor provide reliability. 
17 Sustainable use of natural resources Analysis No. 01/2019: The EU's response to the "diesel scandal" In 2015 there were differences between the test bench and the exhaust emissions achieved on the road for diesel engines. 
Studies showed that so-called "default devices" were used, which caused lower emissions in official tests than in normal driving. 
The type-approval authorities of some Member States responded to the emissions scandal by re-testing diesel cars. 
These tests showed that emissions from road emissions for almost all light diesel commercial vehicles in the Euro 5 and Euro 6 emission classes significantly exceeded the permitted NOx limits, in some cases more than 10 times. 
We considered the measures taken by both the EU and the Member States in response to the "diesel scandal". 
We also included the changes made after September 2015 on the system for measuring exhaust emissions. 
We noted that numerous legal changes to the EU system of vehicle type approvals and emission tests were adopted expeditiously. 
The Commission is now empowered to review the work of the national type-approval authorities. It may also have vehicles tested and type-approvals revoked or suspended. 
Affected third parties can now carry out emission tests. 
The Commission also launched infringement proceedings against certain Member States. 
We also noted that in several Member States there has been an increased readiness to restrict motor vehicle traffic in order to improve air quality. In addition, low-emission zones have been created in several European cities where car traffic is restricted or prohibited. 
We presented our results in the form of an analysis as the changes made to the legislation will not have any measurable effects in the near future. 
Our analyses do not contain any recommendations. 
18 Investments for Cohesion, Growth and Inclusion Special Report No 08/2019: Wind and solar energy for power generation: in order to achieve the EU targets, significant efforts are needed to generate electricity either from non-renewable sources such as fossil fuels, non-recyclable waste and nuclear fuels in conventional reactors, or from renewable energy sources such as hydropower, wind and solar energy, biomass, etc. 
Renewable energy also serves the production of heating and cooling as well as the production of fuels for the transport sector. 
Currently, 79 % of the EU's total greenhouse gas emissions are due to the use of fossil fuels for energy production. 
A higher share of renewable energy in electricity generation will contribute to achieving the EU's target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions. 
Member States shall determine how best to use their energy resources and how they structure their energy supply. 
The EU can support Member States' actions by providing additional funding for investments in renewable energy projects. 
We assessed the progress made by the EU and Member States towards the renewable energy share targets in order to meet the EU's overall 20 % target by 2020 and 32 % by 2030. 
In Germany, Greece, Spain and Poland, we examined on the ground whether the promotion of electricity generation from wind energy and photovoltaics was effective. 
We found that significant progress had been made with regard to the share of renewable energy in the energy mix from 2005 onwards, but this trend slowed down after 2014. 
The share of renewable energy in electricity generation in the EU has increased from around 15 % (in 2015) to just under 31 % (in 2017), doubling. 
Wind and solar energy were the technologies that made the biggest contribution to this increase. 
However, reaching the targets will be a major challenge for around half of the Member States. 
We recommended that the Commission encourage the Member States to support further development - by conducting auctions to allocate additional capacity in the field of renewable energies, promoting greater participation of citizens, simplifying administrative procedures and eliminating inadequacies in networks. 
In addition, we recommended that the Commission review the legal requirements for Member States in order to improve the timeliness of statistical data. 
19 External Policies, Security and Justice Special Report No 24/2019: Asylum, relocation and return of migrants: In 2015, the European Union experienced unprecedented influx of migrants, followed by an increase in asylum applications. 
In recent years, immigration numbers have fallen back to pre-crisis levels. 
We conducted interviews with staff at the European Commission, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO) and the European Border and Coast Guard Agency (commonly referred to as Frontex). 
Audit visits were carried out to national authorities, international organisations and non-governmental organisations carrying out EU-funded projects. In addition, 20 EU support measures in Greece and Italy have undergone an investigation. 
Both Member States are particularly affected by these migratory flows. 
We assessed whether the objectives of EU-funded support were achieved and whether asylum and return procedures were carried out effectively and swiftly. 
We also examined whether the targets and objectives of the temporary emergency resettlement schemes were achieved. 
We found that the rates of registration and fingerprinting in the hotspots had improved significantly. 
Nevertheless, very many migrants continue to move to other EU Member States and apply for asylum there without their fingerprints being stored in the Eurodac database. 
In both Member States, the implementation of asylum procedures continues to be characterised by long processing times and bottlenecks. 
Indeed, a high proportion of applicants were relocated (80 % in Greece and 89 % in Italy). 
Nevertheless, the relocation process in the countries receiving migrants has not been monitored by the Commission since February 2018. 
As in other EU countries, return rates from Greece and Italy are low. 
We recommended that the next Commission should take appropriate measures to improve the management of emergency aid. 
In addition, the Commission should use past experience in developing future voluntary relocation mechanisms. 
Finally, EASO support for asylum procedures should be improved and Frontex's support for return operations should be adapted. 
20 Market regulation and competitive economy Special Report No 10/2019: EU-wide stress tests for banks: the EU-wide banking stress test aims to assess the potential impact that a common shock could have on the financial situation and the viability of large European banks. 
It is the task of the European Banking Authority (EBA), in cooperation with the European Systemic Risk Board (ESRB), to initiate and coordinate the implementation of Union-wide banking stress tests. 
Stress tests have been carried out in the EU since 2011, with all of them following the bottom-up approach. The banks provided the results of the shock scenario on the basis of the methodology approved by the EBA. 
We assessed the implementation of the EU-wide banking stress test under the mandate given to EBA. 
We found that at the beginning of the procedure, EBA did not specify the risks or severity it considered relevant to the stress test procedure. 
In turn, the ESRB, which developed the stress scenario, received substantial input from the ECB, as well as from the national central banks and authorities. 
As a result, the EBA lacked control over key stages of the procedure. 
In the United States, regulators rely on a top-down approach, giving them a much greater level of control over the results achieved by banks. 
Conversely, the role of EBA in the EU is limited to the initiation of stress tests, the provision of the methodology and the broad coordination of stress tests. 
The EBA's stress test assessed the vulnerability of the system and banks to an economic downturn rather than a severe financial shock affecting the system. 
Although EBA pursued the objective of broad coverage, certain risky banks were excluded from the stress test. 
EBA's bottom-up approach resulted in limited reliability and comparability of the results achieved by banks. 
We recommended that EBA strengthen its control over the stress test procedure and develop a top-down approach to complement the current bottom-up approach. 
In order to fulfil their purpose to assess resilience to adverse market developments, future stress tests should also take due account of risks arising within the EU financial system, ensure a minimum level of stress and provide clear statements about banks' resilience. 
Finally, the selection of banks for the stress test should be done not only by size, but also by risk. 
21 Financing and management of the Union Special Report No 14/2019: Your opinion counts! 
While the Commission's public consultations involve citizens, there is a lack of outreach The aim of "better regulation" is to ensure that policy decisions are prepared openly and transparently, based on the best available facts, and supported by citizens and other stakeholders, such as civil society organisations and representative associations that are fully involved. 
The Commission is obliged to consult citizens and representative associations in all areas of Union action. 
The Better Regulation Guidelines define stakeholder consultation and also rank citizens as 'stakeholders'. 
Stakeholder consultations, in particular public consultations, gather information and opinions from citizens and other stakeholders when the Commission prepares a policy initiative or evaluates ongoing interventions. 
The Commission conducts on average more than 100 public consultations per year. 
We assessed whether the Commission's public consultations have effectively contributed to reaching citizens and stakeholders and making use of their contributions. 
We examined the design of the Commission's framework, the way in which the Commission prepared and conducted a selection of public consultations, and how it provided information on the consultation activities and used the consultation work. 
We reviewed a sample of 26 Commission public consultations conducted by five DGs over the period 2016-2018 and conducted an opinion poll to determine how satisfied the participants were actually in public consultations. 
We noted that the Commission's public consultation framework has a high standard. 
In addition, the Commission's overall sample of public consultations recorded a positive record and their perception by the participants was generally satisfactory. 
Shortcomings were identified in public relations and feedback. For example, the full range of communication channels was not always used, clear criteria were missing to justify why a questionnaire was not available in all official EU languages, and some questionnaires were long and complex. 
We recommended that public advertising for consultations should be made to a greater extent and more targeted in order to improve visibility and allow more people to participate. 
We also encouraged the Commission to report better on the follow-up to the public consultation. 
Finally, there is room for improvement in citizen participation when it comes to launching legislative proposals under the European Citizens' Initiative. 
Audit previews provide information on ongoing audit tasks (in the area of performance audit). 
They are based on the preparatory work carried out before the start of an audit and shall serve as a source of information for all those interested in specific policy areas and/or programmes subject to an ongoing audit. 
In 2019, we issued 18 exam previews (2018: 12). 
Annual reports and special annual reports The annual reports mainly contain the results of our Statement of Assurance on the budget of the European Union and the European Development Funds (EDFs). 
The special annual reports contain the results of our annual audit of the accounts of the EU agencies, decentralised bodies and Joint Undertakings as well as the European Schools. 
We also publish a report on the contingent liabilities resulting from the performance of the Single Resolution Board (SRB). 22 
Annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2018 Each year we audit the EU's revenue and expenditure to check whether the annual accounts are reliable and that the underlying revenue and expenditure transactions are in line with the relevant legislation at EU and Member State level. 
In addition, we present specific assessments on all key areas of the EU budget, based on the (sub-)headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for the period 2014-2020. 
Furthermore, we analyse why and where errors have occurred, make recommendations for improvements and examine whether and to what extent our previous recommendations have been put into practice. 
Finally, we provide information on budgetary and financial management as well as performance-related information. 
This extensive work forms the basis for our Declaration of Assurance, which we must submit to the European Parliament and the Council in accordance with our mandate set out in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). 
EU general budget: an unrestricted opinion on the reliability of accounts and revenue; limited opinion on expenditure In 2018, EU expenditure amounted to EUR 156.7 billion; this corresponds to 2.2 % of total government expenditure of EU Member States and 1 % of the Union's gross national income. 
Our auditors examined a sample of 728 payments to beneficiaries made in all expenditure areas of the EU budget from a population of around EUR 120 billion to be audited. 
This means that we assessed various cases where EU funds had been used to support key infrastructure projects, SMEs, research institutions, farmers and students in the EU Member States or to support beneficiaries in non-EU countries. 
For the financial year 2018, we issued a full audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's accounts and revenues. 
In addition, for the third year in a row, we were able to present a limited audit opinion on EU spending. 23 
Around half of the expenditure audited has no material error rate, as in previous years, we found that the errors in EU expenditure were not comprehensive and that payments were legal and regular, with the exception of high-risk expenditure (mainly expenditure on a reimbursement basis, complex rules). 
24 Overall, with an error rate of 2.6 %, the Commission and the Member States maintained the progress recorded in the two previous years (financial year 2017: 2.4 %; Financial year 2016: 3.1 %. 
We see this as an encouraging sign. 
Mistakes - what does that mean? 
An error or irregular payment is the amount of funds that should not have been paid out of the EU budget because they have not been used in accordance with EU or national rules and therefore do not comply with the objectives pursued by the Council and Parliament with the relevant EU acts or are contrary to specific national rules in the Member States. 
We estimate the error rate using statistical methods, based on quantifiable (i.e. monetaryly measurable) errors that we identified by examining a sample of transactions within the total audited population of expenditure. 
The most error-prone MFF heading: Economic, social and territorial cohesion In the financial year 2018, "Economic, social and territorial cohesion" was the most error-prone MFF (sub)heading, followed by "Natural resources" and "Competitiveness for growth and jobs". 25 
Annual Report on the European Development Funds: an unrestricted opinion on the reliability of accounts and revenue; 26 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are the main EU aid instruments for development cooperation. 
The EDF aims to overcome poverty and promote sustainable development and the integration of African, Caribbean and Pacific countries and territories into the global economy. 
The EDFs are financed by the Member States of the Union and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB). 
As in previous years, for the financial year 2018, we issued an unrestricted audit opinion on the reliability of the EDF accounts and revenue and a limited opinion on EDF expenditure. 
Specific Annual Reports on EU Agencies and Joint Undertakings The EU Agencies are separate entities with their own legal personality set up to carry out specific technical, scientific and administrative tasks, thus helping to shape and implement the policies of the EU institutions. 
There are 43 agencies in total. 
Joint Undertakings are EU public-private partnerships with industry, research groups and Member States, which play an important role in the implementation of certain aspects of EU research policy. 
The European Commission is the public sector member of the Joint Undertakings and represents the EU. 
There are eight Joint Undertakings in total. 
27 Note: The United Kingdom resigned from the European Union on 31 January 2020. 
Full audit opinion for all agencies except one; in total, a total of 4.2 billion euro was allocated to all agencies (excluding the SRB) for all agencies (excluding the SRB), 20 % more than in 2017 (3.5 billion). This corresponds to approximately 2.9 % of the EU general budget for 2018 (2017: 2.7 %. 
Overall, our audit of the agencies' accounts for the financial year 2018 confirmed the positive results shown in previous years. 
We issued unrestricted audit opinions on the reliability of the accounts, revenue and payments underlying the agencies' accounts; this does not apply to EASO, which has been granted a limited opinion on the payments. 
We also issued full audit opinions to all Joint Undertakings on the reliability of accounts, revenue and expenditure. 
The publication of our annual reports is at the beginning of the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament, on a recommendation from the Council, decides whether the Commission and other bodies have managed the EU budget satisfactorily. 
In October 2019, we presented our annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the EDFs to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and subsequently also to the plenary of the European Parliament, the Council ("Economic and Financial Affairs") and to the Parliaments and national authorities of 21 Member States. 
28 Other annual reports: contingent liabilities and European Schools We are obliged to report annually on all contingent liabilities incurred by the Single Resolution Board, the Council and the Commission in connection with the performance of their tasks in the field of bank resolution. 
In our 2018 report, we concluded that the Committee has improved the presentation of its accounts, but requires better reporting on contingent liabilities at national level. 
We also publish an annual report on the annual accounts of the European Schools. 
Our auditing of the annual accounts for 2018 revealed a material error rate for one of the 13 European Schools. 
Digitalisation is about leveraging the potential of technologies to provide more and better information for the accountability process. 
The digital transformation is also of great importance for our audit work and our organisation. 
We have set up a five-member Steering Committee for Digitalisation to manage this transition process in the coming years. 
As the first important initiative in the audit area, we launched a pilot trial in 2019 to automate the audit of the accounts of executive agencies. 
In this pilot test, we will simultaneously use traditional and digital instruments. 29 
Opinions Opinions: a way to strengthen the Commission's approach to Better Regulation is the publication of opinions on Commission proposals for new or amended acts. 
If these are legislative proposals with significant financial implications, the Court's opinions are required under EU law. 
In addition, other institutions may ask us to provide opinions on specific issues. 
Our opinions are submitted to the European Parliament and the Council. 
In 2019, we published three comments: on the proposal concerning the European Union Intellectual Property Office, a proposal for the Financial Regulation of the Single Resolution Board (SRB) and the proposal for the financial regulation of the Community Plant Variety Office. 
Our comments on the new MFF at the beginning of 2019 also published our briefing on the ECA's observations on the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) 2021-2027. 
This factsheet focused on the proposed procedure for setting the spending priorities for the EU, flexibility of the EU budget, performance orientation and administrative simplification, as well as accountability and auditing arrangements. 
This analysis was mainly based on several opinions we made in the course of 2018 on the Commission's proposals, but also our recent papers and other reports on EU finances. 
Throughout the year, we have reached a relatively balanced number of publications, with a peak in October when we publish our annual reports. 
31 32 The European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) is at the forefront of the fight against fraud affecting the EU's financial interests. 
We have adopted detailed guidelines for our auditors on how to deal with fraud risk. 
We forward any suspicion of fraud or any other illegal activity to the detriment of the financial interests of the EU that arises or is reported to us in our audit work. 
These cases will then be dealt with by OLAF, which decides on possible investigations and, if necessary, cooperates with Member State authorities. 
In 2019, we also signed an administrative arrangement setting out the operational provisions for our cooperation with OLAF, including coordination of training, workshops and staff exchanges. 
10 cases of suspected fraud have been forwarded to OLAF We are the external auditor of the EU. 
Our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud. 
Nevertheless, our auditors regularly identify a number of cases where they suspect fraudulent activity. 
In 2019, we sent 10 suspected fraud cases to OLAF (2018: nine cases), eight of which we encountered in the course of our audits, as well as two cases resulting from third-party evidence. 
Additional information on the nature of these suspected fraud cases and the resulting recoveries, as recommended by OLAF, can be found in our annual report on the general budget of the EU. 
In 2019, we also published two special reports closely related to the fight against fraud in EU spending: Special Report No 01/2019 "Combating fraud in EU spending: Action is needed"and Special Report No 06/2019"Combating fraud in EU cohesion spending: Managing authorities need to strengthen detection, response and coordination". 
33 Finally, we devoted a special edition of the ECA Journal to the fight against fraud and corruption and the protection of the EU's financial interests. 
Focus on sustainability UN Sustainable Development Goals at the heart of our audit work In recent years, where we focused on environmental and climate issues, sustainability issues have been of paramount importance. 
In 2019, our work in the field of sustainability was complemented by the analysis of sustainability reporting. 
This analysis provided an overview of how the EU institutions publish sustainability information and how they contribute to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). 
We also organised a conference - the ECA Forum on Sustainability Reporting - to raise awareness of the issue and bring together key stakeholders. 
In July, we attended a meeting of the SAI presidents and stakeholders on the topic "ORKBs make a difference: Consideration of the implementation of the SDGs" at the UN High-Level Political Forum for the 2030 Agenda. 
Finally, we published a special edition of the ECA Journal on the SDGs. 
Examination team: Analysis "Sustainability reporting: an inventory of the EU institutions, bodies and agencies". 
Institutional relations Continuous increase in presentations to the European Parliament, the Council and national parliaments We work closely with the European Parliament (EP), the Council and national parliaments in the Member States, as the impact of our work depends to a great extent on the benefits these institutions draw from our audit results and recommendations. 
Our audit reports are presented to the relevant committees of the European Parliament and to the Council working groups. 
In addition, we present our annual reports as well as our special reports and analyses to national parliaments. 
In 2019, the presentations of our reports to these institutional addressees continued to increase, mainly due to a significant increase in presentations to national parliaments. 
At the same time, fewer presentations to the EP took place due to the parliamentary break from mid-April to September 2019. 34 
Meeting with the newly elected Presidents of the EU institutions 2019 was a year of change at the forefront of many EU institutions: After their election, our President met with the President of the European Parliament, the President of the European Commission and the President of the European Council. 
35 ECA President Lehne with EP President David Sassoli, Commission President Ursula von der Leyen and President of the Council Charles Michel. 
European Parliament Our members and audit teams are regularly invited by the European Parliament's committees and bodies, and in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control. 
In 2019, due to the elections to the European Parliament in May 2019, special circumstances prevailed in so far as parliamentary committee meetings paused in mid-April and then resumed in September. 
We presented 14 committees 31 special reports and 10 analyses (2018: 39 reports and 14 committees). 
Following the elections, we launched an awareness campaign to inform Members of the European Parliament about our work as an external auditor of the EU. 
We also organised a series of workshops for EP staff. 
Finally, in October 2019, we set up a publication portal that allows not only EP members but also the general public to have more user-friendly access to our reports. 36 
Council of the European Union In 2019, our audit teams presented 22 Council Working Groups and two Committees 26 Special Reports (2018: 40 reports and 27 working groups). 
We also presented two analyses: one to the Committee on Budgets during an informal Council meeting in Romania and another of the Working Group on the 2030 Agenda. 
We also participated in an exchange of views with the Committee on Financial Services on the Memorandum of Understanding with the European Central Bank and with the Committee on Budgets on our draft budget for 2020 and presented our work programme 2020 in December 2019. 
In October 2019, the President of the Eurogroup visited us to discuss the state of play and future reforms of the Economic and Monetary Union and our potential contribution to fiscal and economic governance in the EU. 
In addition, the Chair of the Eurogroup Working Group met with our members in May 2019. 
Governments of Member States and national parliaments More appearances in national parliaments Our members regularly visit national parliaments and governments. 
In 2019, we held 90 presentations in 21 Member States (2018: 50 presentations in 14 Member States). 
This is the highest number so far. 37 
Exchange of views with our audited bodies at the highest level For years, it has been common practice for our Members to hold an annual meeting with their counterparts at the Commission. 
These meetings provide an opportunity to take stock and reflect on how our cooperation can be further improved. 
This tradition continued in June 2019 when President Jean-Claude Juncker invited our members to exchange views with the College of Commissioners in Brussels. 
In October 2019, we signed an agreement with the European Central Bank setting out the practical arrangements for the exchange of information on the supervisory activities of the European Central Bank for our auditors. 
Cooperation with Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCB) Contact Committee of the EU-ORKB Annual Meeting 2019 in Poland Our cooperation with the EU-ORKBs takes place primarily within the framework of the Contact Committee of the EU-ORKB Presidents. 
This network of the EU-ORKBs allows us to promote the activities of independent external financial control in the EU and its Member States. 
In June 2019, we attended the annual meeting hosted by the SAI of Poland, which was also chaired. 
The discussions focused primarily on the challenges and opportunities that Digital Europe brings to the EU-ORKB. 
At this meeting we took over the chair of the Contact Committee, as we do every three years. 
Contact Committee meeting, Warsaw, June 2019. 39 
Online portal "Public Financial Control in the EU" In January 2019 we launched an online portal on financial control in the European Union. 
This online portal provides information on the mandate, status, organisational structure, activity and output of the EU and its Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions. 
In December 2019, on behalf of the Contact Committee, we published a second examination Compendium on Public Health in the EU, which provides information on the audits carried out throughout the European Union in the field of public health. 
The Compendium provides background information on public health, its legal bases, its main objectives and related competences at Member State and EU level. It also illustrates the main challenges facing the EU and its Member States in this regard. 
It is based on recent audit findings by the European Court of Auditors and the SAIs from 23 EU Member States. 
In 2019, we started the preparatory work for a third audit compendium to be published in 2020 and will focus on cybersecurity. 40 
INTOSAI In 2019, the ECA continued its active involvement in the activities of the International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI), in particular as Vice-Chair of the Committee for Technical Standards (since December 2016) and as a member of the Subcommittee for Auditing Accounting and Accounting, the Subcommittee for the Audit of Legal Standards and the Subcommittee for Performance Audits. 
We also participated in the activities and projects of other INTOSAI working bodies, mainly in the areas of environmental assessment, big data, financial modernisation and regulatory reform, as well as evaluation of public policies and programmes. 
We also participated in the INTOSAI Task Force on the professionalisation of auditors, the INTOSAI Development Initiative (IDI) and the revision project for the ISSAI 200 under the aegis of the Subcommittee for Auditing Accounting and Accounting. 
INTOSAI Congress (INCOSAI) in September 2019 in Moscow. 
Two main topics were discussed in detail at the conference: Information technology for the development of public administration and SAIs' contribution to national priorities and objectives. 
EUROSAI was also actively involved in the activities of the European Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI), the European Regional Group of INTOSAI, especially in their working groups on environmental auditing, IT auditing and assessment of disaster relief, as well as in its task force audit and ethics. 
We also participated in several workshops and seminars and, together with 14 other European SAIs, contributed to the publication of a joint air quality report. In October 2019, we organised the seventeenth annual meeting of the EUROSAI Working Group on Environmental Assessment and a joint conference on biodiversity. Finally, we attended the third joint EUROSAI-ASOSAI conference on "New Issues and Emergency Situations" in Israel in March 2019, as well as the first joint EUROSAI-AFROSAI seminar in Lisbon in November 2019 hosted by the Portuguese SAI.

Peer review is an external independent review of one or more elements of the organisation and/or the functioning of an SAI by a team of peers from one or more SAIs. 
It does not constitute an examination, but an assessment and advice by peers, which is carried out on a voluntary basis. 
In 2019, a peer review team led by our Secretary General, together with the SAIs of Poland and the United Kingdom, conducted a peer review of SAIs of Lithuania. 
The main objective was to assess whether the audit practice of the Lithuanian SAIs complied with international auditing standards. 
In December 2019, the final report was submitted to the Lithuanian Parliament (Seimas). * This designation is without prejudice to positions on status and is in line with UN Security Council Resolution 1244 (1999) and the ICJ Opinion on the Kosovo Declaration of Independence. 
Our management The members of the ECA act as a collegial body of members each with one member per Member State. 
Each Member shall be appointed by the Council after having been appointed by his or her national government after consulting the European Parliament. 
We have no role in the appointment and appointment of members. 
When they take office, they shall assume a solemn obligation in this regard before the Court of Justice of the European Union. 
43 meeting of the College of Members of the ECA, held in Luxembourg on 18 July 2019. 
In 2019, the Council appointed four new members of the Court: Viorel tefan (Romania) from 1 July 2019 and Ivana Maletic (Croatia) from 15 July 2019 and Joëlle Elvinger (Luxembourg) and François-Roger Cazala (France) from 1 January 2020. 
In addition, the Council extended the terms of office of three members in office: Alex Brenninkmeijer (Netherlands), Nikolaos Milionis (Greece) and Klaus-Heiner Lehne (Germany). 
Phil Wynn Owen (UK) was a member until 31 January 2020. 
As of March 2020, following the appointment of Janusz Wojciechowski as a member of the European Commission in December 2019, a Polish member must be appointed and appointed. 
In 2019, the College of Members of the ECA is 21 times (2018: 18 times) met. 
President The President's remit includes the institution's strategy, planning and performance management, communication and media work, relations with other institutions, legal issues and internal audit. 
The President also represents the Court in all his external relations. 
Members elect the president from among them for three years, with the possibility of re-election. 
Klaus-Heiner Lehne was elected President in September 2016; his re-election took place in September 2019. 
The President and Members 44 Note: As of March 2020. 
The members are assigned to one of our five examination chambers. In the Chambers, most of our audit reports, analyses and opinions are prepared and adopted. 
The chambers are under the direction of a doyen or a doyenne elected by the members of the Chamber from among them. 
As of December 2019, the five examination chambers were led by the following Doyens/Doyennes: Nikolaos Milionis, Iliana Ivanova, Bettina Jakobsen, Alex Brenninkmeijer and Lazaros S. Lazarou. 
Daničle Lamarque was the member responsible for quality control in the area of audit (until the end of her term of office in December 2019). 
She chaired the Audit Quality Control Committee. 
The chambers shall divide their responsibilities among the members. 
Each member is accountable to the Chamber and the Court for its own audit tasks. 
Members are supported by a cabinet. 
In addition to their role in the examination chambers, some members have also taken on other tasks: Oscar Herics was chaired by the Ethics Committee, Samo Jereb that of the Audit Committee, Eva Lindström that of the Steering Committee Digitalisation and Joăo Figueiredo this of the Advisory Committee Strategy and Foresight. 
Rimantas Šadžius was the member responsible for institutional relations. 
Decisions on further strategic and administrative issues shall be taken by the Management Committee and, where appropriate, by the College of Members, each chaired by the President. 45

We use Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) to inform our management of the progress achieved towards our strategic goals, to support the decision-making process and to provide our institutional addressees with information about our performance. 
These KPIs provide a comprehensive overview of how we are organising our work in terms of dissemination, impact and perception.

Media Presence Continuous increase in social media coverage We track media coverage of our work and our body, which can vary significantly depending on the topic and complexity of a report. 
At the same time, external factors can greatly influence the interest of the media in our publications. 
This may be the case, for example, when the date of publication of a report coincides with an important event or political development, which may significantly increase the public interest in the topic concerned. 
In total, more than 50,000 free online articles and social media articles were recorded in 2019. 
49 For 2019, we noted a significant increase in our social media contributions, also due to the more active use of these communication channels during the year. 
In 2019, we intensified our contacts with the press and the media. 
We achieved this by publishing o 61 press releases in 23 EU languages (2018: 76) as well as numerous briefings and references to the media in certain languages; O 25 press briefings held (2018: 20), including sectoral and country-related press briefings related to the annual report. 
These press briefings usually take place in Brussels. 
We also received journalists working in Brussels and in the Member States for local visits and organised several briefings on selected reports to stakeholders from industry, NGOs and think tanks. 
Visit of journalists from the Member States to Luxembourg in November 2019. 50 
One million visitors to our website in 2019 exceeded the number of visits to our website for the first time 1 million. 
In total, we recorded around 511,000 individual visitors. 
Throughout the year, we have seen an increase in our presence and engagement on social media - especially on Facebook, Twitter and LinkedIn - which are now an essential part of our communication activities and enable us to engage in direct exchanges with citizens. 
At the end of 2019, our three social media accounts recorded around 29,500 followers (2018: about 22,500). 51 
88 % of the stakeholders surveyed consider our audit reports useful We assess the likely impact and usefulness of our audit work on the basis of feedback from our stakeholders from the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, from EU agencies, the permanent representations of Member States, Member States' public bodies and SAIs, NGOs, science, media and other parties. 
Since 2018, we have been requesting feedback from our stakeholders through anonymous electronic surveys on a selection of special reports and analyses as well as on the annual report. 
Through these surveys, stakeholders can also provide feedback on the quality of the reports and make general proposals on the Court's work. 
Overall, 88 % of respondents confirmed the usefulness of our reports for their work in 2019 and 81 % gave them an impact. 
52 Follow-up of our recommendations Almost all our recommendations implemented We determine the state of implementation of our recommendations based on the follow-up made by our auditors. 
For 2019, we analysed the recommendations we made in our 2015 Special Reports and the Annual Report from the same year. 
This analysis shows that 96 % of the recommendations we made in our 2015 annual report and 94 % of the recommendations in our 2015 special reports were fully, largely or (at least) partially implemented. 53 
At the end of 2019, our staff had 853 permanent and scheduling positions (2018: 853 posts), of which 534 in the audit chambers, including 118 posts in members' cabinets. 
54 Furthermore, at the end of the year, 75 contract agents and 16 seconded national experts were employed by the Court (2018: 76 and 15 respectively). 
Our recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions. Our employees have a broad academic and professional background. 
In 2019, the Court hired 77 employees (2018: 79 employees: 17 officials, 33 temporary agents, 21 contract staff and six seconded national experts. 
In addition, we provided 55 internship positions (2018: 60) available for graduates for periods of three to five months. 
Almost three-quarters (74 %) of staff in active employment at the end of 2019 are between 40 and 59 years old. 
55 More than half of our directors and senior managers are 50 years old or older. 
As a result, in the next five to 10 years, when these employees retire, there will be a renewal in management positions. 
Equal opportunities The Court offers its employees equal opportunities at all levels of the organisation. 
Overall, we have a balanced proportion of women and men among our employees. 
In 2019, around one third of our directors and senior managers are women. 
In 2019, we continued to diversify and expand the training offer for our staff. 
We organised a record number of training courses, conferences, presentations and workshops on a wide range of topics. 
We also provided financial support to employees for their participation in externally organised courses and programs to acquire or maintain professional qualifications and degrees. 
We also launched a program to develop leadership skills, which consists of courses, coaching and mentoring for employees who want to expand their leadership skills. 
We supported the work processes of the HR department by training newly created pools of career consultants, mentors and internal intermediaries. 
Once again, we exceeded the requirement for professional training days (5 days of non-language-related training per year), which was set in accordance with the recommendations of the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC). 
Our auditors completed an average of 7.5 training days; our non-audit staff accounted for an average of 3.6 days of training. 
In July 2019, the second Summer Academy on Public Financial Control and Accountability took place at the University of Pisa on "Digitalisation of Examination". 
In addition, we continued our cooperation with the University of Lorraine, in which we offered the fifth edition of the postgraduate course "Audit of public organisations and policies", which results in the Master's degree "Management of public organisations". 
In addition, we launched a new postgraduate program on "Fundamentals of statistics applied to audit". 
These programmes are now open to European Commission staff. 
Finally, we intensified our cooperation with the NATO International Audit Committee (IBAN) in the field of training. 
In May 2019, the Court held a workshop on "Assessment of the Union's Security and Defence Policy", which brought together auditors from the Commission, NATO, the European Defence Agency, the Joint Arms Cooperation Organisation (OCCAR), the Athena Mechanism and several EU Supreme Audit Institutions. 
ECAdemy In addition, we launched ECAdemy, a tool that allows us to exchange course material, publish recordings of conferences and organise webinars with all those interested in public financial control in the EU and its Member States. 
This e-learning platform is open to the general public free of charge at https://ecademy.eca.europa.eu.

Translation In 2019, we translated and revised more than 223 000 pages including external contracts (2018: 251 000). 
We translate our publications into all official EU languages. 
We also translate our correspondence with Member States' authorities in their national language, as required by law. 
Our translators are also often involved in our auditing activities by providing linguistic support during audit visits and drafting reports. 
Information technology, work environment and innovation Transition to cloud-based services An important milestone is the transition to cloud-based services, which generally provided an easy-to-use system for various applications from end-users (IT, personnel matters, office equipment, security, etc.). 
A new IT Security Action Plan has achieved many of its objectives, such as the more effective and regular elimination of software vulnerabilities, preventing unauthorised access to cloud services, reviewing information security governance and improving our security monitoring capabilities. 
Finally, an ambitious technical programme was implemented in 2019 to provide devices and systems that enable all employees to work more flexibly, e.g. home office, teleconferencing and mobile work. 
In 2019, we also adopted a new open data access policy. 
The re-use of documents and the process of providing our data are determined in cooperation with the Publications Office. 59 
ECALab, our interdisciplinary innovation laboratory team, has continued to research technologies such as text mining, artificial intelligence and process mining. 
In 2019, the ECALab also started to support a number of audit tasks. 
In November 2019, at the "Big and open data" conference held at our premises in Luxembourg, we also established the network of the EU-ORKB for Technology and Innovation for Audit (TINA). 
Conference on Big and open data, November 2019, Luxembourg. 
In order to accompany the development of the European Blockchain Services Infrastructure by the European Commission and the Member States on the basis of our "proof of concept", another EU-ORKB network on blockchain technology in the audit area has been set up. 60 
Buildings The courtyard currently has three buildings ("K1", "K2" and "K3") which form a single integrated technical unit. 
K1 The K1 building, which opened in 1988, has offices for up to 310 employees and meeting rooms. 
In the basement there are parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, the library and the main archive, while the entire top floor is used for technical facilities. 
The K1 building was modernised in 2008 to bring it into line with national health, safety and environmental requirements. 
As far as possible, the technology in the K1 building has been adapted to ensure compatibility with the K2 and K3 buildings. 
In the basement there are parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms and the fitness centre. 
The remaining floors are used for offices for up to 241 employees; they also have meeting rooms, a conference room with interpreting booths, video conference rooms, a cafeteria and simple kitchen areas. 
We are currently modernising the K2 building in order to optimise the organisation of its work areas and to update certain technical facilities. 
A detailed study on this project was carried out in 2019 and work started at the end of the year. 
As approved by the European Parliament and the Council in March 2014, the Court will use the remaining budget of the K3 construction project completed a few years ago to finance this modernisation. 61 
In the basement there are parking spaces, technical facilities, storage rooms, unloading areas, equipment for storing waste, printing, kitchens and archives. 
In addition, this building has offices for 503 employees, meeting rooms and an IT room. 
Based on the world's leading Building Research Establishment Environmental Assessment Method (BREEAM), the K3 building was rated as "very good". 62 
In 2019, we took a number of measures to increase the safety of our buildings in Luxembourg. 
This included the establishment of a team of armed security officers. 
An agreement has been concluded with the Luxembourg police, which allows us to use their national training centres. 
We have also agreed with the European External Action Service to assist our auditors in their visits to high-risk countries. 
63 Eduardo Ruiz García, Secretary General ECHR, and Helga Schmid, Secretary General EEAS. 
As an EU institution, it is our duty to follow the principle of sound environmental management in all activities. 
We strive to continue to systematically reduce our CO2 emissions and regularly analyse greenhouse gas emissions caused by our activities. 
Our greenhouse gas emissions in 2018 totalled 10 178 tonnes of carbon dioxide equivalent (tCO2e), which represents a 3 % reduction compared to 2017. 
We are proud of our EMAS certification for environmental management and auditing: We successfully operate an EMAS-compliant environmental management system and fully meet the certification requirements of ISO 14001:2015. 
An external EMAS audit was conducted in the last quarter of 2019, which resulted in our EMAS certification being renewed for the period 2020-2022. 
New initiatives such as the "plastic-free ECA" initiative are progressing as planned. 
In 2019, in cooperation with the Luxembourg Ministry of Agriculture, we also set up four beehives in our gardens. 
The bees are supervised by volunteers. 
We believe this will have a positive impact on the sustainability of pollinators in our environment. 64 
Accountability of the Court Financial Information The Court is financed from the general budget of the European Union, with its budget falling under the heading administrative expenditure. 
For 2019, our budget amounted to around 147 million euros, of which 98 % were used during the year. 
This represents less than 0.1 % of the EU's total expenditure, or around 1.5 % of the EU's total administrative expenditure.

Internal and external audit Internal Audit The Internal Audit Service advises the Court on risk management issues. 
It provides independent and objective assurance and provides advisory services designed to increase and improve the Court's activities. 
It shall also report to the Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and an external expert. 
The Committee regularly monitors progress on the various tasks laid down in the annual work programme of the Internal Audit Service and ensures the independence of the department. 
In the course of 2019, the Internal Audit Service performed three selected tasks: "Risks and challenges of the Audit Quality Control Committee", "Members' travel expenses and high-level officials, expenses related to representation of members and use of the Court's vehicle fleet" and "professional training activities of the Court". 
In addition, our risk management strategy and three annual declarations by subdelegation have undergone an investigation. 
In addition, the Internal Audit Service supervised the implementation of its previous recommendations by ensuring that the agreed action plans were implemented and discussed issues of the Court's new internal control framework. 
Our internal auditor did not identify any shortcomings which, due to their nature or scale, would seriously jeopardise the reliability of the internal control systems as a whole; these control systems had been introduced by the authorising officer by delegation to ensure the legality and regularity of the Court's financial operations in 2019. 
External Audit Our annual accounts are audited by an independent external auditor. 
We attach great importance to this audit as it shows that we apply to ourselves the same principles of transparency and accountability as for the bodies we audit. 
The auditor's report - PricewaterhouseCoopers S.ŕ.r.l. - on the Court's annual accounts for the financial year 2018 was published on 4 April 2019. 67

December 2018 and the results of its operations, cash flows and changes in net assets for the year ended that reference date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union and repealing Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002.

On the use of resources and the Court's control procedures: "In our work steps described in this report, we have not encountered situations from which we would have to conclude that, in all material respects and taking into account the above-mentioned assessment criteria o, the resources allocated to the Court were not used for the intended purposes and o the control procedures put in place do not provide the requisite assurance that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations." 
Discharge for the financial year 2017 Like the other EU institutions, the Court is also subject to the discharge procedure. 
In March 2019, the European Parliament granted our Secretary-General discharge in respect of the implementation of our budget for the financial year 2017. 
As every year, we have carefully analysed all the issues raised during the discharge procedure with regard to our audit and management responsibility, took appropriate action and reported in detail to the European Parliament on our follow-up. 
Finally, in 2019, our ethics framework was subjected to an external peer review by the SAIs of Poland and Croatia. 
The corresponding report was finalised in January 2020. 69

De EUROPEAN COUNCIL 2013 Brief information on the audit of the EU Presentation of the European Court of Auditors' annual reports on the financial year 2013 
Luxembourg: Office for Publications of the European Union, 2014 ISBN 978-92-872-0998-6 doi:10.2865/23970 (c) European Union, 2014 Reprinted with source allowed. 
De 2013 Short information on the EU audit Presentation of the European Court of Auditors' annual reports on the financial year 2013 
President 02 Each year in November, the European Court of Auditors reports on the results of itsannual EUfinancial management audits in the previous financial year. 
On the basis of the audit evidence obtained, the Court provides assurance on the use of EUfunds and highlights the greatest risk that EU funds have not been used properly. 
The guidelines also contain recommendations for possible improvements to the EU'sfinancial management. 
In this way, the Court supports the European Parliament and the Council in the review of EUspendingand contributes to the effective implementationofaccounting obligationstowards EU citizens. 
This "Short Information on the EU Audit in 2013" summarises and explains the main findings in our year2013 on the implementation of the EUbudgetand /or the European Development Funds. 
As in previous years, the reports provide information on the extent towhich EUfinancial managementactors at EU and national levelhave provided a true picture of financial management in their reports, ensured the application of EUfinancial rulesand complied with the basic set of economy, efficiency and effectiveness. 
2013 was the last year of a seven-year programming period, and we publish ourreports on this financial year in a transition phase that is important for the EU and its finances. 
As our reports show, a new European Parliament and a new Commission arefacing both long-standing and new challenges for financial management and accountability in the now ongoing 2014-2020 programming period. 
The pressure on EU and national finances continues to require careful management and control of EU funds and better forecasts of long-term financing needs. 
In particular, in our reports, we point out that the Commission and the authorities ofthe Member States need to pay greater attention to the use of EUfundsto deliver results that could not be achieved equally efficiently or effectively by other means. 
At the same time, the Court's audit results show that even more can and should be done to ensure thatthe EU discharges are carried out in accordance with the rules. 
The Court will gladly take the opportunity to support the new European Parliament and the new Commission in solving these and otherproblems of financial management and accounting at EU level. 
To this end, based on our audit experience, we have also produced two landscape analyses highlighting the EU's key challenges in the areas of accounting, auditing and financial management. 
Vítor Manuel da SILVA CALDEIRA President of the European Court of Auditors

Summary of the Statement of Assurance for 2013 The European Court of Auditors (ECA, 'the Court') gives an unrestricted opinion onthe reliability of the 2013 accounts of the European Union. 
Overall, the revenue for 2013 is legal and regular. 
Overall, the commitments for 2013 are legal and regular. 
Payments for 2013 are materially affected by errors. 
Therefore, the Court gives a failed opinion on its legality and regularity. 
The text of the Statement of Assurance can be found in Chapter 1 of the 2013 Annual Report. ? The Court estimates that the level of error measured by the levelof irregularities for 2013 is 4.7 %. This figure is close to the error rate for 2012 (4.8 %) and consistently above the materiality threshold of 2 %. ? Overall, the audited supervisory and control systems - with significantdivergences between Member States - ensured the regularity of payments due to a conditional effect. ? Most likely, the two expenditure areas were regional policy, transport and energy with an error rate of 6.9 % and rural development, environment, fisheries and health with an error rate of 6.7 %. 
Under shared management, i.e. including agriculture: Market support and direct payments as well as employment and social affairs,the estimated level of error was 5.2 %. ? corrective measures and recoveries by the authorities in the Member States andthe mission had a positive impact on the estimated error rate. 
EU funds for 2013 Each year, the Court audits the EU's revenue and expenditure and, in its audit report, assesses thereliability of the annual accounts and how the revenueand expenditure transactions arein line with the rules and regulations. 
In 2013, expenditure from the EUbudget amounted to a total of EUR 148,5 billion, or around EUR 290 per citizen. 
This expenditure represents about 1 % of the EU's gross national income and accounts for about 2 % of the total public expenditure ofthe EU Member States. 
The EUbudget is adopted annually by the European Parliament and the Council on the basis of a seven-year financial framework. 
The Commission's primary task is to ensure that the budget is spent on a regular basis. 
For around 80 % of expenditure, particularly in agriculture and cohesion, the Commission shares this task with the EUMember States. 
Where do the funds come from? 
The EU budget is financed from various sources. 
The largest share is due to payments made by Member States on the basis of their gross national income (EUR 110.0 billion). 
Other sources include payments made by Member States on the basis of the VAT they collect (14.5 billion euro) as well as customs and agricultural duties (EUR 15.4 billion). 
The annual EUbudget is spent in a wide range of policy areas (see Figure 1). 
The payments made are intended to support activities as diverseas research activities, training of unemployed persons or agricultural production.

Overall results 09 Errors, waste and fraud The error rate estimated by the Court is not a measure of fraud, inefficiency or waste. 
It is abudget which should not have been disbursed because they have notbeen used in accordance with the applicable law. 
Typical errors include payments for ineligible expenditure or for purchases for which procurement rules have not been properly applied. 
Fraud is a deliberate deception with the aim of gaining benefits. 
The Court forwards cases which it encounters during its audits and in which it suspects fraud to OLAF (the European UnionAnti -Fraud Office), which is responsible for carrying out any furtherinvestigations with the authorities in the Member States. 
A comparison of the estimated error rates for the different spending areas is shown in Figure 5. 
Higher quotas in research and other internal policies, administrative expenditure and related expenditure were offset by lower rates in rural development, environment, fisheries and health, as well as external relations, external assistance and enlargement. 
As in 2012, the two spending areas of regional policy, transport and energy, as well as rural development, environment, fisheries and health were the most flawed. 
These two areas are combined with the other two areas of shared management (agriculture: Market support and direct payments, as well as employment and social affairs), an estimated error rate of 5.2 %. 
For all other operational expenditure (mostly managed directly by the Commission), the estimated level of error was 3.7 %. 
In addition, the Court found an estimated error rate of 1.0 % for administrative expenditure.

12 The Court analyses the contribution of the different types of error as well as of the individual expenditure areas tothe estimated overall error rate (see Figure 6). 
Expenditure that did not meet the necessary conditions to be declared underEU-funded projects had the largest share of the estimated total error rate (including ineligible costs in the cost statements: 39 % or 1.8 percentage points of the estimatedtotal error quo). 
In the second place were projects where either the object(s) financed or the beneficiary should not have been funded under the applicable rules (ineligible projects/activities or beneficiaries: 22 % or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate). 
As the largest expenditure area with the highest estimated level of error, regional policy, transport and energy contribute by far the most to the estimated overall error rate (44 % or 2.1 per cent ofthe estimated total error rate). 
The Agriculture Sector: Market support and direct payments, where the volume of expenditure was almost as high, contributes about half as much to the estimated overall error rate. 
Corrective measures have a positive impact on the error rate The Member States and the Commission apply corrective measures to protect the EUbudgetincases of unaffected control systems or irregular expenditure. 
If such corrective measures had not been applied to the 2013 payments audited by the Court, the estimated total error rate would have been 6.3 % instead of 4.7 %. 
However, the estimated error rate could still be significantly reduced by better application of existing control systems and corrective measures. 
We found that the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before requesting reimbursement from the Commission for a large part of the error-bearing transactions in the areas of sharedmanagement. 
For example, this would have reduced the estimated error rate in regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9 % to 3.9 %, in rural development, environment, fisheries and health from 6.7 % to 2.0 % and in employment and social affairs from 3.1 % to 1.9 %. 
New challenges for the presentation of reliable financial information The reporting of the corrective adjustments mentioned above does not clearly distinguish betweenthe main types of corrective adjustments. In addition, the information is provided largely outside the accounting system. 
This makes a more detailed analysis and reduces the accuracy of the figures reported in the accounts and related financial reporting. 
A further development is the increasing use of financial instruments to support investments in potentially economically viable projects, in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk mechanisms. 
Due to their complex structure, financial instruments require special care in their assessment and recording in accordance with internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector. 
Overall results 13 Continuous increase in the amounts to be financed from future budgets The main features of EU financial management and management in 2013 include: ? a strong increase in the volume of payments which the Commission was entitled tomake through correction plans: 9.6 % of the initial budget; ? a continued increase in commitments giving rise to payments in the future (by 2.6 %) despite the high volume of payments; ? an unchanged long period (on average more than two years) between the date of the initial commitment and the date on which the declarations of expenditure are accepted by the Commission; ? only 37 % of the funds allocated to financial instruments had been disbursed to final beneficiaries at the end of 2012; ? repayments, interest and dividends amounting to EUR 259 million, which has accumulated since2008, were not recognised as revenue. 
What are commitments and payments? 
The EUbudget consists of two elements: Commitments (to be paid in the current or coming years) and payments (covering funding paid in the current year). 
Payments can only be made against valid commitments. 
The annual ceilings for commitment and payment appropriations are set out in the multiannual financial framework agreed by the Council and Parliament. 
The nature of EUspending programmes, in particular the long period between commitment and payment, is putting increasing pressure on future payment budgets. 
This is reflected in a significantly higher budget for payments in 2013, and this trend will continue similarly in future budgets. 
14 In the Court's view, the Commission should publish more meaningful information on the functioning of the correction mechanisms (time, origin and nature) and increase the accuracy of the corresponding figures by recording information within the traditional accounting systems; record and assess all financial instruments and financial instruments in accordance with internationally recognisedpublic sector accounting principles, in particular through reliable procedures for identifying and recording impairments; provide information on the cash resources held until disbursement to the final beneficiaries; prepare and publish a long-term cash flowforecast, updated annually; this would make it easier for the stakeholders concerned to identify future payment needs and todefine the House's priorities.
