Full information on the main audit findings can befound in Chapter 1 "Declaration of reliability and related statements" of the 2013 annual report on the implementation of the EU budget. 
Overall results 15 EU funds and output of EUfunds should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (economy, efficiency and effectiveness). 
Against this background, inputs are needed to achieve good performance (financial, human, material, organisational or regulatory resilience required for programme implementation), outputs (which is to be achieved under the programme), results (immediate changes due to the programme's direct participants or direct beneficiaries) and impacts (long-term societal changes, at least partly due to the EUaction). 
The Court assesses these aspects in its performance audits. 
The focus is not enough on performance In the 2007-2013 programming period, the focus was on absorption (use it or loose it) and compliance with legislation rather than good performance. 
In the selection of projects for EUfunding, for example, the need to usethe available EUfunds was paramount. Second came the necessary compliance with the rules, and only to a certain extent - and only to some extent - was the achievement of results and effects. 
This focus on performance is a crucial weakness in the way a large part of the EUbudget is built up. 
According to the Commission, the focus in the 2014-2020 programming period is more onelicitation, with performance reserves being the main incentive. 
Through these reserves, the Commission will retain 6 % of the resources allocated to individual Member States until the performance is considered satisfactory. 
In practice, however, input and output indicators will continue to be largely in tune with the release of funds. 
Result indicators will only be used by the Commission in some areas. 
Whether performance reserves work more effectively will depend on the Commission's success in negotiating appropriate targets and milestones at the beginning of the programming period and in obtaining accurate, reliable and up-to-date data from Member States to determine whether the targets have been achieved. 
The reporting framework is not suitable for the desired performance culture The performance reporting is divided into several general reports at the level of the general budget. 
These reports do not provide information on progress towards the achievement of the Europe 2020 strategy objectives, nor provide a comprehensive overview of the results in the form of EUadded value. 
However, the fourth evaluation report represents a step in the right direction in that it seeks to establish a link between the main financial programmes and the available performance information relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy. 
At the level of each Directorate-General of the Commission, performance targets for policy areas under their respective competences are defined in the management plans. It will then be reported in the Annual Activity Reports. 
The Court's analysis of the management plans and annual activity reports of the Commission's Directorates-General showed that assurance is limited to aspects of regularity and internal control and performance aspects are not taken into account. 
In addition,the objectives are too general to be used for management purposes, and the selected indicators are not always suitable for performance measurement. 
Overall results 16 The added value generated by EU spending is not always demonstrated In the 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013, performance audits cover a wide range of topics and assess whether the EUinterventionhas been implemented in line with the principles of sound financial management (economy, efficiency and effectiveness). 
We examined the lessons learned from our special reports adopted in 2013 for thepreparation of the new programmes and projects for the2014-2020 programming period and reached the following conclusion: ? The EU added value could not always be ensured. ? In several cases, there were potential carry-over effects, i.e. the beneficiaries would have carried out the activity even without EU funding. 
Example: European Globalisation Adjustment Fund The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund compensates workers affected by collective redundancies. 
We found that one third of the funding was used for actions that would have already been paid by Member States (Special Report No 7/2013 "has the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provided EU added value in the reintegrationofredundant workers?". 
Example: The Commission had not sufficiently demonstrated that the EUfunds provided under the Financial Facility on a risk-sharing basis (financial instrument designed to facilitate access to external financing in the field of research)result in higher investments than the beneficiaries would make without public funds (Special Report No 2/2013 "Has the Commission ensured an efficient implementation of the Seventh Framework Programme?". 
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been implemented The Court's follow-up to its recommendations following performance audits is a key part of the accountability cycle and can facilitate the effective implementation by the Commission of the recommendations contained in the reports. 
The Court analysed how the Commissionfurther addressed recommendations from eight special reports adopted in 2007-2010 and noted that the Commission had implemented 79 % of the recommendations either fully or largely. 
The Court recommends that the Commission: ? The Commission should streamline the framework for its performance in the next revision of the Financial Regulation. ?The Commission should ensure that the evaluation report contains a summary overview of all available information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. ? The Commission should further develop its performance managementand reporting system in order to be able to assume responsibility for sound financial management and the contribution of the EUbudgetto political successes. All special reports are available on the Court's website: http://www.eca.europa.eu/de/ Pages/AuditReportsOpinions.aspx. 
The contributions calculated on the basis of the gross national income (GNI) of the Member States or of the VAT collected by Member States accounted for 74 % and 10 % of revenue respectively in 2013. 
Import duties and theproduction levy on sugar levied by the authorities in the Member States on behalf of the EU accounted for 10 % of the EU's revenue. The remaining 6 % comes from other revenue. 
The EU revenue based on GNI andVATwill be calculated on the basis of macroeconomic statistics and estimates provided by Member States. 
The Court's audit of the regularity of the underlying transactions relates to the processing of these data by the Commission, but not to the initial collection of those data by the authorities in the Member States. 
Consequently, the Court's audit conclusion concerns the impact of any errors made by the Commission on the total amount of revenue. 
As regards customs duties, the Court examines how the Commission deals with the claims established bythe Member States. 
These data are not sufficiently harmonised among Member States. 
A reservation is an instrument that allows the possibility of correction to be kept open for a contentious element in GNIdatatransmitted by a Member State. 
There is a general reservation on the Greek GNI data for the years 2008 and 2009, as the data are still based on preliminary estimates. 
This aspect is part of a problem affecting Greece's national accounts. 
19 The customs authorities of the Member States carry out checks to verify that importerscomply with customs and import requirements. 
We found that the quality of these controlswas very different in the Member States visited. 
This may lead importers to decide to notify goods in a Member State other than that in which they are established in order to reduce the likelihood of inspection and to make it difficult to collect the duties due. 
One example in which this procedure appears to be present is the case of an importer who loaded Chinese textiles in Hamburg (Germany) and transported them to Rotterdam, where they were declared for free circulation and subsequently sent them to Poland for final sale. 
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ? The Commission should work to ensure that Member States harmonise their methods for calculating unobserved economic activity data. ? The Commission should draw up a detailed action plan with clear milestones and closely monitor itsimplementation in order to address the problems in the preparation ofGreece's national accounts. ? The Commission should establish minimum standards for controls by Member States' customs authorities in order to allow for a more targeted focus on importers at high risk. Want to know more? 
Full information on the Court's audit ofEUrevenue can be found in Chapter 2 of the Annual Report on the implementation ofthe EU budget for the financial year 2013. 
20 This area of expenditure covers the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), one of the two main instruments of the EU's common agricultural policy. 
The aim of this policy is to increase the productivityof farmers, to ensure an adequate standard of living for the agricultural population, to stabilise markets, to ensure supply and to ensure the supply to consumers at reasonable prices. 
Expenditure is subject to shared management with the Member States. 
Yes Estimated errors- quote: 3.6 % (2012: 3.8 %) Control systems examined: Most expenditure in this area is calculated on the basis of agricultural land. 
Many quantifiable errors are the result of inaccuracies in beneficiaries' applications, most of which are excessive area indications (see example). 
Example: Over-declarations - Application for aid for ineligible land In Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Poland and Romania* someareas declad as permanent pasture for which corresponding payments were made were actually covered in whole or in part with ineligible vegetation (dense bushes or trees). 
EU aid should not have been paidforthese ineligible areas. 
In Greece, this error occurred because such areas were classified as eligible grassland and were included in the agricultural parcel identification system accordingly. * Note on the mention of Member States in the examples: The sampling approach applied by the Court does not audit transactions every year in each Member State, beneficiary country and/or region. 
The examples of errors are intended to illustrate the most common types of errors. 
They do not provide a basis for conclusions on the Member States, beneficiary countries and/or regions concerned. 
For all EAGFdirectaidschemes, EU beneficiaries are legally obliged to comply with 'other-wide obligations' (cross-compliance) relating to environmental protection, human, animal and plant health and animal welfare, as well as the conservation of areas in good agricultural and ecological conditions.
If farmers fail to comply with these obligations, their aid will be reduced. 
In its audits, the Court found infringements of 25 % of the transactions related to these obligations. 
In the case of a significant number of transactions affected by errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before requesting a refund to the Commission. 
If this information had been used to correct errors before the expenditure was declared to the Commission, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2.5 %. 
21 The Court's investigation of integrated management and control systems (IACS) in four Member States (Germany, Ireland, France and Italy) revealed weaknesses in the management control procedures and the quality of databases in three Member States( Ireland, France and Italy), ? deficiencies in the quality of on-the-spotchecksin two Member States (Germany and Italy), ? weaknesses in the procedures for recovering unduly paid amounts in two Member States (Ireland and Italy). 
Despite the deficiencies identified during the audit, IACS contributes significantly to the prevention of errors in the expenditure covered by this system. 
In the Member States that joined the EU in 2004 or later, producer groups in the fruit and vegetables sector mayreceive EU aid. 
In order to be recognised as a producer group, certain conditions must be met with regard to the number and relative size of the member producers. 
We found that nine of the 40 producer groups audited in Poland did not comply with these conditions. 
In its 2013 Annual Activity Report, the Commission reported that it had reserved a risk amount of 25 % of the totalexpenditure under the measure concerned in Poland. 
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations: ? The Commission and the Member States should take the necessary measures to ensure that the potential of IACS is fully exploited. To this end, they should ensure, for example, that the eligibility and size of agricultural parcels are correctly assessed and recorded. ? The Commission should monitor the corrective measures related to the shortcomings of the EUaidto producer groups in Poland. Want to know more?

22 This area of expenditure covers rural development policy areas, climateand environmental policy, maritime affairs and fisheries, and health and consumer protection. 
88 % of payments in this area are financed by the European AgriculturalFund for Rural Development (EAFRD). 
Expenditure is subject to shared management with the Member States. 
The EAFRD co-finances rural development expenditure under relevant Member States' programmes. 
Expenditure covers area-related measures (such as agri-environmental payments and compensatory payments to farmers in areas with natural handicaps) and non-area-related measures (such as modernisation of agricultural holdings andbasic services for the rural economy and population). 
Yes Estimated error rate: 6.7 % (2012: 7.9 %) Control systems examined: Conditionally effective Most of the errors were due to the failure to comply with the eligibility conditions. In particular, this concerned the following conditions: Agri-environment commitments (see example), specificrequirements for investment projects and procurement rules. 
Example: Non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments A farmer in Sardinia (Italy) was compensated for not using environmentally harmful plant protection products when cultivating artichokes. 
During its on-the-spotcheck, the Court found that the beneficiary had used such plant protection products twelve times during the audited period. 
Therefore, the payment for aid was not eligible. 
Similar cases of non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments have also been detected in the Piedmont region (Italy) as well as in Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania. 
23 In the case of a significant number of transactions affected by errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before requesting reimbursement from the Commission. 
If this information had been used to correct errors before the expenditure was declared to the Commission, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2.0 %. 
The Court's examination of rural development control systems showed that: ? deficiencies in the checks on eligibility conditions, e.g. non-recovery of VATamounts or the riskof double financing (in seven of the eight Member States examined - Germany, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Malta, Romania and Slovenia; Poland was the exception); ? inadequate assessment of the plausibility of costs (in all four Member States examined - Italy,Lett -land, Poland and Romania); ? inadequacies in the design and implementation of cross-compliance controls (in all four MemberStates sought - Czech Republic, Spain, Italy and Malta); the crosscompliance obligations require beneficiaries to meet specific conditions, such as environmentaland social standards, in order to qualify for aid; ? shortcomings in the checks on procurement rules (in all three Member States examined - Italy, Lett-land and Poland; see example). 
Example: In Latvia, the Paying Agency was a beneficiary of an EAFRDaidamounting to EUR 2 million to finance its outsourced IT system. This contract was subject to the rules governing the award ofpublic contracts. 
We found thatseveral serious errors had occurred in the procurement of the ITsystemand the subsequent data records. 
For example, instead of an open or restricted procedure, the Paying Agency applied a handling procedure, as provided forin the legislation. 
Due to non-compliance with the prescribed procedures, expenditure is noteligible for EU funding. 
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations in favour of rural development: ? Member States should improve the implementation of their existing administrative controls by using all relevant information available to paying agencies. 
In this way, most of the errors could be detected and corrected. ? Member States should ensure that the action plans aimed at addressing the high estimated rural development rate of ruraldevelopment include all regions and take into account all measures, in particular investment measures, and that they take into account the Commission's and the Court's auditfindings. Full information on the Court's audit of the EUexpenditurein rural development, environment, fisheries and health can be found in Chapter 4 of the Annual Report on the implementation of theEU budget for the financial year 2013. 
This audit covered regional policy (96 % of payments in this area of expenditure), mainly financed by the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF). 
The aim of regional policy is to strengthen economic and social cohesion in the European Union by reducing the development gap between the different regions. 
Expenditure on regional policies is subject to shared management by the Commission and Member States, with projects being co-financed under approved spending programmes. 
The remaining 4 % of this audited expenditure area is covered by transport and energy policy areas. 
Transport and energy policy aims to provide European citizens and businesses with safe, sustainable and competitive transport and energy systems and services. 
This expenditure is managed directly by the Commission. 
Yes Estimated mostlikely error rate: 6.9 % (2012: 6.8 %) Control systems examined: Conditionally effective We found serious errors in public procurement, accounting for 39 % of our estimated level of error. 
The cumulative contract value of the 122 audited procurement procedures is estimated to be 4.2 billion euros. 
Example: Unjustified direct award contracts for additional works at the passenger terminal of an airport in Germany were awarded freelyto the original contractor. 
This additional work was necessary becauseof the thorough preparation, planning and implementation of the project and not dueto unpredictable circumstances. 
In such cases, a direct award is inadmissible, which is why the additional work should have been tendered. 
Similar cases involving unjustified direct award wereidentified in projects in Bel-gien, the Czech Republic, elsewhere in Germany, Spain, Italy and Sweden. 
25 In addition, the Court's auditors examine whether the EUruleson State aid are complied with. 
Unlawful State aid confers an unjustified advantage on the beneficiary authorities and therefore affects the internal market. 
State aid errors accounted for 17 % of the estimated error rate in this area (see example). 
Example: Aid for research and development in the automotive industry has been granted to a small or medium-sized enterprise (SME) in Slovenia. 
However, the SME was wholly owned by large companies and carried out its research activities exclusively for them. 
Since larger companies are subject to stricter public funding rules, the company was not entitled to the total funding. 
Similar cases were found in Bulgaria and Hungary. 
In the case of a significant number of transactions affected by errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors beforerequesting approval from the Commission. 
If this information had been used to correct errors before the expenditure was declared to the Commission, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 3.9 %. 
The Court's auditors also noted that financial instruments continued to recorddisbursement rates to final beneficiaries in 2013. 
The Funds concerned support companies or urban development projects through equity investments, loans or guarantees. 
The Funds will be provided with funds when their legal structure has been created and then use these funds to support projects. 
In total, 940 financial instruments have been set up in 25 Member States, endowed with around EUR 12.6 billion. 
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ? The Commission should require Member States to confirm in their management declarations theeffectiveness of the primary controls carried out by the managing authority and the certifying authority. ? The Commission should, as required by the Financial Regulation, carry out a thorough assessment of the anhal-likeproblem related to the primary controlscarried outby public authorities in theMember States during the programming period 2007-2013. ? The Commission should analyse the reasons for the frequency of non-compliance with the EUruleson State aid. ? The Commission shouldreduce the persistent delays in disbursement of EUfunds through financialinstruments. Want to know more?

A closer look at the revenue and expenditure sectors Employment and Social Affairs 16.2 billion euro the subject of our audit 26 The audit related to employment and social affairs, which forms part of the EU's cohesion policy. 
The main objectives of expenditure in this area are the fight againstunemployment, the development of human resources and the promotion of integration into the labour market. 
Employment andsocial policies are mainly implemented through the European Social Fund (ESF): 98 % of the payments made in this area of expenditure in 2013 were borne by this Fund. 
The ESF will support investment in human capital in the form of training and other employment measures. 
In a private school in Portugal, the full salary of the school director was charged to the EU project, although he also had to carry out other tasks. 
In addition, the salary co-financing ceiling has not been respected. 
Similar findings were also found in projects in Germany, Spain, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom. 
In the case of a significant number of transactions affected by errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error beforerequesting approval from the Commission. 
If this information had been used to correct errors before the expenditure was declared to the Commission, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 1.8 %. 
27 At the Court's recommendation and with the aim of reducing the likelihood of errors and administrative burdens for project promoters, the application of lump sums and flat rates was extended in 2009 instead of the reimbursement of "actual costs". 
In its 2013 audit, the Court did not detectany quantifiable errors specifically related to the application of lump sums and flat rates. 
This suggests that projects whose costs are reported using such payment options are less flawed.

Yes Estimated error rate: 4.6 % (2012: 3.9 %) Control systems examined: With most payments in this area of expenditure, the Commission reimburses costs declaredby beneficiaries in project cost statements. 
Errors arise when beneficiaries report ineligible costs that are not detected by the control systems prior to reimbursement by the Commission. 
35 % of the estimated error rate is due to incorrectly calculated or ineligible personnel costs. 
For example, the estimated and not actual staff costs and working time not spent on the project are claimed. 
Apart from non-compliance with expenditure rules, the reimbursement of ineligible costs is also hindering the successful implementation of the policy objectives and therefore limits the added value provided by EU funding (see example). 
Example: Ineligible expenditure reduces EU addedvalueThe EU provides funding to ensure efficient and effective controls at the EU'sexternal borders. 
We examined a project in Spain that consisted of the purchase of four helicopters to be used 75 % for the surveillance and control of the external borders. 
However, the Court found that only 25 % of the operating hours of helicopters accounted for this purpose. 
As a result, the EU should have paid only 25 % and not the 75 % of the cost of helicopters actually covered.

Background information 35 The audit approach at a glance The Court's audit opinions in the context of the statement of assurance are based on objective evidenceobtained, in particular, from audits carried out in accordance with international audit principles. 
The EU budget is complex. 
The Commission's Directorates-General annuallyarranges for entries for dogs based on data from many different sources (including Member States). 
The Court examines whether the accounting procedures are functioning properly and that the resulting accounting data are fully, correctly recorded and properly presented. ? Assessment of the accounting system to determine whether it provides a solid basis for reliable (complete and accurate) data. ? Verification of the main accounting procedures to determine whether they function correctly. ? Analytical audits of accounting data to determine, whether they are coherent and appear plausible. ? Direct audit of a sample of accounting entries in order to determine whether the underlying advances areactually present and correctly recorded. ? Audit of the annual accounts to determine whether they represent the financial situation appropriately. In order to ensure that errors are properly assessed and that the errors are properly assessed, the relevant rules are assessed in accordance with therelevant rules? ? The statistical methods are used to draw samples from all parts of the EUbudgetof transactions that serve as a basis for in-depth audits of the Court's auditors. ? Thetransactions recorded in the sample are examined in detail, usually on the spot at the endrecipients (e.g. a farmer, a research organisation, a company that carries out publicly writtenconstruction work or provides servicesto be properly assessed bymeans of an error.

Background information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (ECA) is the independent audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg. 
It employs around 900 staff ofallEU nationalities, composed of auditors and staff in horizontal services. 
Since its establishment in 1977, it has raised awareness of theimportance of EU financialmanagement and contributes to improving it. 
The Court's audit reports and opinions form an important link in the EU's accountability chain. 
Our results will be used to hold the EU's financial management bodies accountable, especiallyin the context of the discharge procedure. 
This is mainly the Commission, but it also affects the other EU institutions, bodies and agencies. 
In shared management, Member States also play an important role. 
Our main tasks: ? Audits of accounting and compliance audits, mainly with regard to the statement of assurance; ? performance audits on topics selected in such a way that we achieve the greatest possibleimpact with our work; ? Opinions on legislation related to budgetary management and other important issues. 
We strive to use our resources to strike a balance between our different areas of activity in order to achieve sound results and appropriate coverage of the different areas of the EUbudget. 
Background information 38 Our results We present the following results: annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds; the annual reportsmainly comprise the audit opinions in the framework of the Statement of Assurance and the resultsof the hearing, and will be published annually in November; ? specific annual reports containing audit opinions on the accounts of the various EU agencies and bodies; 53 reports will be published in 2014; ? Special reports on selected audit topics, which will be published throughout the year; these are mainly performance audits; approximately 25 reports will be published in 2014; ? Opinions used by the European Parliament and the Council in the adoptionof EU legislation with a significant impact on financial management; six opinions are to be published in 2014; ? Landscape analyses of selected areas of EUpolicy, where major challenges and long-term trends are analysed; two such analyses are to be published in 2014; ? the Annual Activity Report, which contains information and explanations on our activities inthe year in question. 
With our work, we contribute to the education and transparency of the EU'sfinancial managementby providing assurance on the state of financial management and bymaking recommendations for further improvements. 
This is done in the interests of the citizens of the European Union. 
Information on the Court's audits at the agencies and other decentralised bodies of the European Union can be found in the specific annual reports for the financial year 2013available on the Court's website. 
The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the EU - Guardian of EU finances In its annual reports on the EU budget and on the European Development Funds, the Court issues an audit opinion (declaration of reliability) on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. 
This brief information provides an overview of the main findings and conclusions. 
The full text of the reports is available on the Court's website and will be published in the Official Journal of the European Union.

8 Annex Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (Ljubljana) Areas of competence of the Union under the Treaty (Article 114 (ex Article 95 TEC) and Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) competences of the Agency (Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council); Commission Regulation (EU) No 838/2010; Regulation (EU) No 1227/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council) Competencies and activities The European Parliament and the Council, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee, shall adopt measures for the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to the establishment and functioning of the internal market. 
The Union's energy policy, in a spirit of solidarity between Member States in the context of the establishment or functioning of the internal market, shall pursue the following objectives, taking into account the need to preserve and improve the environment: ensuring the functioning of the energy market; ensuring the security of energy supply in the Union; promoting energy efficiency and energy savings and developing new and renewable energy sources and (d) promoting the interconnectivity of energy networks. 
The European Parliament and the Council shall adopt, in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, the measures necessary to achieve the objectives. 
Those measures shall be adopted after consulting the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. 
The purpose of the Agency is to assist national regulatory authorities in carrying out the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and, where necessary, to coordinate their actions. 
Tasks - Complementation and coordination of the work of national regulatory authorities, - Participation in the development of rules for European networks, - subject to certain conditions, making binding individual decisions on the modalities for access and operational security of cross-border infrastructures, - Advising the European institutions on energy-related issues, - Monitoring and reporting on developments in energy markets; - drawing up a proposal to the European Commission on the annual compensation for cross-border infrastructure under the ITC mechanism; - cooperation with national regulatory authorities, ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and, where appropriate, national competition authorities to monitor wholesale energy markets, - Assessment of the functioning and transparency of different categories of marketplaces and different types of trade; - Make recommendations to the Commission on market rules, records of transactions, trade orders, standards and procedures that could improve the integrity of the market and the functioning of the internal market.

12.In addition, the Agency has carried over 3.1 million euro or 91 % of the total committed appropriations under Title III, also in connection with the implementation of the REMIT Regulation. 
The extraordinarily high carry-over rate for Title III is mainly due to an additional increase of around 3 million euro by an amending budget approved on 31 October 2013. 
At the end of the year, the Agency had EUR 5.5 million in cash, including around 3 million from the late adopted ADB001936DE04-14PP-CH068-14APCFIN-RAS-2013_ACER-TR.DOC 8.7.2014 7 amending budget (see paragraph 12). 
Nevertheless, the average cash balance during the year was significantly higher than justified by operational needs.

EN 6.12.2017 Official Journal of the European Union C 417/27 responsibilities of the Prfer for the preparation of the annual accounts and the underlying claims 11. Our objectives are to obtain sufficient certainty as to whether the Agency's annual accounts are free from material misrepresentation and the underlying claims are legal and orderly, as well as to the European Parliament and the Council or other relevant discharge requests based on our examination, to provide an explanation about the eligibility of the invoice, as well as the legality and legality of the underlying claims. 
Misrepresentations and understandings may be intended or unintentional and are considered material if they could reasonably be expected, individually or collectively, to influence the economic decisions of users made on the basis of these accounts. 
12. An inspection involves the execution of inspections in order to obtain proof of proof of the value and other information contained in the annual accounts, as well as for the legality and regularity of the underlying assets. The selection of the procedures is at the discretion of the Prfer. To that end, the assessment of the risks of material intentional or unintentional misrepresentations in the annual accounts and substantial intentional or unintentional interpretations against the legislation of the European Union leads to the underlying advances. 
When assessing these risks, the Prfer shall take into account all internal controls relevant to the preparation and proper presentation of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying assets in order to plan inspections that are appropriate under the circumstances, but not with the aim of issuing a test opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system. 
A review shall also include the assessment of the adequacy of the accounting policies applied, the reasonableness of the audited values determined by the management in the accounts and the assessment of the overall presentation of the annual accounts. 
13. With regard to revenue, we assess the grant received from the Commission by the Agency and assess, where relevant, its procedures for collecting fees and other revenue. 
14. With regard to expenditure, we examine the payment advances after the expenditure has been settled, recorded and accepted. 
Advance payments are checked after the fund has proven their proper use and the Agency has accepted the evidence by settlement of the advance payment in the same year or even in the same year. 
15. In accordance with Article 208(4) of the EU Financial Regulation (6), we took into account the audit work of the independent external authority to the Agency's annual accounts when preparing this report and explaining the eligibility.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 17. In its May 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed the urgent need to crank up roles and skills and to analyse the workload of the contracting authority in order to increase the efficiency of processes and procedures. 
The IAS also concluded that the planning and monitoring of procurement should be significantly improved. 
The Agency and the IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures. 
COMMENTS ON THE BUDGET 18. The Agency allocated EUR 4.9 million or 86 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: EUR 1.4 million and 59 % respectively. 
As in previous years, these transfers were mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation on the integration and transparency of the energy wholesale trading market(7) and amounted to EUR 4.7 million in 2016 (2015: 1.1 million euros). 
For Title II (Administrative expenditure), the Agency allocated EUR 1 million or 38 % of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: EUR 0.8 million or 35 % respectively. 
19. The increase in appropriations is worrisome and is at odds with the budgetary principle of honorability. 
The transfer rate is directly linked to the conclusion or signature of procurement procedures and contracts in part towards the end of the year, leading to a shift of deliveries and/or payments to the following year. 
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 contracts were signed in November and December (EUR 5 976 122.47 and 40 % of the total value of the contracts closed in 2016). 
The Agency may draw up separate budget appropriations in order to better reflect the multi-dimensional nature of the activities and the inevitable distortions between signatures, deliveries and payments.

Audit comments General comments Background 6. The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 as a European Community satellite body and aims to promote vocational training at Community level. 
Cedefop began its work in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Thessaloniki in 1995. 
7. As defined in that Regulation, it is for the Centre to 'support the Commission in order to promote and develop training and continuous training at Community level', to contribute to the implementation of a common vocational training policy and, in particular, to promote the exchange of information and experience. 
In the field of vocational training, the Centre has in particular the task of "producing documentation, contributing to the further development and coordination of research, ensuring the dissemination of appropriate documentation and information, promoting and supporting initiatives to achieve a coordinated solution (in particular in the harmonisation of training levels and mutual recognition of certificates) and to establish a meeting point for the parties involved". 8. The Centre is headed by a Board of Directors of 48 members (in this context, costs of ECU 334 000 were incurred in 1995). Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75, published on 13 February 1975, 
The Management Board shall elect one Chairperson and three Vice-Chairs from among its members for a period of one year. 
At the time of the audit (May 1996), the Chair of the Administrative Council was chaired by the Director-General of DG XXII - Education, Training, Youth. 
The Director of the Centre shall be appointed by the Commission on the basis of a list of candidates submitted by the Management Board. 
9. In accordance with the basic Regulation, the Director is responsible for the day-to-day management of the Centre, while the Board of Directors has overall responsibility. 
The Management Board shall adopt decisions, adopt the work programme and the annual report, draw up the statement of revenue and expenditure for the preceding year and the estimates of revenue and expenditure for the coming year. 
10. The Commission's role, carried out by representatives of DG XXI I, is not only to represent the Commission within the Management Board, but also to adopt the work programme, to examine the Jah-re Report and the statement of revenue and expenditure, and to forward the estimates of revenue and expenditure to the Council and the European Parliament. 
In accordance with Article 23 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 * of 30 June 1993, all commitments and payments made by the Centre must, prior to the actual payment, receive a reasonable cost. the efficient use of human resources and other resources; C) high quality products that meet the needs of Cedefop customers; a clear and coherent role in the framework of the European Community's vocational training policy. 
Financial data 14. For the 1995 financial year, the Centre had a budget of ECU 16.50 million. 
The commitments made resulted in payments of ECU 10.11 million and transfers to 1996 of ECU 4.67 million, with the balance of ECU 1.72 million cancelled. 
From appropriations carried over from the previous year, ECU 2.16 million was disbursed and ECU 0.29 million was cancelled. 
Annex 1 to this report contains an analysis of the use of the appropriations for the financial year and the appropriations carried over from the 1994 financial year. 
Annex 2 gives an overview of the budgetary accounts for the financial year 1995 and the balance sheet of assets and debts at 31. December 1995. 
Comments on the implementation of the budget separation of activities 15. Following the move to Thessaloniki, until the time of the audit (May 1996), the Zentrum had not yet put in place appropriate procedures to separate the activities of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the imprest administrator. 
For example, it was observed that the accounting officer took over the imprest administrator. 
Paying Agency 16. The share of payments made without the approval of the financial crisis remains high (60 % in 1995 excluding salaries). 
The strong use of the paying agency procedure is not in line with the spirit of financial rules. 
A more acceptable practice would be to cover only current and low-volume expenditure where the risk of irregularity is comparatively low, through the Paying Agency procedure. 
Transfers within the budget 17. Transfers between different budget lines totalled ECU 922 000 in 1995, i.e. 5.6 % of the initial budget, compared with 10.9 % in 1994. 
No C 81/4 | EN | Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 transfers (ECU 570 000) were carried out in the last two months of 1995, compared with 33 % in 1994. 
18. The Centre did not carry out any transfer of funds between different titles in 1995. 
As a result, the remark made by the Court in the past year has been taken into account (2). 
Transfers and cancellations of appropriations 19. The practice of carrying over large amounts of appropriations already observed in previous years (3) continued to increase in 1995. 
In 1995, only 61 % of the final appropriations were disbursed, compared with 73 % in 1994. 
The share of commitments carried over to 1996 amounted to 28 % (compared to 23 % in 1994). 
The proportion of deferred appropriations was 10 %, compared with 5 % in 1994. 
Table 1 shows, by title, the appropriations carried over from the original 1995 budget and their subsequent use. 
20. The carry-overs in the field of operational expenditure amounted to 53 % of the initial appropriations compared to 40 % in 1994. 
As 8 % of the appropriations for operational expenditure fell, this means that the Centre paid out only 39 % of its 1995 operational budget in 1995. 
At the end of the first quarter of 1996, only 34 % of the appropriations carried over from 1995 within Title 3 had been disbursed. 
21. The high number of transfers within the budget and cancellations, as well as the large amount of transfers to the next financial year, indicate that the work programme has not been carried out as planned and that the principles of economic implementation have been jeopardised. 
This fact and the lack of staff (see paragraphs 42 to 45) will have a serious impact on the implementation of the 1996 budget. 
Comments on the budgetary accounts and the statement of assets revenue(Committee of the Commission) 22. The financial contribution to the general budget of the Communities for the financial year 1995 has been disbursed by the Commission in several instalments. The first instalment of ECU 2 300 000 was paid on 6 February 1995, followed by further instalments of ECU 2 400 000 on 20 April 1995, of ECU 2 500 000 on 28 June 1995, of ECU 2 800 000 on 5 October 1995, of ECU 5 875 000 on 22 November 1995 and ECU 525 000 on 1 January 1995. December 1995. 
As in previous Jah-ren (4), this rhythm of payment is not in line with the Court's annual report for 1994. 
(3) The Court's annual reports on the financial years 1992, 1993 with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation for the Centre, which states that payments are to be made in the first half of each quarter and adapted to actual needs. 
Expenses 23. Following the decision to move the centre to Thessaloniki, a new deputy director was appointed in 1994, who lived and worked in Thessaloniki at that time. 
Staff moved to Berlin and received an installation allowance equal to his dual basic salary. Not even a year later, i.e. after the move of the centrum to Thessaloniki, the same staff member again received an installation allowance equal to twice the basic salary. 
Since the relocation of the centre quickly took place, the stay of the operator concerned in Berlin was only of short duration (11 months); in addition, he spent part of that time in Thessaloniki, receiving full subsistence allowances (including weekends). The Court takes the view that these decisions are not in line with the principle of sound financial management and are contrary to Cedefop. 
24. The contract of another Deputy Direk-tor, who had already moved from Berlin to Madrid in July 1995, was signed by the Board of Directors with effect from 3 1. 
The staff member then received a payment of ECU 71 030. 
The Court considers that this decision of the Board of Directors is not consistent with the principles of economic housekeeping. 
25. Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993, authorises the award of a contract by hand if the amount of the contract does not exceed ECU 12 000. 
At least 12 cases have been allocated over an amount higher than ECU 12 000, without complying with the procurement procedure described in Article 45 of the abovementioned regulation. 
26. Almost 40 % of the commitments made under the 'Pilot Studies and Projects' budget line for the 1995 budget year (ECU 300 000) were made in the last two months of 1995. 
An amount of ECU 150 572 was committed to the budget line "Exchange of officials and experts" for the remuneration of an expert who commenced his work at the Cedefop on 1 February 1,996 and for another expert whose contract was on 22 February. It was signed in December 1995. 
These commitments have been overcrowded in order not to allow the appropriations to be forfeited. 
27. Rent for the temporary premises of Cedefop for January. 1996 (ECU 22 750) has already been included in the 1995 budget accounts. 
Since those expenditure relates to the 1996 financial year, they should also have been recorded at the expense of 1996. and 1994. 
The Court urges the Centre to draw up an up-to-date inventory as soon as possible, as required by Article 52 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993. 
29. The balance sheet shows, among the outstanding claims from the previous financial year, an outstanding amount of ECU 3 134 for an invoice issued in 1991. 
The Court's comment made last year (5) was not taken into account, although the Centre had given a corresponding assurance in its reply. 
The Court recommends that the Centre write off this amount as long as there is no reason to believe that this amount will be recovered. 
30. At the end of the year, the Centre had remaining treasury amounts of ECU 5.9 million. 
The Centre therefore bears responsibility for managing large amounts of cash, although it has little expertise in this area. 
The Court reiterated last year's remark (6) that this situation should be avoided by making the Commission's quarterly call-off of funds more appropriate to its actual cash needs. - At the same time, the Commission should ensure that it receives a realistic liqui-dity forecast from the Centre before making its payments. 
Transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki General remarks ^B 31. At the European Council of 29 October 1993 it was decided to relocate the headquarters of the Cedefop from Berlin to Thessaloniki in Greece (7). 
32. The actual transfer to Thessaloniki took place in August 1995, and in September 1995 the Centre started operations in Greece. 
According to the Court's calculations, the 1995 budget accounts include some ECU 3 300 000 for expenses related to the move. 
33. Since 1 September 1995, the centre has been housed in a building of the Institute of Agriculture and Industry of Thessaloniki. 
No later than 1 September 1999, the Greek State will provide the Centre with a permanent accommodation building. 
The Centre has signed four agreements (i) of the Court's annual report on the 1994 financial year. 
(6) The Court's annual report on the 1994 financial year. 
(7) Council Decision 93/C 323/01 of 29 October 1993, OJ C 323, 30. 11. 1993, p. 1. net relating to the rent for temporary premises and the construction of the building for permanent accommodation. 
The basic agreement between Cedefop and the Greek State was signed in Thessaloniki on 22 June 1995. 
The three other agreements, including an agreement between the Greek State and the organisation responsible for the entire construction, are part of this basic association. 
Temporary accommodation 34. The provisional building of the Centre shall be subject to an annual rent of ECU 273 000, payable directly to the owner. 
35. Pursuant to Article 1 of the Agreement between the Greek State and the Centre, the Greek State shall make available to Cedefop the building with the temporary premises, including all related installations, from 1 September 1995. 
The Greek authorities are responsible for electrical and electronic cable connections and telephone connections. 
36. When the building was handed over, the Centre did not raise any written objections. 
However, during the first four months in Thessaloniki (September to December 1995), the Centre had to invest ECU 120 000 to make the building with temporary premises functional. 
Among other things, electronic and electrical cable connections and telephone connections had to be installed. 
37. These investments were fully borne by the Centre and the corresponding costs were included in the 1995 budget accounts. 
The agreements do not give a clear indication of who is to take over these investments. 
Final accommodation 38. The Greek State is obliged to provide the Centre with a building for final accommodation by 1 September 1999 at the latest. 
For the construction of the building, Cedefop will pay the Greek State a total amount of ECU 6 879 750, which will be transferred in four equal instalments of ECU 1 719 937 each. 
For the first three tranches, 1 September 1995, 1 September 1996 and 1 September 1997 were set as payment dates. 
The last instalment will be paid at the final handover of the building. 
39. The Centre has not ensured that these payments are linked to the actual progress of the works. 
The Centre will have already paid an amount of ECU 5 159 811 more than two years before the transfer of the building. 
40. The Court recommends that the Centre ensure that interest is used for the first tranche in favour of the V. 
No C 81/6 | EN | Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 41. The Centre should make sure that the Employee Accommodation Organisation (O.E.K.), which is responsible for the overall performance of the work, is perceived by Cedefop. 
Staff: General remarks 42. The establishment plan for 1995 provides for 79 posts, of which 24Ŕ,11LA,15B,26Cund3D.At the time of the audit (May 1996), 37 people actually worked for the Cedefop (14 A, 7 B, 14 C and 2 D), 11 persons had been taken over by other EU institutions, 14 had left the centre before moving to Thessaloniki and 17 persons had been locked to stay in Berlin. 
In 1995 and 1996 many new employees had to be recruited and this development will continue in 1996. 
43. The 17 persons remaining in Berlin are free to work for public and private institutions or other EU institutions, while continuing to receive their salary for a maximum period of 18 months, depending on their seniority at Cedefop (each year of service corresponds to a monthly salary, the minimum period of service must be 6 months). 
At the end of this period, the persons concerned can either move to Thessaloniki or seek another solution. 
This situation leads, inter alia, to the fact that Cedefop cannot fill these 17 posts (May 1996), since they are blocked in the budget and cannot be filled, as the persons concerned may decide at a later time to move to Thessaloniki. 
44. It is unclear what should happen to those from this group of 17 people who do not want to move to Thessaloniki after the fixed duration of their stay in Berlin. 
Article 20 of the Staff Regulations provides as follows: 'The official shall, at the place of his employment or at such distance from that place, take the place that he is not hindered in the performance of his duties'. 
Regardless, three cases of staff who were not willing to move to Thessaloniki have already been brought to the EU Court of Justice. 
45. This situation, in which 17 important items foreseen in the budget plan are blocked by staff who do not currently work for Cedefop, had a significant impact on the Centre's work already in 1995 and will continue to have this in 1996 and 1997. 
Staff: Change of status 46. Article 13 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 of 10 February 1975, as amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995, provides: 'The Centre's staff shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities. 
The Centre shall exercise the powers conferred on the appointing authority vis-ŕ-vis its staff. 
The Management Board of the Centre shall, after consultation with the Commission, adopt the corresponding implementing rules." 
Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 repeals Council Regulation (ECSC, EEC, Euratom) No 1859/76 of 29 June 1976 laying down the employment conditions for staff of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training. 
The amendment was necessary "to make the management of the staff of the single decentralised institutions coherent at Community level" (8). 
However, while the staff of the Centre have been appointed officials, the staff of the other decentralised institutions consist of temporary staff. 
47. The Court examined the changes to employment conditions and other agreements between the Management Board and the staff, and identified a number of irregularities. The most serious irregularities from the Court's point of view are described in paragraphs 49-66. 
48. The Management Board has not submitted these arrangements to the Financial Controller for the purpose of issuing its endorsement. 
Nevertheless, all the financial commitments resulting from these agreements were settled through the Paying Agency procedure and subsequently received the financial controller's endorsement. 
Appointment of staff to officials 49. In connection with the move to Thessalo-niki, the Centre has taken the following measures to adapt the situation of its staff: As a first step, all staff members were appointed as temporary staff on 1 March 1995 (Article 2(b) of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the European Communities) in the same grade and step as staff in the contractual relationship. - A second step, these staff were recruited as EU officials from 1 April 1995, following an internal competition which had been 'arranged' exclusively on the basis of qualifications. 
Infringement of the Staff Regulations relating to the classification in step of the appointment of the former contract staff of Cedefop at the time of the appointment of the former contract staff of Cedefop at the time. When Cedefop's contract staff were initially appointed as temporary agents on 1 March 1995, none of the staff members could have been classified at a higher step than level 3 (or step 4 at grades A 1 (8) Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 amending Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 on the maintenance of Cedefop, fourth recital. 
13. 3. 97 | EN~1 Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/7 to A 4, LA 3 and LA 4) (see Article 32 of the Staff Regulations applicable to temporary staff pursuant to Article 15 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants). 
51. Nevertheless, 33 of the 59 CEDEFOPs appointed as temporary staff were classified at a higher level than level 3. 
In the conduct of the internal competition procedure for the appointment of former contract staff of Cedefop as officials 52. On 1 March 1995, the Centre published 15 interlinked vacancy notices and announcements of internal competitions. 
Following these competitions, all former Cedefop employees were appointed officials. ^w' 53. According to the Staff Regulations, the purpose of a selection procedure is to organise a competition between several candidates in order to fill the vacant position with the most qualified candidate (Article 27(1) of the Staff Regulations). 
A selection process is therefore by definition associated with a competitive situation and the risk of non-existence (10). 
This means that appointments must be regarded as unlawful following a selection procedure in which there is a misuse of powers (n). 
56. The Legal Service of the Commission came to the same conclusion as confirmed by its note of 4 January 1995 (c) (12). 
57. Since the selection procedures in question pursued an objective other than that laid down in the Staff Regulations, it must be held that the selection procedures conducted by Cedefop had misuse of powers, which is why they must be regarded as unlawful. 
Breach of the Staff Regulations in relation to the classification in grade in the appointment of Cedefop's former contract staff as officials 58. In accordance with Article 31 of the Staff Regulations, Cedefop's staff members should have been appointed officials from 1 April 1995 as follows: - Officials of category A or Special Career Language Service (LA): in the initial grade of their category or special career (i.e. A 7 or LA 7) (Article 31(1)); - Officials of other categories: in the incoming remuneration corresponding to the post for which they have been recruited (i.e. ? 1, ? 3 or ? 5; C 1, C 3 or C 5, D 1, D 3 or D 4) (Article 31(2)); - in the case of up to half of the appointments, exceptionally staff members may be appointed in the next higher group; this applies to six posts to be filled within each grade (Article 31, paragraph 2 b). 
59. Contrary to the Staff Regulations, 32 out of 43 staff were named in a higher grade than the initial grade in their category (13). 
(10) Judgment of 29.9.1976, Case 105/75 GI UFFRI DA v RAT, Collection p. 1395. (N) Judgment in GI UFFRI DA, see above. 
(12)A selection procedure by definition entails the risk of non-existence and there are obvious legal reasons why this risk margin should remain. 
(13) Of 17 staff appointed in category A, 13 were appointed at a higher grade than A 7 (the Staff Regulations foresees a limitation to six appointments); all five LA staff were appointed in a higher category than the LA 7 category (the Staff Regulations do not provide for such a possibility); out of 18 members of staff in category C, 12 were appointed at a higher grade than the initial group of staff in their category (the Staff Regulations foresees six appointments); two out of three staff in category D were appointed in a higher grade than in the initial grade of their category (the Staff Regulations do not provide for such a possibility). ^ ^ 54. On the other hand, the 15 selection procedures carried out by Cedefop pursued a completely different purpose, since the aim was to regulate the situation of staff after the move to Thessaloniki. 
No C 81/8 DE Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Non-compliance with obligations relating to the probationary period 60. Before a member of staff can be appointed as an official for a lifetime, he must successfully take a probationary period (Article 34 of the Staff Regulations). Therefore, following the probationary period, an objective ex-post assessment of the official must be carried out on a probationary basis. 
61. Contrary to the Staff Regulations, probation officials were informed beforehand that their final appointment would take place. The probationary period was clearly described in advance as a necessary 'legal formality', which was not really to be regarded as a probation test (paragraph 4.1 of the 'Framework Association'; Letter of 7 February 1995 to probation officials, second subparagraph and paragraph 1(f) of the Annex: The probationary period is a legal formality to be carried out as such by any probationary official). Illegitimate secondment of officials during the probationary period 62. Under Article 38 of the Staff Regulations, only lifetime officials may be seconded to other institutions, i.e. officials who have already successfully completed the probationary period. 
65. This means that a system has been set up in which up to 50 % of the remuneration of staff members is transferred in a currency to which a higher correction coefficient applies (namely the correction coefficient of 111.4 % applicable to Germany than to Thessaloniki (for Greece a correction coefficient of 80.2 %). 
Unequal treatment vis-ŕ-vis other civil servants through the introduction of special rules of action 66. The Commission has committed to the Centre to introduce specific V rules on mobility. 
Those provisions are contrary to the principle of equal treatment of all officials. 
Article 13 of Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 clearly provides that the Staff Regulations and the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants are applicable to the staff of the Centre. 
This means that all the provisions contained therein shall apply to staff of the Centre, including Article 29(1)(c), which concerns the takeover of officials by other institutions. 
Thus, there is no justification for special treatment with regard to mobility. Summary | 67. The Court's audit showed that the Centre's work programme was not carried out as planned due to significant staff shortages. 
This led to large transfers and cancellations. 
The audit has also shown that no functioning management and accounting procedures have yet to be put in place. 
68. Two Deputy Directors received remuneration corresponding to the basic salary for four months. These payments and a payment of ECU 71 030 to one of the Deputy Directors were not in line with sound financial management and the interests of the Centre. 
69. At the time of the Court's audit, there were 79 authorised posts, but only 37 people actually worked at the Centre. 
17 staff had been appointed as EU officials, even though they did not want to move to Thessaloniki, nor had they been taken over by another Community institution. 
Conclusion 71. It is understandable that efforts have taken place in connection with the move to Thessaloniki to keep staff with the EU institutions and to reduce the complicated problems associated with the move. 
The problem, however, is that the regulatory framework within which the move had to be carried out was not compatible with adequate treatment of staff of seniority even after the changes to the employment conditions and did not allow for a smooth transfer of Cedefop without under-calculation of his activities. 
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 21 November 1996.

The Management Board will follow the structure of the Court's observations and conclusions. 
3. The Board of Directors has a legitimate expectation that all institutions and decentralised entities will be treated in a similar way and on the basis of the same technical standards and practices that ensure equal treatment. 
4. The Management Board considers that the uniform presentation of the problems fails to mention essential facts which could be summarised as follows: - The decision of the European Council of 29 October 1993 was taken without prior assessment of the impact of such a transfer. 
At his first meeting with the staff, he expressed his firm determination to carry out the move on 1 September 1995, a timetable which CEDEFOP maintained despite the problems caused by the relocation of the Centre. - The Chairman of the Management Board sent a letter to the Commissioners responsible, Mr van Miert and Mr Ruberti. 
On 18 November 1994, the Chairman and Vice-Chairs of the Management Board of CEDEFOP were welcomed by the members of the Commission. 
The Chair addressed the urgent appeal to the Commission to develop social accompanying measures, in particular for those staff who were unable to leave Berlin. 
In the light of the regulations in force, the Commissioners stated that they were willing to examine the specific problems of some staff in a positive and pragmatic spirit. 
They also expected this from the other institutions of the Community (European Parliament, Council, etc.) - The Administrative Council was at its meeting on 8/9. In December 1994 it was not possible to decide on the date of the transfer, since it seemed unacceptable to simply dismiss staff who could not move to Thessaloniki without a modern social plan. 
At the same meeting, the Management Board instructed the Director to prepare a Management Council Decision (to be taken at an extraordinary meeting on 27 January 1995) which provided for a socially acceptable transfer of the Centre on 1 September. In the second half of December 1994, the Council began to examine the Commission's proposal to amend Article 13 of the Regulation applicable to CEDEFOP, which provided that the staff of the Centre should be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities. 
The Director adopted this amendment as a basis for the formulation of the Framework Agreement on Social Accompanying Measures in connection with the transfer of CEDEFOP to Thessaloniki. 
On 23 January 1995, the framework agreement was signed with the staff. 
The preparations were carried out in close cooperation with the European Commission, which proved to be very helpful throughout the transition period (1994-1996). - The Board of Directors decided to accept the Framework Agreement and to relocate the Centre to Thessaloniki on 1 September 1995. 
13. 3. The Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/13 was able to move to Thessaloniki. 
According to the Framework Agreement, staff members who were unable to leave Berlin decided to make themselves available to other EU institutions or public/private organisations and to receive a salary from the Centre for at least six months, with a monthly salary paid for each starting year of service. 
The principle of paying a monthly salary for each year of service is largely in line with the social plans and usual practices in Germany and neighbouring countries. - Early retirement was taken into account in 1995 for 17 staff members (aged over 55 with 10 years of service and over 50 years old with 15 years of service). 
These measures did not form part of the Framework Agreement and were finally not proposed by the Commission following the decisions of the Council of Ministers of 17 November 1995 to accept the "release" of officials in connection with the accession of new Member States only for officials of the European Parliament. 
The Management Board will reply in more detail in its opinions on paragraphs 46-66. 
In general, it should be stressed that the political aspects must be taken seriously and that subsequent criticism should be avoided. 
The relocation of a complete Community body within the restrictive framework of a large number of different regulations and in view of a considerable number of social and individual problems is indeed unique in the history of the Community. 
5. The Board of Directors will return below in this reply to the exception mentioned in the last sentence. 
8. The costs of the meetings of the Management Board in 1995 are due to the fact that two additional meetings (in January and June) had to be held in connection with the transfer. 
Moreover, the December 1995 meeting caused higher costs due to the official start of activity in Greece. 
Only two meetings are planned for 1996. 
13. The Management Board regrets that the Court has not responded to the European Parliament's decision to postpone the discharge for the 1994 budget. 
This raises serious questions, since - the 1994 discharge should be seen in the context of the Court's 1994 report and the Council's recommendation on granting discharge and should comply with the usual rules and procedures; - The European Parliament's assessment of the financial year 1995 without the existence of a report from the Court of Auditors for 1995 on which the Management Board could have given its opinion leads to the mixing of very different situations; the centre was moved to Greece in 1995. 
The installation was carried out smoothly and under acceptable conditions. 
This transfer requires a transitional period, due to the disruptions to which the staff were exposed, which can only be completed in 1997. 
15. There is a noticeable improvement in this respect. 
In the initial phase in Thessaloniki, the staff helped each other to carry out their work. 
16. As was pointed out last year, the increased use of the Paying Agency procedure took place at the request of the financial controller, who justified this on the basis of the cost-benefit ratio. The previous system caused high express delivery codes and led to delays. 
It also meant that the financial controller had to act more frequently. 
The use of the Paying Agency procedure for all expenditure that could require provisional commitments limited administrative costs and avoided delays. 
The situation is even more difficult due to the payment modalities in Greece (most payments are made in cash or by cheque). 
Invoices indicating bank details are rare; contractors shall collect their own claims. 
The geographical distance from the financial controller and the lack of reliability of postal delivery should also be taken into account. 
In addition, DHL express deliveries may only be made once a week for cost reasons (3 000 Bfrs per shipment). 
An amendment to the decision to set up the paying agency procedure will be submitted to the Management Board shortly in order to better take into account the wishes of the Court of Auditors. 
17. The transfer of appropriations in the last two months is explained by the need for optimal use of the budget (of which ECU 2 000 000 had been deferred and only shortly before the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki) and by the decision of the Management Board (7/8). 12. 1995), to recruit national experts seconded in accordance with the requirements of the Commission (also to promote the work of the Centre). 
19. The Board of Directors was aware that 1995 and 1996 would be years of transition and renewal. 
A certain decline in productivity is inevitable in this international relocation, which, in the opinion of the Board of Directors, has been carried out in an acceptable and smooth manner. 
The centre is still facing problems caused by the transition phase. 
20. With the relocation of the centre with a greatly reduced number of employees, the work of the administration and all other services slowed down. 
For this reason, a non-automatic transfer was requested and approved. 
No C 81/14 | D Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 22. The Management Board notes that the Commission shall make every effort to comply with the rules laid down in Article 26 of the Financial Regulations applicable to the Centre and to disburse the grant in accordance with actual needs during the first two weeks of the quarter. 
There was an improvement in 1995 compared to 1994. 
However, due to the length of internal procedures (in which the authorising authority, the financial controller and the accounting officer are involved) and the length of the transfer procedure by the bank, an overall delay in the processing period (on average 12 days in 1995) cannot be completely avoided. 
Nevertheless, three payments would have been made in 1995 almost in accordance with the rules laid down in Article 26, as they arrived at the centre less than four days after the end of the first two weeks of the quarter. 
If the processing period for all payments (which was between 9 and 22 days) had corresponded to the average period of 12 days, then all payments would have been made in accordance with Article 26 of the Financial Rules. 
The first payment did not comply with the rules, but that payment must be preceded by the commitment which requires a certain period of time. 
23. The deputy director moved from Thessaloniki to Berlin because there was uncertainty about the actual date of the transfer of the center. 
At the time of appointment (1 October 1994), no decision had yet been taken beyond the date of the removal (which could have been postponed further). 
It was to be hoped that his stay would be short, but his final duration was still unknown at the time. 
For the usual family reasons, he moved to Berlin under the conditions of status. 
The subsistence allowances for missions were granted in accordance with the same procedure as for other staff. 
As regards the second installation aid, the Deputy Director repaid that sum to the Centre after the audit, even though he would have been fully entitled. 
24. At its meeting in June 1995, the Management Board terminated its contract on 31 December 1995. In December 1995, the Director instructed the Director to implement this Decision and to arrange for payments in accordance with the Staff Regulations. 
The Management Board was pleased that the Deputy Director was ready to participate in the implementation of the 1995 Work Programme and to assist the Centre in its new start in Thessaloniki. 
The compensation (the payment of one third of the basic salary from the date on which his duties ceased until the expiry of his contract) corresponded to his contract and Article 47 of the CEOS. 
25. Given the difficulties of the initial phase and the large number of new contracts, the Centre was not able to carry out the usual tender procedures in each case. 
In the case of longer-term contracts, tender procedures are currently being carried out or are planned for 1996. 
In addition, in order to ensure balanced budgetary management throughout the year, the Management Board will prefer the adoption of the work programme in order to allow the services to have the necessary time for tenders and to make commitments and to conclude the corresponding contracts in the first months of the financial year. 
26. The 40 % of commitments for the budget line "Pilot Studies and Projects" (ECU 300 000) were made in the last months of the year, due to the late release of the deferred appropriations in the 1995 budget by the budgetary authority and the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki. 
The Centre had to act logically and consistently, leaving no other choice since it had first to fulfil its financial obligations under Titles I and II and could only make further commitments under Title III after the deferred appropriations had been released. 
The possibility of secondment of national experts was granted by the Management Board at its meeting in December 1995 and could only be financed by the deferred appropriations. 
The Director had to act swiftly and within a short period of time to prevent funds (which became available very late) from falling. 
The application of the (Austrian) expert (officially endorsed by the government) was already available at the beginning of 1995. 
27. The reason for recording the rent for January 1996 in the financial statements for 1995 was purely practical in nature. 
According to the contract, the rent must be paid in advance in two instalments on 1 January and 1 July. 
Since the first payment was made only in October 1995 and it would have been difficult to pay immediately on 1 January 1996, the first payment was made for a period of five months, which included January 1996.
