29. This will be matched. 
30. The Centre shall ensure that it submits to the Commission a realistic statement on the cash flow. 
The last payment in the year should be the largest, as it must also be used to cover the first months of the following year, where normally larger payments are to be made. 
31. See the comments on point 4. 32. The management of the Centre shall carry out an assessment of the costs of the transfer and an assessment of developments in order to obtain a comprehensive picture of the costs and benefits of the transfer to Greece. 
13. 3. 97 I DE 1 ^ Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/15 36.-37. 
As the center was expected to resume its work immediately after the move, some additional investments and changes were required. 
As it was noted, the agreements do not contain a clear statement about this because the center needed more power connections and stronger computer cables than the existing ones. 
Other investments concerned additional security requirements and communication facilities, such as "Europe by Satellite", in order to be able to receive broadcasts directly through the institutions. 
The Centre has nevertheless placed questions on the provisional building on the agenda of the Steering Committee, which deals with the new building and, if necessary, the provisional building. 
The Board of Directors is aware that the content of the agreement on the new building confers a great responsibility on the Greek Government, which currently fulfils the agreement. 
Two points of particular concern are: - securing the provision of a high quality building at a reasonable price; - securing the timely completion of the building (if possible before 1 September 1998). 
The fact that large payments were made in advance (half of the building has already been paid even though the construction work has not yet started) can also have a positive impact, as the actual works (after the selection of the construction plan and the construction company in October/November 1996) could progress rapidly due to the immediate availability of the necessary financial resources. 
In general, the Management Board has full understanding of the Court's concerns, also shared by Members of the European Parliament, Mr Kellet-Bowmann and Mr Tappin, who visited the Centre on 1/2 and 14-15 May respectively. 
The Management Board is ready to address this issue in line with the Commission's recommendations. 
42. Due to the various accompanying social measures, the staff situation was very complicated, but all persons on the CEDEFOP salary list who were not made available to other organisations or seconded in Berlin were working for CEDEFOP and its work programme. 
43. The Management Board has taken the decision on the social accompanying measures related to the transfer (framework agreement) in order to take "appropriate measures as soon as possible" (see the statements contained in the minutes of the Council). 
The evaluation of the measures must therefore take into account their political background. 
The Centre is located in Thessaloniki, and the Board of Directors and the Director decide on the organisation of the work. 
Some items are certainly blocked as long as the social accompanying measures are effective. 
However, at the end of 1996 almost all measures will expire and then the CEDEFOP will be able to operate with full capacity on the basis of the medium-term priorities (to be decided by the Administrative Statute in November 1996) and the 1997 work programme, which is also based on these priorities. 
CEDEFOP will therefore move into the future with a revitalised and new approach from 1997 onwards. 
44. The persons who cannot leave Berlin for social or personal reasons, when the specified duration of their stay in Berlin ends, have three alternatives. 
In this respect, the V-resident of the court of first instance issued three orders rejecting the requests for transitional proceedings. 
These persons must move, leave the service of the Centre or find solutions to the Staff Regulations. 
45. The impact in 1996 is of course serious, but will only be minimal after the first months of 1997. 
The transfer had its consequences and costs. 
However, when compared to a similar transfer at national level, such as that of the CEREQ (Centre d'Etudes et de Recherches sur les Qualifications) from Paris to Marseille (where only 21 of the 120 employees moved with the Centre), the CEDEFOP did not have an excessively negative impact in view of an international transfer of almost 2 000 km. 
Cautious cost estimates indicate that cost neutrality will be achieved in 2000 and that work will be even more cost-effective after that (mainly due to the lower labour costs in Greece). 46.-66. 
The points raised need some general comments in advance: a) As the Court states in its conclusion (71) it is understandable that efforts have been made to assist staff in order to encourage them to continue their work for the EU institutions and to alleviate the difficult problems of relocation. (b) However, it is not the failure of the Management Board to "that the regulatory framework within which the relocation took place was incompatible with the proper treatment of high-age staff and did not allow the smooth relocation of CEDEFOP". (c) following the decision of the Management Board of 27 January 1995, on 6 February 1995 (Regulation (EC) No 251/95), the Council amended Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 to the effect that 'the staff of the Centre shall be subject to the rules and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities'. 
Despite the lack of transitional provisions, such as when Regulation (EEC, Eura: Torn, ECSC) No 269/68 of the Council (see Article 102 of the Status of Officials of the European Community 
No C 81/16 | D | Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 and Article 99 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the European Communities) should have been taken into account that CEDEFOP staff could well be regarded as 'staff of the European Communities', even though they were subject to an ad hoc Council Regulation. (d) Since Community legislation did not provide for transitional measures, the Management Board had no choice but to act on its own responsibility; in order to safeguard the rights and interests of CEDE FOP staff. e) It should not be forgotten that Regulation (EC) No 251/95, which moved the seat of CEDEFOP from Berlin to Thessaloniki, meant a sudden change in the place of employment listed in the employment contracts: Berlin was the only seat of CEDEFOP for 20 years, and at no time since 10 February 1975 there was the slightest indication that this seat could be moved, let alone to another, far away Member State. 
The CEDEFOP staff have entered into an employment relationship on this basis and have directed their private decisions (place of employment of spouses, education of children) accordingly. f) In view of these circumstances, the Management Board had the duty to: - to provide staff with a high level of security with regard to their job (appointment as lifetime civil servants), - to ensure the maintenance of their category, grade and step, and - to help staff wishing to find another job. g) The Management Board would also like to point out that the posts authorised by the budgetary authority to CEDEFOP were permanent posts. 
According to Articles 2 and 8 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the EC, these posts may be filled only by officials or temporary staff. (h) The wording of Regulation (EC) No 251/95 (the Centre's staff is subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities) clearly provides for the employment of officials. 
Since the posts filled by staff are permanent, the decision on civil servant status was appropriate and justified instead of temporary contracts. 
The Management Board would also like to comment on the points raised by the Court: 46. (last sentence) The Management Board had the choice to either appoint staff as lifelong civil servants or offer them two-year contracts (see opinion under point (g) above). 
It was considered unacceptable to require staff to move from Berlin to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract. 
48. Although it is true that the Board of Directors did not formally submit the agreements to the Financial Controller for the purpose of issuing a endorsement, the latter was informed of the decisions taken. 
At the time of signature of the agreement, it was not yet clear, on the basis of the outstanding individual decisions of the staff, the precise financial implications of the agreement. 
It provided a framework that provided the basis for individual decisions and received the full approval of the financial controller during his visit to Berlin. 
50-51. 
In view of the arguments set out in (e) above, the decision taken (see remark, second indent) was the only possible one. 
It was also in line with the Commission's unambiguous statement (see the last sentence of the statement for the Council minutes annexed) "that there must be no deterioration in the conditions of employment for CEDEFOP staff". 
The considerations of the Commission Legal Service, which are only partially cited in paragraph 56, leave sufficient room for such a decision. 
The Management Board reiterates that Article 29 of the Staff Regulations provides that the appointing authority is entitled to conduct internal competitions for the purpose of filling vacant posts in an institution (point lb). 
The competitions were conducted in full compliance with Annex III to the Staff Regulations. 
55. The aim and obligation of the Management Board was to ensure that the largest possible number of CEDEFOP staff members agreed to move to Thessaloniki. 
It must not be overlooked that Regulation (EC) No 251/95 amended the rules applicable to staff with effect from 1 March 1995 and that the move to Thessaloniki took place in August of the same year. 
The Board's approach was based on the following considerations: - it was unthinkable to require staff to move to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract (remark under (g) and point 46 above); - there was not enough time to organise an open competition before moving to Thessaloniki, and again it would not have been realistic to expect staff to move around without a secure employment commitment. 
13. 3. 97 I DE | Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/17 56.-59./The Management Board has already explained (see above, remark under (e)) that the move to Thessaloniki meant a sudden change in the place of employment that inevitably caused social problems and impaired productivity for a certain period of time. 
To require staff to relocate after allocation of a low grade or step would have worsened their situation. 
The note from the Legal Service of the Commission, referred to in paragraph 56 above, provides sufficient arguments to justify the position taken by the Centre under point (d). 60.-61. 
All staff applying for an appointment as officials for a lifetime were granted the probationary period laid down in Article 34 of the status. 
62. According to remark (f), 3. Indent, above, the Management Board considered it its duty to assist staff in an acceptable manner. 
This view was also expressed by the Commission's Legal Service. 
65. The rules governing the remittance modality of part of the remuneration allow this percentage to be increased from 35 % to 50 % in individual cases where there are justified reasons in accordance with Article 4 of the Regulation. 
The Framework Agreement allowed the transfer of a higher percentage (> 35 % in accordance with the Staff Regulations, but 50 % under the Staff Regulations) in individual cases and certain obligations under the Staff Regulations received before 29 October 1993 (the date on which the European Council decided to relocate the Centre). 
The application of these rules is completely different in the case of CEDEFOP and concerns only a limited number of persons with high liabilities in Berlin. 
66. The Management Board would like to thank the Commission for the assistance it has provided in a number of cases in finding alternative employment opportunities for staff unable to move to Thessaloniki, as well as for any other assistance it sent to the Centre almost daily during the relocation. 
68. See comments of the Management Board on paragraphs 23 and 24. 69.-70. 
See in particular the general comments under paragraphs 46-66. 
71. The Board of Directors regrets that the legislator did not include transitional legislation in Regulation (EC) No 251/95 in order to solve the difficult personnel problems caused by the move to Thessaloniki. 
Given the lack of appropriate tools, the Management Board was all the more obliged to provide the best possible support to CEDEFOP staff. 
The Board of Directors believes that it has acted in the only acceptable manner in the given and truly unprecedented circumstances. 
In the end, it was obvious that he had to make such efforts (as the Court recognises), since it is his duty as an employer to carry out the international representation of a complete institution in a socially acceptable manner. 
The Board of Directors, the Director and the staff acted in this positive spirit, possibly taking some risks but did not engage in abuse of power or acted unlawfully.

13. 3. 97 I DE | Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/25 ANTWORT 8. The Foundation has put in place a number of measures to separate the duties of the authorising officer and the accounting officer. 
The Court of Auditors took note of these initiatives in previous reports. 
The only problem that persists in practice is the procedure whereby the authorising officer records expenditure in the existing integrated accounting system. 
This problem will be solved once the foundation has acquired a new accounting system. 
Following the consultations of 1995, the Foundation, together with other EU agencies, participated in a joint tender procedure for the acquisition of an appropriate accounting system in 1996. 
The result, however, was that none of the candidates met the requirements of the institutions one hundred percent. 
Following in-depth contacts with the Commission services, the Foundation is expected to acquire an appropriate accounting system from the Commission in the course of 1997, following the recent completion of the work on a corresponding system that meets the technical and legal requirements of the agencies. 
9. The Foundation has contacted the Commission services with regard to solutions to the identified problem. 
The Foundation has now been informed that this issue is being discussed between the Commission and the European Parliament in the context of the ongoing dialogue on the agencies' Financial Regulation. 
10. Following the last report of the Court of Auditors, the Foundation asked the Commission services to clarify the Foundation's Financial Regulation with regard to the transfers in question. 
The Foundation is now informed by the Director-General of DG XIX that the transfers have been carried out in accordance with the Foundation's Financial Regulation (see also paragraph 16). 
11. All missions within the Foundation were documented and approved by the Authorising Officer after they had verified that they were in line with the Foundation's work programme or administrative requirements. 
The Foundation will review its procedures to record and find the necessary documentation relating to missions. 
The Regulation establishing the Foundation requires that the European institutions be consulted and the social partners involved in their work. 
Although there has been a deepening of exchanges with the relevant EU bodies in Brussels in recent years, the number of missions to Brussels has not increased. 
No missions are made if other means of communication can be used. 
As far as possible, telephone, Internet, e-mail and other electronic tools are used. A videoconferencing pilot project was also launched in November 1995. 
Similarly, experiments with co-puter conferences have also been carried out. 
14. On the basis of a proposal submitted by the Irish authorities, the lawyers are currently preparing a revised lease agreement. 
16. As mentioned in paragraph 10 above, the Foundation has been informed by the Commission that the transfers concerned are fully in line with the Financial Regulation. With its help, the Foundation was able to use the funds made available to it through the decisions of the budgetary authorities in the most efficient way. 
However, the Foundation recognises the position of the Court of Auditors and Parliament and endeavours to carry out such transfers only in urgent cases. 
These contracts mainly concerned studies with a deadline of 12 months or more. 
18. The Foundation will remind the Commission services that the grant must be implemented by the 15th of each quarter. 
19. The contract for conducting a European investigation into working conditions shows that this contract had been concluded under the framework contract for the Eurobaromčtre-Stan-dard between the European Commission and INRA (Europe), drawn up on the basis of an open tendering procedure. 
The direct award of contracts was fully in line with the procedure laid down in Article 46 of the Financial Regulation of the Foundation and the criteria to be followed in this respect. These are followed. For the supply of computers, Article 46(d) was applied. 
Only one supplier had the required software as well as the special multi-spracbig tasta-tures and provided local support: The other two contracts relate to research proposals. 
At its meeting of 25 March 1994, the Board of Directors of the Foundation approved the introduction of new procedures, which were to be fully operational during 1995, for the award of contracts based on calls for expressions of interest published in the Official Journal, as well as calls for tenders. 
The two contracts were concluded during the transition period set by the Board of Directors. 
20. The Foundation operates a decentralised ordering system. 
The two invoices were part of a series of orders placed by an operational unit whose total orders exceeded the committed appropriations. 
Appropriate measures will be taken to prevent this from happening again. 
The provision of a new rectification system should ensure the automatic implementation of the necessary controls. 
21. The implementation of the study contracts is monitored on a monthly basis at the programme management department. 
22. The appointment was placed for the services concerned on 11 October 1994.

Commercial accounting systems available on the market do not take into account the specificities of Community financial rules. 
For this reason, the Agencies published a call for tenders in 1995 for a system that meets their needs. 
Until the introduction of the new system, the agency works with a spreadsheet system.

All budget operations are documented on the matter.

In accordance with Article 137 of Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94, the latter is also responsible for drawing up and submitting the invoice (3), while complying with the internal fiscal rules. In accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community, the Court of Auditors is required to audit such accounts. 
This is a report on the Office's first examination. 1.3. 
Main observations on the implementation of the budget of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market for the financial years 1994 and 1995 Commission grant 1.5.

(3) In accordance with the provisions of Article 137(1) of Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94, the accounts for all revenue and expenditure of the Office for the financial year 1995 were drawn up on 29 March 1996, signed by the President of the Office and transmitted to the Commission, the Committee on Budgets and the Court of Auditors.

In the Court's view, the Office should have issued a recovery order for the entire budget (10.1 million ECU) in order to be able to comply with the commitments carried over to 1996 (4.6 million ECU). 
During the 1995 financial year, the Office established an accounting system. 
This is contrary to the internal financial regulation (Articles 4(1) and 29(1)). 
Transfers and transfers 1.7. 
The appropriations carried over to 1996 represent 46 % of the budget and mainly relate to computerised material (Titles II and III of the budget). 
Moreover, the appropriations available were carried over from Title I (staff) to Title II (expenditure) for a total amount of ECU 2,529 million (25 % of the budget). Inventory 1.8. 
The inventory is kept only in terms of quantity, but not in value. 
It is therefore not possible to coordinate with the amounts shown in the Office's balance sheet. Separation of tasks 1.9. 
The administrative system set up by the Office does not guarantee adequate separation of tasks and proper implementation of the rules on revenue, commitments and payments (authorising officer, financial controller and accounting officer). Property, plant and equipment T.10. 
The office is currently housed in a building of the Spanish government. 
However, there is no contract for the use of this building. 
In view of the future provision of its final seat, the Office should clarify the need for accommodation of its services.

C 81/36 p 5 Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 ADDITIONS OF THE Commission's grant 1.5. 
Neither the Commission nor OHIM was aware of the need for a recovery order. 
OHIM took note of this observation by the Court of Auditors, prompting the issuing of a recovery order for the financial year 1996 for the entire grant minus the provisions. 
Accounting for budgetary transactions 1.6. It is true that the accounting system currently in use by OHIM allows subsequent changes to the accounts. 
For the period up to the introduction of the Sincom2 system developed by the Commission, OHIM has put in place organisational arrangements for additional security guarantees when using the current system. 
Until then, OHIM has no other option than waiting for the Commission's accounting system, which is likely to be available before the end of the year, since the development of such a system entails a large financial burden which an Office cannot bear on its own. 
In 1995, the Office's budget was adopted taking into account a provision of ECU 2 million required by Parliament for a general budget of 10.1 MECU. 
The provision was repealed in two stages: - ECU 1 million in October 1995, the balance in November 1995. 
The temporary blocking of funds, of course, has had an impact on their use, in particular the appropriations under Title I (staff), as there was uncertainty as to whether the provisions would be effectively lifted. 
Under no circumstances could OHIM be allowed to hire staff until payment of salaries was guaranteed by the end of the financial year. 
Following the release of the provisions, measures were taken to use the decommitted appropriations in the budget lines where it was still possible due to the deadlines for the budgetary commitment procedures and where there was a real need. 
For this reason, the Office has requested a transfer of appropriations from Title I to Title II in order to mainly create computerised material which was particularly urgently needed during the start-up phase of the Office. 
It must be recalled that OHIM started its activities on 1 April 1996 and that since then more than 30 000 trade mark applications have been received, whereas the workload for the whole financial year had been estimated at 15,000 applications. 
Inventory 1.8. At the time of the Court's audit, OHIM had just received from the Commission the software for the computerised management of the inventory; it was just installed at the time. 
Separation of tasks 1.9. 
A question from the Court of Auditors made it clear that this point concerns the order of signatures to be followed in the budgetary and payment procedures. 
It is therefore not a confusion with regard to the duties of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the financial controller. 
Rather, the remark concerned the fact that the transaction was first signed by the accounting officer and then by the authorising officer. · This approach had the advantage of ensuring that, in the start-up phase of the Office, when there was no manager of funds, it was ensured that the funds were available before a transaction was signed by the authorising officer. Once OHIM has a financial manager, the following order of signatures can be observed in the various budgetary documents: 1. Middle management, 2. Authorising officer, 3. Financial Controller, 4. Accounting officer. 
Property, plant and equipment 1.10. 
There is an agreement (see copy in annex) between the Minister of Industry of the Spanish Government 
13. 3. Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/37 and Commissioner Vanni d'Archirafi, responsible for the internal market at the time. On the basis of this Agreement, the Spanish authorities shall make a building (preliminary seat) available to the Office free of charge; this is the building in which the Office is currently housed. 
It is precisely this agreement that the Spanish Government will take measures to provide the Office with a definitive seat. 
The decision on the site and the specifications for the tendering of the building to be constructed was taken by the Spanish authorities on 3 July 1996. 
These specifications will be published on 30 July of this year in the Official Journal of the European Communities (S series - invitation to tender). 
Following these recent developments, the Office will take the necessary steps without delay.

1,6. It must be stressed that the advance payments were not used for all purchases of equipment or for the participation in real estate, which constituted a significant part of the budget. 
In addition, the use of general advances in accordance with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation has been reduced and all accounting documents of a given month shall be sent to the auditor in Brussels within the 10th and 20th of the following month respectively. 
On the one hand, the contracts under discussion, closely linked to the activities and projects forming part of the Foundation's work programme, constitute an extremely small part of the Foundation's activities, both in terms of number and budget.

This procedure had been chosen at the time mainly because of urgency. 
In addition, the contracts under discussion had the task of organising conferences and seminars in the name and on behalf of the Foundation and under its strict control. 
The corresponding budget was divided into two parts: the fixed part of the remuneration (below ECU 12 000) and the operational part determined in advance by the Foundation and repaid on the basis of the supporting documents. 
On the basis of these elements, the Foundation considered that the actual contract amount would not exceed ECU 12 000. 
When it became clear at the beginning of 1996 that the Court of Auditors did not share this view, this system was abandoned. 
The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.

The Court considers that during the financial year 1995 the Agency should have issued a recovery order for the outstanding balance (ECU 5.8 million) in order to meet the commitments carried over to the financial year 1996 (a total of ECU 7 million). Average overrun 1.6. 
In the context of Titles I (staff expenditure) and II (material expenditure) of the budget, several overruns totalling around ECU 0.4 million were recorded. 
This amount, which could not be entered at the expense of the 1995 budget, is entered in a custody account on the assets side of the balance sheet and must be entered at the expense of the budget for the financial year 1996 (infringement of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the Agency). 
Paying Agency 1.7. 
Almost all payments to be charged to Titles I and II of the budget were handled by a paying agency. 
The use of this imprest is not compatible with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation for the Agency, as the imprest administrator was both accounting officer and manager of some budget lines. 
Moreover, the deadlines for submitting the supporting documents have not been met and the availability of committed appropriations for payments has not been verified. 
This seems to be the main reason for the above-mentioned overruns. 
Transfers 1.8. 
As at the end of 1994, a very high proportion of the available appropriations was carried over at the end of 1995 (7 million ECU - 57.2 % of the total budget). 
Most of the transfers concerned Title III (operational expenditure) (6,4 million ECU - 90.3 % of the appropriations entered in this Title). 
A large part of the amount of ECU 8.5 million carried over from 1994 to 1995 had to be cancelled (21 % of the appropriations carried over).

Several applications for commitments amounting to ECU 0.5 million were submitted to the financial controller in retrospect. 
In these cases, the financial control-leur has denied its endorsement, which the Board of Directors has disregarded. 
The Court underlines the commitment to comply with the Financial Regulation that "for all measures that may result in expenditure being charged to the budget" (Article 27 of the Financial Regulation for the Agency), a request for commitment must be made in advance. Separation of tasks 1.10. 
The separation of tasks was not complied with in the Agency's administrative department. 
Due to the lack of accounting staff, the same person was simultaneously accounting officer, imprest administrator and manager of funds/authorising officer of some budget lines. 
Accounting systems 1.11. 
Two independent systems are used for the management of budget transactions and general accounts. 
Moreover, the accounting system does not provide for any margins for budgetary transactions if the available or committed appropriations are exceeded. 
Financial Controller 1.12.

• The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994. 
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was already adopted on 31 October 1994. 
Since the decision on the Agency's seat had been delayed, it was necessary to do particularly fast work at the beginning of the activities of the Environment Agency. 
Thanks to a large amount of work, projects could be identified and commitments made before the end of the year, but for obvious reasons, the implementation of the commitments could hardly begin before the end of 1994. 
In 1995, the Agency was faced with the difficult task of implementing not only the 1994 budget, but also a new budget of ECU 10.5 million for 1995, before the Agency's regular staff had entered into service. 
The Agency's vacancies were advertised in November 1994 and, following a lengthy selection process with more than 7 000 applications, the first selected candidates started their work in the summer of 1995. 
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work programme and practically two budgets, but had only a very limited number of staff for this task. 
Nevertheless, the work progressed and in 1995 significant projects such as the Dobris Situation Report and the revision of the 5. Environmental Action Plans, completed. 
Five European themed centres have been set up and EIONET has been set up. 
The Agency's regular staff increased from 1 person on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, such as national experts and auxiliary staff) and reached on 31 January 1995. In December 1995, 22 regular staff members continued to be assisted by 10 temporary agents. 
The Agency's administrative apparatus has been gradually expanded as the same open recruitment procedure has been applied. 
Nevertheless, in 1995 the Agency was clearly insufficient in terms of staff to cope with the procedural and financial aspects of the work. 
As regards the financial side, only one person was available in the first half of the year to deal with the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme. 
In June 1995, the head of the administrative department took up his duties, and it was not until the beginning of 1996 that the other financial and contract staff were added. 
Although the Agency fulfilled its mission, some errors have been made in the area of finance and budget with regard to the prescribed procedures. 
Overruns Some budget lines have been exaggerated. 
This was due, on the one hand, to the fact that the Agency's budgetary control system did not work to the satisfaction and, on the other hand, some payments made were not recorded as the Agency's financial department was clearly understaffed. 
Consequently, the clearance of accounts resulted in a discrepancy between the accounts and the actual payments, which appeared as an overdraft of certain budget lines. 
Since after 1 January no offsetting between different budget lines may take place, these amounts must be included in the accounts for 1996, i.e. financed from the 1996 budget. 
In 1996, the expenditure and the appropriations available under Titles I and II (i.e. the 1995 problem points) were carefully checked in order to avoid a surplus of expenditure. 
Non-compliance with procedures (subsequent referral to the financial controller) A work programme was drawn up during the establishment phase of the Agency and its implementation started before the administrative procedures were clearly defined and an appropriate administrative structure was available that could have monitored compliance with the procedures. 
In some cases, this led to the commissioning and execution of work, disregarding certain procedural rules. 
In particular, work was commissioned without the prior approval of the Financial Controller in Brussels, which is a precondition for this type of operational expenditure. 
The error was purely procedural and was justified by the fact that work had to be carried out, but that the necessary administrative structures to ensure compliance with the rules laid down by Brussels had not yet been established. 
A clear delegation of the authorising powers has been made and staff are informed of the procedural rules. 
As in all public institutions, certain functions of a financial nature should remain separate for the Environment Agency. 
One of the basic principles is that commitments and payment orders should not be made by the same person. 
However, during the period of establishment of the Agency in Copenhagen, the number of staff was so low that this principle could not be respected. 
This fact is rightly criticised by the Court of Auditors. 
In the case of the Environment Agency, the financial controller of the Agency and that of the Commission shall be the same person established in Brussels. 
This would significantly impede the Agency's work. 
The way out of this dilemma is to set up a paying agency. 
In principle, it works like a small cash reserve, although the amounts settled on it are quite significant. 
Instead of obtaining the prior recovery of financial control, the agent orders the disbursement and, once a month, sends the statement of the steps to be carried out by the paying agency for subsequent approval of the financial con-troll. 
On the one hand, this facilitates the work of the Paying Agency, but on the other hand it is also a double sword, since the internal control of the Agency and the Finance Department must be able to meet this additional responsibility. 
In this respect, the Court of Auditors' complaint is understandable, but as long as the financial controller is based in Brussels, the Agency does not see any alternative to an extensive use of the paying agency. · For this reason, the Agency has taken a great deal of attention to the Court's recommendation that the Commission would like to allocate a financial contribution to the Agency.Environmental Agency would welcome such a step. 
Computerised accounting system The Court of Auditors stressed the need for the Agency to introduce a modern accounting system that covers both general accounting and budgetary control. 
For the EU's complimented financial system, such a computer-based system is essential if one wants to avoid large amounts of money being tied through financial and budgetary work. 
The Environment Agency fully supports the conclusions of the Court of Auditors. 
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has repeatedly tried to find a solution to this problem. 
By the way, it is in the same form for the other EU agencies. 
In 1996, the Agencies issued a joint call for tenders, which remained unsuccessful, i.e. no satisfactory system was found. 
At the moment, the Agency is considering the possibility of using the new Sincom 2 budgetary control system. 
The planning foresees that it should be installed in time and ready for operation in order to implement the 1997 budget. 
However, there will continue to be a software for budgetary control and another for general accounting. 
Also, the pay-three will not be integrated into the software. The Agency will continue to look for an appropriate solution to these problems and will endeavour to coordinate this work with the other agencies.

13. 3. 97 | Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/53 The following notes concern the most important observations of the Court of Auditors concerning the implementation of the EMCDDA budget for the 1994 and 1995 budget (points 1.5 to 1.11 of the Court of Auditors' budget). 
The EMCDDA agrees with the Court of Auditors' view that it would have been more appropriate to issue a recovery order for all the appropriations entered in the balance sheet as a grant to the Commission, and for the 1996 budget year, the EMCDDA has acted in accordance with the provisions of the Commission's financial commitment (which is also financial controller of the EMCDDA) within the meaning of Article 54 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities and Article 82 of the Implementing Rules for the same (in accordance with the spirit of Article 142 of the Financial Regulation for the general budget of the European Communities). 
However, the EMCDDA is aware that this can only be a provisional system (based on Excel files) and that it needs a more efficient accounting system. 
In this context, the decentralised agencies (including the EMCDDA) launched a call for tenders under the coordination of the European Training Foundation in Turin at the end of December 1995 with the aim of equipping themselves with an integrated compu-ter-based system for general accounting and budget accounting. 
No C 81/54 | EN | Official Journal of the Communities 13. 3. 97 For the following financial years, the EMCDDA is implementing a plan for the programming and control of the implementation of the budget and its work programme, aimed at improving the use of the allocated appropriations and, in particular, limited transfers only to exceptional cases. f) separation of tasks (point 1.10 of the Court's observations) C Due to its very limited staffing in 1994 and 1995, the EMCDDA could not fully ensure compliance with the principle of separation of tasks, as pointed out by the Court of Auditors. 
The separation of the duties of the authorising officer, the authorising officer and the accounting officer, as required by Article 16 of the OEDT financial rules for the tasks of the authorising officer, the financial controller and the accounting officer, has been fully complied with. 
The EMCDDA is already trying to ensure the separation of tasks in the execution of the various tasks in question. 
In this context, it shall, as far as possible, take into account the requirements communicated by the Court of Auditors in defining its short-term staffing needs, in order to ensure that the administrative tasks mentioned by the Court (payment agency management, accounting, management of staff or contracts) are carried out by different persons. 
Proposals will be submitted to the EMCDDA Management Board. (g) Financial Controller (point 1.11 of the Court's observations) The EMCDDA's Management Board has taken a negative decision when adopting the EMCDDA's financial rules in June with regard to the transfer of the tasks of the financial controller to an EMCDDA staff member (in particular due to the European Commission's objection). 
Moreover, since the financial controller of the European Commission is the financial controller of the EMCDDA, it would be for the Commission, taking into account the rules on this issue in the other decentralised agencies, to verify the feasibility of the possible designation of a financial controller on the spot.

EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 1 of 5 Avis juridique important 31997Y0313(06) Report on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies Official Journal C 081, 13/03/1997 P. 0043-0048 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies (97/C 81/06) (For the period from 1 September 1994 to 31 December 1995) 1.1. 
This report is addressed to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency in accordance with Article 13 (4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1). 
The Court of Auditors has examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995. 
The budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Executive Director in accordance with the requirements of Article 13 (1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. His responsibilities include the preparation and presentation of the accounts (2) in accordance with the internal financial provisions set out in Article 14 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community requires the Court of Auditors to audit these accounts. 
This report constitutes the first audit of the Agency. 
The Court conducted its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in so far as they are applicable in the community context. 
The Court carried out checks on the accounts and records and also applied such additional auditing procedures as it considered necessary in this context. 
The main observations resulting from the Court's audit are presented in the second part of this report. 
The financial statements for the financial years 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the underlying operations were carried out, on the whole, in accordance with the rules concerning legality and regularity. 
Main observations concerning the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 The Commission subsidy 1.5. 
During the financial year 1995 the Agency used only part of the Commission subsidy provided for in the general budget (ECU 12 million, of which ECU 6,2 million was drawn down). 
It is the Court's opinion that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the financial year 1995 for the balance remaining due (ECU 5,8 million) in order to meet the commitments that were carried over to the financial year 1996. 
Spending in excess of available appropriations 1.6. 
Several cases of expenditure in excess of available appropriations, amounting to approximately ECU 0.4 million altogether, were found under titles I (staff expenditure) and II (administrative expenditure) of the budget. 
This http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 26/10/2010 
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 2 of 5 amount, which could not be charged to the budget for 1995, was entered on the assets side of the balance sheet in a suspense account, and had to be charged to the budget for the financial year 1996 (contravention of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation). 
Imprest account 1.7. 
Most all payments charged to the budget under titles I and II were made via an Imprest account. 
The utilisation of this account was not in accordance with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, since the administrator of the Imprest accounts was, at the time, both the Accounting and the Authorising Officer for certain budget headings. 
Furthermore, the deadlines for the submission of supporting documents were not met and the availability of funds committed was not verified before payments were made. 
This situation seems to be the principal cause of the cases of spending in excess of available funds pointed out above. 
Appropriations carried forward 1.8. 
At the end of the financial year 1995, as was already the case at the end of the financial year 1994, the percentage of funds carried forward was very high in relation to the funds available (ECU 7 million-57.2 % of the total budget). 
The majority of these Carryovers concern title III (operational expenditure) (ECU 6,4 million, representing 90.3 % of the funds under this title). 
A large share (ECU 1,8 million) of the funds carried over from 1994 to 1995, totalling ECU 8.5 million, had to be cancelled (21 % of the funds carried over). 
A posteriori referral to the Financial Controller 1.9. 
Several proposals for the commitment of funds totalling ECU 0,5 million were submitted, a posteriori, to the Financial Controller for his approval. 
In these cases, the Financial Controller withheld his approval, but this refusal was overruled by the Management Board. 
The Court wishes to emphaise the obligation to respect the Financial Regulation and to submit proposals for commitments in due form prior to 'any measure of a kind which might lead to expenditure from the budget' (Article 27 of the Agency's Financial Regulation). 
Separation of duties 1.10. 
The separation of duties within the administration of the Agency has not been observed. 
Due to a shortage of staff in the financial accounting department, the same person was, at one and the same time, Accounting Officer, administrator of the Imprest accounts and Authorising Officer for certain budget headings. 
Accounting systems 1.11. 
The budgetary accounting and general accounting are carried out on two independent and unconnected computer systems. 
The budgetary accounting system is, moreover, not programmed to refuse entries in the event of funds available, or appropriations committed, being exceeded. 
The Financial Controller 1.12. 
The Management Board appointed the Commission's Financial Controller as their own Financial Controller. 
The Court considers it would be advisable, in respect of the Agency's present mode of operation, to appoint a full-time Financial Controller for the Agency. 
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors in Luxembourg at the Court meeting of 28 October 1996. http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 3 of 5 For the Court of Auditors Bernhard FRIEDMANN President >TABLE> >TABLE> >TABLE> (1) OJ L 120, 11. 5. 1990, p. 4. 
(2) Contrary to the requirements of Article 13 (3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts for all revenue and expenditure of the Agency in respect of the financial year 1995 were not prepared until 20 June 1996, the date on which the accounts were signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and sent to the Commission, to the Board of Management and to the Court of Auditors. 
These accounts were received by the Court on 28 June 1996. 
The abridged version of these financial statements is presented in the tables annexed to this report. 
The AGENCY'S REPLIES The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994. 
A first budget of ECU 10,2 million was adopted already on 31 October 1994. 
Since the decision on where to locate the agency had been delayed a fast start was needed. 
Through a significant effort, projects could be identified and the budget committed before the end of the year, but for obvious reasons the execution of the commitments could barely start before the end of 1994. 
Thus, in 1995 the Agency faced the daunting task of executing, not only the budget from 1994 but also a new budget for 1995 of ECU 10,5 million, and this before the regular staff of the Agency had taken up duty. 
The vacant posts in the Agency were published in November 1994 and the selected candidates started coming on board in summer 1995 after a long selection procedure involving more than 7 000 applications. 
In short, the agency had an ambitious work programme and virtually two budgets to execute, but very limited staff for the task. 
Despite this, work went ahead and in 1995 the Agency finalised major projects, like the Dobris assessment, the review of the fifth environmental action plan. 
Five European topic centres were established and the build-up of the EIONET advanced. 
The build-up of the Agency progressed with regular staff increasing from 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, for example national experts and auxiliary staff) to 22 on 31 December 1995, still supported by 10 temporary staff. 
The Agency's Administration has progressively developed since the same open procedure to recruitment was applied. 
Nevertheless, it was clearly too understaffed in 1995 to handle the procedural and financial aspects of the work. 
On the finance side only one person was available to handle the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme during the first half of the year. 
In June 1995 the Head of Administration took up duty, and only in the beginning of 1996 did the rest of the finance and contract staff come on board. 
The Agency rose to the challenge, but some mistakes of a procedural nature were made in the areas of finance and budget. 
Overspending There was overspending on some budget lines. 
The reason was, on the one http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 
26/10/2010 
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 4 of 5 hand, that the Agency's budgetary monitoring system did not function in a satisfactory way and on the other hand some executed payments were not introduced due to the fact that the Agency was seriously understaffed in the finance department. 
As a consequence, when the accounts were closed, the discrepancy between the accounts and the payments actually made, showed up as overspending on some budget lines. 
Since no adjustment between budget lines can be made after 1 January, this has to be booked on the 1996 accounts, i.e. be financed from the 1996 budget. 
In 1996, the expenditures and the availability of funds in titles I and II, which was where the problems occurred in 1995, were carefully monitored in order to avoid overspending. 
Procedures overlooked (Saisine a posteriori) During the build-up of the Agency, a work programme was established and started being executed before administrative procedures had been well established and an administration in place to monitor that procedures were followed. 
In some cases this led to work being ordered and carried out without all the procedures being observed. 
In particular, work was contracted without the Financial Controller in Brussels having given his visa which is a prerequisite for this kind of operational expenditure. 
It was not a question of finances being wasted or that the finances were not there. 
The mistake was procedural and reflected that work had to be done and the procedures to assure that this was done according to Community rules were not yet in place. 
Procedures are now in place to avoid similar problems. 
A clear delegation of authorising powers have been established and staff informed of the rules. 
Separation of functions In the financial framework of the Agency, as is the case in all public institutions, certain functions should be kept separate. 
A basic principle is that the same person should not commit money and order payment. 
However, during the period of establishment of the Agency in Copenhagen the number of staff in the Agency was so small that it was not possible to observe this principle. 
This is rightly criticised by the Court of Auditors. 
However, once the staffing of the Agency started to increase this was corrected and these functions have been rigorously separated in the Agency since autumn 1995. 
Extensive use of Imprest accounts The normal procedure for committing and ordering payments in the EU-system is to have prior approval by the Financial Controller in practically all cases. 
In the case of the Agency, the Agency Financial Controller is the same as the Commission's and located in Brussels. 
To send all financial transactions to Brussels for approval before they could actually be executed would be an excessively tiresome procedure. 
It would seriously obstruct the working of the agency. 
The way out of this dilemma is the Imprest account. 
It works in principle as a petty-cash reserve although the amounts involved are important. 
Instead of seeking prior approval from Financial Control, the Agency executes the payment and once a month the Imprest account is sent to the Financial Controller to have the ex post approval of the payments which have been made. 
On the one hand this facilitates the functioning of the Agency, but, on the other hand, it is a double-edged sword since the Agency's internal controls and the financial department must have the capacity to handle this additional responsibility. 
So, the criticism by the Court of Auditors is understandable, but as long as http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 5 of 5 the Financial Controller is located in Brussels there, in the Agency's view no alternative to an extensive use of the Imprest account. 
It is therefore with great interest that the Agency has noted the recommendation by the Court of Auditors that the Financial Controller of the Commission should place a Financial Controller in the Agency. 
The Agency would welcome this step. 
Computerised financial system The Court of Auditors underlines the need for the Agency to find an up-to-date computerised financial system which can integrate the accounting side with the budget monitoring side. 
In the complicated financial system of the European Union such a computerised system is crucial to avoid having to tie down a lot of resources in financial and budgetary work. 
The Agency supports wholeheartedly the conclusion by the Court of Auditors. 
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has again and again tried to find a solution to this problem. 
It is a problem which the European Environment Agency shares with the other EU Agencies. 
In 1996, the Agencies launched a joint call for tenders to find a solution but this call for tenders has not been successful, i.e. no satisfactory system has been found. 
Thus, the Agency is at present pursuing the possibility of using the new budget monitoring system Sincom 2. The plan is to have it installed and operational in time to execute the 1997 budget on the basis of this system. 
There will be one software for the budget monitoring system and another for the general ledger. 
Nor will the Imprest accounts be integrated in the software the Agency will continue to look for an efficient way of solving these problems and will endeavour to coordinate this work with the other Agencies.

C 309/28 DE Official Journal of the European Union 19.12.2007 ANTWORT OF THE AGENTUR The present share of payments to 2007 is mainly due to incidents of exceptional importance in 2006, which prompted us to postpone interim payments to thematic centres until the satisfactory delivery of the services. 
The proposed budget commitments were the obligation to conclude licensing agreements before 1 January of each year in order to maintain the continuity, as well as the time needed to determine and negotiate the costs and time for complex new work. 
The Agency will continue to endeavour to reduce the proportion of transfers in this context. 
The risks associated with the situation described were assessed by the management and controls were carried out to mitigate the risks. 
The remaining risk is considered acceptable. 
This situation will be reassessed as part of a review of safety sensitive tasks to take place in mid-2007.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/41 INCLUDING 1. The European Agency for Reconstruction (hereinafter the Agency) was established by Council Regulation (EC) No 1628/96(1), most recently gendert by Council Regulation (EC) No 756/2006 of 28 November 2006 (2). 
The Agency, established in 2000, had the original mandate to manage the European Union assistance programmes in Kosovo. 
Spter was also extended to Serbia-Montenegro and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia. 
The Agency is implementing institutions building and good governance programmes to support the development of the market economy and basic infrastructures for civil society.

For CARDS, the deadline for commitment is 2009 and 2010 for disbursement. 
The cost of these three programmes, which had not yet been completed, amounted to EUR 1.8 billion.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/61 ANTWORTEN DER AGENTUR 7. More than 50 % of the Agency's budget was used to prevent environmental pollution. 
In this area, the Agency launched calls for tenders with regard to the award of four tenders for vessels specifically barred to pollution. 
Towards the end of this process, two companies decided to withdraw their bids at the last moment, so that only two contracts could be awarded. 
This led to the cancellation of payment transactions in a significant amount at the end of the year. 
8. The move of the Agency from Brssel to Lisbon in 2006 had an impact on the budget, which was difficult to predict, including the departure of nearly 20 % of the recruited staff. 
9. The procedures for avoiding deferred commitments will be tightened. 
The conditions of pre-financing shall be revised in accordance with the Court's remark. 
10. ABAC Assets' disposal of the old inventory management system in June 2007 leads to the resolution of the problems raised by the Court.

C 311/58 EN Official Journal of the European Union 5.12.2008 INCLUDING 1. The European Maritime Safety Agency (hereinafter 'the Agency') was established by Regulation (EC) No 1406/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 June 2002 (1). 
The Agency's tasks include the achievement of a high level of safety in maritime transport, the supply of pollution from ships, the technical support of the Member States and the Commission, as well as the monitoring of the application of Community legislation and the assessment of their effectiveness. 
Tables 2, 3 and 4 contain, for information, essential information from the Agency's annual accounts for the financial year 2007. 
4. The Agency's annual accounts for the 31st Financial year ended in December 2007 (3) was drawn up by its Executive Director in accordance with Article 18 of Regulation (EC) No 1406/2002 and sent to the Court, who provides an explanation of the eligibility of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying assets. 
(3) The annual accounts were drawn up on 11 June 2008 and received by the Court on 2 July 2008. 
COMMENTS 7. The Agency's 2007 budget amounted to EUR 48.2 million against EUR 44.7 million in the previous year. 
The Agency's budget is mainly financed by the European Commission. 
The procedures for drawing up the budget have not been handled strictly enough. 
This resulted in a high number of transfers (5), an incorrect presentation of the budget (6) and the irregular change of the source of funding in the measures taken to address pollution (7). 
8. Legal commitments were made before the corresponding commitments were made (8). 
(5) More than 32 budget transfers in 2007. 
(6) In the case of differentiated appropriations, the budget must include a view on the payments due to commitments made in previous financial years in the next financial years (Article 31(2)(c) of the Agency's Financial Regulation). 
(7) From mid-June to December, 25 million euros for measures taken to address pollution were granted by the budgetary authority as a reasonable amount (C1) to the assigned revenue (R0). 
(8) Three fines with a total value of EUR 208 000.

At no time have members of the Staff Committee been invited by the appointing authority to participate in the recruitment procedures. 
This approach did not ensure transparent and non-discriminatory procedures.

29. 12. COURT OF AUDITORS REPORT on the financial statements and management for the financial year 1996 of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop - Salonika), accompanied by the replies of the Centre (97/C 393/01) CONTENTS THE FINANCIAL STATEM ENTS OF THE EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE VOCATIONAL TRAINING FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1996 AUDIT OBSERVATIONS Introduction Background of revenue of the audit financial data Observation OF THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE VOCATIONAL TRAINING FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1996 3 21 3 22-23 3 24-26 4 27-29 
C 393/2 EN I Official Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS OF THE EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF VOCATIONAL TRAINING FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1996 1. This report is addressed to the Council and the European Parliament in conformity with Article 12 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 (a) as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1946/93 (2). 
2. The Court has examined the financial statements of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training for the financial year ended 31 December 1996. 
In accordance with Article 18 (1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 (3) as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (4), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Management Board. 
This responsibility includes the drawing up and presentation of the financial statements in accordance with the financial provisions as provided for in Articles 65, 67 and 68 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (4) amending Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 (3). 
The Court of Auditors is required within the meaning of Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community to examine these financial statements. 
3. The Court undertook its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards, in so far as they are applicable in the Community context, and, accordingly, carried out such tests of the accounting records and such other auditing procedures as the Court deemed necessary in the circumstances. 
4. In the opinion of the Court the financial statements for the financial year ended 31 December 1996'are reliable and the underlying transactions are, as a whole, legal and regular. 
Audit OBSERVATIONS Introduction Background 5. The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by the Council Regulation EEC No 337/75 {) as a satellite body of the European Community with the task of promoting vocational training at Community level. 
Cedefop commenced operations in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Salonika in 1995. 
6. The same Regulation defines its role as that of assisting 'the Commission in encouraging, at Community level, the promotion and development of vocational and in-service training', of contributing 'to the implementation of a common vocational training policy' and particularly encouraging 'the exchange of information and the comparison of expertise'. 
ITS main tasks in the field of vocational training are 'to compile documentation, to contribute to the development and coordination of research, to disseminate useful documentation and information, to encourage and support initiatives likely to facilitate a coordinated approach (specifically in respect of the approximation of standards and the mutual recognition of certificates) and to provide a forum for all those concerned'. 
Scope of the audit 7. The Court carried out a financial audit of the 1996 accounts and has reviewed the Centre's decisions concerning its temporary and permanent premises and staff situation. 
Financial data 8. Tables 1 and 2 summarise the financial statements of the Centre. 
Available funds for the financial year 1996 amounted to ECU 14,8 million. 
Commitments entered into gave rise to ECU 11.4 million in payments and ECU 2.1 million in carry-overs to the financial year 1997, the balance of ECU 1,3 million having been cancelled. 
Appropriations carried over from the previous financial year gave rise to ECU 4.2 million in payments and ECU 0.6 million in cancellations. 
Table 3 of this report gives an analysis of the utilisation of the funds for 1996 as well as of those carried over from 1995. 
Observations concerning budgetary implementation Separation of duties 9. The Centre has put in place adequate procedures for the separation of duties of authorising officer, accounting officer and Imprest Holder (5). 
Imprest account 10. A high proportion (in 1996 74 %, including salaries) of payments continue to be made prior to approval by the Financial" Controller. 
Last year (5) the Court recommended that the use of the.imprest account be limited to ongoing or small expenses, where' the risk of irregularities is comparatively low. 
A Management Board decision defining which kind of expenses may be paid thrnnph the imnrest account has been established and came into force on 1 January 1997. 
Transfers of appropriations 11. The value of transfers of funds between different budget lines in 1996 was ECU 891 600 (6 % of the initial budget), down from ECU 922 000 in 1995. 
29. 12. 97 1 EN I Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/3 12. Following consultations with and the approval of the different services in the Commission (DG IX, DG XIX and DG XX), the Centre transferred ECU 30 000 from budget line 117 6 'Other services and work sent out for translation and typing' to a newly-created budget line 1 1 1 0 'Auxiliaries', and ECU 40 000 from budget line 1 1 0 0 'Basic salaries' to a newly-created budget line 1 1 1 2 'Local agents'. 
These new budget lines were created by the Centre. 
The Court acknowledges the reasons for making these transfers, but notes that they are contrary to paragraph 4 (a) of Article 21 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 which states: 'appropriations may be transferred only to budget headings for which the statement of expenditure has authorised appropriations or carried a token entry'. 
The same budget lines are also included in the 1997 budget with approval of the Budgetary Authority. 
Carry-overs and cancellations of appropriations 13. The volume of funds carried over has decreased in 1996. 
Almost 77 % of final appropriations for 1996 were paid out in 1996 as compared with 61 % in 1995. 
The percentage of commitments made and carried over to 1997'was 14 % (28 % in 1995). 
The percentage of cancellations was 9 % compared with 10 % in 1995. 
Table 4 shows the carry-overs from the 1996 initial budget by title and their subsequent use. 
Observations concerning the revenue and expenditure account and the balance sheet Revenue 14. The EU subsidy for the Centre for 1996 was ECU 14 625 000. 
The Centre actually requested and received ECU 14 410 000. 
15. In 1996, for the first time Norway and Iceland paid the Centre ECU 9 6 1 3 5 as a contribution for their participation in the work programme. 
Expenditure 16. Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 stipulates that contracts may be made by direct agreement where the contract involves an amount not exceeding the limit of ECU 12 000. 
In the case of at least 17 study contracts and five fixed asset purchases, contracts over that limit were made without following the tendering procedure as described in Article 45 of the Regulation, but all payments were approved by the Financial Controller. 
17. The result of a study of delays in the submission of work by contractors for 1996 showed that 55 % of the contractors did not respect the contractual deadline. 
None of the minutes of management meetings contained any evidence of a review of the performance of contractors in meeting contractual deadlines. 
Balance sheet 18. The Centre made an up-to-date inventory list as foreseen in Article 52 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (s). 
Fixed assets of ECU 1 443 431 recorded in the 1996 balance sheet represent the historic cost of materials and furnishings. 
19· At the year end, cash balances held by. the Centre were ECU 4.1 million, down from ECU 5,9 million in 1995. 
The Centre is again taking responsibility for managing large cash balances. 
The Court recommends the Centre make its quarterly drawings from the Commission on the basis of its actual cash needs. 
20. The balance sheet includes an amount of ECU 483 308 relating to 'VAT to recover', of which ECU 251 434 relates to the year 1995 but not yet recovered due to the move to Salonika. 
The Court asks the Centre to do the necessary to recover this amount as soon as possible. 
With regard to the 'VAT to recover for 1996', the Centre is recommended to explain to the responsible tax authorities every detail related to this procedure to avoid funds being cancelled or excessive delays in reimbursement. 
Audit of the Centre's premises' and staff situation Temporary premises 21. As the Court observed last year (8), the Centre had to invest ECU 120 000 to fit out the premises to make the temporary building functional and 'ready for use'. 
At the time of the audit (May 1997), the Centre 'explained that these costs were incurred to improve the conditions for efficient functioning of the Centre', but was unable to explain who was liable to bear these costs. 
Permanent premises 22. The Centre and the Greek State signed on 22 June 1995, a basic agreement regarding the construction of the permanent building. 
According to this agreement, the Centre will pay to the Greek State ECU 6 879 750 in four equal instalments of ECU 1 719 937. 
The first two were paid on 1 September 1995 and 1 September 1996 
This third instalment has to be approved by the Budgetary Authority and the last instalment will be paid when the building is handed over. 
23. If approval is given by the Budgetary Authority before 1 September 1997, the Centre will have paid to the Greek State ECU 5 159 811 for the construction of the permanent building. 
The construction of the building was planned to begin on 30 March 1997. 
At the time of the audit (May 1997), the tendering procedure, which is managed by the Greek authorities, was not yet finalised nor were any contracts signed. 
As a consequence, no financial data or budget related to this investment was available for audit. 
Staff 24. In 1996, the Staff Complement Table Authorised 81 posts (permanent and temporary positions), of which: 25 A, 11 LA, 15 B, 27 C and 3 D. At the time of the audit (May 1997), 78 persons were actually working in. 
Salonika, of which: 60 officials and temporary officials (25 A/LA, 10 B, 23 C and 2 D), 7 national experts, 5 local agents, 3 auxiliaries, 2 interims and 1 'stagiaire'. 
25. Another three persons are working at Cedefop's office in Brussels, one person is seconded to Eurostat for a cooperative project, three persons we're still in Berlin, This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors and 13 November 1997. four staff members are on special leave (CCP) and one person has been ill for many months. 
Many new members of staff have been recruited during 1996. 
26. The Court has been informed of an investigation by the Greek tax authorities concerning, among others, tax and social security payments for local staff put at the disposal of Cedefop by a company in Salonika. 
Conclusion 27. In the case of at least 17 study contracts and five fixed-asset purchases, contracts over the limit of ECU 12000 were made without following the tendering procedure as described in Article 45 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 as amended by Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 (see paragraph 16). 
28. The Centre once again holds large cash balances. 
This situation should be avoided by making quarterly drawings from the Commission on the basis of actual cash needs (see paragraph 19). 
29. The Centre is recommended to make sure that the work concerning the permanent premises is progressing in conformity with the contract (see paragraph 23). in Luxembourg at the Court's meeting of 12 For the European Court of Auditors Bernhard FRIEDMANN President (!)

C 393/8 EN Official Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 REPLIES OF THE EUROPEAN CENTRE FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF VOCATIONAL TRAINING The nature of the observations of the Court of Auditors makes it possible for the Management Board of the Centre to react in a direct manner. 
The Board will follow the structure of the Court's observations and conclusions. 
The numbering of the annotated paragraphs corresponds to that used in the Court's report. 
12. The Centre thanks to the Court for the understanding shown for the indicated transfers, which were necessary for smooth functioning in the Greek context and points out the exceptional nature of these operations which will not recur under normal circumstances. 
16. Concerning the procedure to call for tenders the following points should be taken into account: (a) Some ongoing contracts are based on earlier calls for interest and for tender. 
In the case of the documentary network, for which contracts are mostly above ECU 12 000, these were signed in most cases with the same specialised institutions as in.previous years. 
A high degree of continuity is needed in this work and a yearly call for tenders with the possibility of frequent changes in contractors would be very disruptive and, due to the need for training and a period of introduction, inefficient. 
Nevertheless the performance of the contracts is carefully evaluated and a call for tenders (on the basis of the call for interest recently made by the Centre) will be launched in cases where it is considered that this performance is not satisfactory. (B) Contracts for preparing new monographs describing the vocational education and training systems in the Member States (or for updating existing ones) are subject to the usual rules, i.e. a restricted invitation to tender is organised. 
In the case of the monographs, this list is drawn up following consultation with members of the Management Board. 
An exception to this rule was made during 1995 and 1996 in relation to monographs concerning the new Member States and the EEA countries, when it was thought more appropriate to take the decision directly following consultation with members of the Management Board. 
As planned, the Centre launched a general call for an expression of interest for participation in networks and the performance of study contracts. 
This was published in the Official Journal of the European Communities (C 214 of 16 July 1997) and the results of this call are now processed. 
17. Delays in completing transactions in relation to contracts in many cases derive from defective administrative procedures, especially the failure of contractors to forward in time the necessary invoices for payment. 
Delays were also incurred sometimes in signing contracts, allowing work on them to begin only some months after the date initially planned which had knock-on effects. 
In other cases delays were due to the need for intensive and time-consuming discussion between the contractor and Cedefop on the basis of the contractor's. draft report. 
In cases in which the contracting institution may be co-funding the activity itself, or obtaining some funding from another source, Cedefop cannot always dictate the timetable. 
This is especially so, when the price that Cedefop is paying is lower than the market might dictate for the work involved. 
Nevertheless, Cedefop will try to avoid delays. 
In the case of unreasonable delays the Centre indicates to the contractors that these imply serious disadvantages for them, as far as the prospects for future cooperation are concerned. 
The new list of interested persons/institutions, which will be the result of the recent call for expression of interest, should enlarge the options available to the Centre for the future award of contracts and therefore make it easier to insist that contractors and their institutions comply strictly with the rules and timetable laid down. 
A business-like approach will be maintained. 
19. The Management Board notes the improvements in 1996 and considers that further progress is possible. 
It wants to intensify its efforts to that end. 
The Centre has improved its procedure by adding to every quarterly drawing from the Commission subsidy a detailed statement with respect to the current supply of means of payment and the total payments expected during the subsequent four months. 
The difference between these shows the balance of the real demand and, as a result, a permanent excessive cash balance will be avoided. 
20. The Centre immediately initiated action after the audit of the Court of Auditors and is pressing for reimbursement. 
The corresponding records for reclaiming from the German financial authorities the value-added tax (VAT) paid in 1995 and 1996 by the Centre have been submitted. 
The Centre has made contact with the responsible tax authorities in Greece and has been informed in detail on the procedure and appropriate preparation of the records for reclaiming value-added tax 
29. 12. 97 EN Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/9 (VAT) paid in previous years. 
In the mean time, the records-concerning the financial years 1995 and 1996 have been prepared and forwarded to the authorities. 
21. The Centre draws to mind that - the rapid refurbished temporary premises are not an optimal· solution (e.g. the available surface area is only ±one third the size of the future new building), - new needs arose after Cedefop's relocation (particularly, investment in the infrastructure for electronic equipment), - neither the initial agreement nor the Greek law is clear on who should bear such costs. 
Legal advice confirmed the uncertainty. 
The Centre had to make modifications to run operations efficiently. 
The Centre Recognises that it would have been better to make arrangements beforehand on any additional investment. 
The owner has taken note of these additional investments made by Cedefop and has shown a generous attitude in new issues (e.g. extra meeting facilities). 
The Centre will try to receive compensation in the settlements at the end of the present rental contract. 
23. The Centre agrees that the preparatory time was very long, but is confident that matters will now proceed rapidly.
