29. 12. Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/11 THE FINANCIAL STATEMENTS OF THE EUROPEAN FOUNDATION FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF LIVING AND WORKING CONDITIONS FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1996. This report is addressed to the Council and the European Parliament in conformity with Article 16 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1365/75 (l) as amended by Article 1 (4) of Regulation (EEC) No 1947/93 (2). 
2. The Court has examined the financial statements of the European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions for the financial year ended 31 December 1996. 
In accordance with Article 1 (16) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 (3) amending Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76(4), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Administrative Board. 
This responsibility includes the drawing up and presentation of the financial statements in accordance with the financial provisions as provided for in Article 1 (52), (54) and (55) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 (3) amending Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 (4). 
3. The Court undertook its audit in accordance with generally accepted international auditing standards, in so far as they are applicable in the Community context and, accordingly, carried out such tests of the accounting records and such other procedures as the Court deemed necessary in the circumstances. 
4. In the opinion of the Court the financial statements for the financial year ended 31 December 1996 are reliable and the underlying transactions are, taken as a whole, legal and regular. 
Audit OBSERVATIONS Introduction Background 5. The European Foundation for the Improvement in Living and Working Conditions (Dublin Foundation) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1365/75 (5) as a satellite body of the European Community with the task of contributing 'to the planning and establishment of better living and working conditions through action designed to increase and disseminate knowledge likely to assist this development'. 
The Dublin Foundation commenced operations in 1976. 
Scope of the audit 6. The Court of Auditors has examined the accounts and financial management of the Dublin Foundation for the financial year 1996 in accordance with the provisions of the relevant regulations(6). 
A review of the cooperation with the European Agency for Health and Safety at Work in Bilbao and Directorate-General V of the Commission in the area of health and safety was carried out. 
Financial data 7. Tables 1 and 2 summarise the financial statements of the Foundation. 
Available funds for the financial year 1996 amounted to ECU 13,8 million. 
Commitments entered into gave rise to ECU 10,5 million in payments and ECU 3,1 million in carry-overs to the financial year 1997, the balance of ECU 0.2 million having been cancelled. 
Appropriations carried over from the previous year gave rise to ECU 2,9 million in payments and ECU 0.1 million in cancellations. 
Table 3 attached to this report gives an analysis by title of the utilisation of the funds for the year and for those carried over from 1995. 
Follow up of previous observations Separation of duties 8. There is still an inadequate separation of duties between the authorising officer and the accounting officer (7), contravening Article 1 (15) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 amending Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76. Imprest account 9. Last year the Court recommended that the use of the Imprest account be limited to ongoing or small expenses, where the risk of irregularities is comparatively low. 
At the time of the audit in April 1997 a written definition of ongoing and small expenses still had not been established by the Foundation in consultation, with the Financial Controller. 
Transfers of appropriations between titles 10. The Court welcomes the fact that no transfers of funds between titles were made during 1996. 
The Court has criticised such transfers in previous years (8). 
Mission Expenses 11. Some improvements have been made to strengthen the controls and monitoring of the results of missions. 
The Foundation should continue its efforts so as to ensure that: 
C 393/12 ? Official Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 - For all missions a report stating the times of meetings, persons met and the results of the meeting is prepared. 
The report should be reviewed by a senior member of staff and filed centrally, - wherever possible, more than one meeting should be arranged during a mission to Brussels in order to avoid the same staff member going to Brussels on successive weeks, - other means of communication, including tele-conferencing, should be seriously considered, especially when communicating with persons in Brussels well already known. 
Study contracts 12. The audit team of the Court followed up last year's observation regarding delays in the submission of work by contractors. 
The minutes of the programme management meetings did not contain any evidence of a review of report deadlines. 
A summary of the information supplied by the Foundation during the audit is shown in Table 4 and demonstrates the need for a formalisation of followup procedures. 
Management of health and safety Coordination with the Bilbao Agency 16. The European Agency for Health and Safety at Work in Bilbao commenced its activities in September 1996. 
'Health and safety' was in the Foundation's programme of work for 1996, but was replaced in the programme of work for 1997 with 'Health and wellbeing'. 
There is an urgent need for a clear and detailed M emorandum of Understanding (currently being negotiated) to be agreed on by both satellite agencies. 
This should maximise cooperation and exclude any overlap in activities. 
17. Formal contacts already exist at administrative level, notably through both directors attending the other's Administrative Board meetings as an observer. 
Links Need to be extended to the research manager level in order to ensure full coordination. 
Cooperation of the Foundation with DG V/F 18. Directorate F of DG V, 'Public Health and Safety at Work', makes use of some of the Foundation's research within this specialised field. 
While maintaining the present independence of the Foundation's Administrative Board, there is a need to make more effort to ensure that its output is as useful as possible to DG V/F in terms of content and timing. 
DG V/F is unable to attend all meetings concerning specific study contracts. 
It would therefore be useful to hold periodic meetings at which the whole range of studies which may concern DG V/F can be discussed. 
Conclusion 19. There is an inadequate separation of duties between accounting officer and authorising officer (see paragraph 8). 
20. The use of the Imprest account should be regularised (see paragraph 9). 
21. Controls over mission expenditure and the monitoring of study contracts should be tightened (see paragraphs 11 and 12). 
22. Cooperation and communication with the Bilbao Agency and DG V/F in the fields of 'Health and safety at work' and 'Health and wellbeing' should be strengthened (see paragraphs 16 to 18). 
Budget implementation and the expenditure account Transfer of appropriations revenue and 13. The value of transfers of appropriations between different budget lines in 1996 was ECU 1 366 000 (9.9 % of appropriations entered into the budget), down from ECU 1 494 000 (11?·%) in 1995. 
Carry-overs and cancellations of appropriations 14. Table 3 shows that the payment rate is 76 % for the account as a whole, but only 55 % for Title 3 Operating expenditure'. 
This is in line with previous years and is due to the fact that studies are usually paid in three instalments over the period foreseen in their contracts. 
Revenue 15. The EU subsidy for the Foundation for 1996 was ECU 13.4 million. 
The actual amount requested and received was ECU 12 895 632. 
The funds were requested as required by the Council Regulations and in line with a cash flow forecast, previously as recommended by the Court.

29. 12. 97 1 EN I Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/17 REPLIES OF THE EUROPEAN FOUNDATION FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF LIVING AND WORKING CONDITIONS Separation of duties 8. The Foundation would ask the Court to note that the two functions of authorising and accounting officers are carried out separately by different individuals: a residual problem of separation of duties is limited to data input to the accounting system. 
This problem will be resolved when the Foundation obtains delivery of a new system. 
The Foundation is in contact with the Commission services with regard to the feasibility of the application of the Commission's Sincom 2 system to the Foundation's accounting requirements. ~ - Imprest account 9. During 1996 the Foundation's use of the Imprest account was, in practice, in accordance with the recommendation of the Court, limited to ongoing or small expenses. 
The Foundation, in June 1997 in consultation with the Financial Controller, established a written definition with regard to these expenses. 
Mission expenses 11. In 1996, the Foundation further developed existing procedures with regard to mission reports. 
This process will continue and will incorporate the suggestions of the Court. 
The Foundation continually seeks to accommodate the optimal number of meetings during a particular mission. 
The Court's comments regarding missions to Brussels are, however, noted. 
Following the successful completion of a pilot scheme during 1996 the Foundation has now installed a tele-conferencing facility. 
It is intended to review the utilisation of this facility at the end of a trial period at which time further decisions will be taken, based on a cost analysis, regarding the value of acquiring more extensive and sophisticated video-conferencing equipment. 
Study contracts 12. Although the minutes of the programme management meetings have not recorded the situation on specific contract deadlines, such discussions on each contract take place at every meeting and appropriate action is taken. 
With regard to such recording the Foundation is now establishing an improved system for formalisation of follow-up procedures in order to present a more realistic picture. of the situation. 
Coordination with the Bilbao Agency 16. The memorandum of understanding currently under consideration is considered as a priority item by the Foundation. 
The establishment of links at research manager level has therefore commenced. 
This will be intensified in line with any increase in activities undertaken by the Bilbao Agency. 
Cooperation of the Foundation with DG V/F 18. The Foundation.is very cognisant of the need for its output to be relevant to the work of DG V. The Commission is represented on the Foundation's Administrative Board by the Deputy Director-General of DG V. Various forms of working relations have been established with the Directorates of DG V, including mutual participation in working groups as appropriate. 
Specifically through the office of the Director of DG V/F the Foundation has regular contacts with officials in the various units within DG V/F. Presentation of aspects of the Foundation's work to DG V officials is provided for within the Foundation's operational activities. 
The Advisory Committee on Safety and Health at Work in Luxembourg is also kept informed of the Foundation's programme and its results. 
More generally there is a flow of relevant documentation from the Foundation to DG V •in relation to the results of the work programmes. 
The Court's acknowledgement that DG V/F is often unable to attend meetings related to specific study contracts is noted. 
The Foundation is fully open to alternative proposals from DG V/F with regard to utilisation of the Foundation's output. 
C 393/18 I EN [Official Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Agency for the Evaluation of Medicinal Products (EMEÄ, London) (Financial year 1996), together with the Agency's replies (97/C 393/03) 1.1. 
This report is addressed to the Management Board of the European Agency for the Evaluation of Medicinal Products, pursuant to Article 57 (10) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 2309/93 of 22 July 1993 (*). 
The Court of Auditors has examined the financial statements of the European Agency for the Evaluation of Medicinal Products for the financial year 1996. 
The budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Executive Director in accordance with Article 57 (7) of Regulation (EEC) No 2309/93 (l). 
His responsibilities include the preparation and presentation of the accounts (2) in accordance with thé internal financial provisions provided for in Article 57 (11) of Regulation (EEC) No 2309/93. Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community requires the Court of Auditors to audit these accounts. 
The Court conducted its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in so far as they are appropriate to the community context. 
It examined the account books and records and carried out such additional auditing procedures as it considered necessary. 
The financial statements concerning the financial year 1996 are reliable and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions as a whole are guaranteed. 
Main OBSERVATIONS concerning the IMPLEMENTATION OF THE BUDGET OF THE EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE EVALUATION OF MEDICINAL· PRODUCTS (EMEA, LONDON) for the FINANCIAL YEAR 1996 Budgetary accounts 1.5. 
The Agency's budgetary accounts do not enable the principle of the inviolability of the accounts to be guaranteed, as a posteriori modifications are possible and undetectable. 
Furthermore, the accounts do not make it possible to detect cases of spending in excess of available funds. 
The current system does not allow the Authorising Officer to input accounting data (proposals for commitments and payment orders) to the computer. 
These data are recorded by the accounting officer in the accounts for the record (temporary freezing) before being approved by the Financial Controller. 
This practice does not provide accurate information on the accounts in real time. 
As the Sincom 2 system, which is supposed to replace the present accounting system, is not yet operational, an alternative solution should preferably be sought without delay. 
General accounts - analytical 1.7. 
The general accounts software that is currently used is insufficient for the Agency's needs and is separate from the budgetary accounts system. 
Furthermore, the Agency has no system of analytical accounts, which is however indispensable if one wishes to establish whether the scale of fees laid down by the Council (3) adequately covers the costs of evaluation. 
Use of appropriations. 
1.8. The funds carried forward from 1995 to 1996 totalled ECU 5,9 million. 
Of this amount, ECU 1.7 million (29 %) was cancelled. 
ECU 0.9 million of 1995 appropriations made available for reuse but not used in 1996 were also cancelled. 1.9. 
Only 79.6 % of current appropriations (ECU 22,6 million before the SAB and ECU 17.9 million after a reduction following the adoption of an amending budget) were implemented and 20.7 % were cancelled (ECU 4,7 million). 
The main reason for this was the impossibility of recruiting staff in good time (only 65 % of the posts for which provision had been made); a second reason was the reduction in licence applications and in the corresponding studies. 
1.10. The funds carried forward from 1996 to 1997 totalled ECU 4.8 million. 
Of this amount, ECU 1.7 million and ECU 2,8 million concerned Titles II (administrative expenditure) and III (operational expenditure). 
In the case of Title II, ECU 1.1 million concerned purchases of equipment based on new technology. 
In the case of Title III, ECU 1,3 million concerned fees to be paid to the inspectors during examinations (started in 1996 and finished in 1997) and ECU 0.8 million was for orphan drugs.

In the absence of a commercial computerised system which meets the requirements of the Financial Regulation and until the new SI2 system, developed by the Commission, which the Agencies are in the process of adapting to their needs, is available, the Agency is managing its budget accounts using Excel software. 
This software ensures that the information required for the sound management of the budget is always available and it provides the Agency's management with information which is relevant and up-to-date. 
The software verifies budget appropriations, commitments, orders, frozen appropriations and payments. 
The existing system indicates cases spending in excess of available appropriations. 
The supporting document for each entry in the budget system is the document signed by the authorising officer. 
It is approved by the Financial Controller and is processed by the accounts department. 
It is true that the Agency's system is not yet completely computerised and, because it does not retain in its memory changes to entries, it does, in principle, allow changes to be made without any indication thereof appearing in the general accounts. 
However, it should be noted that all commitments, cancellations, payment orders, etc. are prepared and classified in accordance with the rules, the relevant supporting documents being placed in an annex. 
In the new system it will not be possible to make ex post facto changes without there being any indication thereof. 
Like most of the Agencies, the EMEA expects that the work on the SI2 project will be completed in 1997 and that the system will be made available. 
The new system will allow the general accounts to be better integrated with the budget accounts. 
Together with the other Agencies, the EMEA issued an invitation to tender two years ago for compatible software; the result was disappointing. 
The EMEA anticipates that the SI2 system, adapted to the needs of the Agency, will be available by the end of 1997. 
1.7. On 5 February 1997 the Management Board adopted a report on the cost of operational activities, which was forwarded to the Commission. 
The Agency is busy structuring its accounts system so as to include analytical accounts. 
In addition, a pilot programme for the electronic recording of activities has been started. 1.8. 
The sum of ECU 0,9 million in 1995 appropriations made available for reuse but not used in 1996 relates notably to Article 204 (fitting-out of premises). 
As these funds could not be transferred and as no significant fitting-out work was carried out in 1996, the sum in question was cancelled. 
1.11. Article 5 of the Financial Regulation stipulates that expenditure for which authorisation reaches the Financial Controller no later than 31 December, and for which the corresponding payments are made no later than the following 15 January, will be entered in the accounts for the financial year which is coming to a close. 
Following the imprecise interpretation of these provisions in 1994 a sum of ECU 16 915,22. was imputed to the Imprest account. 
Following discussions with the Court's auditors the sum in question was settled in the 1997 accounts. 
1.13. Even if, with more experience in the field, the Agency was able to improve its estimates of the volume of dossiers to be received, taking account also of the seasonal nature of their submission, the Agency would still be no more able in the future it is present at formulate, one year in advance, exact estimates of the plans of the pharmaceutical industry and therefore of the amount which might be expected from fees. 
These uncertainties mean that the Agency is obliged to pursue a cautious policy with regard to expenditure. 
29. 12. Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/23 REPORT on the financial statements of the Office for Harmonisation in the I nternal Market (OHI M, Alicante) (Financial year 1996), together with the Office's replies (97/C 393/04) 1.1. 
This report is addressed to the Budget Committee of the Office for Harmonisation in the I nternal Market pursuant to Article 137(2) of Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 of 20 December 1993 C. 
The Court has examined the financial statements of the Office for Harmonisation in the I nternal Market for the financial year 1996. 
The budget was implemented under the responsibility of the President of the Office in accordance with the requirements of Article 119 (2) (c) of Regulation (EC) No 40/94 (2). 
His responsibilities include the preparation and presentation of the accounts (3) in accordance with the internal financial rules, as provided for by Article 137 of Regulation (EC) No 40/94. Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community requires the Court.of Auditors to audit these accounts. 
The Court carried out its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in so far as they are applicable in the community context. 
I t carried out tests on the account books and records and such' additional procedures as it considered necessary in this context. 
The main observations resulting from the Court's audit are set out in the second part of this report. 
1.4. For the reasons indicated in paragraphs 1.8 to 1.12 (own revenue) the Court was unable to form an opinion as to whether the accounts underlying the revenue shown in the financial statements are reliable. 
Subject to the above reservations, the financial statements for the financial year 1996 are reliable and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions are, on the whole, assured. 
Main OBSERVATI ONS IMPLEMENTATION OF THE BUDGET OF THE OFFI CE FOR HARMONI ZATI ON I N THE I nternal MARKET FOR THE FINANCIAL YEAR 1996 Budget accounts 1.6. 
Although 1996 is the Office's third year of activity, the accounts department of the Office still does not have proper budget accounting software. 
Monitoring the implementation of the budget is carried out with the aid of a tool which is not a real accounting system (changes may be made to entries with no subsequent record of their having been made, absence of any link to the general accounts, etc.). 1.7. 
The Office does not possess any system of analytical accounting, which is, however, indispensable for the purpose of establishing the real cost of services rendered. 
Own revenue 1.8. 
Before the entry into service, in May 1996, of the system set up to monitor the charges associated with the filing of trade marks (Euromarc), two alternative systems had been used temporarily to monitor applications for trade-mark registrations. 
The risk that is inherent in the transfer of data from these temporary systems to Euromarc is high and the Court was therefore unable to form an opinion as to whether such transfers were complete. 
The Office was not able to demonstrate that the Euromarc system was functioning according to the description it had given. 
The Court is, therefore, not in a position to state with certainty that the reliability of the system is assured. 
The new description drawn up by the Office reached the Court too late for it to be able to carry out the additional work that was necessary to remove this uncertainty. 
For reasons which are mainly due to the unwieldiness of Euromarc and the complexity of the THE regulations, long delays in dealing with applications were observed. 
Some clients complained to the Office on this account. 
Moreover, the accumulated delay prevented the entry of more than ECU 12,4 million of revenue out of a total of ECU 45,9. million in receipts. 
The difference, i.e. ECU 33,5 million, was entered under liabilities and shown on the balance sheet as 'advances from clients'. 
Of this amount, ECU 4,7 million was made up of payments that could not be linked to the related trade-mark applications. 
Bearing in mind that new payments arrive every day, these old transactions must be identified as a matter of urgency. 
C 393/24 1 EN I Official Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 ACPC 1.12. 
The Office's ACPC was not created until 1 April 1996. 
Several contracts for which the opinion of the ACPC would have been required, had. already been approved by the Office on the basis of an operating report, in some cases, by a note from the legal department, concerning the regularity of the procedure followed. 
Search notes can, under no circumstances, replace the opinion of the ACPC. 
Appropriations carried over; cancellations; transfers 1.13. 
Appropriations carried over to 1997 totalled ECU 14.5 million (total automatic carry-overs), i.e. 44.8 % of the total of ECU,32,4 million of appropriations for the financial year. 
These funds carried forward originating in the large volume of trade-mark applications which had not been processed at the end of the year. 
The total of current appropriations which lapsed was ECU 5,6 million, i.e. 17.3 % of the funds for the financial year. 
As far as the funds carried over from the financial year L995 are concerned ECU 4,65 million, i.e. 14.6 %, lapsed (ECU 0.68 million). 
Transfers of funds amounted to ECU 7,6 million. 
The. totals quoted, as well as the funds carried over to the financial year 1997 and the volume of revenue received, show the inaccuracy of the budget estimates for the financial year 1996. 
An amendment of the initial budget estimates should have been made during the financial year. 
Buildings 1.16. 
The Office continues to occupy a building belonging to the Spanish authorities and placed at its disposal free of charge. 
However, no contract exists in this respect. 
As far as the final location is concerned, the Office has opened negotiations in respect of a proposed acquisition and has entered an initial amount in the budget for supervisory work. 
1.17. It must be emphasised that the Office must ensure that the necessary appropriations are available before a legal commitment is entered into.

29. 12. 97 I EN I Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/27 REPLIES OF THE OFFICE FOR Harmonication IN THE INTERNAL MARKET 1.4. 
Own revenue The payment of the fees and charges associated with the filing and registration of a Community trade-mark is the final step in a lengthy procedure, which is laid down in Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 of 20 December 1993. 
Between the time a trade-mark application is filed and the time the corresponding charges are entered in the accounts there is usually an interval of two months, in the course of which the case is handled by at least three different types of staff. 
The whole process is computerised and each category of staff involved is authorised to access the computer system which covers the duties for which they are responsible. 
In order to be able to cover in a limited amount of time (two to three days) all the stages involved from receipt of application to entry in the accounts of the charges, it is absolutely essential that the cases selected at the outset receive priority treatment. 
This is possible providing two conditions are met: 1. That a single user is authorised, temporarily and by way of exception, to have access to all the computer systems required to complete all the stages, up to entry in the accounts, and 2. that the demonstration of the accelerated procedure takes place in a test environment in order that there may be all the flexibility of use required without the production base being contaminated. 
During the visit of the auditors in February 1997 it was not possible to carry out such a demonstration in the time available for technical reasons. 
Measures have already been put in place to ensure that a complete presentation of the revenue payment system can be made during the auditors' visit which is planned for October 1997. 
Budget accounts Like the other Agencies, the OHIM is awaiting the final version of the Sincom 2 budget accounting software. 
This software ought to be available towards the end of 1997. 
Once the OHIM receives the software, it will be brought into use over a period of a few months. 
Analytical accounts The Office will start to establish analytical accounts for certain areas of activity at the beginning of 1998, when it will have a sufficiently broad and stable production base in certain sectors to be able to establish realistic standards. 
Own revenue - change of system While changing over to the final system for monitoring applications and charges, the Office verified extremely thoroughly that the data transferred were consistent. 
Moreover, bank Reconciliations confirmed the results of the transfer. 
The Office therefore considers that the transfer was carried out correctly. 
1.9-1.10. 
System for the payment of charges See reply to paragraph 1.4. 
Delay hi the identification/entry of payments On account of the large number of applications received in 1996 (43 000 rather than the 15 000 anticipated), the Office built up a certain backlog in 1996 in the entry of application charges. 
The Office has almost caught up with this backlog. 
As regards the ECU 4,7 million made up of non-identified payments, the situation has been rectified since March 1997, as intended and explained to the Court's auditors. 
At present, the time-lag between the receipt of a cheque by the OHIM and its identification and transfer to the bank is six days. 
C 393/28 Occupational Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 1.13 ACPC The ACPC began operating as soon as the Office's Financial Regulation and the implementing rules applicable to the Financial Regulation, which govern the composition of the ACPC, entered into force. 
Before the creation of the ACPC the OHI M had no alternative but to follow the procedure which it did, namely to consult the legal department in respect of contracts exceeding a threshold of ECU 42 000, in order to ensure that the procurement procedure was in accordance with the rules applicable to the conclusion of public contracts. 
In the case of sizeable contracts, the OHI M was compelled during this transitional period to use the contracts of the other institutions and of the Commission in particular, in order to benefit from the legal guarantee attached to such contracts and the economies of scale which necessarily result. 
Appropriations carried over a relatively large amount of funds were carried over in 1996. 
80 % of the carry-overs in question related to procedural expenditure (searches/translation/publication, etc.). 
In accordance with Article 29 of the Financial Regulation, the Office must commit the procedural expenditure arising from Council Regulation (EC) No 40/94 on the Community trade-mark the moment application charges are entered in the accounts. 
This is effectively unavoidable expenditure, the implementation of which is directly linked to the collection of the application charges. 
Clearly, during this start-up phase, taking into account the fact that the number of applications was much higher than anticipated (+ 280 %), the discrepancy between the commitment of procedural expenditure and the actual implementation of the procedures in question is much greater than normal operation. 
This situation is progressively being regularised; in 1997, appropriations carried over in respect of procedural expenditure will be significantly less. 
Lapsed appropriations/transfers of appropriations The 1996 budget was drawn up at the end of June 1994 and submitted to the Budgetary Authority in February 1995. 
At that stage, there was nothing to suggest that the OHIM would be faced with such a number of trade-mark applications. 
In June and September 1996 the OHI M informed its Budget Committee of how the situation was developing, drawing its attention to the budgetary consequences. 
It should be noted that some of the.lapsed funds come under Chapter 1 1 and relate in particular to Heading 1 1 3 3 (Constitution or maintenance of pension rights for temporary staff) (ECU 1 031 000). 
These funds were entered in the budget at the request of the Commission in order to cover the employers' contribution to pensions payable to staff (it was said that this entry was contrary to the staff regulations). 
I n the mean time, the Commission has indicated that no pension fund exists and that no amount is due as an employers' contribution. 
As regards the other lapsed appropriations, they are essentially funds relating to procedural expenditure for which it was impossible to make commitments in 1996 due to lack of time. 
Building There is no lease contract between the Spanish authorities and the OHI M. for the latter's occupation of its temporary seat at 20 Avenida de Aguilera. 
There is, however, a document entitled 'Acte de remise des clés du sičge provisoire' (Deed of delivery of keys to the temporary seat), which was signed on 25 February 1994 by the COSOAMI and the OHIM and which provides for the OHI M to occupy the temporary seat until it is able to occupy the final seat. 
Final seat The OHI M has taken note of the Court's observation concerning the availability of funds for the acquisition of the final seat. 
ITS Budget Committee has, however, approved the acquisition of the first phase of the final seat by means of bank loan financing. 
29. 12. 97 I EN I Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/29 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA, Copenhagen) (Financial year 1996), together with the Agency's replies (97/C 393/05) 1.1. 
This report is addressed to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency, pursuant to Article 13 (4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 i1). 
The Court of Auditors has examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial year 1996. 
The Court carried out tests on the account books and records and also such additional auditing procedures as it considered necessary in this context. 
The observations set out in paragraphs 1.6 to 1.15 show that there are accounting practices in use at the Agency which are not consistent with the regulations. 
There are also certain sums for which no justification could be given. 
Subject to the above reservations, the Agency's financial statements for the financial year 1996 are - reliable and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions are, on the whole, guaranteed. of accounts. 
No such reconciliation was made during the financial year 1996. 
Furthermore, for the financial year 1996, such reconciliation was complicated by the consolidation of a substantial proportion of the general account entries (the various budget accounts were grouped into five major expenditure accounts in the general accounts; several non-budget entries concerning various credit or debit operations in respect of staff were also grouped together in a single account in the general accounts. 
Another weakness of this accounting system is the impossibility of checking a posteriori the level of funds during the year and thus of ensuring that available funds have not been exceeded. 
1.8. Furthermore, it was noted that a balance of approximately ECU 0,02 million was shown on the balance sheet (sundry accounts payable) for which the Agency was unable to provide the Court with the appropriate supporting documents (see consolidation problem mentioned in paragraph 1.6). 
The Agency's budget accounts are still behindhand and could not provide the authorising officers and the financial controller with the information they need if the former are to commit themselves legally in respect of third parties and the latter to give his approval to the proposals for commitments that are submitted to him. 
For this reason, the Agency has had to set up a parallel system for monitoring the implementation of the budget so as not to exceed available appropriations, as it did during the previous financial year (see report on the implementation of the 1995 budget), and to enable the authorising officers to check at all times the level of commitment of the funds for which they are responsible (failure to observe Articles 58 and 59 of the implementing provisions for the Commission's Financial Regulation, so apply to the EEA, as the Agency has not adopted its own implementing provisions). 
As the Sincom 2 system is unlikely to be available within a reasonable time, the Agency should preferably seek an alternative solution so as to have an effective accounting system at its disposal.

C 393/62 1 EN | Official Journal of the European Communities 29. 12. 97 REPLIES OF THE EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR SAFETY AND HEALTH AT WORK The Court of Auditors visited the Agency for Safety and Health at Work from 12 to 16 May 1997 and carried out the audit for the financial year 1996. 
The Director presented the objectives, programme and activities carried out, under way or planned. 
In order to facilitate the work of the Court, the accounts and all relevant supporting documents were made available to the Court. 
The personnel files and the contracts concluded were also presented. 
The Court forwarded its preliminary comments with a view to drawing up the report on the financial statements of the Agency (financial year 1996) in its letter No 001594 of 15 July 1997. 
The Agency, which welcomes the conclusions drawn in paragraph 1.4 of the Court of Auditors' draft report, in so far as the Court states that the financial statements for the financial year 1996 were reliable and, on the whole, the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions were guaranteed, would like to comment on the following paragraphs. 
Paragraph 1.5. 
The breakdown is incomplete because when the budget was drawn up in 1995 it was not possible to plan in detail the budgetary requirements for the financial year 1996 and to include specific amounts; this was due to the fact that the Agency was in its start-up phase. 
As a result, 'token entry' was entered in most chapters. 
Paragraph 1.6. 
It is true that there is no documentary evidence to show that the Administrative Board of the Agency approved the amendments to the initial budget for 1996. 
In order to avoid a similar situation in the future it was agreed, at the meeting of the Bureau of the Administrative Board on 5 and 6 June 1997, that the minutes of meetings would include, in addition to the account of the discussions at meetings, a document explaining the formal decisions taken, in order to facilitate their retrieval. 
Paragraph 1.7. 
The Agency does not indeed possess suitable software for its budgetary accounts and it is provisionally using Excel. 
In order to overcome this, the Agency has joined forces with the other Agencies to analyse the feasibility of an integrated software package such as the prototype of the beta version of SI2 provided by the European Commission. 
Moreover, the Agency is following with interest the progress of the software being developed by Cedefop in Salonika, which would appear to meet our needs as it comprises a budgetary and accounting management module as well as human resource management modules. 
The Bilbao Agency will take a decision before the end of the year on the installation of one system or another, depending on the results of tests using both systems and the opinion of the supervisory bodies (Financial Controller and Court of Auditors). 
The Agency is doing all it can to improve the administration of its Imprest account and in September 1997 installed the RAI software with the assistance of the EMCDDA in Lisbon. 
Paragraph 1.8. 
In order to make good the deficiency described by the Court of Auditors, the Agency acquired Cubic software in June 1997 which, the training of the competent staff having been completed, is already being used to keep the general accounts. 
Paragraph 1.9. 
It is true that the implementation of the budget for 1996 was adversely affected by the delay in the recruitment of the Director and staff for the administration unit of the Agency. 
The staff were only recruited in May 1997, when the head of the unit and two assistants (a computer expert and a financial officer) took up their posts. 
This means that the gradual introduction of all the systems necessary to ensure sound financial management (staff management, budgetary and accounting management, conclusion of contracts and general services) did not begin until after the said date. 
Paragraph 1.10. 
At the time of the negotiations on the seat of the Agency the Basque Government and the County of Vizcaya committed themselves to pay 75 % of the cost of the rent of the office building occupied by the Agency. 
Despite the 
29. 12. 97 1 EN Official Journal of the European Communities C 393/63 absence of an agreement signed between the Agency and the Basque authorities to this effect, the Basque Government has, as of September 1997, paid the Agency a subsidy of Pta 20 million and the County of Vizcaya has initiated the necessary procedures for the payment of its subsidy of Pta 10 million. 
Paragraph 1.11. 
In accordance with the provisions of its Financial Regulation, the Agency is doing all it can to make good the deficiencies pointed out by the Court of Auditors as regards public contracts and has recently submitted a draft Regulation for the creation of an ACPC for the opinion of the Financial Controller at the Commission and to the Court of Auditors for information; the Regulation is based, as far as possible, on the models adopted by the other Agencies. 
As regards the contracts for the procurement of goods and services concluded by the Agency, notably since the audit conducted by the Court in May 1997, it should be pointed out that invitations to tender have always been issued, even where the value of the estimated expenditure would have allowed private treaty. 
The Agency would like to assure the Court that it is doing all it can to acquire, as quickly as possible, all the means necessary to carry out the improvements indicated by the Court of Auditors. 
It would ask the Court to take account of the difficulties it has had in its start-up phase in respecting in full the rules arising from Financial and other Regulations to which all its activities should be subject. 
Notice TO READERS In 1998 several changes to the Official Journal (OJ) L & C subscription will be introduced. 
This notice aims to help paying subscribers make an informed choice about the new possibilities. 
EU LAW SERVICE Starting in January 1998, the full text (including tables and graphics) of new editions of the OJ L & C will be available in all 11 languages free of charge on the Internet (http://europa.eu.int) for a period of 20 days. 
OJ L&C CD-ROM In 1998 a CD-ROM version of the OJ L & C will be published in quarterly, cumulative, single-language editions. 
Current subscribers to the OJ L & C who purchase the CD-ROM subscription in addition to the paper or microfiche version or CELEX will benefit from a promotional discount of 50 % on the CD-ROM. 
A LAN option will be available. 
Individual copies of each CD-ROM can also be purchased. 
Flat FEE SUBSCRIPTION TO CELEX In Spring 1998 a flat fee subscription to CELEX will be available, offering one year's access at a fixed price (960 ECU), independent of consumption. 
CELEX is the EU's official legal database offering unparalleled coverage of EU legislation since 1951 (http://europa.eu.int/celex). 
Penalties FOR LATE Renewals OF PAPER SUBSCRIPTION Despatch of the paper version of the OJ L & C will be stopped on 31 January 1998 to all paying subscribers who have not renewed their subscription by then. 
Subscribers starting or renewing a subscription to the OJ L & C after this date may choose: (I) not to receive retroactive despatch of missing editions, and pay only for months received; (II) to receive the CD-ROM version of the missing editions, and pay the normal annual subscription fee; (III) to receive the paper version of the missing editions, and pay double for each month requiring retroactive despatch. 
Please note it is now possible to purchase all versions of subscription to the Official Journal L & C (paper, microfiche, off-line and CELEX) from any member of the EUR,-OP sales networks, except document delivery agents. 
Please contact your sales agent for further details on the above.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/5 INCLUDING 1.1. 
In accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (1), the European Court of Auditors is the external partner of EU finances. 
In this capacity, the Court plays the role of the independent Hter of the Union's financial interests, in particular by helping to improve EU financial management. 
More detailed information on the Court's work can be found in its annual reports and annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget, as well as its special reports, landscape analyses and opinions on new or gendered EU legislation or other decisions affecting financial management (2). 
As part of its mandate, the Court annually examines the annual accounts and the underlying accounts of all Union institutions, agencies and other bodies (3). 
This report contains the results of the audit of the EU agencies and other bodies of the Union (together adie Agencies) for the financial year 2017. 
The report is structured as follows: N Chapter 1 gives a review of the agencies and the nature of the inspection of the Court. N Chapter 2 presents the overall results of the inspection. N Chapter 3, each of the 41 agencies, contains a declaration of eligibility, together with the audit judgments and the Court's observations on the eligibility of the agencies' accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying revenue and payments (Vorgnge). 
The EU AGENTURES Different types of agencies contribute to the design and implementation of EU policies at 1.4. 
Agencies are separate entities with their own legal personality, created by an act of secondary law, in order to carry out specific technical and scientific tasks or administrative tasks, thereby contributing to the design and implementation of the political measures taken by the EU institutions. 
Many agencies are clearly visible and have a significant impact on important areas that are important for the daily lives of European citizens, such as health, security, freedom and justice. 
The information contained in Chapter 3 is accompanied by a brief description of the tasks carried out by each agency. 
In this report, the agencies use their respective crazes, which can be taken from the list at the beginning of this report. 
There are three types of agencies: decentralised agencies, executive agencies and other bodies. 
Its main characteristics are below. 
The number of agencies has increased over the years and was 41 agencies in 2017 as shown in Figure 1.1. 
(1) Articles 285 to 287 (OJ C 326, 26.10.2012, p. 169-171). 
(2) Available on the Court's website: (3) Three defence agencies (the European Defence Agency, the European Union Institute for Security Studies and the European Union Satellite Centre) financed by the contributions of the Member States are not tested by the Court but by other independent external agents. 
De C 434/6 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 1.1 Increase in number of agencies Source: European Court of Auditors. 
The Commission's executive agencies, like the Commission itself, are based in Brssel or Luxembourg. 
Decentralised agencies and other bodies are located throughout the EU and are spread across 23 different Member States, as shown in the list of Krzel and Figure 1.2. 
The seat of the agencies shall be decided by the Council or jointly by the Council and the European Parliament. 
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/7 Illustration 1.2 Headquarters of the agencies in the Member States Source: European Court of Auditors. 
Decentralised agencies address specific policy needs 1.8. 
The 32 decentralised agencies (4) play an important role in the preparation and implementation of EU policies, in particular technical, scientific, operational and/or regulatory tasks. 
The main objective is to meet specific political needs and to strengthen European cooperation by combining the expertise and expertise of the EU and national governments. 
The decentralised agencies have been established indefinitely by Regulation of the Council or the European Parliament and of the Council. 
Decentralised agencies operate under the control of a Management Board composed of representatives of the Member States, the Commission and in some agencies also from other parties. 
The Management Board shall define the operational framework to be followed by the Agencies, such as the multiannual and annual work programme, the budget drawdowns and the posts carried out under the responsibility of the respective Executive Directors/Directors. 
Each decentralised agency shall be subject to its own discharge procedure in relation to the implementation of its budget covering staff, administrative and operational expenditure. In most cases, discharge is granted by the European Parliament and the Council (5). 
(4) Cedefop, Eurofound, EEA, ETF, EMA, EMCDDA, CdT, CPVO, EUIPO, EU-OSHA, FRA, EASA, EFSA, EMSA, Eurojust, ECDC, ENISA, ERA, Frontex, GSA, EPA, EFCA, ECHA, EIGE, ACER, Bro des BEREC, Europol, EASO, EBA, EIOPA, ESMA and eu-LISA. 
(5) Two self-financed agencies (CPVO and EUIPO) are subject to the discharge procedure by their Management Board. 
De C 434/8 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 The executive agencies of the Commission carry out EU programmes through 1.10. 
The six Commission Executive Agencies(6) are entrusted with implementing and operational tasks relating to one or more Union programmes. Their duration is limited in time. 
They have been set up by Commission decision and operate under the supervision of a steering committee appointed by the Commission. 
Their work is based on multiannual and annual work programmes established and implemented under the responsibility of an Executive Director. 
They are subject to individual discharge procedures by the European Parliament and the Council for their own budgets. 
In contrast to decentralised agencies, their budgets cover only human resources and administrative expenditure, while all the operational expenditure they cover comes from the Commission's budget and is therefore part of the total relief granted to the Commission. 
The own budget of the executive agencies therefore corresponds only to a very small part of the budget they actually carry out. 
The other bodies have specific tasks 1.11. 
The three other bodies are the EIT, the Euratom Supply Agency and the SRB. 
The EIT in Budapest is an independent, decentralised EU body that leverages science, business and education resources to boost the Union's innovative capacity by providing financial support. 
The Institute was established indefinitely by the European Parliament and the Council. 
It is headed by a Director and supervised by a Management Board and is subject to its own discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council. 
The Euratom Supply Agency in Luxembourg was established by the Council for an indefinite period to support the objectives of the Treaty establishing the European Atomic Energy Community. 
It is subject to its own discharge procedure by the European Parliament and the Council. 
An advisory board composed of members from the Member States shall assist the Euratom Supply Agency in carrying out its tasks by issuing opinions and providing analyses and information. 
The Director-General of the Euratom Supply Agency shall work under the supervision of the Commission. 
The SRB is the central resolution authority in the Banking Union and is based in Brssel. 
The SRB is responsible for the orderly resolution of insolvency-threatening banks with a minimum impact on the real economy, the financial system and the public finances of the participating Member States and beyond. 
The SRB shall be reprsented by its Chairperson, who also performs the role of the appointing officer. 
The Chairperson of the SRB shall be subject to a separate discharge procedure by the Board, which invites members of the national resolution authorities of the participating Member States. 
Agencies are financed from various sources and under different MFF headings 1.15. 
The total budget of all agencies (excluding the SRB) in 2017 amounted to EUR 3.5 billion (2016: 3.4 billion euros). This corresponds to around 2.7 % of the EU's 2017 overall budget (2016: 2.4 %), as shown in Figure 1.3. 
The agencies with the highest increase in 2017 were the GSA and the EIT financed under the MFF (7) subheading 1a (Competitiveness for Growth and Employment), Frontex, EMA and EASO financed under MFF heading 3 (Security and Union Funding). 
In addition, the SRB's 2017 budget in Hhe is EUR 6.6 billion (2016: 11.8 billion euros) (8). 
It consists of the contributions paid by credit institutions to the Single Resolution Fund. 
(6) INEA, REA, EACEA, ERCEA, Chafea and EASME.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/13 The Network of EU Agencies promotes agency-wide cooperation and communication with interested parties 1.21. 
The EU Agencies Network (EUAN) has been set up by the Agencies as an agency-wide forum for cooperation to increase the visibility of agencies, identify and generate potential efficiency gains and add value. 
The EUAN works on the basis of the priorities set out by the agencies in a 5-year strategy agenda (2015-2020) and the annual work programmes, which define the activities and the results to be achieved. 
An important role played by the EUAN is to ensure efficient communication between the agencies and interested parties, mainly to the EU institutions.

The financial year ended December 2017 and (b) the legality and regularity of the underlying accounts.

The Court assessed the reliability of the results of this review in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing and took these into account when drawing up its own audit opinions. 
The Court's assessment of the risks identified is 1.25. 
In order to obtain sufficient certainty, the Court has designed its inspection in such a way as to shed light on the main risks identified. As regards the eligibility of the agencies' accounts, there is generally a low risk 1.26. 
Overall, the Court considers the risk to all agencies to be low in terms of the reliability of the accounts. The accounts of the agencies shall be drawn up using the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer, which are based on internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector. 
The number of material errors identified in the past was small.

There is a low to high risk.

De C 434/16 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 INCLUDING 2.1. 
This chapter provides a review of the results of the agencies' annual audits for 2017 carried out by the Court, as well as further audit work related to the agencies carried out by the Court in the course of 2017. 
OVERALL, THE RESULTS OF THE ANNUAL TESTS OF THE FR AGENCIES IN 2017 ARE POSITIVE 2.3. 
Overall, the Court's audit with regard to the annual accounts of the Agencies for the 31st year The year ended December 2017 and the revenue and payments underlying these accounts the positive results from previous years. 
The Court delivered unbridled opinions on the annual accounts of all agencies. 
According to its assessment, the annual accounts of the agencies present their merging and financial position at 31. In all material respects, in all material respects, the results of their advances and cash flows for the year ended on that date in accordance with their respective financial rules and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer (13) are appropriate in all material respects. 
Absences to emphasise a situation are fundamental to the understanding of the annual accounts 2.5. 
As regards EASO, the Court pointed out that the staff situation in the Bro was exponentially deteriorating. 
The Bro does not currently have the administrative capacity to fill the many vacancies. 
Overall, the staff situation has significantly contributed to the continuation of the bros's activities at present. 
In the case of the SRB, the Court highlighted that the contributions to the Single Resolution Fund are calculated on the basis of the information provided by credit institutions to the Board on the national resolution requirements. 
However, the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework to ensure the reliability of this information. 
We also found that the method for calculating contributions laid down in the legislation is very complex, which entails risks for accuracy. 
For reasons of confidentiality, the Board shall not disclose the data of credit institutions used for the calculation of the Funds; this reduces transparency. 
With regard to ECHA, the Court highlighted that the Agency is partly self-financed and that it receives a fee from each company requesting the registration of chemicals, as provided for in the REACH Regulation.(14) 
The calculation and invoicing of the fees shall be carried out by the Agency on the basis of the information provided by the undertakings at the time of submission of the application. 
The ex-post reviews carried out by the Agency have shown that there is a need for rebate corrections, the total amount of which was not known at the end of 2017. 
This finding shows the constraints of a system which, in too high terms, is based on self-crowding of the applicants. 
With regard to the GSA, the Court pointed out that the outcome of the public procurement procedure for one of the Agency's main contracts (framework agreement worth EUR 1.5 billion) was challenged by one of the tenderers. 
With regard to the two agencies established in London (EMA and EBA), the Court pointed out that they will leave the United Kingdom in 2019 and that their annual accounts, together with the desire to recover, have been drawn up on the basis of the information available at the time of their signature. 
The Court highlighted the impact of the current lease agreements in London and the potentially declining revenue resulting from the withdrawal of the United Knigreich from the EU. 
These are based on internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector. Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18. December 2006 on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Control of Chemicals (REACH)

Absents referring to other facts deal with issues of particular importance 2.15. 
In order to indicate other facts, the reader should draw attention to important points that are neither presented or specified in the annual accounts nor concern the legality and regularity of revenue and payments. 
With regard to the EIT, the Court found that the initial reimbursement rates for Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) were raised towards the end of the Frder period. 
In addition, two KICs have added some new tricks to the annual business splint. 
For one of the KICs, this resulted in a significant EUR change in the original grant decision. 
Significant EUR changes may affect the equal treatment of KICs and are not in line with the Financial Regulation. 
In the case of Frontex, the Court has repeatedly reported since 2014 that the co-operating States often provide insufficient evidence of the expenditure they claim. 
This was also confirmed by this year's testing results. 
In response to the recommendation made by the Court in 2016, Frontex is currently implementing a simplified cost reimbursement model. 
With regard to EBA, EIOPA and ESMA, the Court pointed out that their budgets are partly financed from the European Union funds and partly from direct contributions from the supervisory authorities and/or the supervised bodies of the EU Member States. 
As a result of the decision of the United Knigreich to leave the EU, Behrden's revenue could decline in the future. 
With regard to the GSA, the Court reported that the Agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom, which may need to be relocated. 
With reference to the CdT, the Court pointed to the fact that several agencies increasingly resorted to in-house or other alternative replacements, which meant that the capacitance of the centre was not used to the maximum. 
In addition, there is double effort at European level with regard to the development of monitoring systems and running costs. 
In December 2016, the Bro of the Body of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (Bro des BEREC) mandated the CdT to issue four calls for expressions of interest with a view to drawing up reserve lists, despite the fact that all the posts authorised by the budgetary authority in the establishment plan of the Bros were filled. 
In the Court's view, the assignment issued in December 2016 was not justified. 
The payment made for this contract in March 2017 amounted to 2.5 % of the 2017 budget. 
De C 434/18 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 2.1 Annual audit opinions 2014-2017 on the annual accounts and advances of the agencies Source: European Court of Auditors. 
The Court's observations cover a wide range of topics 2.22. 
The Court made a total of 145 comments concerning 37 agencies in order to highlight important issues and identify areas where there is a need for improvement. 
These comments set out in Chapter 3 are summarised below. 
Major risks lead to significant weaknesses in EASO 2.23. 
In the case of EASO, the Court pointed out the major risks arising from the nature of its activities and the extraordinary challenges posed by the migration crisis. 
These risks were not mitigated by a sound governance structure and effective controls, which led to numerous essential stances against the legislation. 
Since 2014, the Bro has been struggling with a high personnel turnover. The recruitment procedures were suspended in December 2017. 
In addition, neither an internal audit body nor a legal service is established at the Bro, and legal documents are not systematically reviewed. 
Almost all the services tested, which were based on public procurement or recruitment procedures, were systematically affected by significant mismatches related to the determination of the needs of the Bros, the preparation of the tender specifications, the choice of the type of contract, the evaluation and award procedures, the changes and improvements of contracts, the use of the contract and the performance of the services provided, etc. 
These angels are at odds with the basic principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination. 
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/19 Progress towards a more streamlined IT landscape 2.26. 
The operational activities of the agencies are broadly researched and require suitable, sometimes tailor-made IT solutions. 
Nevertheless, central operational and administrative activities are carried out on the basis of the same legal framework, suggesting that their procedures are used and that IT consultations can be used to support these procedures. 
While the agencies made very large progress on the use of financial and accounting systems, the Court reported in its 2016 summary report on the results of the audits at the agencies, a large number of IT services were still used in other key areas such as human resources management and procurement and management. 
The agencies will consider further harmonising IT operations in these areas, in particular to increase cost-efficiency, reduce the risks associated with internal control and strengthen IT governance. 
In 2017, a number of progress was made on IT tools for human resources management when 20 agencies concluded agreements with the Commission on the use of the SYSPER II tool, creating a more uniform IT landscape in this area. 
The majority of the agencies will use the Commission's tool from 1 January 2019, while it will be used in some agencies starting in the third quarter of 2018. 
In this fragmented IT landscape, the use of electronic tools for the procurement of supplies and services (electronic procurement) would also be an important step towards a streamlined IT framework among agencies. 
In accordance with the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation, which entered into force in 2012 and 2013 respectively, all EU institutions and agencies shall design and implement, as far as possible, the submission, storage and processing of data submitted in grant and procurement procedures; they shall establish a common area for electronic data exchange (15), (16) for applicants, candidates and tenderers. 
While no target date has been set in the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation for the implementation of e-procurement, the 2014 EU Directive on public procurement(17) requires the use of electronic means for public procurement in the EU Member States by 2018, and pursuant to the EU directive on electronic invoicing(18), which was also adopted in 2014, it is necessary to allow the receipt of electronic invoices by 2019. 
(15) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012, Article 95(2) e-government. 
(16) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013 of 30 September 2013 on the framework financial regulation for bodies referred to in Article 208 of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council, Art. 79 e-government) 
(17) Directive 2014/24/EU of the European Parliament and of the Council of 26 February 2014 on public procurement and repealing Directive 2004/18/EC

All agencies publish their tenders electronically via TED (Tenders Electronic Daily), the online version of the EU Public Procurement Official Journal. In addition, the Commission launched e-invoicing tools (2010), the electronic publication of contract notice documents in the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). By the end of 2017, most agencies had introduced e-invoicing and electronic tendering for certain procedures, but not the electronic submission of tenders. 
Improvement in IT consulting services and project management at EMA and eu-LISA IT consulting services and project management at EMA 2.30. 
In the course of the audit carried out last year, the Court analysed how the agency manages advisory services. 
The extensive use of consulting firms has led to a critical affiliation of external expertise. 
The Court also reported that the control of project development and implementation was insufficient and that the projects resulted in appreciable distortions and cost increases. 
In the course of 2017, the agency took several measures to improve the situation. 
However, it will take time to reduce the critical adequacy of the agency of consulting firms, and the impact of the measures taken will only show up in the years. 
It consulting services and project management at eu-LISA 2.32. 
The Agency mainly uses consulting services in connection with IT projects due to the nature of its activity. 
In 2017, the Agency's IT projects were implemented within the financial and time frame. 
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which around 90 % of the corresponding work is carried out by three contractors. 
Although the IT projects are owned and controlled by the Agency, a model in which the development capacities for such sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent entails the risk of excessive adequacy from the contractors. 
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/21 2.34. 
At the same time, the small number of staff in operational key units creates a risk for the continuance of the holding. 
Public procurement is intended to ensure competition between economic operators and to ensure the most economically viable purchase, with a transparent, objective and consistent approach on the basis of the current legal framework. 
We identified 14 agencies (Bro des BEREC, EPA, Chafea, eu-LISA, EASO, EBA, EEA, EFSA, EIGE, EUIPO, ERA, EASA, FRA and SRB) Mngel in the field of public procurement, mostly in relation to services that pose risks for optimal use of funds. 
Among the most frequently identified mismatches, the lack of a balanced relationship between price and quality aspects in the award criteria, the lack of optimal design of the framework agreements, the use of framework agreements allowing the procurement of services, the description and/or price of which were not sufficiently defined and the use of intermediary services. 
Most agencies analysed the impact of Brexit 2.36. On 29. In March 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit). 
Unlike most other agencies, fnf agencies (ACER, Bro des BEREC, EPA, ENISA and EU-OSHA) did not carry out a comprehensive analysis of the potential impact of Brexit on their organisation, operational discharges and accounting. 
Vacancy notices were published on the EPSO website 2.37. 
Most agencies (ACER, Cedefop, EPA, Chafea, EASA, EBA, ECHA, EEA, EIGE, EIOPA, EIT, EMA, EMCDDA, EMSA, ENISA, ESMA, eu-LISA, Eurojust, Europol, Frontex, GSA and SRB) publish vacancy notices on their own websites and on social media, but often not on the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). 
A publication on the EPSO website would increase transparency and publicity and allow Brgers to view vacancy notices from all European institutions. 
The main reason cited by the agencies is that EPSO requires the publication of vacancy notices in all the official languages of the EU, which entails high replacement costs. 
Fewer comments on the legality and regularity of payments 2.38. 
The number of comments on the legality and regularity of payments decreased to eight (2016: 11), which illustrates the continued commitment of the agencies to comply with the legal framework, in particular the provisions of the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation and the Staff Regulations. 
While fnf comments again concerned Mngel in relation to procurement procedures (EASO, EASA, EIGE and Frontex), three were related to recruitment procedures (EASO, Cedefop and Frontex). 
Budget management has improved 2.39. 
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, budget appropriations for a given year may be transferred to the next year under certain conditions (19). 
It is true that the Financial Regulation does not set any ceilings for such transfers and the multi-annual nature of the operations also largely justified. Nevertheless, outstanding transfers may be an indication of distortions in the implementation of work programmes or procurement procedures and may also be contrary to the budgetary principle of honorability. 
Illustration 2.4 shows how many agencies the Court reported in 2017 and in previous years on high budget transfers. 
The move to only two agencies (Chafea and EU-OSHA) in 2017 should be attributed to the fact that the agency's contributions have been better and more transparently lured and welcomed, but also to the Court's gendered approach to reporting in 2017. 
(19) The conditions for transfers are met in Article 13 of the Financial Regulation. 
De C 434/22 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 2.4 Less comments on excessive or high appropriations Source: European Court of Auditors based on information provided by the agencies. 
In addition, the Court found that two agencies (Frontex and EUIPO) cancelled budget appropriations from previous years. 
This was an indication that the need for funds was overestimated, in particular by the public authorities of the Member States and other cooperating States. 
Accounting could be further improved 2.42. 
In the course of this year's audits, the Court also reviewed the accounts of the agencies, which has an important role to play in drawing up the annual accounts. 
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, each agency has its own accounting officer. This has led to a total of 37 accounting directors responsible for 2 % of the EU budget. 
The main tasks of the accounting officer are the acquisition of payments, the acceptance of receipts and the recovery of the receivables, the preparation and presentation of the annual accounts as well as the accounting management, the establishment and validation of the accounting systems and the cash management. 
In order to increase efficiency, the Commission's accounting officer requested all agencies to delegate their accounting function on a contract basis in 2012. 
The first agency to adopt this proposal was the EPO in 2014. 
By the end of 2017, only three other agencies (GSA, Bro des BEREC and ACER) had joined the scheme. 
The hierarchical position of an accounting officer within an agency may affect his independence. 
In particular, the accounting directors must be independent of persons who are (subordinately) able to make commitments, enter into legal commitments and direct payments. 
This comment concerns a total of 13 agencies (CdT, EACEA, EASA, EASME, EEA, EFSA, EIOPA, EMA, EMCDDA, ERA, EU-OSHA, Eurofound and FRA). 
The designation and annual appraisal of the accounting officer should then also fall within the scope of the Board of Directors. 
In accordance with the Financial Regulation, accounting directors must insist that the agencies' accounting systems function properly (validation). 
While the validation of the accounting systems of most agencies is up-to-date, we found that the accounting systems of seven agencies (ACER, Bro des BEREC, EPA, EASME, EIT, EMA and GSA) were subject to timely revalidation due to major EUR changes. 
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/23 Illustration 2.5 Status of the independence of the agencies' auditors and the revalidation of accounting systems Source: European Court of Auditors based on information provided by the agencies. 
In three agencies (EASO, CPVO and REA), procurement, grant and recruitment procedures have been undeniably documented. 
In three agencies (ACER, EIT and Frontex), Mngel was identified in the implementation of the Internal Control Standard concerning the Emergency Plne. 
In the event of catastrophes, these angels could present a significant risk for the maintenance of business operations, as data could be irrevocably lost. 
Agencies continue to track audit findings from previous years 2.47. 
Where applicable, the Court reported on the state of play of the follow-up measures taken by the agencies following comments from previous years. 
Figure 2.6 shows that the correction measures related to the 170 comments not yet implemented at the end of 2016 were completed or underway in most cases. 
Of the 13 outstanding observations, the corrective measures required for three observations were not subject to the Agency's control.

Special report by the Court on SRB 2.51. 
The Single Resolution Board (SRB) based in Brssel was established in August 2014. It is part of the political response to the financial crisis. 
The Board's task is to resolve insolvency-threatening banks that fall within its scope. 
In January 2017, the SRB was responsible for 139 banks, including 130 banking groups (21). 
In the context of the inspection (22), it was examined whether the Committee was in favour of effectively winding up banks. Particular attention was paid to the quality of resolution planning for individual banks and whether the Board was properly prepared to meet the legal requirements in the area of resolution planning and provided sufficient human resources to carry out its tasks. 
We identified deficits in all these areas. However, since the establishment of the Committee as a completely new structure was a huge challenge, the weaknesses should be seen against this background. 
The Court made a number of recommendations to the Board with regard to the preparation of resolution plenums and the completion of its rules and guidelines, with a view to increasing staff and improving human resources management procedures. 
(21) On 1 January 2018, the number decreased to 127 banks and 119 banking groups. 
(22) Special Report No 23/2017: aSingle Resolution Board: First steps have been taken on the challenging path to the banking union, but it is still a long way to reach the goal, published on 19. December 2017. 
De C 434/26 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Special annual report of the Court on contingent liabilities resulting from the performance of the Single Resolution Board 2.54. 
In accordance with the Regulation on the Single Resolution Mechanism (23), the Court must draw up a report on all contingent liabilities resulting from the fact that the Board, the Council and the Commission carry out their tasks under this Regulation. 
At 31. In December 2016, the contingent liabilities of the Committee resulting from the ex-ante contributions amounted to EUR 842 million, which increased to EUR 1 420 million as of 30 September 2017. 
In 2016, the Board did not initiate bank resolution and, consequently, no contingent liability related to resolution decisions was to be reported for the financial year 2016. 
However, at the time the Court's 2016 report was published on contingent liabilities resulting from the Board's performance of its tasks, 90 legal proceedings against the Board had been brought before the General Court of the European Union by the end of October 2017 on the resolution decision taken in June 2017 with regard to Banco Popular Espaol S.A. and 46 complaints were lodged with the SRB Board of Appeals. 
The Commission and the Council were informed of 26 proceedings brought before the General Court in connection with the above-mentioned resolution decision.
