De C 434/28 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE NETCWERKS OF THE EU AGENTURES The Agencies welcome the Court's positive conclusions on the reliability of their annual accounts and the accounts underlying those accounts. 
The network expressed its concerns that given the fact that the Commission only provides them with a basic package of modules in Sysper, the Agencies will be forced to continue to use separate tools for assessment, teleworking, flexitime and staff reporting. 
The IT landscape in the field of human resources management will therefore only become partially more uniform and even less so than the Commission can decide. 
The Agencies also consider the possibility of carrying out a joint operation for the services concerned in order to support recruitment procedures not currently covered by Sysper. 
In the field of procurement, there has definitely been a development towards harmonisation of electronic tools over the last two years. 
This development began in 2015/2016 when the e-PRIOR/electronic procurement tools designed by DG DIGIT in cooperation with DG BUDG were developed. 
Since then, this set of electronic modules for all phases of the procurement cycle has become more and more a standard that agencies adhere to. 
In 2018, this trend continued to grow when new modules for electronic submission and the ABAC LCK module were introduced and made available to the agencies. 
Little by little, the agencies put the use of their own isolated tools in some fast, some less fast, but relentless of how quickly this development is going to take place, the trend in itself is not in itself. 
In practice, the proposed efficiencies that could be achieved through the transfer of accounting tasks to the European Commission are difficult to achieve. 
The required workload not only depends on the balance of the budget, but it must also be taken into account that the annual accounts must be finalised at the beginning of each year in a tight time window. 
Experience shows that almost twice as much staff is required for the conclusion of more than one package of annual accounts (i.e. with additional financing through delegation agreements), although the corresponding betrge are smaller (and the financial assets paid less). 
However, when transferring these assets to the Commission, each agency would still have an accounting team, as accounting tasks still need to be carried out. 
As long as this is the case, any savings in staff would not be equivalent to a full-time equivalent. 
In addition, the annual fee must still be paid. 
For this reason, only a few agencies have decided to give this task to the Commission. 
The network would like to point out that no investigation or risk assessment has yet been carried out to justify the conclusion that the irresponsibility of the accounting officer would have been stalled if he was directly subordinated to the authorising officer and not to a duly authorised authorising officer. 
Some agencies have decided to adopt a charter of accounts, including rules for reporting to the governing body where necessary.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/31 3.1. 
We have carried out our testing in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing (ISA) as well as the professional behaviour requirements of the IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Officers (ISSAI) of INTOSAI. 
Our responsibilities according to these standards are further described in the section of our report. 
We are independent in accordance with the Code of Ethics for Professional Accountants of the International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants (IESBA Code) as well as the professional behavior requirements relevant to our testing, and we have fulfilled our other professional behavioral obligations in accordance with these requirements and the IESBA Code. 
We believe that the proofs we obtain are sufficient and suitable to serve as the basis for our examination judgment. 
Responsibilities of management and those responsible for monitoring 3.1.2. 
In accordance with Articles 310 to 325 TFEU and the financial regulations of the agencies, management is responsible for drawing up and presenting annual accounts on the basis of internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector as well as for the legality and regularity of the underlying accounts. 
This includes the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures, as necessary for the preparation and presentation of an annual financial statement free of material misrepresentations intended or unintentional. 
The management of the agencies bears the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the assets underlying their annual accounts. 
When drawing up the annual accounts, the management is responsible for assessing the ability of the agencies to continue business, to state facts relating to the continuation of business, where relevant, and to apply the accounting principle of continuing business, unless management intends to either liquidate the entity or discontinue business, or does not have a realistic alternative to it. 
Responsibilities of the author for the preparation of the annual accounts and the underlying claims 3.1.5. 
Our objectives are to obtain sufficient certainty as to whether the annual accounts of the agencies are free from material misrepresentation and the underlying claims are legal and orderly, as well as to the European Parliament and the Council or other relevant discharge requirements based on our examination of the eligibility of the agencies' billing, as well as the legality and regularity of the underlying advances. 
Misrepresentations and misrepresentations may be intended or unintentional and are considered material if they could reasonably be expected, individually or collectively, to take into account the economic decisions taken by users on the basis of those accounts. 
3.1.6. 
With regard to revenue, we review the grants received by the agencies from the Commission or co-operating States and assess, where relevant, their procedures for collecting fees and other revenue. 
3.1.7. 
With regard to expenditure, we examine the payment advances after the expenditure has been settled, recorded and accepted. 
Advance payments are checked after the fund has proven their proper use and the Agency has accepted the evidence by settlement of the advance payment in the same year or even in the same year. 
3.1.8. 
As part of an inspection in accordance with the ISA and ISSAI, we exercise a duty of discretion and maintain a critical basic attitude during the entire examination. 
In addition, we identify and assess the risks of significant or unintentional misrepresentations in the annual accounts, as well as material intentional or unintentional understandings against the legal frameworks of the European Union in the underlying advances, plan, plan and conduct inspection acts in response to these risks, as well as obtain proof of verification sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our assessments. 
The risk of material misrepresentation or misrepresentation of legal provisions resulting from doless actions may not be revealed as a result of erroneous acts, since doless acts may involve treacherous interaction, flogging, intended imperfections, erroneous representations or the replacement of internal controls; 
The Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 we gain an understanding of the internal control system relevant to the inspection in order to plan procedures that are appropriate under the circumstances, but not with the aim of issuing a test judgement on the effectiveness of the internal control system; we assess the adequacy of the accounting policies applied by management, as well as the reasonableness of the financial statements presented by the management and constraints; we conclude with regard to the adequacy of the management's application of the accounting principle of continuing business and on the basis of the audit evidence obtained whether there is a material uncertainty in connection with events or circumstances that may raise significant doubts as to the ability of an agency to continue its business. 
If we conclude that there is material uncertainty, we are obliged to draw attention to the information required in the annual accounts in our note from the financial statements or, if this information is inappropriate, to modify our audit opinion. 
We draw our conclusions on the basis of the audit evidence obtained by the date of our final report. 
We are responsible for the instructions, supervision and execution of the inspection. 
DE 3.1.9. 
We discuss with the management, among other things, on the planned scope and the planned timing of the inspection as well as on significant inspection findings, including any significant mismatches in the internal control system, which we recognise during our inspection. 
3.1.10. 
We determine the facts about which we have exchanged with the agencies, those which were most important for the preparation of the annual accounts of the current period and are therefore the particularly important aspects of auditing. 
We describe these facts in our Note of the Final Report, unless laws or other legal provisions exclude the disclosure of the facts to the public or we determine in very rare cases that a situation should not be communicated in our Note of the Final Report, because it is reasonable to expect that the negative consequences of such communication would exceed its benefits for the public interest. 
(24) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012.

As a result, the backup data is now stored at the same location as the original data. 
As a result, there is a significant risk for the maintenance of business operations in the event of disasters, as data could be irrevocably lost. EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/37 ANTWORD OF THE AGENTUR 3.2.8. 
The Agency agrees with the outcome and clarifies that the Agency records all financial transactions in the financial system provided by the European Commission, updated, maintained and validated by the Commission. 
With the outsourcing of accounting from October 2017 to the Commission, the Agency will accept the validation of the accounting system provided by the Commission in 2018. 
Since the ARIS prime location and disaster management site migrated to the internal ACER data center at the beginning of April 2016 and integrated into a single site in June 2017 to optimise and revitalise performance and to cope with increasing space requirements, it is no longer possible to maintain operations. 
However, it should be noted that the current situation in which the maintenance of operations cannot be achieved has been imposed on the Agency by the appreciable reduction of its budget over the last two years. 
The Agency has repeatedly warned the Commission and the budgetary authorities about the serious consequences of the budgetary restrictions, but without reaching a result with regard to additional resources. 
The Agency will continue to see the possibility of restoring a disaster management site for ARIS, but without using such funds in 2018. 
The restoration of the disaster management site would require additional financial resources to be provided to the Agency. 
Given that the risks associated with BREXIT were considered low and limited, management carried out only an informal analysis of Brexit in 2017. 
At the beginning of 2018, the Agency published a comprehensive analysis of the impact of Brexit on organisational management, operations and financial areas by highlighting the impact and the necessary measures. 
In 2014, the Agency's Management Board adopted Decision AB 15/2014 on the Agency's language regime. 
Nevertheless, the Agency still needs to translate the vacancy notices published on the EPSO website into all official EU languages. 
Due to the very limited financial resources repeatedly identified by the budget authority, the Agency is unable to pay the replacement costs for each vacancy notice in all official EU languages for the publication of this call on the EPSO website. 
In 2017, four out of nine vacancy notices, including two public calls, were published on the EPSO website and therefore translated into all official EU languages. 
The tendering of positions in operational departments was published only on the Agency's website, as these were mainly of interest to applicants who are already active in the field and who usually follow the agency's measures on our website. 
This approach corresponds to a pragmatic weighting between contacting potential candidates and efficient use of limited resources.

In addition, the competitive procedure covered only the tenderer's administrative fees, but not the potential event costs. 
The award procedure therefore did not result in appropriate price competition, which may not lead to the most economically advantageous offer.

3.3.11. 
The decision on a framework contract was taken in 2015. 
Firmness is considered compatible with the Financial Regulation, as other EU institutions have closed several such contracts and still close (e.g. services provided by travel brokers or banks). 
Due to the specificity of BEREC's activity, a large part of the expenditure on BEREC events covered by the BEREC Bro, concerns the renunciation of experts, predominant by public bodies located in the EU Member States (e.g. NRAs). 
It should therefore be noted that the Contractor has no influence on this type of expenditure. 
Following the observations and the valuable exchange of views with the Court, BEREC will also take into account other types of framework distortions that were not foreseen under the 2015 legal framework when reopening the procurement procedure. 
The Bro of BEREC takes note of the Court's observations and informs the Court that it intends to include these modules by the end of 2018, taking into account the availability of the Agency's budget.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTING PROCEDURE 3.5.8. 
The Court considers it necessary to reduce the independence of the accounting officer by directly reporting to the Director (administrative matters) and the Management Board (functional matters) of the Agency. COMMENTS ON THE RECHTMEURSCURITY AND ORDERALITY OF VORGEURNGE 3.5.9. 
Framework agreements are concluded with companies in order to determine the conditions applicable during the duration of the agreement for certain procurements (individual contracts). 
FR used a framework agreement with three contractors in the cascade system to award IT services of up to EUR 22 million. 
In this procedure, the contractors will be placed in a ranking (the cascade) following a competitive procedure, which must be respected for all individual arrivals. 
However, the terms of the framework agreement were not specific enough to allow fair competition and to justify the establishment of a ranking of the contractors for all strong individual contracts. 
In accordance with the rules of application of the Financial Regulation (54), the individual contracts must be awarded by means of a competitive procedure between the selected contractors. 
3.5.10. 
In accordance with the Agency's financial regulations (55), procurements must be approved by the Board of Directors, either in the Agency's annual work programme or by an ad hoc financing decision. 
An IT framework agreement with a maximum amount of EUR 15 million was tendered and signed, although the financing decision only covered an amount of EUR 5 million. 
In 2014, the Commission concluded, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including EASA), a framework agreement with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software, maintenance and support services (IT services). 
The contractor of the framework agreement shall act as an intermediary between the Agency and companies that can provide the IT services. 
Although most of these IT services and the respective prices were set out in the framework agreement concluded under the competitive procurement procedure, the latter also includes the procurement of non-specific IT services. 
In the case of a verified payment of around EUR 300 000, the Agency had acquired IT services from the contractor without a competitive procedure. 
In 2017, payments totalling EUR 2 million were made to the contractor of the framework agreement.

The European Chemicals Agency (hereinafter 'adie Agentur', also known as aECHA), established in Helsinki by Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council (68). 
Its main task is to ensure a high level of protection for human health and the environment and to ensure the free movement of substances in the internal market while improving competitiveness and innovation. 
The Agency also advocates the development of alternative assessment methods for hazards associated with substances.

De 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/57 Highlighting a situation 3.7.5. 
Without calling into question its assessment, as set out in point 3.7.4, we would like to emphasise that the Agency is partly self-financed and that it is paid a fee from any company requesting the registration of chemicals as provided for in the REACH Regulation (72). 
The applicable fees are based on the size of the enterprises (micro, small, medium and large enterprises) and the quantity of chemicals registered (various quantity thresholds). 
3.7.6. 
As provided for in the Implementing Regulation (73), the Agency's calculation and invoicing shall be carried out on the basis of information provided by undertakings at the time of the application. 
Since the first registrations in 2009, around 30 % of companies have stated that they are micro, small or medium-sized enterprises. 
The Agency made considerable efforts to implement a system for ex-post inspections, which checks the information provided by these applicants on the company's credentials. 
For example, the Agency was able to establish that on the basis of the previously completed reviews, around 55 % of the above mentioned companies, which, according to their own information, were micro, small or medium-sized enterprises (16 % of all enterprises) had misrepresented their size, resulting in lower fees. 
In order to remedy the situation, the Agency has invoiced approximately 16.4 million Euros as a result of ex-post reviews over the years for correction purposes. 
However, the checks are significant in the rectangle, and the remaining amount of the necessary corrections was not known at the end of 2017 (74). 
This finding shows the constraints of a system which, in too high terms, is based on self-crowding of the applicants. 
The REACH Regulation stipulates that the verification of the quantities declared by the companies is the responsibility of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement. 
The Agency is therefore not involved in the review of this second element for the calculation of the rebate. 
Payments Judgment on the legality and regularity of payments underlying the annual accounts 3.7.8. 
According to our assessment, those of the annual accounts for the 31st In all material respects, payments underpinning the financial year ending December 2017 are legal and regular in all respects. 
3.7.9. 
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.7.10. 
The Agency's ex-post reviews have shown that for more than half of the companies registered and reported to be micro-enterprises, small or medium-sized enterprises, the information on the size was incorrect (see the paragraph highlighting a situation in point 3.7.5). 
This can be explained in part by the complex provisions of the Commission on the determination of company sizes (75) and partly by the financial incentive to indicate a too small size, since the registration fees for larger companies are far higher. 
Given that the original registration fees are collected on the basis of the company's stated data, false information may have a significant negative impact on the Agency's revenue if they are not detected. 
Although the Agency reviews the specified size for smaller companies in the context of ex-post inspections, the reviews have been completed significantly at the rectification level and only until 2012 (for the years with the largest quantities of chemicals registered).

(74) Ex-post inspections for registrations were completed by the end of 2017, but are still underway for the following years.

If errors are detected, the Agency shall charge the difference between the original fee paid and the final fee, as well as an administrative fee. 
On 31. In December 2017, the amount to be recovered amounted to EUR 4.7 million, of which EUR 3.2 million was related to administrative charges. 
However, the Agency appears to encounter difficulties in recovering administrative charges. 
In its 2017 annual accounts, the Agency recorded a receivable receivable position of EUR 2.8 million (i.e. EUR 600 000 more than at the end of 2016). 
3.7.12. 
The inspection of the quantities declared by the undertakings is the responsibility of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement; the Agency has no enforcement powers (see paragraph highlighting a situation in point 3.7.5). 
The measures taken by the enforcement authorities of the Member States shall be coordinated by the Forum for the exchange of information on enforcement. 
On 6. In December 2017, the Forum adopted new strategies and minimum criteria for the enforcement of chemical regulations (astrategies and minimum criteria for enforcement of chemical regulations), which provide a framework for the development of national enforcement strategies. 
The Agency's ability to fulfil its mission depends on the effectiveness of the practical implementation of this framework by the national authorities. 
In its 2017 general report, the Agency states that around two thirds of companies did not update the registered information on the quantities of chemicals they handle. 
This implies the effective implementation of the REACH Regulation and, in addition, the accuracy of the calculation of the rebate. 
COMMENTS ON THE SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.7.13. The Agency publishes vacancy notices on its own website and on social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). 
OTHER COMMENTS 3.7.14. 
The Agency's revenue from fees is linked to the registration deadlines for chemicals in the EU set out in the REACH Regulation (2010, 2013 and 2018). 
The Agency therefore does not charge any regular fees and, with a mismatch between relatively stable expenditure and staggering, less foreseeable revenue, has to pluck, which makes budget planning more difficult. 
In dealing with this situation, the Agency shall be assisted by a grant which it receives from the Commission. 
As the third and final registration period for chemicals under the REACH Regulation is exhausted in 2018, the revenue from fees and charges is expected to decrease from 2019 onwards and that the Agency will be subtracted from the EU budget in financing its operations.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/59 Year 2014 2016 2016 2016 State of revision (completed/in progress/e.g.) In progress (1) In progress pending ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years' observations of the Court's observations on procedures related to a new specific activity of the Agency, the implementation of the Regulation on biocidal products, were in principle covered by requests for the assessment of the antrge for the registration of these products. 
However, the fees collected in 2014 covered only 17 % of this expenditure, so that the bulk was actually financed by the Union (6,3 million euro) and EFTA countries (0.2 million euro) to the Agency's budget. With 10.1 million euros or 39 % (2015: 7.3 million euro and 32 % respectively, the rate of committed appropriations for the following financial year remained high for Title III (Operational Expenditure). For Title IV (Operational Expenditure) it fell at 1.3 million euro and 68 % (2015: 1.5 million euros, or 74 %, are even higher. 
Such a high transfer rate is at odds with the budgetary principle of honor. The Agency may take into account the use of separate budgetary resources in order to better reflect the multi-year nature of the activities and the inevitable distortions between signatures, deliveries and payments. 
In accordance with the Biocidal Products Regulation, ECHA contributes to the functioning of the market for biocides and biocidal products. 
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the structure and practical implementation of ECHA's internal control system with regard to the Agency's processes and activities under the Biocidal Products Regulation is effective and efficient. 
Although no serious mismatches have been identified, the IAS still sees a need for improvement. 
Unlike most other agencies, periodic external evaluations of their activities, which are essential for performance evaluation, are not explicitly required in the ECHA's Grndung Regulation.

De C 434/60 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 ANTWORD OF THE AGENTUR 3.7.10. 
The relevant legislation (REACH Ordinance (EC) 340/2008) does not provide that the Agency should carry out an ex-post review of the size of all SME registrants. 
The Agency's Board of Directors approved a concept whereby SME registrants with the largest financial impact (i.e. with the majority of registrations within the larger quantity range) are given priority. 
The Agency is currently reviewing the company credentials of SME registrants who submitted their dossiers by 2015. In 2017, the Agency also focused its attention on SME registrants from the United Knigreich in order to review their company credentials prior to the withdrawal of the United Knigreich from the European Union. 
In the future, we are increasingly carrying out the agency's assessment of the size of SMEs on the basis of the cost-benefit principle. 
3.7.11. 
The REACH Remuneration Regulation (EC) No 340/2008 does not provide the Agency with tools necessary for the enforcement of the collection of administrative charges. 
The Agency proactively reminds debtors of their payment obligation. If this does not succeed, it entrusts local law firms to claim the outstanding fees and fees directly in the Member States. 
The law firms have so far contacted 74 % of the companies that are required to pay administrative fees. The result of this initiative will then be subject to a cost-benefit analysis to identify the next steps. 
Member States have the primary responsibility for enforcing the REACH and CLP Regulations, in particular the obligation to register chemicals. 
The Agency's ability to fulfil its mission and to obtain revenue from the fees to an appropriate extent depends on the effectiveness of the practical implementation of enforcement strategies by the national authorities. 
Discussions with the Commission will be conducted in order to address this problem. 
3.7.13. 
The Agency takes note of the comments submitted. This is a horizontal matter that concerns a number of agencies. 
The Agency publishes vacancy notices like other agencies on its own website, on social media and on the website of the EU Agencies Network (EUAN) (https://euagencies.eu/). 
The Agency recommends that the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) refer to the EUAN website in order to increase transparency and publicity and to allow Brgers to view vacancy notices. 
3.7.14. 
The preliminary remark is correct. 
The Agency shall be financed by a combination of revenue through fees and fees and from a compensatory grant from the European Union. 
The Agency has submitted to the Commission a number of alternative financing proposals, including the introduction of regular fees, as with some other EU agencies. 
The Agency points out that according to its Communication on the review of the REACH Regulation of 5. Mr 2018 (COM(2018) 116 final) will explore all possible options to ensure sustainable financing of the Agency in the future.

EUROPEAN SUPERVISORY BOARD RDE FR INSURANCE AND OCCUPATIONAL PENSIONS (EIOPA) INTRODUCTION 3.8.1. 
The European Insurance and Occupational Pensions Authority (hereinafter referred to as "adie Behrde" (also known as "aEIOPA"), established in Frankfurt, was established by Regulation (EU) No 1094/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council (76). 
The task of the Behrde is to contribute to the establishment of high-quality common regulatory and supervisory standards and practices, to contribute to the cohesive application of the binding Union acts, to encourage and facilitate the delegation of tasks and to facilitate the delegation of tasks and to facilitate the monitoring and evaluation of market developments in their field of competence, and to encourage the protection of policyholders, pensioners and beneficiaries.

EUROPEAN INSTITUTE OF INNOVATION AND TECHNOLOGY (EIT) INTRODUCTION 3.9.1. 
The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter adas Institute), also established in Budapest, was established by Regulation (EC) No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (82). 
The aim of the Institute is to contribute to sustainable economic growth in Europe and to increase competitiveness by stepping up the innovation capacitance of the Member States and the European Union. 
The Institute is seeking financial support for an increasing number of Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) that interconnect higher education, research and business, thereby fostering innovation and entrepreneurship. 
The KICs coordinate the activities of hundreds of partners.

Other comments 3.9.7. 
In December 2016, shortly before the end of the Frder period (1 January 2016-31. The EIT signed amendments to the Specific Grant Agreements with KICs EIT Digital, InnoEnergy, Health and RawMaterials. 
The EUR amendment to the Specific Grant Agreement with Climate KIC was signed even in January 2017, after the end of the Frder Period. 
The increase in the individual reimbursements agreed in these EUR changes allowed KICs to receive 15 million euros in financial assistance from the EIT (6.0 million euro in addition to Climate KICs, 5.6 million euros for EIT Health, EUR 2.2 million for KIC InnoEnergy and 1.2 million euros for EIT RawMaterials). 
This approach is at odds with the intention of encouraging the KICs to develop sources of funding and to encourage them to gradually reduce their financial adequacy from the EIT. 
It could also affect fair competition between the KICs, as the co-financing of expenditure also plays a role in the annual grant decisions. 
3.9.8. 
Also due to changes in the business of KIC InnoEnergy and EIT Digital, a number of activities not foreseen in the original business units were added to the total value of around 3.3 million euros and 0.6 million euros respectively. 
In the case of KIC InnoEnergy, the Court considers that it is a substantial change in the original business plan on the basis of which the maximum amount of the grant was applied. 
Since the Hhe of the grants awarded to the individual KICs is the result of a performance-based assessment procedure to which its originally proposed operations will be subjected, substantial changes to these funds call into question the grant decisions and equal treatment of the KICs and thus constitute a breach of Article 180(4) of the Rules of Application for the Financial Regulation. 
3.9.9. 
COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTS 3.9.10. 
In 2017, the institution introduced a paperless payment system. 
Although this has led to changes in its procedures and accounting system, the accounting system has not been revalidated since 2012. 
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.9.11. 
In order to further strengthen the internal control system for grants to KICs, the EIT carried out centralised ex ante controls for those KIC partners whose cost statements exceeded EUR 325 000. 
The checks were carried out by two business inspection companies on behalf of the EIT (86) and carried out on certified cost statements of the KIC partners. 
The results of the ex-post controls carried out by another economic survey company mandated by the EIT confirm that the new approach to the certified cost statements is effective and important, as most of the material errors found concerned cost statements that had not been subject to these ex ante controls. 
(86) In previous years, certification was carried out by a large number of private companies on behalf of each KIC partner whose submitted cost statements exceeded the threshold of EUR 325 000 (reimbursement of actual costs and unit costs). 
De C 434/66 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.12. 
The business continuity plan and the EIT disaster recovery plan were adopted in 2013 and are outdated. 
For example, more than half of the members of the crisis management team did not work for the EIT in 2017. 
An updated version of the Plne has been working for two years, but it has not yet been adopted. 
As in previous years, the KICs did not take full advantage of the EIT-funded grants. 
The accepted total cost of the KIC added-value activities of the fnf KICs, which were functional before 2016 (KICs of the first and second wave taken together), were adopted by 15 % compared to the specific grant agreements concluded at the beginning of 2016 (87). 
The fact that the funds were not used was mainly due to the incomplete implementation of the business operations due partly to the approval of the grant agreements and the multi-annual nature of the KIC activities, as well as the in-house financing ratio of the administrative costs incurred by some KICs than planned. 
Part of this appropriation has been used to increase the early costs related to KIC added-value activity originally defined (see paragraph 3.9.7). 
In particular, the KICs of the second wave (EIT Health and RawMaterials) had to pluck with distortions when starting their activities. 
For the KICs of the first wave, according to the evaluation reports of the EIT, the performance of Climate KICs in particular was insufficient. 
3.9.14. 
The EIT underwent a performance assessment for the implementation of the business and then calculated some corrections. 
However, these corrections had no financial impact on any of the KICs. 
In line with the Horizon 2020 methodology for grant calculation, the EIT applies only those of the two in the case of corrections that become necessary due to financial controls and performance assessments. 
While this methodology is appropriate for individual Horizon 2020 projects, it is less suitable for the grants awarded to the KICs, which finance a wide range of different activities. 
It is questionable whether it is justified to offset corrections to be made on the basis of performance, for example in the case of educational activities, against corrections to be made on the basis of financial controls, which may, for example, affect innovation projects. 
3.9.15. 
In 2017, all KICs adopted strategies for sustainable financing in line with the EIT Guidelines, which is an important step towards a greater impact of the KICs in the future. 
Nevertheless, the KICs of the first wave continued to generate little revenue (between 2 % and 6 % of the cost of KIC value-added activities) and little progress was recorded in 2017. 
Co-financing by the KIC partners is also still low (and lower than those provided for in the original specific grant agreements): The KIC added-value activities are still financed from 62 % to 90 % by EIT grants, depending on the KIC. 
3.9.16. 
The EIT publishes vacancy notices on its own website and on DG Human Resources and Security's website, but usually not on the European Personnel Selection Office's website (EPSO). 
3.9.17. 
In accordance with their Framework Financial Regulation, the Agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (88). As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT system covering all phases of public procurement procedures. 
It launched e-invoicing tools (2010), the electronic invitation to tender in the online edition of the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).

Consequently, the EIT may only offer temporary employment to its temporary staff with a maximum duration of five years, which can be applied once by fnf years. 
Those employees who started their activity at the EIT shortly after its establishment in 2009 will reach the maximum contract term of ten years in 2020, which in the coming years could lead to the continuance of measures and administration.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/69 DE Comments of the Court of Auditors of the EIT Regulation on the tasks of the Institute for the mobilisation of funds from public and private sources and [the] use of resources in accordance with the provisions of this Regulation. 
In particular, the Institute aims to raise a significant and growing share of its budget from private finance and revenue generated through its own activities. 
Despite this provision, which clearly relates to the budget of the EIT, the contribution from Horizon 2020 budget accounted for 99 % of its 2015 budget. 
Although the institution may use unused appropriations (i.e. uncommitted appropriations during the year or released at the end of the year) in the budget for the following three years, it has not adjusted its procedures in time to be able to estimate 26.6 million euro available under the 2014 grant agreements in the 2015-2017 budget allocations. 
These funds were available because the KICs used less funds than expected. 
According to the Commission's original objective, the institution should acquire its financial autonomy in 2010. 
However, in June 2011, the Institute received only part of its financial autonomy, as grants and award procedures worth more than EUR 60 000 are still subject to prior approval by the Directorate-General for Education and Culture. 
The Institute is supporting the EIT Digital Master School programme, in which 16 European universities participate. 
The model for reimbursing university costs is based on a combination of a lump sum of EUR 8 000 per student (in accordance with the provisions of the Erasmus Mundus programme) plus the actual costs including indirect costs calculated on a flat-rate basis. 
On this basis, the universities received an average of EUR 15 000 per student in 2015 (including the lump sum). 
However, the model has never been frightened and it is not possible to distinguish which activities fall under the lump sum amount and which are covered by the actual costs. 
The institution should switch to a clear and flawed model for the recovery of costs, based on a single methodology, such as a uniform flat-rate amount based on proof of costs.

C 434/72 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 DE Court's observations The coordination and representation of the KICs is carried out by the legal entities of the KICs, which are almost entirely financed by the Institute. 
In its inspection, the Court paid particular attention to the procurement procedures carried out by these bodies, which we consider to be a high-risk area. 
In accordance with the 2015 grant agreements, the legal entities of the KIC and/or the KIC partners must ensure that the best price-performance marriage is achieved in procurement or that the criterion of the lowest price is applied where appropriate. 
For all amounts exceeding EUR 60 000, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must, according to the grant agreements, invite at least three economic operators to submit tenders and document the procurement procedure to demonstrate its transparency. 
We examined a sample of procurement procedures worth around 7 million euro, carried out by the legal entities of the KICs and fully financed by the EIT. 
The inspection resulted in significant amounts, such as direct award of contracts, lack of essential elements in tenders, significant extensions of the initial increases in duration and/or scope, increases without limiting the duration and/or size or quality/price weights that led to price competition. 
The Institute also identified the Mngels in the procurement procedures of a legal entity of the KICs and set up an action plan to improve the procurement procedures of all KICs' legal entities. 
Despite the significant increase in the budget from EUR 309 million (2008-2013) to 2.4 billion euro (2014-2020) and although there have been six and no more than three KICs since the end of 2016, the number of posts granted to the institution has hardly changed (see Table 2). 
As the Court noted in its Special Report No 4/2016 (9), there is a risk that the Institute will not have capazitt in order to cover the workload incurred. 
The interim director of the institution has pointed out this risk in the Institute's annual activity report for 2015.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/73 ANNEX OF THE INSTITUTE 3.9.7. 
The EIT would like to clarify that the specific grant agreements in accordance with the provisions of the KIC Framework Partnership Agreements of the EIT may be submitted at any time during the period of funding. 
The KICs' EUR amendment was subject to a technical and financial assessment by the EIT and the prior approval by the European Commission. 
Subsequently, the EUR changes were signed in December 2016. 
In the case of EIT Climate-KIC, the KIC received the approval of the EUR amendment application on 21. December 2016 (i.e. within the Frder period) formally communicated. 
As regards the establishment of the individual reimbursements, the EIT points out that no additional grant amount was paid to the KICs as a result of the EUR changes to the Specific Grant Agreements in 2016. 
The total amount of the final grant (EUR 241.8 million) was significantly lower than the initial amount (EUR 274.9 million). 
As regards the call for KICs to develop their own sources of funding and to become financially viable, please refer to our reply to section 3.9.15. 
In the context of the assessment of the EUR change, the EIT, after consulting the European Commission, concluded that the adjustment of the individual reimbursement rates is in line with the applicable legal basis and does not affect the equal treatment of KICs. 
The possibility to adjust the individual refunds was open to all KICs on equal terms. 
With regard to the second remark, the EIT considers that the EUR amendments corresponded to Article 180(4) of the Rules of Application for the Financial Regulation, since they did not call into question the decision to award grants and did not conflict with equal treatment of applicants. 
It should be borne in mind that there is no provision on a materiality threshold showing which EUR change in a measure is to be regarded as material in assessing whether the EUR change is relevant for obtaining the grant. 
Whether the inclusion of new activities corresponds to that provision must be determined on a case-by-case basis on the basis of the relevance and impact of the activities for the entire KIC business plan. 
The EIT carried out the assessment prior to the approval of the EUR change and concluded that the EUR changes did not call into question the decision to obtain grants. 
Since each KIC had the opportunity to include new cheerful activities in its gendered business on equal terms, KIC's equal treatment was also required. 
Finally, the EIT points out that in the case of EIT InnoEnergy, the only activity in question represented only 3.9 % of the gendered budget estimates of the KIC business plan. 
For EIT Digital, this share was 0.6 %.

3.9.12.

3.9.13. 
The 2016 Specific Grant Agreements with EIT Health and EIT RawMaterials were signed as planned, as the Framework Partnership Agreements had to be signed first. 
The specific grant agreements for 2017 and 2018 were systematically signed in February, allowing KICs to start their activities in advance in the respective year. 
Due to their dynamic and fast-moving nature, innovative measures cannot be planned linearly. 
Some innovation projects or projects do not meet expectations of their potential and must be discontinued during the implementation of grant agreements. Berdies are some of the operational activities of the KIC, such as master's and doctoral studies or long-term research and innovation projects, designed from home to several years. 
To address this issue, the EIT intends to enter into multi-annual grant agreements with KICs after 2020, provided that corresponding commitment appropriations are allocated in multi-instalments in the EIT budget. 
In fact, the EIT has complied with the methodology required by the legal basis for the calculation of grants without limitation and will continue to comply with the legislation in force in the future. 
The financial strength of KIC is a unique ambition of the EIT-KIC model and one of the most difficult aspects of the EIT mission. 
In the meantime, some of the innovation communities can already have an appreciable co-financing with which they dispute their activities and generate considerable revenue compared to their budget. 
For example, EIT Digital received co-financing of 26 % (22 million euros) to cover the costs of the KIC value-added activities in 2016. In addition, the partner organisations carried out and paid for KIC activities of more than 200 million euros in Hhe. 
Another example is EIT Health: In its first year of operation, KIC generated a respectable amount of EUR 6 million in revenue compared to the total financing it had received from the EIT (approximately EUR 19 million). 
De C 434/74 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.17. 
Following the conclusion of the necessary agreements with the European Commission, the EIT intends to introduce the tools for electronic tendering and electronic submission of tenders.

The contractor of the framework agreement shall act as an intermediary between the Agency and companies that can meet the needs of the Agency. 
The contractor of the framework agreement receives these intermediate services from two to nine percent on supplier prices. In 2017, payments totalling EUR 1.7 million were made to the contractor of the framework agreement. 
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and discounts with the tenders of the companies and did not systematically review the invoices issued to the contractor of the framework agreement. DE ANHANG Follow-up of observations from previous years The Agency plans to partially relocate administrative staff from Heraklion to Athens in 2016. 
For Title II (Administrative Expenditure), the rate of committed appropriations for the following financial year is 0.3 million euro and 25 % (2015: 0.15 million euros or 22 % respectively. 
This high rate is mainly attributable to transfers of funds under Title I (staff expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) and is primarily related to IT investments made shortly before the end of the year and the acquisition of a company car. 
As foreseen in the Agency's financial rules, external evaluations of the Agency's performance were carried out for 2014 and 2015; the final reports were presented in October 2015 and May 2016. 
The 2014 evaluation concluded that the operational core activities carried out under the 2014 Work Programme have a clear link to the Agency's legal mandate; the effectiveness of the Agency has been assessed as good. 
However, there was a need for improvement regarding the division of the Agency between Heraklion and Athens, which leads to heavy workloads, as well as a lack of communication and cooperation. 
The 2015 evaluation concluded that the Agency's activities and outputs correspond to a need for network and information security across the EU and in the Member States and that the Agency effectively meets the expectations of its stakeholders. 
However, the report stressed the need to improve communication between the Agency and its stakeholders, which considers that the mandate and scope of the Agency are too limited. 
The Agency is currently implementing an action plan on which it has as a consequence agreed with the Management Board. 
In 2016, the agency relocated eight additional employees to Athens, reducing the number of employees in Heraklion to 14 (1). 
As the Court pointed out in our 2013 report, the costs could probably be further reduced by pooling all staff at one site.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE ACCOUNTING PROCEDURE 3.12.8. 
In December 2016, the agency's accounting officer, in addition to this function, was appointed interim head of the Finance and Procurement Department. 
As part of this additional function, he is responsible for the management of staff responsible for the initiation and verification of commitments and payments. 
The Agency's financial rules stipulate that those financial actors are under the authority of the authorising officer. 
However, according to the principle of separation of tasks, authorising and accounting powers are separate functions and are excluded from each other. 
In 2014, the Commission concluded, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency), a framework agreement with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software, as well as maintenance and support services (IT services). 
In the case of a verified payment of around EUR 47 000, the Agency had acquired IT services from the contractor without a competitive procedure or prior market analysis. In 2017, payments totalling EUR 1.1 million were made to the contractor in Hhe.

COMMENTS ON BUDGET 3.14.9. 
The appropriations for Title II (Administrative Expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) were high at 40 % for each title or a total of 3.5 million euro, which is contrary to the budgetary principle of honor. 
There is no indication that the funds allocated are linked to expenditure planned during the budgetary procedure. 
For example, in December 2017, the Agency ordered IT equipment and Brombel for an amount of EUR 220 000. 
In accordance with their Framework Financial Regulation, the Agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (123) (124). As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT system covering all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched e-invoicing tools (2010), the electronic publication of contract notice documents in the online edition of the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). 
The agency had not implemented any of these tools by the end of 2017.

3.16.11. 
The publication of vacancy notices on the EPSO platform requires a translation into all EU official languages, whereas English is the only working language of the Agency and the publication of vacancies in English is seen as a useful pre-selection step to ensure that our working language is understood at once. 
In addition, the placement of vacancy notices in all EU official languages would entail an additional financial and time-consuming effort for the Agency, so that this would not result in any benefit from the abovementioned circumstances. Instead, the GSA intends to publish all vacancy notices on the agency portal, which the agencies consider to be equivalent to EPSO and offer sufficient transparency to EU leaders. 
In addition, the Agency publishes its vacancy notices also on specialised space websites. 
Electronic communications in TED (available by the Office for Publication) for the publication of contract notices, contract notices, notices of corrections, EURmodification notices, etc. are currently used in the GSA whenever this is appropriate in accordance with Article 264 of the Rules of Application. 
The Agency also intends to use the e-Tendering system TED to draw up and publish tenders. 
Against this background, the GSA is currently in consultation with the Office for Publications to register and create a system account. 
With regard to high value tenders (above the thresholds of Article 118(1) FR), the GSA is currently taking the necessary administrative steps to use the Ăe-Submission module of the Ăe-PRIOR information system developed by the European Commission (available by DG DIGIT) in order to ensure that the electronic system set up for the submission of all tenders is met by the FR and AB. 
It is pointed out that the module Ăe-Submissions currently supports exclusively open procedures and therefore the GSA may only use it for such procedures. 
In this context, the GSA has already held a first coordination meeting with DG DIGIT and is in the process of finalising and signing an agreement with it in order to define the framework for and start implementation of the Submission Framework.

COMMENTS ON THE SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.17.9. 
The Agency acknowledges that the Court will continue to improve its management of the ETC in terms of both financial and operational controls. 
In order to reiterate the problem encountered at the ETC in 2017, the task in question was removed from the annual action plan and transferred to the Agency. 
The Agency shall endeavour to maintain the current level of controls on grants awarded to the ETC. 
The Agency confirms that it has gendered the requirements relating to the verification of the financial performance of tenderers in the course of 2017 and that tenderers are now required to provide information on key financial figures (liquid, solvency and rentabilitt); in addition, in accordance with the provisions of Article 147(1)(a) of the Rules of Application (AB), a minimum turnover is now required, which must be at least twice the value of the value of the annual contract. 
The Agency would like to emphasise once again that the decision to offer framework distortions to individual contractors has been made consciously and with due regard to the fact that competition is limited to the relevant markets, as well as the nature and complexity of the services to be provided. 
When awarding individual contracts on the basis of the framework contract, the Agency shall not only take into account the contractually agreed daily rates, but also the number of days required to carry out the tasks in order to calculate a depreciation value for the budget to be allocated for a specific specific contract. 
Only then will negotiations be initiated with the contractor on the details of his tender, always paying attention to achieving the best price-performance ratio. 
In the event of a resumption of the call for tenders, the Agency shall not be responsible for any further negotiations on the tenderers' tenders. 
In line with the decision of the Management Board of 9 November 2015 to introduce an e-invoicing in the EEA in the course of 2014, the Agency has introduced electronic invoicing procedures for certain procedures and is now in the process of extending the application of this module to all its procedures; the electronic call for tenders, on the other hand, has been applicable to all general tenders since 1 January 2015. 
The integration of the electronic submission of tenders started at the beginning of December 2017 and the first call for tenders in which this module was used was launched on 18 June 2018 (EEA/COM/18/002 provision of publishing services to the EEA). 
The Agency takes note of the Court's observation and confirms that it is currently adapting its selection/recruitment procedures in the following areas: a) The completion of the individual steps in the different phases (pre-selection, selection, application review and written examination) is confirmed in the relevant documents with the time indication (not only with the date). b) On the given questions for the application test and the written examination will be systematically prepared during the pre-selection phase. c) In order to improve reporting, an electronic (paperless) procedure is introduced. 
3.17.14. 
EPSO has refused to publish to the Agency with the approval that the precondition for all job vacancies to be replaced in all official languages is not satisfied. 
However, the Agency does not have the resources or resources to comply with EPSO's request. 
In this case, not only should all vacancies be filled, but also the applications must be processed in all official languages, which entails unsustainably high additional costs. 
As with most other EU agencies, the Agency has therefore looked for an alternative to EPSO's website and, since May 2018, has used a website for its announcements with the same purpose; it is the Job Advertisement Board set up and maintained by the EU Agencies Network. 
In addition, the agency uses LinkedIn, its own website and its own Facebook pages to ensure the best possible distribution.

COMMENTS ON THE COST-EFFECTIVENESS OF ACCOUNTING 3.19.8. 
The Agency delegated its accounting function to the Commission's accounting officer in 2014. 
In addition, the headquarters of the agency was relocated in 2014 and its mandate was redefined in 2016. 
Although these events resulted in EUR changes in the Agency's procedures, the accounting system has not been validated again since 2013. 
In December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement with an economic operator with a value of 1.6 million euro and a duration of four years on the provision of temporary employment. 
The only competition criterion in the award procedure was the price. 
A framework agreement with several companies selected on the basis of price and quality criteria would have been better with regard to the timely provision of high-quality services. 
3.19.10. 
On 29. In March 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit). 
3.19.11. 
The Agency publishes vacancy notices on its own website and on social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). This would increase transparency and publicity and make it possible for Brgers to view job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies. 
3.19.12. 
In accordance with their Framework Financial Regulation, the Agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (160) (161). As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT system covering all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched e-invoicing tools (2010), the electronic publication of contract notice documents in the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).

Highlighting a situation 3.20.8. 
As of the end of 2017, the staff situation at the Bro deteriorated exponentially. 
At the management level of the Bros, four out of ten Heads of Unit and 18 out of 27 Heads of Unit were not filled. 
In the aAdministration department, three out of four Heads of Unit and fnf out of 10 Heads of Unit were not filled. This represents a deplorable challenge for the bros's management level. 
In addition, 129 temporary staff posts were filled at the end of May 2018, but 78 were still open. 
71 of the contract staff posts were filled and 13 were still open. 
The Bro does not currently have administrative capacity to fill so many vacancies (see Table 2). 
Overall, this situation has significantly contributed to the continuation of the bros's activities at present. 
De C 434/118 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Table 2 Organisation chart of the Bros early June 2018 
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/119 NOTICES FOR RECOMMENDATION AND ORDERALITY OF THE PAYMENTS AND THE DECISION OF INTERNATIONAL CONTROLLS The nature of its activities results in major risks for Bro 3.20.9. 
Since 2016, the Bro has been confronted with an unprecedented extension of tasks and activities to provide operational and technical support to Member States in the context of the migration crisis. 
This is reflected in an increase in the budget from EUR 19 million in 2016 to EUR 79 million after the second change in the 2017 budget. 
The number of procurement procedures increased from 87 in 2015 to 140 in 2017. 
Payments increased by 225 % from 2 578 in 2015 to 8 381 in 2017. 
3.20.10. 
The Bro is one of the few institutions of the European Union that has several locations. 
In addition to its headquarters in Malta with 179 statutory staff, the Bro manages two major support actions in Greece and Italy, in which 747 experts from Member States and associated countries, 202 cultural mediators (interpreters), 178 temporary workers and 21 staff members of the Bros were involved in 2017. 
3.20.11. 
As we have already seen in our Special Report No 6/2017 aReaction from the EU to the refugee crisis: the hotspot concept has determined that the Bro is highly dependent on the Member States making sufficient resources available. 
The efficiency of the activities is particularly affected by the fact that Member States send their experts for very short periods of time (six to eight weeks). 
The extraordinary operational challenge caused by the migration crisis was not mitigated by a solid governance structure and effective internal controls 3.20.12. 
With the inclusion of the activities to support Greece and Italy in 2015, the Bro was confronted with the fact that Member States provided insufficient resources for posting. 
It had already been difficult for the Bro to fill the posts provided for in its establishment plan. 
Since 2014, the Court has regularly reiterated its remark that the Bro has to pluck with a high staff turnover. 
In its previous annual reports, the Court repeatedly stressed that this situation poses a serious risk to achieving the objectives set out in the annual and multi-year work programmes. 
Despite repeated attempts (36 recruitment procedures and 100 new contracts in 2017), the Bro has not succeeded in recruiting and retaining staff in general (see also paragraph a Emphasis of a situation in point 3.20.8). 
3.20.13. 
The extraordinary challenge in the operational area caused by the migration crisis was not mitigated by a solid management structure. 
The Board of Directors did not set up an internal audit body at the Bro and the actions in Greece and Italy were not subject to internal audits. 
By the end of 2017, the Board of Directors had limited supervision over the budget management. 
3.20.14. 
The Bro does not have an internal legal service, nor is legal documents systematically reviewed internally. 
The brochure awards most legal questions (mainly personnel and procurement questions) according to paragraphs, without clearly defining in internal decisions or guidelines who may issue which legal questions externally, to which law firm and under what conditions. 
Although the Bro employs at least eight different law firms, a comprehensive list of all relevant contracts, cases and expert opinions is missing. 
3.20.15. 
Legal services are not adequately reviewed by the Bro to ensure that they are exclusively used to defend the interests of the Bros and not to defend the interests of individuals. 
The appropriate procedures to protect against conflicts of interest are not always effective. 
In general, the use of external applications restricts the possibility of resolving disputes prior to bringing proceedings. 
3.20.16. 
The facts set out in points 3.20.13-3.20.14 expose the Bro to the risk of financial losses and reputation damage. 
These issues are currently being investigated internally by the Bro. 
Numerous essential provisions against regulations as a result of lack of internal controls payments for temporary benefits 3.20.17. 
In 2017, payments in Hhe amounted to 7.7 million euros for temporary payments. 
In the absence of a competitive public procurement procedure, the Court found the contract for temporary assistance in Greece to be irregular in its 2016 audit. 
Nevertheless, in 2017 the Bro still made payments in Hhe of EUR 4.8 million under this non-compliant order. 
De C 434/120 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.20.18. 
The procurement procedures carried out in Malta in 2017 for temporary services (payment volume in 2017: 1.0 million euros) were inconvenient in their resolution (e.g. short deadlines for submission of tenders, lack of transparency in time-limits), which ensured competition was one of the most important principles in public procurement procedures. 
As a result, the procedures had to be repeated several times because no offers were received. 
3.20.19. 
The contracts were insufficiently checked for compliance with the national rules on temporary employment contracts, which exposed the Bro to significant financial and reputational risks. 
In addition, the examination of proof of working time for temporary workers and detected irregularities showed significant weaknesses. 
Payments for personnel expenditure 3.20.20. 
Personnel-related payments amounted to EUR 13.5 million in 2017. The Court found serious misfortunes in four of the 14 audited recruitment procedures. 
3.20.21. 
For example, the Bro did not publish a vacancy notice to fill the position of a senior adviser, but carried out the recruitment directly on the basis of a reserve list drawn up for the post of head of department. 
The deadlines were not always justified in view of the number of applications received by the original deadline. 
3.20.22. 
Some procedures for recruiting AD staff were not suitable for the grade advertised. 
In a procedure to fill a management post in the aAdministration department, the vacancy notice was more restrictive than for the same posts in other departments. 
In another procedure, the examination of candidates' suitability was not adequately documented by the Bro. 
Payments for rent and related construction services 3.20.23. 
The total rent for all Bros at the various locations amounted to two million euros in 2017. 
The Court found that the Bro had signed the lease for the expansion of its headquarters in Malta and several new Bros in Athens, Lesbos and Chios, without having previously adequately analysed the local market. 
3.20.24. 
In June 2017, the Bro signed a lease agreement for Broflchen in Lesbos. 
It also accepted a contract with the landlord without any competition for the works to adapt the rented building to the needs of the Bros. 
The value of the construction contract (0.7 million euros during the first months of the rental contract) increased the annual value of the lease by many times. 
The investment of significant stakes in rented buildings is accompanied by serious financial and operational risks. 
3.20.25. 
In 2018, the Bro decided to cut a lease for Broflchen in Chios and related construction services. 
It is currently limited to the financial risk exposure resulting from the denunciation. 
Payments for travel expenses 3.20.26. 
In 2016 the Court found an order for travel services worth EUR 4 million for irregularity during its inspection. 
The contract was awarded to a tenderer who did not fulfil all the selection criteria. 
On the basis of this irregular order, the Bro continued to make payments in 2017 in Hhe of 1.5 million. 
3.20.27. 
In 2017, the Bro found significant amounts of recognition of travel services, in particular the lack of evidence to demonstrate that the travel services in question were actually requested or provided. 
This issue is currently being investigated internally by the Bro. 
Other payments 3.20.28. 
In addition, other services such as cleaning services, security services, interpreting and consulting services based on public procurement procedures were also systematically affected by the same rules. 
The Court identified significant differences in the assessment of needs for the Bro, the preparation of the tender specifications, the choice of the type of contract, the procurement procedures applied, the time limits for submission of tenders, the evaluation and award procedures (i.e. the weighting of the price criteria over the quality criteria), the EUR changes and the delays, the use of the contract and the verification of the services provided. 
They have an impact on the fundamentals of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination of tenderers. 
The following digits contain some examples of the above mentioned Mngels. 
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/121 3.20.29. 
In 2017, the Bro awarded a service contract for consultancy services related to the implementation of the Action Plan on Greek Islands. 
The contract was awarded to a pre-selected economic operator without any of the procurement procedures provided for in the Financial Regulation. 
The procurement procedure and all related payments (EUR 992 000) were therefore irregular. 
3.20.30. 
The Bro has since amended the original contract of EUR 5 000 concluded with a law firm in 2016 and increased it to EUR 259 000 in 2018. 
For the contract, payments totalling EUR 98 332 were made in 2017, partly for consultancy services requiring a competitive public procurement procedure. 
The changes and payments relating to these advisory services were therefore irregular. 
3.20.31. 
The execution of the contract concluded in 2013 (value: EUR 120 000, increased to EUR 132,000 in 2017) for the organisation of four to six major events in an international hotel during a period of four years was not in line with the original subject-matter of the contract. 
The Bro used the contract instead for an unbelievable 50 smaller events. 
The execution of the contract has therefore not been carried out in accordance with the provisions.

In accordance with the agreements between the European Union and the Knigreich Norway, the Swiss Confederation and the Frstentum Liechtenstein (also referred to as Associated Lnder) concerning their participation in the Bro, the associated Lnder are fully involved in the work of the Bros and are entitled to support measures of the Bros.

De C 434/126 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 ANTWORD OF THE BROS The Bro thanked the Court for the most helpful report. 
At the same time, the Bro is grateful to the Court for its commitment to the extremely difficult situation in which the Bro was in the reporting period due to the enormous expansion of its tasks: In addition, it has been mandated to support Member States and participate in the implementation of initiatives at EU level; to this end, the redistribution and explanation of EU-Trkei, the increase in the budget, the exponential increase in payments and the increase in procurement procedures (both in terms of number and complexity). 
In addition, the Bro has to manage a variety of locations and many management positions (heads of department, heads of unit, sector heads) are not filled. 
In its present reply, the Bro will address some of the Court's observations; overall, however, it accepts the report and the findings contained in it. 
3.20.6 and 3.20.13. 
With regard to the systematic stances against the provisions in the Bro, the Bro under the new leadership has begun to take the necessary steps to ensure that compliance with the regulations prevails and becomes the central element of culture and the implementation of all its measures. 
This includes objective, honest and open internal control, self-assessment. 
The Bro accepts the Court's finding that the surveillance structures and internal control structures responsible for the Bro have not received in the past the attention necessary to ensure adequate legality and regularity. 
In this regard, too, the Bro would like to state that the structure of the structures and procedures for the systematic performance of legality and legality (and the correspondingly pricial and comprehensive reporting) will have absolute priority under the new direction. 
3.20.6., 3.20.8. and 3.20.12. 
The Court rightly underlines the fact that the staff situation in the Bro has deteriorated and is insufficient and that it is also an obstacle to the proper functioning of the internal control system. 
For the Bro, the current staff situation is one of the biggest challenges related to the rectification of the Mngels identified by the Court in its observations, which can be seen to a large extent as a consequence of the lack of resources for structured and orderly work. 
The paper addresses the problem directly and, on the basis of a well-founded recruitment plan leading up to an assessment of needs, carries out recruitment procedures with urgency to fill the management posts and other important (operational and administrative) posts. 
In addition, the Bro is making efforts in the area of employee satisfaction to address the problem of staff turnover. Although it must be borne in mind in this context that the low correction coefficient in Malta plays an important role compared to the rather high cost of living in Malta, the Bro acknowledges that greater efforts must be made to improve employee satisfaction. 
Some measures such as flexible working opportunities, improved internal communication and organisation of employee events have already been implemented. 
3.20.9. and 3.20.19. 
The Court gives a correct description of the difficulties and the rapid increase in financial transactions and procurement procedures, expressed in absolute terms. 
These figures speak a clear language, but basically do not adequately reflect the financial and procurement gaps. 
In these figures, further facts and measures, which, in addition, the compulsory situation in the procurement sector, are not taken into account, such as the following two aspects: N the use of externally funded experts (Articles 204 and 287 of the Financial Regulations), which represents a high workload for the procurement sector. 
In the coming years, further deterioration can be expected in this regard, as the Bro [medical] expert will have to use [medical] experts to assist in tasks related to medical information about origin. 
N market-specific difficulties and constrictions that coincide with our geographical areas of activity. 
In the regions of Italy and Greece, the conditions for a competitive market for the provision of services and products for the Bro are not very good. 
In addition, the Bro is atypical in relation to the contract terms for economic operators in Malta as a customer, since they mostly lack the capacitates in order to meet the requirements associated with more extensive contracts of the Bros. 
3.20.10.-3.20.12. and 3.20.19. 
This characteristic is essential for the understanding of the high level of administrative support and the extremely complex environment when it comes to introducing functioning internal control structures. 
In addition, it should be noted that due to its operational capacity, its geographically wide range of operations and (as the Court correctly notes) the constraints in the use of Member State experts depend on contractors to an unsatisfactory extent. 
This is a factor that causes a multiplication of the tasks associated with procurement and finance (including decentralised financial actors), as for locations in Greece, Italy and Cyprus 
De 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/127 and specific contracts for hotspots in Greece and Italy (leasing, cleaning, security, water supply and essential services, e.g. providing temporary and interpreting services) are required.

3.20.14., 3.20.15. and 3.20.16.

3.22.8. 
In order to ensure the independence of the accounting officer, the formal requirement laid down in EFSA's financial regulations is implemented by EFSA as follows: The current accounting officer was appointed by the EFSA Management Board in 2008. 
The accounting officer is under the authority of the head of the BuS department. In order to ensure the functional independence of the accounting officer in the procedures for appraisal of performance, the Head of the BuS Department shall act as an assessor and the Chair of the Audit Committee shall act as countersigning staff. 
The accounting officer may be removed from office at any time by the Board of Directors. 
3.22.9. 
There is no obligation to use the model of individual invitations to tender and both models may be appropriate depending on the scenario. 
EFSA considers that individual calls for standard services to be tendered for competition are again more appropriate and are used in EFSA contracts for statistical services, systematic literature review and target group research. 
EFSA uses the cascade model when a long-term contractual relationship is in the foreground. 
In particular, in the case of the framework contract for external inspection services, the main aim is to ensure (i) an adequate understanding of EFSA's activities, (ii) a consistent testing method and (iii) credibility at all levels of administration. 
EFSA has control over the budget for proposals made by the contractor in the cascade system.
