3.23.7. 
The following observations do not call into question the Court's assessment. COMMENTS ON RECHTMEURSCURITY AND ORDERALITY OF VORGEURNGE 3.23.8. 
At the end of the financial year 2017, the Institute was defendant in four disputes brought before the General Court by unsuccessful bidders in connection with three procurement procedures. 
In each of those cases, the applicant applied for the annulment of the award decision and the award of damages. 
The claim for damages claimed in these four cases amounts to EUR 700 000 or 9 % of the annual budget of the Institute. 
According to the evaluation of the Institute's external lawyer, a position of EUR 75 000 (or 1 % of the Institute's annual budget) was recorded in Hhe to cover the expected losses. 
The judgment delivered by the General Court in each of these cases will rule on the legality and regularity of the procurement procedures in respect of those increases and the payments due. 
In 2016, the Institute launched an open invitation to tender for travel services. 
The service descriptions and the evaluation process did not provide a sufficient guarantee for the best price-performance marriage. 
The award formula and pricing mechanism were unsuitable as they did not allow for an appropriate assessment of the tenders submitted by the tenderers. 
The framework agreement was concluded for a maximum duration of four years and a maximum amount of EUR 700 000. 
In 2017, payments were made in Hhe of EUR 137 000. 
3.23.10. 
In accordance with their Framework Financial Regulation, the Agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (180) (181). As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT system covering all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched e-invoicing tools (2010), the electronic publication of contract notice documents in the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). 
According to the Commission, by the end of 2017, the Institute had introduced electronic invoicing for certain procedures, but not the electronic tendering and electronic submission of tenders. 
3.23.11. 
The Institute publishes vacancy notices on its own website and on social media, but not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO). This would increase transparency and publicity and make it possible for Brgers to view job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies.

The number of posts in the Agency's establishment plan has not been increased, which allows you to gain the necessary expertise in the fields of business and IT development. 
Extensive use of external consultants Since the agency had only 13 employees in its IT delivery department, it used the services of consulting companies in the areas of business analysis, information technology, project management and quality assurance. 
In the second quarter of 2016, 131 consultants were on site and 60 other consultants outside of their rumours. 
The Agency is therefore dependent on external expertise since the beginning of the projects in critical terms, but does not have a strategy that regulates the use of consultants. 
Insufficient control of project development and implementation When the Agency was entrusted with the new tasks in 2012 and 2014, it did not have an appropriate method for managing projects under this Regulation. 
In 2014, a new method was introduced, which had to be implemented significantly in September 2016.

3.24.13. 
The EMA offers transparency and publicity, as it publishes or has access to it, depending on the profile on the EMA website, LinkedIn, agency-absorbing jobs or in specialist publications. 
As a result, the EMA attracts great interest among applicants throughout the EU. Some competitions involved more than 1 000 candidates. 
Furthermore, the general rules governing the recruitment and use of temporary staff states that the selection notices for temporary agents referred to in Article 2(f) of the CEOS are published only in the working languages of the agencies; On the other hand, agencies that do not have a fixed working language publish the selection notices in all the official languages of the European Union. 
Following a decision by the Administrative Director, the EMA's working language has been English since June 2015. 
However, EPSO has informed EMA that, in order to be published on its website, it will continue to require the EMA to post the vacancy notices in all official EU languages and make these language versions available on the EMA website. 
It should be noted that the invitation to tender of posts in all EU official languages has a significant impact on the duration of the competitions and entails a higher cost. 
3.24.14.

In its January 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) highlighted the need for the Observatory to improve the management of IT projects. 
In particular, the IAS concluded that there is a lack of a long-term overall strategic vision for the IT systems supporting the Centre's central operational discharge, that the Centre's IT project management methodology was only partially adapted to its needs, and that the procedure for managing system requirements is incessant.

De C 434/152 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 RESPONSIBLE 3.25.8. The Centre considers that the current organisational structure has not affected the independence of its accounting directors.

3.26.7. 
COMMENTS ON THE SOUND FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND PERFORMANCE 3.26.8. In 2017, the Agency encountered difficulties in reaching a sufficient number of bidders for several medium-value procurement procedures. 
3.26.9. 
The Agency currently manages three proprietary, non-integrated IT systems (SIS II, VIS and Eurodac), all of which process data on EU policies on freedom, security and justice. 
This approach prevented the Agency from achieving economies of scale and synergies between the different systems. 
The current responsibilities to extend the Agency's mandate in the coming years to the management of several additional IT systems underpin the growing urgency of this problem. 
The Agency, in consultation with the Commission and the Member States, should prepare a detailed cost-benefit analysis to contribute to a discussion on the future development strategy for the systems. 
3.26.10. 
The project for the construction of a new building at the Stra§burg site was considerably distorted. 
Although the Agency had already paid the full price for the construction work in 2016, these were still not completed at the end of 2017, and the progress reports on the work taken were only about 70 % of the works. 
Part of the Agency's staff has already moved into the new booth, although the work is still ongoing. 
The Agency and the Contractor shall blame each other for the distortions. The contractor lodged financial claims to the Agency in December 2017 and filed an action. 
The Agency shall make its own legal claim against the Contractor (205). 
3.26.11. 
3.26.12. 
In accordance with their Framework Financial Regulation, the Agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (206) (207). As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT system covering all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched e-invoicing tools (2010), the electronic publication of contract notice documents in the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). 
Advice 3.26.13. 
The Agency mainly uses consulting services in connection with IT projects due to the nature of its activity. 
According to the Agency's records, IT projects were implemented within the financial and timeframe in 2017. 
Exception reports have been drawn up for the few development maintenance projects, which are slightly behind the schedule. 
(205) See also the Agency's 2017 annual accounts, Section 2.1.5 aEvents after the reporting date. (206) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013, Art. 79 e-government.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/155 3.26.14. 
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which around 90 % of the corresponding work is carried out by contractors. 
There are three main framework agreements with three consortia, one for each system. 
The payments made for these framework agreements in 2017 amounted to EUR 3 million for Eurodac, EUR 16 million for SIS II and EUR 13 million for VIS. 
Although all phases of the IT projects, from the definition of the requirements and the milestones to the start-up of new system components, are owned and controlled by the Agency, a model in which the development of such sensitive IT systems is outsourced to this extent poses significant risks with regard to an excessive subsistence from the contractors. 
This is all the more so given the limited number of potential contractors, which are limited from operational and security-related limits, who can deal with systems of this type and these requirements. 
3.26.15. 
At the same time, the low number of staff in operational key units, especially in the Application Management and Maintenance Unit (AMM), poses a significant risk to the continuity of operations. 
In the second half of 2017, the Head of Unit AMM also held the post of Head of the Operational Department and the Head of the Department of Operations and Infrastructure, thus uniting the three highest management positions in the Operational Department, which entails further risks for the continuit. 
3.26.16. 
The framework agreements concluded with the respective consortia for the operation of the main IT systems include not only normal maintenance, but also development maintenance work, the price of which cannot be calculated on the basis of the costs included in the framework agreements. 
The Agency shall calculate the prices for the individual percentages on the basis of a combination of fixed price and estimated time and budget, aiming at sound cost control. 
FR the VIS contract was also based on the method of IFPUG(208), a standard method based on the function point analysis to determine prices for development. 
The agency could also use the IFPUG method for other systems. 
COMMENTS ON BUDGET 3.26.17. 
The Agency committed global commitments for a total of EUR 69.9 million in order to cover future expenditure on new tasks and IT systems originally to be transferred to it in 2017, but for which the legal basis had not yet been adopted by the end of the year (Eurodac recast and allocation system to Dublin) or shortly before (Regulation on the Entry/Exit System of 30 November 2017). 
The corresponding payment appropriations were reduced by two amending budgets in a height of 85.6 million euro, from 153.3 million euro in the original budget to 85.6 million euro in the final adopted budget.

3.26.14. 
The Agency confirms the high level of participation of external contractors in IT projects (operative and organisational). 
This high outsourcing rate is directly linked to the Commission Communication COM(2013) 519 on the financial and human resources planning for decentralised agencies for the 2014-2020 period. 
When the Agency was established in 2012, the establishment plan did not provide sufficient posts for the scope of the tasks assigned to it. 
In addition, the scope of the Agency's tasks has been significantly increased from 2013 onwards; however, their requests for additional staff were rejected and the Agency had to reduce staff (a total of seven posts), as requested by the Commission Communication. 
In order to ensure proper separation of tasks, the contractors involved in quality assurance do not provide any external support services for the operational management of IT-Gro§systems. 
The Agency acknowledges this exceptional situation in which a staff member had to carry out additional tasks. 
The appointment was compulsorily due to the long absence of the head of the Operational Division and the ongoing recruitment procedure for the further free management position. 
In order to remedy the situation, the Agency appointed another employee, the Head of Unit aSecurity, as the head of the aOperations and Infrastructure Unit, until the newly recruited manager took up its activity on 1 July 2018.

EUROPEAN UNION FR AGENCY FOR LAW ENFORCEMENT COOPERATION (EUROPOL) INTRODUCTION 3.28.1. 
The European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), also established in The Hague, was established by Regulation (EU) 2016/794 of the European Parliament and of the Council (214) which repeals and replaces Council Decision 2009/371/JHA (215). 
The aim of the Agency is to support and reinforce the effectiveness of the police officers and other law enforcement officers of the Member States, and their mutual cooperation in the engagement and repression of serious crime, terrorism and forms of criminality affecting two or more Member States, which infringe a common interest which is the subject of a Union policy.

De C 434/168 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 ANNEX OF THE AGENTUR 3.28.8. 
Europol employs more than 220 liaison officers from EU Member States and third countries and organisations. 
The common working language at Europol is English. Therefore, Europol's internal language regimes adopted by the Management Board stipulate that, unless otherwise agreed, recruitment procedures should be carried out in English. 
For this reason, Europol's vacancy notices are published in English. 
Europol has an effective and transparent recruitment process with a 0 % vacancy rate at the end of 2017. In the 89 recruitment procedures conducted in 2017, there were an average of 58 candidates per competition. 
The publication on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) is required, in addition to the English version, to be translated into the official EU languages. 
Due to the high number of vacancy notices per year, the transfer to the official EU languages would result in high costs and the duration of the procedures. 
Europol focuses on operational needs in budgetary expenditure, which is why it is only possible to place vacancy notices in all EU official languages, including EPSO's publication, in certain cases (e.g. the Executive Director or Deputy Executive Director).

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/173 3.30. 
EUROPEAN AGENCY FR THE BORDER AND COAST GUARD (FRONTEX) INTRODUCTION 3.30.1. 
The European Border and Kstenwache Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), also known as aFrontex, was established by Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (228) (aneue Grndungverordnung), which repealed Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 (229). 
It has been strengthened, while maintaining the abbreviation aFrontexn and its headquarters in Warsaw on the basis of the European Agency for Operational Cooperation at the external borders of the Member States. 
The new Grndung Regulation extends the mandate of the Agency; in addition, the Agency is entrusted with the task of ensuring an integrated border management at the external borders at the European level in order to efficiently manage the crossing of the external borders. 
This includes the affiliation of migratory pressure and potential threats at these borders, while at the same time contributing to the suppression of serious crime with a cross-border dimension in order to ensure a high level of internal security within the Union, while respecting fundamental rights and respect for freedom in this area.

Note 3.30.7. 
The Agency's expenditure on grants increased significantly from 123 million euro (2016) to 167 million euro (2017). 
Unlike in previous years, the Agency did not undergo ex post checks on expenditure related to grants in 2017. 
It takes the view that the ex-ante reviews carried out before reimbursement have been improved and now provide the necessary security as soon as they reach a certain level of coverage. 
However, since 2014, the Court has repeatedly reported that the co-operating States often provide insufficient evidence of the expenditure they declare, which was confirmed again in this year's inspection (see paragraphs 3.30.12-3.30.13). 
3.30.8. 
In 2016, the Court recommended that the Agency identify the most appropriate financing mechanism in an in-depth analysis (233). 
In this context, the Court notes that at the end of 2017, the Management Board decided to use unit costs instead of reimbursing the actual costs for operational activities. 
At the same time, a pilot project was launched in 2018 to determine unit costs for deployments sent by cooperating states. 
In addition, in June 2017, the Management Board approved a new organisational structure of the Agency, which will take effect from 2018 and include the creation of a new inspection and control bro, which directly reports to the Executive Director and the Management Board in order to adapt the existing organisation to the new mandate (see paragraph 3.30.9). 
3.30.9. 
In view of the migration crisis facing the Union, the mandate of the Agency was significantly extended in 2016. 
The Agency's budget increased by 75 % in 2016 and the budget for 2017 was again 21 % higher than in the previous year. 
Staff increased by 18 % in 2016 and 43 % year-on-year. 
The adaptation of the systems and procedures to the new mandate and the new framework is still ongoing. 
The following comments do not call into question the Court's assessment and should be read in the light of the challenges faced by the Agency. 
COMMENTS ON THE RECHTMEURSCURITY AND ORDERALITY OF VORGEURNGE 3.30.10. 
Following an open call for tenders, the Agency received four offers for the freezing of migrants within Greece. 
Following completion of the selection criteria, three tenders were retained and one excluded. 
The only award criterion was the price. 
In April 2017, the Agency signed a framework agreement of EUR 2 million for a period of three years with the company offering the lowest price. 
However, the contractor's allowances were seasonally limited and he had problems meeting the contract so that the agency opened the contract at the end of 2017. 
In order to ensure the continuity of the services, the Agency signed a new framework agreement for the remaining period of EUR 1.8 million with the bidder ranked second in November 2017, which had offered the second lowest price. 
It did not negotiate the terms of that replacement contract with the tenderers ranked second and third, but signed the new contract on the basis of the original tender submitted by the second tenderer. 
The direct award of the replacement contract was irregular because the original procurement procedure was concluded and there was no negotiated procedure for agreeing the terms of the contract until the conclusion of a new open procedure. 
No payments were made for this replacement order in 2017. 
3.30.11. 
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff will be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (234). 
In 2017, the Agency provided two staff (2016: 14) in Hheren AST grades.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/175 NOTICES TO INTERNATIONAL CONTROLLS 3.30.12. 
In 2017, the Icelandic Kstenwache Agency provided financial support in connection with the deployment of an aircraft in Greece. 
Before reimbursement of expenditure declared by Iceland, the Agency requested invoices as proof of a category of expenditure declared. 
Although the invoices were never presented, the Agency reimbursed around EUR 440 000. 
In this case, the ex-ante review was therefore ineffective. 
3.30.13. 
The Agency also co-financed the use of an aircraft used by the Spanish Guardia Civil. 
In the absence of supporting documents for the costs claimed for inspection and maintenance, the Agency reimbursed EUR 430 000 on the basis of average costs per flight hour. 
These average costs were calculated on the basis of cost ceilings used in contracts between the Spanish bidders and private contractors for inspection and maintenance work. 
There is a risk of reimbursement of costs than actually incurred. 
3.30.14. 
Although the Agency has already obtained its current Bros in 2014, it has still not drawn up a comprehensive contingency plan approved by the Management Board. 
COMMENTS ON BUDGET 3.30.15. 
The Agency cancelled again high committed appropriations from the previous year for reimbursement of expenditure of States participating in joint operations, in terms of 7,7 million euro and 16.5 % respectively (2016: 5.6 million euros and 17.6 % respectively. 
This shows that the co-operating States had once again overestimated the expenditure to be reimbursed by the Agency. 
Although appropriations for joint operations had to be cancelled in two consecutive years, the Agency transferred an amount of EUR 9.6 million from other budget lines to joint operations in 2017, which again transferred an amount of EUR 40.5 million to the following financial year. 
Joint actions account for 69 % of the total appropriations cancelled in 2017 (11.1 million euro) and 46 % of the total appropriations transferred to 2018 (87.6 million euro). 
3.30.16. 
In 2017, 66.5 million euros were available for return operations. However, fewer actions were carried out than funds were available. 
The Agency therefore paid the Commission 13.5 million euro or 20.3 % (2016: 23 million euros or 37.5 % respectively. 
In addition, the Agency contributed EUR 4 million to the budget budget (staff expenditure) under Title I, as not as many new staff could be recruited as planned in 2017. 
3.30.17. 
The Agency's initial budget for 2017 amounted to EUR 8.8 million for the required operational financial situation for the financing of emergency individuals for border security purposes and reverse actions (235). 
However, in September 2017 and again in October 2017, the Agency deducted 1.9 million euros (totalling EUR 3.8 million) from its operational budget to finance other activities. 
3.30.18. 
Following the implementation of transfers from other budget lines and the establishment of an amending budget, the appropriations entered in the rectangled position amounted to 24.7 million euro and 8.1 % of the original budget. 
However, the Agency mainly used it to finance standard operations (8.4 million euro) and to finance a remote-controlled air surveillance project (drones, EUR 7 million), for which it had estimated only EUR 1.1 million. 
The assessment and use of non-mandatory rectangles is incompatible with the budgetary principle of speciality and affects budgetary transparency.

C 434/178 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 DE Court's observations The Internal Security Fund was established for the period 2014-2020. 
It consists of two instruments: the instrument for financial support for foreign borders and visas, as well as the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, over 2.8 billion euros (restrictions and visas) and 1 billion euros (police cooperation) for the financing of ones. 
Under the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, the Commission shall reimburse Member States for the cost of equipment such as vehicles or vessels, as well as operating costs, such as fuel or maintenance costs. 
The Agency shall also reimburse such costs to participants in joint operations. 
There is therefore a risk of double financing (4), which is not taken into account. 
States participating in the border shall explain the costs incurred on the basis of cost statements, which include aFix costs (depreciation and maintenance costs), avariable expenditures (mainly fuel) and aDeployment costs (mainly losses and other expenses for crew members). 
The reported costs are based on actual values and comply with national standards. The stance of the participating states therefore differs, resulting in a particularly complex system for all parties involved. 
In its Special Report No 12/2016, the Court recommended to the agencies to make use of simplified cost options whenever deemed appropriate to avoid such inefficiencies (5). 
The Agency's previous Grndung Regulation, which was in force until 5 October 2016, provided for the financing of joint return operations carried out with participating States. 
However, from January to October 2016, the Agency financed national returns with an amount of 3.6 million euros. 
These payments are irregular.

In 2016, the Agency recruited 14 staff in Hheren AST grades.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/181 ANNEX OF THE AGENTURY NOTICES FOR RETURNS AND ORDERALITY OF THE COUNCIL 3.30.10. 
After Frontex decided to terminate the contract, it was necessary to ensure the continuity of the services until the selection of a new contractor. 
In view of the limited market for the services in the region (except for the very small number of operators), the most suitable solution was to conclude a contract with the undertaking which, in the initial tender for the selection of shipowners, had been awarded the second best supplier. 
Therefore, in this case it is not the continuation of a tendering procedure which has already been concluded. 
In its decision, the Agency took into account that the company had already had experience in providing services to Frontex and that this was positive; the offered Fhre met all technical minimum requirements. 
The contractor agreed to provide the services on the same terms as required and offered in the original invitation to tender. 
A derogation was signed in November 2017 in which the hindrances for this decision were taken. 
The transfer agreement was signed by both parties in December 2017 and entered into force in January 2018. 
The application of the price as the sole criterion had been carefully tested and was based on the experience of Frontex over the past two years with the award of contracts for the provision of catches between the Greek islands and the Trkei. 
As a result of market restrictions in the geographical region, very small number of operators with a limited offer of Fhren was not intended to establish qualitative award criteria. 
The services provided by Frontex were short journeys between the Greek islands and the Trkei to facilitate returnees under the EU-Trkei takeover agreement, ensuring that these actions were carried out in a safe environment and in full respect of fundamental rights. 
In line with the last sentence of Article 31(2) of the Staff Regulations (aIn order to take account of the specific needs of the institutions, the recruitment of officials may also take into account the labour market situation in the Union). 
This decision was fully in line with the posts (which form an integral part of the budget) and had never been questioned by the budgetary authorities. 
Since March 2017, Frontex has not recruited any external candidates in higher grades than grade AST 4. 
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12. 
The costs for inspection/maintenance work are defined as costs for all inspection/maintenance work during the entire life of the equipment (...). 
Set on the basis of the data communicated by the manufacturer or the maintenance office of the Behrde using the means. 
This means that the hourly rate may be indicated in the form of an explanation of the costs of the persons concerned, either on the basis of cuts made by the manufacturer or on a price calculated on the basis of the actual costs incurred in the previous years, or on a cost depreciation, using reference data for means of input where it is a new input and no data is available. 
Invoices (or accounting documents equivalent to the data quantity) can only be made available if the hourly price is based on the costs actually incurred in the reference year. 
However, the person concerned also has the possibility to set an hourly rate on the basis of average reference prices if no invoices have actually been issued. 
This was the case with the selected payment, whereby the Icelandic Kstenwache Frontex provided a depreciation of the constant maintenance costs. 
The documents submitted by the Icelandic Kstenwache took into account the results of the ex-post controls carried out by a Frontex ex-post control team during a 2015 visit to the maintenance centre in Iceland; in doing so, the team had reviewed the documents provided by the Icelandic Kstenwache as the basis of their calculation methods. 
Therefore, in Frontex's view, the document submitted by Iceland offers sufficient reason for the approval of the issue. 
The total hourly rate for all inspection/maintenance work of an aircraft with fixed loaders results from three wards with special regulations: The signed contract provided for a maximum amount of EUR 9 010 475.50; however, the payments are based on the hourly rate for the maintenance of an engine. 
The Guardia Civil calculates the hourly rate for engine maintenance according to the contractual requirements. 
If less time is spent on engine maintenance, the total limit is not reached. 
Therefore, in this case, the total value of the contract is not relevant, but the hourly rate. 
De C 434/182 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 
The Agency assumes that upon termination of the contract, Guardia Civil will pay the total amount specified in the contract. 
The Hhe of an hourly price is calculated by dividing this total cost by the number of flight hours. 
The provisions of the contract are, as above, a contract for a total price (not a framework contract), with monthly invoices for the specific work carried out by the contractor. 
The Agency assumes that upon termination of the contract, Guardia Civil will pay the total amount specified in the contract. 
On the basis of the abovementioned reasons, the Agency cannot proceed to the Court's risk assessment, since those refunded to the Guardia Civil would ultimately correspond to the bets reimbursed on the basis of a contract relating to a total price of bets, which are reimbursed on the basis of specific invoices. 
The current concept of measures for the production performance of the operation, the current strategy and the resulting emergency plne were developed and (yetly) updated on the basis of the legal framework and structure, which were in force until the end of 2016. 
In particular, due to the extended mandate and the corresponding new structure, the emergency responses will be reviewed by the relevant bodies, as the organisational changes also require a complete revision of the underlying discharge. 
COMMENTS ON BUDGET 3.30.15. 
The biggest challenge is related to the availability of commitments during a given year. 
In order to avoid the risk of high cancellations, in the fourth quarter of 2016, Frontex also appealed to the parties concerned to submit their antrge for the final payment for deposits that ended in the first half of this year and to provide Frontex with respect to current ones costs (December 2016) or planned deposits (January 2017) in the context of operational activities in 2016. 
The main objective of these calls was to identify possible delays, reduce the corresponding SFD allocations and reuse the funds in 2016. 
Despite some positive results of this action, the financial transfers were still very high. 
Consequently, despite an orderly reduction of the actual financial needs, Frontex used additional resources to ensure the financial coverage of the deposits in autumn 2016, as the decommitted appropriations of the completed and ongoing ones were not available at that time. 
The Agency has developed a simplified Frderschema, which will be implemented from the operational cycle in 2018 and will be applied significantly to a significantly higher level of Stck Costs for feeds of up to one year; the Agency not only intensifies the monitoring of the settlement of surcharges, but also seeks to reduce the cancellation of transfers. 
Despite the rectification of funds to the Commission, the main objective of the Agency in relation to the reverse actions was achieved: It provided the Member States with technical and operational support for carrying out reverse operations and carried out specific pre-return measures (for the identification of sweepers, training/training, knowledge exchange between Member States, etc.). 
In 2017, the number of reverse operations coordinated by Frontex increased significantly: With an increase of 47 % compared to the previous year, the number of migrants in an irregular situation increased from 10,700 in 2016 to 14,200 in 2017. 
This represents a share of 10 % of the total number of EU migrants actually returned to third countries (in 2014 the corresponding figure was 2 %). 
Recruitment Payments of appropriations for staff expenditure were mainly due to the difficulties and the consequent distortions in the recruitment process: lengthy procedures, long notice periods, insufficient number of candidates and lack of geographical balance due to a low correction coefficient. 
Nevertheless, the Agency considers it to be a success that more than 250 new staff have been recruited and incorporated within one year.

2017 was the first year for the Agency to implement the new EGKW Regulation. 
Pursuant to Article 75(13), the Agency is obliged to put into its budget an operational financial position of 4 % of the appropriations earmarked for operational measures in order to finance emergency catches for border security purposes (RABIT) and reverse operations. 
On 1 October of each year, at least one quarter of the rectangle should remain available in order to meet a demand until the end of the year. 
The required operational position has been put in place so that the Agency can, at any time during the year, provide for a certain reserve for the implementation of emergency catches for border security purposes and to cover the initial costs of such rapid intervention. 
The European Parliament had gendered the original text of the ECFC Regulation proposed by the Commission by adding the addition, that by 1 October only a quarter of the gap for the remaining three months of the year must remain available. 
The ECFC Regulation is silent on what will happen to the remaining three quarters of the recoil after 1 October; this point is unclear. 
The first transfer at the end of September was intended for the financing of truncated operational measures in the air and at sea and the acquisition of own air surveillance services; the second transfer took place after 1 October. 
The Board of Directors was informed in the monthly report on transfers. 
The Agency considers that the legislator should ensure clarity.

Towards the end of 2016, the EPPD 2017-2019 had already been completed and had to be approved by the Management Board, which fully supported the creation of the non-mandatory position in view of the passage to the European Border and Coast Guard. 
In its opinion on the 2017-2019 SPD, (C92016)8722, the Commission stated in point 63: the Commission acknowledges that contingency planning has become a guiding principle for the preparation of the annual work programme and that the Agency intends to allocate almost 10 % of its operational budget to the so-called âoperative Flexibilitt (...). 
In this context, the Commission invites the Agency to set up two separate positions within its budget, the first fully in line with Article 75(13) of the ECFC Regulation and the second gives the Agency the possibility to maintain the operational flexilitt in order to address emergency situations other than immediate ones.

3.34.10. 
However, the list of services to be provided in connection with the framework agreement was not confusing in the case of a framework agreement with a value of EUR 80 million for general consultancy, project management and studies. 
In order to evaluate the tenders, the tender specifications contained two business cases relating to the management of a project and a multi-project programme. 
This framework agreement is a mixed multi-frame agreement, partly applying a cascade procedure (general advisory and project management services) and in part a reopening of competition (study and studies). 
The units have been pre-determined by the Office, but tenderers were invited to define the distribution between the different profiles. 
The framework agreement and also some of the related individual contracts were therefore advertised on the basis of unit prices, types of profiles and quality, but not the expected number of squared units, which is another essential element in the calculation of a fixed price contract. 
3.34.11.

The person days required for the provision of these services cannot be derived from the business cases set out in the tender specifications or from the description contained in the specific contract. 
In the case of a fixed price as set out in this specific contract, there is therefore a risk that the services will not be rendered in the most economical way. 
3.34.12.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/197 DE 2016 Status of corrections (completed/in progress/pending/e.g.) Completed (3) ANNEX Follow-up of observations from previous years' observations of the Court's observations The Office's budget implementation rate was low at 89 %, indicating an inaccurate reduction of its expenditure in the 2016 budget. 
As a result of the recent amendments to the Staff Regulations and the Financial Regulations of the Office, it has become more important that the Office, if necessary, draws up an accurate budget by means of an amending budget, as it now provides for a tightening of mechanisms foreseen in the budget, such as the allocation of surpluses to a backlog fund(1) and a related compensation mechanism (2). 
In 2014, the Office launched a call for tenders for a four-year framework contract covering an increased market volume of EUR 30 million for consulting services covering a wide range of activities, including audit services, project management, general advisory services and studies. 
However, the procurement procedure and subsequent use of the framework contract were sometimes not adequately managed. 
The objectives and the activities to be carried out had not been defined precisely enough to ensure that the volume of the framework contract was sharply reduced. 
Therefore, the resources of the framework contract had already been completely eliminated after only two years and six months. 
In addition, despite the diversity of the services to be procured and the very different spending hahes, no lots were used per activity. 
The use of lots can encourage smaller companies to participate in the low-value process. 
Finally, the price competition has been neutralised and the contractor is entitled to pay due to the fact that fixed price offers were requested by a single contractor using the framework contract. 
The Office should consider entering into agreements with several suppliers and, if necessary, reopening competition. 
The Office's regulation stipulates that the relocations necessary for the work of the Office are to be carried out by the Centre for the Institutions of the European Union (CdT), which leads to the Office being the main client of the Centre. 
The Office is increasingly resorting to internal applications such as linguistic and translation memory as well as additional software. 
These tools are designed to improve the cost-effectiveness and efficiency of the Office. 
From the perspective of the European Union, however, the current situation could lead to a doubling of the effort and the corresponding costs. 
2016 In progress (4) 2016 In progress (1) in accordance with Article 89(1) of its Financial Regulations, the Office shall set up a reserve fund, the amount of which is to continue its activity and to carry out its tasks for one year, i.e. the appropriations set out in Titles 1, 2 and 3 of the Office's budget are in line with the appropriations set out in Titles 1, 2 and 3 of the Office's budget. 
(2) In accordance with the fourth and sixth paragraphs of Article 139 of its Regulation, the Office shall, each year, offset the costs incurred by a Member State in respect of the industrial property rights of the Member States, the Benelux Office for Intellectual Property and any other inclined bidder to be designated by a Member State as a result of the specific tasks which they carry out as functional components of the trade mark system of the European Union in the context of various services and procedures; this obligation applies only to the absence of a budget deficit this year.

De C 434/198 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REQUIREMENT OF THE AM NOTICES FOR Budget 3.34.8. 
While the cancellation rate is just above 15 %, the amount of cancelled tied transfers at EUR 3.2 million is the lowest in the last decade (since 2008). 
The Office continues to cooperate with the national EURmtern in order to reduce the cancelled transfers by means of interim reports on the implementation and half-year reviews with deferred control measures, which constitute an integral part of each new cooperation agreement. 
In addition, further measures were enforced internally, such as awareness-raising measures through coaching, training, information notes and meetings with the financial actors. 
In addition, before the end of 2017, the Office calculated that the level of cancelled transfers would rise to 15 % and proactively took additional measures to reduce transfers for the next year. 
The Office took note of the Court's observations. 
As a preliminary point, it should be noted that the scenarios for the future uses of the contract described in the procurement documents were aimed at being as vivid and representative as possible and not expected to be linked in detail to each specific contract. 
As regards the adequacy of the reopening of the competition mechanisms and as stated in the Office's reply to the 2016 audit, this approach has already been incorporated into the audit and studies framework contract. 
The Office has compared the added value of this mechanism with the associated administrative costs and, given the intensive use by the Office of the advisory and project management services, concludes that this should not be considered as the most efficient way of managing the latter types of contracts. 
Taking into account the fact that the current framework contract is valid until 2020, the extension of this mechanism to the advisory and project management services would require a new call for tender at that time, which the Office does not consider appropriate. 
In the existing cascade system for consulting and project management services, the Office reiterates its response to the 2016 audit on the use of fixed price procedures. 
The main reason for the choice of this option is that proceedings against the Office before the Spanish labour courts in relation to a non-legislative transfer of employees, which are related, inter alia, to the use of the earlier aTime and Means' rule. 
In the fixed price procedure (under the cascade system), the Office has experience in evaluating the offers. 
EUIPO has set up a specific team that, based on previous practice and expertise, is able to dedicate the resources needed to fulfil the tasks behind fixed price performance. 
However, we believe that the Court's concerns can be addressed through contractual methods other than the fixed price, such as the aQuoted Time and Means' procedure, a method that the Office could take into account in the future after a case-by-case examination. 
The Office undertakes to provide further information and to document its own resources necessary to carry out the tasks for fixed price services before the request for tender is issued in order to provide evidence of the above-mentioned experience of the Office in advance.

Single Resolution Board (SRB) INTRODUCTION 3.35.1. 
The Single Resolution Board (hereinafter referred to as the Board), also established in Brssel, was established by Regulation (EU) No 806/2014 on the Single Resolution Mechanism (aSRM Regulation) (259). 
3.35.2.

Emphasis on a situation 3.35.9. 
Without calling into question our audit opinions set out in paragraphs 3.35.6-3.35.8, we would like to stress that the contributions to the Fund are calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee by credit institutions (and some investment firms). 
When examining the Committee's revenue, the Court relied on this information, which it did not consider its reliability. 
The SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework that ensures the reliability of the information. 
In addition, the Board cannot provide details of the claims per credit institution calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, as the calculations are interlinked and contain confidential information about other credit institutions.

De C 434/204 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 ANNEX OF THE COMMITTEE 3.35.9. 
The annual ex-ante contributions to the Fund shall be calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Board of credit institutions and certain investment firms. 
Although the SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework providing for the reliability of this information, the SRF pays all possible attention to this aspect. 
The data provided shall be reviewed on the basis of the data transmitted by institutions in the previous year and the data contained in the ECB database. 
Deviations are indicated to the national resolution authorities who are asked to clarify the facts. As a result, it was possible for the SRF to improve the quality of the data in the previous cycles. 
In addition, the Board cannot provide details of the ex-ante contributions per institution calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, as the calculations are interlinked and thus reveal confidential information about other institutions. 
However, the SRF has disclosed the calculation method and in-depth calibrations in order to ensure transparency and cooperation. 
3.35.12. 
In 2017, due to a combination of an unexpectedly high workload, an unfortunate turnover in the financial team and general difficulties in finding experienced employees, the capacitit of the financial team was not sufficient to ensure the efficient processing of all financial transactions, including invoices. 
Since the 4th quarter of 2017, the team's capacitance has been reversed and measures have been taken to ensure timely processing of invoices. 
To date, almost 98 % of invoices have been settled in 2018 within the deadlines set. 
Each case of late payment is now being investigated closely in order to achieve further improvements in this area. 
3.35.14. 
The SRB's preliminary procurement plan for 2017 was adopted in 2016 when the Committee was only in its second full year. 
At that time, no resolution cases had been processed and the Agency had little experience on the basis of which its procurement plan could be drawn up. 
As a new agency, it was possible for the SRB to use various interinstitutional frameworks managed by the European Commission. 
This led to the fact that several procurement procedures, which should be launched by the SRB in 2017, were ultimately not carried out. 
In 2018, the implementation of the procurement plan will be closely monitored and additional efforts are being made to improve the planning of procurement procedures. 
In 2017, the SRB spent a total of EUR 20 million in funding for the provision of legal advice. 
Almost all negotiated procedures without prior publication of a contract notice concerned litigation (eight out of 10 in total, with a total value of EUR 10.9 million), which did not fall within the scope of Directive 2014/24/EU. 
This also includes a high number of disputes brought before the ECJ after the SRB's first resolution procedure. 
The SRB therefore does not consider that it is using such procedures. 
As regards the economic and financial evaluation of two of the Twelve cases in 2017, the reopening of competition proved to be unsuccessful. The SRB was therefore forced to resort to negotiated procedures. 
Due to the subject-matter of the contract and the need for the utmost confidentiality, the contract notice was not published in accordance with the applicable rules. 
3.35.16. 
Online access to tender documents has been available to economic operators on the SRB website since the Committee was founded and has been fully integrated into the electronic tendering platform since the end of 2017. 
In June 2017, the SRB asked to use the electronic submission of tenders. However, the Commission has not yet secured access. 
The SRB has found that such publications on the EPSO website do not increase the quality or number of applications and that they are also very costly due to the mandatory posting of the vacancy notices. 
Therefore, the SRB publishes its vacancy notices preferably on its own website as well as on EU_CV online and LinkedIn and informs its stakeholders (central banks, ministries of finance, national bidders, other EU agencies and permanent representations).

Note 3.36.7. 
The Centre's mission is to provide the agencies and bodies of the EU with regard to their service. It also carries out this task against the EU institutions, which can use the services of the Centre. 
Most Agencies and Institutions Regulations provide that they benefit from the Centre's transfer services. 
Some agencies and institutions (which are more than the centre's revenue) are increasingly resorting to in-house opportunities or other alternatives. 
However, this means that the centre's capacitance is not used to the maximum, that there is a duplication in terms of the development of systems and the running costs at the European level, and that the business model and business continuity of the centre could be carried out. 
An external assessment of the adequacy of the Centre's business model was carried out in 2017. 
The final evaluation report had not yet been adopted at the time of the Court's inspection (268). 
3.36.8. 
COMMENTS ON THE COST-EFFECTIVENESS OF ACCOUNTING 3.36.9. 
In accordance with their Framework Financial Regulation, the Agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (269) (270). 
As a corresponding requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing a comprehensive IT system covering all phases of public procurement procedures. It launched e-invoicing tools (2010), the electronic publication of contract notice documents in the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). 
By the end of 2017, the Centre had introduced e-invoicing for certain procedures, but not the electronic tendering and electronic submission of tenders.

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1. 
The European Court of Auditors is the body responsible for auditing the finances of the European Union (EU) in accordance with the Treaty. 
As an external auditor of the EU, we contribute to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens. 
More detailed information on our work can be found in the Annual Activity Report, which is available on our website www.eca.europa.eu. 
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget; it concerns the financial year 2014. 
The annual report on the European Development Funds shall be presented separately. 
0.3. 
The general budget of the EU shall be adopted annually by the Council and the European Parliament. 
Our annual report, together with the special reports, forms the basis for the discharge procedure, during which the European Parliament, following a Council recommendation, decides whether the Commission has satisfactorily carried out its budget implementation tasks. 
At the same time as the transmission to the European Parliament and the Council, we send our annual report to the national parliaments. 
0.4. 
The central element of our annual report is the statement on the reliability of the consolidated accounts of the European Union and the legality and regularity of transactions (hereinafter referred to as the "order of transactions"). 
We complement this Statement of Assurance with specific assessments on all major areas of activity of the EU. 
0.5. 
The chapter structure now reflects the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF); our report is therefore even more relevant. 
The financial framework entered into force in 2014 and aims to determine the size and distribution of EU spending over the period up to 2020. 
This should make it easier for readers to establish a link between the findings of our report and the relevant budgetary and accounting information. 
0.6. 
There are no separate financial statements for each MFF heading; therefore, the conclusions submitted in the context of specific assessments do not constitute an audit opinion. 
0.7. 
This year's report is structured as follows: - Chapter 1 contains the statement of assurance and a summary of the results of our audit on the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of transactions. - In Chapter 2, our findings on budgetary and financial management are presented. - Chapter 3 contributes to our strategic objective of improving the EU's public accountability. The focus is on the extent to which the performance framework enables the Commission to monitor and manage progress towards Europe 2020. - Chapter 4 contains our findings on revenue. - Chapters 5 to 9 (for MFF headings 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5)(1) provide the results of our audits on the regularity of transactions and the audit of selected systems and annual activity reports. 
0.8. 
The Commission's replies (or, where applicable, the replies of other EU institutions and bodies) to our comments are included in the report. When explaining our findings and conclusions, the respective replies of the audited body are taken into account. 
However, as an external auditor, it is our sole responsibility to submit our audit findings, to draw conclusions from these findings and to carry out an independent and impartial assessment of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions. 
(1) How do not provide specific assessments on MFF heading 3 ('Security and citizenship') and 6 ('Compensation payments').

De C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11,2015 THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND THE COUNCIL REGULATIOND REQUIREMENT OF THE HOFES - MEMBER OF THE UNABILITY CONTROL I. We have (a) the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union, the consolidated annual accounts(1) and the aggregated statements on the implementation of the budget (2) for the annual accounts of the European Union on 31. The financial year ended December 2014 and approved by the Commission on 23 July 2015 and (b) the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying those accounts in accordance with Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). 
Responsibility of Management II. In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for the preparation and proper presentation of the consolidated accounts of the European Union on the basis of internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector and for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying it. 
This responsibility includes the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures as necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements free of material, intentional or unintentional misrepresentation. 
The Commission has the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU). 
Responsibility of the examiner III. On the basis of our audit, it is our task to provide the European Parliament and the Council with a statement on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying it. 
We conducted our audit in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing as well as the professional behaviour requirements of the IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions of INTOSAI. 
These standards require us to comply with professional conduct requirements and to plan and carry out the audit in such a way as to obtain reasonable assurance as to whether the consolidated accounts of the European Union are free from material misrepresentation and the underlying transactions are legal and regular. 
IV. An audit involves carrying out audit procedures in order to obtain evidence of the values and other information contained in the consolidated accounts, as well as the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying it. 
The selection of the audit procedures is at the discretion of the auditor. This includes assessing the risks of material, intentional or unintentional misrepresentation in the consolidated accounts and material, intended or unintentional, breaches of the European Union legislation in the underlying transactions. 
When assessing these risks, the auditor shall take into account all internal controls relevant to the preparation and proper presentation of the consolidated accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions in order to plan audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not with the aim of issuing an audit opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system. 
An audit shall also include the assessment of the adequacy of the accounting policies applied, the reasonableness of the estimated values in the accounts and the overall presentation of the consolidated accounts. 
V. In the area of revenue, we use the macro-economic aggregates relevant to their calculation as a starting point for our assessment of own resources based on VAT and derived from gross national income and assess the Commission's systems for processing these data up to the receipt of Member States' contributions and until they are declared in the consolidated accounts. 
In the area of traditional own resources, we examine the accounts of customs authorities and analyse the tax flows until they are received by the Commission and until the amounts are entered in the accounts. 
(1) The consolidated financial statements include the balance sheet, the statement of income, the cash flow statement, changes in net assets, as well as a summary of key accounting rules and other explanations (including segment reporting). 
De 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/11 VI. In the area of expenditure, we check the payment transactions after the expenditure has been made, recorded and accepted. This audit shall be carried out for all types of payments, except advances, (including payments for the acquisition of assets) only after they have been made. 
Advance payments shall be audited if the beneficiary submits or is required to provide proof of their proper use and the advance is settled or can be recovered. 
VII. We believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and suitable to serve as the basis for our audit opinions.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 DE NOTICES OF THE HOFES INTRODUCTION EU expenditure is an important tool for achieving policy objectives 1.1. 
EU spending is an important tool for achieving policy objectives. 
Other important instruments are legislation, free movement of goods, services and capital and free movement of persons throughout the Union. 
On average, EU spending amounts to 1.9 % of total government expenditure of EU Member States (see Figure 1.1). 
Under the Treaty, our role is inter alia - to assess whether the use of the EU budget is in line with relevant laws and other legislation; - to deliver our opinion on the annual accounts of the EU; - report on the economy, efficiency and effectiveness (4) of EU spending; - To present opinions on legislative proposals with financial implications. 
With our audit work to underpin the Declaration of Assurance, we fulfil the first and second of these objectives. 
This audit work allows us to identify risks that impair the economy, profitability and effectiveness. 
It also provides an important input on the opinions we make on proposed financial rules. 
(4) In Article 30(2) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the financial rules applicable to the general budget of the Union 
L 298, 26.10.2012, p. 1), these terms are defined as follows: 'The principle of economy requires that the resources used by the institution concerned in its [sic] activities be made available at the right time, in sufficient quantity and quality and at the lowest possible cost. 
The principle of economic efficiency concerns the optimal relationship between the resources used and the results achieved. 
The principle of effectiveness concerns the achievement of certain set objectives and results.'

COMMISSION REPLY 1.11. 
The Commission notes that the error rate reported by the Court is an annual estimate that takes into account accounting corrections of project expenditure made before the Court's audit is announced. 
The Commission notes that it is bound by the Financial Regulation, which stipulates in Article 32(2)(e) that its internal control system should ensure, inter alia, that its internal control system should 'adequately deal with the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the programmes and the nature of the payments concerned'. 
In the 2014 Synthesis Report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of correction mechanisms at EUR 2.7 billion, representing 1.9 % of payments from the EU budget. 
The Commission will continue to carry out its monitoring function by carrying out financial corrections and recoveries at a level corresponding to the level of irregularities and deficiencies identified throughout the period and after the closure of the programmes.

De NOTES OF THE HOFES A new audit approach... 
For 2014, we redesigned our approach to quantifying serious breaches of public procurement rules. 
This approach clarifies how we assess the impact of these infringements. 
In particular, we have introduced a proportional approach to the calculation of errors related to the modification of contracts. 
1.14. 
In order to ensure the comparability of the results presented in this report, we adjusted the figures for 2012 and 2013 in Table 1.1 and in Figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6 in line with this new approach. 
Annex 1.4 contains the unadjusted historical data on the estimated error rates for the period 2009-2013. 
This adjustment reduced the estimated total error rate by 0.2 % in 2013 and by 0.3 % in 2012. 
The adjustment does not affect the conclusions we reached in relation to those years and remains a clearly significant error rate. 
1.15. 
In 2015, we will align our approach to cross-compliance with the amended regulatory framework for the Common Agricultural Policy. 
While we will continue to report on the information provided by the Commission on cross-compliance, this element will no longer be the subject of our audit procedures. 
This year, we found numerous cross-compliance errors with regard to one in four of the farms visited. 
The share of these errors in our estimated total error rate is 0.2 percentage points (2013: 0.2)(14) and the error rate for the chapter "Natural resources" 0.6 percentage points (2013: 0,5). 
The Commission welcomes the change in the Court's approach from 2015. 
For 2014, it reiterates its view that cross-compliance does not affect the eligibility conditions for payments (see the Commission's reply to paragraph 7.7).

C 373/24 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 COMMISSION RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE HOFES type of expenditure and error rates are closely linked 1.20. 
We analysed the relationship between the type of expenditure and the risk of error. 
EU expenditure is characterised by the extent to which the correct calculation of payments to beneficiaries depends on information provided by the beneficiaries themselves. 
This applies to the largest category of expenditure schemes based on payment entitlements: the area-related aid paid to farmers. 
This is particularly important in the area of refund schemes: Beneficiaries must provide information in their application to prove that they have participated in an eligible action and incurred costs eligible for reimbursement. 
All modes of management are affected by this (15). 
1.21. 
Figure 1.6 is based on all audits carried out in relation to EU expenditure over the last two years for both the annual reports on the general budget and the European Development Fund (16). 
The cash flows are grouped according to their nature. 
The size of the circles in this figure represents the respective share of total expenditure, with their respective positioning along the 45-degree line indicating the corresponding estimated error rate; their color can be seen whether they are based on claims or reimbursement-based expenses. 
1.22. 
This figure includes both elements of proper discretion (assessment of the impact of systems and risks related to the type of operation - see Annex 1.1, paragraph 1) as well as empirical elements (measurement of estimated error rates over a two-year period). 
On the one hand, the aim is to respond to the wishes of our audience for more information on the different risk profiles, on the other hand, to assist the Commission in taking action in relation to areas with persistently high error rates. 
1.20. 
The integrated management and control system (IACS), which includes the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS), contributes significantly to the prevention of errors and the reduction of the error rate (see paragraph 7.32). 
LPIS is established and maintained by the national authorities. 
Payments to final beneficiaries are only possible after their claim has been reconciled with the data available in the area identification system. 
Thanks to LPIS, the error rate for area-related aid is lower than for all other types of aid under shared management. 
The Commission considers that Box 1.2 and Box 1.3 confirm this view.

Errors related to ineligible beneficiaries, activities or expenditure accounted for the second highest share (approximately a quarter of the estimated error rate). 
The main remaining shares are cross-compliance (one-sixth) and administrative errors (one-sixth).

C 373/28 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE HOFES Box 1.1 - Example of errors in the reimbursement of costs for a project under MFF heading 3 "Security and Citizenship" were the subject of a sample of the Commission's payment to a beneficiary acting as coordinator of a cooperation project under the "Fundamental Rights and Citizenship" programme. 
The beneficiary public body assigned two permanent staff (officials) to the project half-day; she invoiced part of her salaries in the project cost statement. 
Seconded staff will only incur additional costs if additional staff need to be recruited in order to replace officials in their usual duties and incur costs as a result. 
Since the beneficiary body has not made any arrangements to replace officials, these costs are not eligible. 
In total, the ineligible costs declared by the beneficiary entity amounted to EUR 58 000 of the total invoiced cost of EUR 237 000. 
We identified ineligible costs for eight of the 25 projects that were the subject of the sample for MFF heading 3, which were reimbursed by the Commission. 
Box 1.1 - Example of errors in reimbursing costs for a project under MFF heading 3 "Security and Citizenship" The Commission was aware of the difficulties faced by public bodies in complying with the eligibility rules applicable to staff costs for public bodies (representing other staff to replace the official staff in their usual duties). 
For this reason, from 2011 onwards, the Commission amended the eligibility rules applicable to public sector bodies, taking advantage of the flexibility provided by the Implementing Rules of the Financial Regulation. 
Therefore, the ineligible costs identified by the Court in the above-mentioned grant (staff costs for staff in public bodies that do not allocate replacements) would now be considered eligible.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/29 RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE HOF There are many forms of corrective measures with different impacts 1.30. 
Our analysis of "errors and corrections" is intended to shed light on the complex mechanisms of the implementation and recording of corrective actions and explain the many ways these mechanisms can influence our audit work. 
In some areas of expenditure, new instruments will be available to the Commission when expenditure for the new programming period is incurred. 
Corrective measures 1.31. 
We strive to take into account corrective measures taken by the Member States and the Commission in advance of the payment or our investigation. 
We also take note of corrections made after our audit announcement. However, we cannot reduce the estimated error rate whenever the audit itself triggers the corrective action (24). 
We review the application of these corrections (which include recoveries from beneficiaries and corrections at project level) and, if necessary, adjust the calculation of the error rate. 
However, the impact of corrective measures varies significantly depending on the expenditure area and the corrective action. 
1.32. 
The Commission and the Member States' authorities had applied corrective measures for 24 of the transactions audited in 2014 as part of a sample, which directly impacted the transaction concerned and were relevant to our calculations. 
These corrective measures led to a reduction in our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (2013: 1.6 percentage points); this corresponds to around 1.6 billion euros. 
Changes in the number of transactions concerned and the impact on our estimated error rate do not indicate that the corrective actions are more or less effective: As these measures apply to a relatively small proportion of our sample, fluctuations are expected from year to year. 
1.30. 
The Commission considers that the Court's annual representative error rate should be considered in relation to the Commission's corrective capacity as reported in the various annual activity reports and in the synthesis report. 
The Financial Regulation requires appropriate consideration of the risks related to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the control systems and the nature of payments. 
1.31. 
Common reply to points 1.31 and 1.32: In the 2014 Synthesis Report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of correction mechanisms at EUR 2.7 billion, representing 1.9 % of payments from the EU budget. 
For a breakdown of figures by policy area, see Table 1 in the Synthesis Report. 
The Commission underlines that all types of financial corrections and recoveries exclude unlawful expenditure from reimbursement from the EU budget (see note 6 to the annual accounts). 
(24) See paragraphs 1.19-1.37 of the 2012 annual report. 
The Commission uses the terms "financial corrections" and "recoveries" to cover a wide range of corrective measures applied both before and after the Commission's execution (or reimbursement) of expenditure. 
1.34. 
Note 6.2.2 of the financial statements sets out a total amount of EUR 3285 million for corrective actions in 2014. 
Figure 1.7 shows how we classify the corrections made at the different stages of the spending cycle. 
One quarter of all corrective actions in 2014 consist of corrections and recoveries that took place at the source, i.e. before the Commission made the related payment (25). 
A further quarter will take the form of withdrawals and the replacement of expenditure on cohesion projects (either during the implementation or completion of the operational programmes). 1.33. 
The Commission considers that the terms "financial corrections" and "recoveries" are used in accordance with the legal framework laid down in the Financial Regulation and the relevant sectoral legislation. 
For more detailed information on the different preventive and corrective mechanisms provided for in the applicable legislation, see note 6 on the EU financial statements and the Communication on the protection of the EU budget. 
(25) For the ERDF and the Cohesion Fund, the corrections reported as "at source" in 2014 amount to EUR 430 million; of this, 75 % had already taken place in previous years.
