COURT'S COMMENTS 1.35. 
The corrective measures discussed in this section of the annual report also include the work of the Member State authorities, as well as the recoveries carried out by the national authorities and the Commission. 
C 373/32 Official Journal of the European Union RECOMMENDATIONS 10.11.2015 DE NOTE OF THE HOF The impact of corrective measures is largely tangible at the time when the Commission accepts expenditure 1.36. 
All relevant sectoral regulations in the area of shared management contain rules on primary controls to be carried out by national authorities or reductions in amounts declared by final beneficiaries before the expenditure is certified. 
In some cases, the national authorities also agree to reduce or cancel certain costs which, due to errors with long-term effects, appear on a permanent basis in the declarations (such as ongoing payments under a contract where there is an error with regard to procurement rules). 
Such adjustments may have a measurable impact on the amount of reimbursement requested for individual projects or the aid paid to individual farmers. The correction then helps to reduce our estimated error rate. 
1.37. 
In the area of direct and indirect management, the 'recoveries' registered by the Commission consist, inter alia, of deducting ineligible amounts in respect of cost claims before the payment is approved. 
The eligibility of the amounts is determined on the basis of desk checks of the available documents or on the basis of the results of checks carried out (see also Figure 1.7). 
This also allows us to reduce our estimated error rate. 
Conformity decisions ("financial corrections" in the agricultural sector) are often made on a flat-rate basis. 
In general, they refer to system deficiencies rather than errors at the level of the final beneficiaries. 
In the rarest cases, they result in recoveries from the farmers concerned. 
This type of corrective action is an incentive for Member States to improve their management and control systems. 
They contribute to the legality and regularity of transactions at the level of final beneficiaries if they lead to continuous improvements in the cost statements accepted by the paying agencies (see boxes 1.2 and 1.3). 
The Commission services also carry out recoveries "at source" by deducting non-eligible expenditure (determined in previous or current cost statements) from payments made. 
1.38. 
Financial corrections made by the Commission for agricultural expenditure are intended to protect the EU budget and will be imposed on Member States. 
They do not directly lead to recoveries of farmers, as the Commission does not pay the final beneficiaries directly but reimburses payments made by Member States to farmers. 
However, if these incorrect payments are identifiable as a result of the conformity clearance procedure, the Commission would expect Member States to pursue them through recovery measures against the beneficiaries. 
See reply to Box 1.3. 
Paying agencies implement conformity decisions by reducing future requests for reimbursement by the Commission for payments to farmers. 
The Commission accounts the full amount paid out to farmers as expenditure, i.e. the correction does not entail a reduction in the amount of the payments registered. 
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and reimbursements to paying agencies is recorded as assigned revenue available to finance agricultural expenditure (26). 
More than two thirds of the "financial corrections" recorded in 2014 in the area of cohesion are replaced by new expenditure,... 
1.40. 
In the area of cohesion, "financial corrections" for more than two thirds of the total amount recorded are cases where the authorities in the Member States withdraw expenditure declared and replace them with new expenditure. 
For some "withdrawals" no concrete projects can be recognised as withdrawn. 
Instead, Member States report additional projects and thus receive a de facto lower co-financing rate. 
1.40. The Commission considers that all financial corrections, including those allowing Member States to contribute new projects and new expenditure to re-use the corrected amounts, protect the EU budget from unlawful expenditure and act as an incentive for Member States to recover from beneficiaries (and thus contribute to improving management and control systems). 
Nevertheless, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections, where Member States are unable to reuse the corrected and recovered amounts and thus lose the funds, is certainly higher. 
(26) If, for example, an agricultural paying agency is subject to a financial correction of 5 % and makes payments of EUR 100 million to farmers, the Commission will reimburse it 95 million euro. However, the Commission will, for its part, account for EUR 100 million of expenditure, which will be offset by assigned revenue of EUR 5 million. 
C 373/34 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REQUIREMENTS OF THE COMMISSION OF THE HOF... whereas net corrections are made less frequently 1.41. 
If a replacement is not possible, the corrections for the Member State concerned will result in a loss of EU funds(27). This, albeit relatively rare, can occur when Member States are unable to provide sufficient eligible expenditure and where replacement is no longer possible (28) or allowed (29). 
The Commission expects that, as a result of amendments to the legislation, net corrections will be more widely applied in the future. 1.41. 
Following the example of the agricultural sector, the legislator has decided to apply a similar mechanism of net financial corrections for the 2014-2020 programming period to cohesion policy. 
This will give Member States an additional incentive to prevent or detect or eliminate serious deficiencies in the management and control systems before submitting the annual accounts to the Commission. 
Otherwise, and if serious deficiencies continue to be identified by the Commission or the Court following the submission of the annual accounts, the Commission must make net financial corrections under the conditions laid down in the relevant regulations, which means that the resources for the Member State are lost. 
Furthermore, the Commission considers that, under shared management, all financial corrections and recoveries, regardless of the method of their implementation, have a negative impact on national budgets. 
In order to avoid a loss of EU funding, the Member State must replace ineligible expenditure with additional eligible transactions. 
This means that the Member State, with its national budget, must bear the financial consequences of losing EU co-financing of expenditure considered ineligible unless it recovers the amounts from each beneficiary. 
(27) Either as a reduction in payments or in the form of a return to the EU budget leading to assigned revenue (see Chart 2.2). 
(28) After completion of the programmes. 
(29) In the event of a disagreement between Member States and the Commission (see point 1.25(b) of the 2012 Annual Report). 
10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union COMMISSION C 373/35 EN NOTICES OF THE HOF In 2014, Commission and Member States applied all these forms of corrective measures 1.42. 
Boxes 1.2-1.4 illustrate different types and effects of corrective actions. Box 1.2 - Example of improving management and control systems - Greece: The Commission has taken measures to enforce the improvement of the Agricultural Parcel Identification System (LPIS), which serves as a basis for payments to farms, such as the single payment scheme (the largest single EU spending scheme). 
This process took place at various stages and led to a decrease in the 'eligible' permanent grassland covered by the Greek LPIS from 3.6 million hectares in 2012 to 1.5 million hectares in October 2014. 
Non-compliant applications for 'permanent grassland', which is not eligible for EU aid, has been a key factor in our estimated "natural resources" error rate for several years. 
We took into account the impact of corrections on individual payments made to final beneficiaries, which were the subject of our sample of EAGF and European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) transactions. 
A further impact is that the Paying Agency rejected a large number of ineligible applications, which resulted in the corresponding expenditure falling out of our sample. 
Box 1.2 - Example of improving management and control systems - Greece: Further examples of the positive impact of action plans are given by the Court in Chapter 7. 
Action plans are implemented whenever deemed necessary and the Commission monitors their implementation with great care and reports on the corrective measures taken in the annual activity report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development. 
The area identification system prevents beneficiaries from claiming claims for areas which do not exist or which do not meet the eligibility conditions or for areas for which claims have already been claimed by another beneficiary. 
When properly implemented, it is a very effective tool to reduce the error rate. 
It covers 75 % of CAP expenditure. 
As shown in the 2014 Annual Activity Report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development, the error rates for area-related payments are lower than for other measures. 
C 373/36 Official Journal of the European Union REQUIREMENTS OF COMMISSION 10.11.2015 DE NOTE OF HOFES Box 1.3 - Example of corrections resulting from conformity clearance procedures (30) - Conformity decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers In 2014, France accepted a correction of 1.1 billion euro (984 million euro for EAGF and 94 million euro for the EAFRD)(31). 
The national authorities stated that this would have no impact on farmers and the amount would be denied from the national budget. 
In previous annual reports, we pointed out that such an approach would not give beneficiaries an incentive to eliminate errors (32). 
The main reasons for the correction were shortcomings in the LPIS/GIS (695 million euro) and the exceeding of the ceiling for payment entitlements, resulting in excessive payments to farmers (141 million euro). 
Another reason, albeit to a lesser extent, was breaches of the cross-compliance obligation of timely notification of animal movements (123 million euros). 
All of these reasons are related to payments made between 2009 and 2013. 
No correction was made for 2014 and the breaches of the ceiling for payment entitlements and the ineligible areas covered by the LPIS of France contributed 0.3 percentage points to our estimated "Natural Resources" error rate this year. 
Box 1.3 - Example of corrections resulting from conformity clearance procedures - Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers Under shared management, Member States are responsible for ensuring that control systems function properly. 
The financial correction of EUR 1.1 billion will be repaid to the EU budget in three annual instalments (2015, 2016 and 2017). 
The Commission points out that, due to the nature of the conformity clearance procedure applicable ex-post, it is very rare, after the accounts of the year and after an adversarial phase in which the Member State concerned can submit its own reasoning and calculation, that a financial correction is already decided in the following year of the expenditure concerned. 
An ongoing conformity clearance procedure will protect the EU budget for 2014. 
Box 1.4 - Example of corrections resulting in additional expenditure: ESF - Romania We pointed out corrective measures in Romania in our annual reports on the financial years 2012 and 2013. 
In 2013, we were able to reduce our estimated level of error in relation to a number of Romanian projects under the European Social Fund (ESF), as the national authorities had identified the impact of the corrections at project level. 
This was also the case in 2014. 
Some projects we are investigating still have errors due to problems that are not covered by the corrections. 
In its 2014 Annual Activity Report, the Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion (DG EMPL) notes that it continues to follow the implementation of the agreed action plan. 
The financial corrections made do not necessarily mean that Romania will receive less EU funding, as Member States can make use of the possibility of claiming a larger amount of expenditure (33).

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/37 REPORTS OF THE COMMISSION OF THE HOFES In its reporting on corrective measures, the Commission does not always quantify their different effects,... 
1.43. 
Note 6 to the annual accounts is to a large extent a voluntary disclosure of information that is not required under accounting rules. 
A significant part of this information does not come from accounting systems. 
The explanatory note provides a description of the different effects of the different corrective adjustments to the EU budget, but not always in quantified form. ... and further improvements would allow for a better analysis 1.44. 
The Commission's capacity to improve the quality of expenditure is linked not only to the amounts concerned, but also to their impact. 
A rigorous assessment of the impact of corrective measures requires better information on the nature of the corrected error and the way corrections are made (34). 
When the relevant Commission DGs assess the impact of their corrective actions, they shall make the necessary adjustments to the figures in Explanatory Note 6 (see paragraph 1.55). 
The Commission's Synthesis Report confirms material errors in transactions 1.45. 
Each Directorate-General of the Commission shall draw up an annual activity report. 
This report includes - a report on the achievement of the main policy objectives (explained in Chapter 3) - a management report from the Director-General to the College of Commissioners and - a statement by the Director-General ensuring that the financial information contained in the report is properly presented and that the operations covered by his/her responsibilities are legal and regular. 
1.43. 
The legislator has provided the Commission with the instrument of financial corrections to ensure that unlawful expenditure is not financed from the EU budget. 
These financial corrections relate mainly to systemic deficiencies that lead to a risk of error. 
It is the responsibility of the Member States and not the Commission to identify incorrect amounts and recover them from the beneficiaries. 
If this is not done, the EU funds will be replaced by national funds, as national budgets will have to bear the burden of financial corrections. 
1.44. 
Several services have duly adjusted their figures in note 6 regarding the protection of the EU budget in order to provide an estimate of future corrections in view of their specific circumstances.

This section of the chapter describes the results of our analysis of the Annual Activity Reports of the Directorates-General and the Commission's Synthesis Report(35). 
The focus is on the consistency and adequacy of the Commission's estimates with regard to - the error rate at the time of reimbursement by the Commission or the payment of its own expenditure by the Commission (the Commission refers to "risk amount"), - the extent to which errors are corrected by subsequent corrections (the Commission refers to its 'corrective capacity' or 'estimated future corrections' (36)).

Directors-general should proceed in this way when - an event having a serious impact on the reputation of the Commission or - the impact of the estimated error rates minus already made financial corrections and recoveries are still material.

THE COURT'S OBSERVATIONS 1.50. 
In line with the request of the discharge authority, in 2014 the Commission further developed its internal guidance (45) on presenting information in Annual Activity Reports. 
The Directors-General will now present an "average detected error rate" (46). 
The application of this error rate to the total payments of the year leads to the calculation of the amount of risk(47). 
This amount is reported in the synthesis report together with the estimation of the future corrective capacity of the ex-post controls carried out by the Commission. The Commission acknowledges that expenditure is materially affected by errors... 
1.51. 
In the 2014 Synthesis Report, the Commission identifies the amount of risk as a range of 3.7 to EUR 5 billion. 
This corresponds to between 2.6 % and 3.5 % of the payments covered by the Synthesis Report for 2014(48). 
These figures show that the overall expenditure is materially affected by errors. ..., however, points to the estimated impact of future corrections 1.52. 
The 2014 Synthesis Report provides an estimated total amount of estimated future corrections (correction capacity). 
Based on the corrections recorded over the past six years(49), the Commission estimates that in the coming years it will be able to identify and correct errors in the total amount of around EUR 2700 million (50). 
(45) Standing Instructions for the 2014 Annual Activity Reports (SEC(2014) 553). 
(46) This is the detected or estimated error rate at the time of payment (not the residual error rate), i.e. without adjustment due to errors corrected retrospectively.
